EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: Aetna Life and Casualty, Hartford, said Robert J. Clark, president of the Commercial Insurance division, had advised the company that he would be resigning because of ''personal reasons.''


Baseball Notebook; How Valuable Was Dawson?
LEAD: Andre Dawson chose a controversial solution to his free-agent dilemma last spring and now he's the subject of another controversy: Should he be named the National League's most valuable player even though his team will finish in last place or close to last?


Jessica Hahn Is Called To Testify on Wedtech
LEAD: Jessica Hahn has been subpoenaed to appear next week before a Bronx grand jury investigating the Wedtech Corporation, according to people familiar with the case.


At the Smithsonian
LEAD: To some mixed emotions, the Smithsonian's National Museum of American History opens an exhibit today celebrating the United States Constitution.
Six years ago it decided to commemorate the signing of the Constitution with a $1 million study and exhibition that documents the experience of 120,000 United States citizens and residents of Japanese dissent who were interned in isolation camps in World War II and of the 30,000 Japanese-Americans who fought with United States forces in the war.


Elizabeth Eden, Transsexual Who Figured in 1975 Movie
LEAD: Elizabeth D. Eden, whose desire for a sex-change operation led to an attempted bank robbery portrayed in the film ''Dog Day Afternoon,'' died of pneumonia resulting from AIDS Tuesday at Genesee Hospital in Rochester.
She was 41 years old and lived in Rochester.


A Chilean Dispute Over University Turns Violent
LEAD: A dispute over Government efforts to reduce state financing and dismiss some faculty members at the University of Chile turned violent in recent days as students took to the streets of Santiago in support of professors.


ABM Hand Unmasked
LEAD: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee has discovered the lawyer at the root of the Reagan Administration's much-disputed new interpretation of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty.
It is not Abraham Sofaer, the former Federal judge who is State Department counsel, but rather a man whose name is familiar to students of last summer's Iran-contra hearings: Bretton


Migration Shift: A Return to Normal
LEAD: After a volatile decade in which economic dislocations forced millions of Americans to move to other regions, migration within the United States generally appears to have settled back into a more stable pattern, according to new Census Bureau estimates and other Government data.


Presser Trial Date Set
LEAD: A Federal district judge has set Feb. 15 as the date for the racketeering and embezzlement trial of Jackie Presser, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and two associates.
The judge, George White, set the date at a pretrial hearing Tuesday.

LEAD: K. Jack Bauer, a naval historian and a professor of history at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, died Sept. 17 at St.
Mary's Hospital in Troy, N.Y., of complications from a heart attack.
He was 61 years old and lived in Brunswick, N.Y.

LEAD: The biggest football game Jim Crocicchia ever played happened last year, when his Penn team (9-0) met Cornell (8-1) in the season finale for the Ivy League championship.
Crocicchia had a good game and Penn won, 31-21.

U.S. Fights Rumors on Manila Coup
LEAD: The American Embassy is not sure whether it ever issued a visa to Col.
Gregorio Honasan, the fugitive leader of last month's attempted coup.
But just to be on the safe side, it has canceled any such visa he may have.


Prince Is Back on Broadway
LEAD: With the opening of ''Roza'' tonight at the Royale Theater, Harold Prince returns to Broadway with a vengeance, after an absence of more than two and a half years.

LEAD: Catharine Crozier, among the leading organists in the country and the recipient of the 1979 International Performer of the Year award from the New York City chapter of the American Guild of Organists, performed on the Aeolian Skinner organ in Trinity Church on Tuesday evening before a small but appreciative audience.

LEAD: The first issue of Manhattan Lawyer, a weekly whose preview edition was sent free in May to all 35,000 of the borough's lawyers in a bid for paid subscribers, is being delivered this week to the 9,500 interested parties.

LEAD: It finally came down to this, waiting in the dampness and the gloom of the last hour of September, darkness falling on them from all directions, things finally out of their control.

Long Road For Tokyo and Bonn
LEAD: Are Japan and West Germany, the countries with the biggest trade surpluses in the world, doing as much as they should to further international economic expansion?


California Accepts Steel Shot Regulation
LEAD: When, in 1976, the Fish and Wildlife Service started its program to get the lead out of waterfowlers' shotgun shells, bitter debates and much heel-dragging by many states resulted.
But this year, all save California had either accepted or accelerated the Federal timetable that will make steel shot mandatory for duck and goose hunting throughout the nation by 1991.


Doctor in Texas With AIDS Virus Closes His Practice Amid a Furor
LEAD: Dr.
Robert J. Huse took his diplomas off the wall today, cleaned out his desk and closed his practice.
At the age of 44, he assumes that his career in general pediatrics is over.


Cardinals' Loss Keeps Reeling Mets Barely Alive; Expos Win, 6-1
LEAD: The celebration had begun in the stands at Busch Stadium the moment the Cardinal fans learned the news from Philadelphia.
The Cardinals had clinched a tie for their third National League East championship in six seasons.
The Mets had lost to the Phillies.

LEAD: Eric H. Haight, the founder of the Westchester Community Health Plan, died Sunday at the Northern Westchester Community Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y.
He was 82 years old and lived in Bedford, N.Y.

LEAD: William M. Shinker was appointed publisher of Harper &amp; Row's trade division yesterday.
Edward L. Burlingame, who had been publisher and editorial director of the division since 1980, has been appointed publisher of a line of books to be issued by Harper under his imprint.

Management Shifts At McGraw-Hill
LEAD: In a series of management changes at McGraw-Hill Inc., John G. Wrede was named yesterday as president of its book company and Harold McGraw 3d has been named to head the publications company.


Queens Woman Acquitted in Killing of Husband
LEAD: Karen Straw, a Queens woman whose trial in the stabbing death of her estranged husband had come to symbolize the anguish faced by battered women, was acquitted last night.


September, The Rush To Spend
LEAD: A Federal shopping spree ended today -abruptly, as it does every year in September's final hours.


Yields Post More Gains
LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose in the week ended yesterday, marking yet another rise in an advance that has lasted more than a month.


Afghan Chief Changes Name
LEAD: Najib, the leader of Afghanistan's Communist Government, is restoring the Islamic element in his name and reverting to Najibullah.
The Afghan press agency, monitored here, instructed all Afghan information outlets today to describe him henceforth as Comrade Dr.
Najibullah.
He has a medical decree from Kabul University.


Baker Hints at Gold As Guide on Policy
LEAD: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d told world financial leaders today that the Reagan Administration ''is prepared to consider'' using the price of gold in trying to steer its own and the world economies.


Banker Expects Steady Policy by Argentina
LEAD: A top banker said today that Argentina, despite fiery rhetoric by its President, has no plans to halt interest payments on its $52 billion foreign debt.


ARTISTS WANT WORK PROTECTED
LEAD: Representatives of movie directors, screen writers and painters urged Congress today to adopt an international copyright convention that grants ''moral rights'' to artists and forbids changes in their works without their consent.


Ward Taken to Hospital After an Asthma Attack
LEAD: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward suffered a severe asthma attack at his home early yesterday, was hospitalized, but by midday was in stable condition, signing papers and joking, the authorities said.


Israel and China Aides Agree On Ties at U.N.
LEAD: The foreign ministers of Israel and China met for the first time today and agreed to maintain regular contacts between their two governments at the United Nations.


CBS Board to Meet On Records Unit
LEAD: CBS stock soared $9.75 yesterday to close at $225.75 as Wall Street eagerly awaited today's early morning board meeting to discuss the sale of the CBS Records unit to the Sony Corporation for an estimated $2 billion.


HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: SELECTING the right home insulation from the numerous brands and products can be bewildering.
What follows is a guide to the kinds available.


Ford Workers Approve Contract by Wide Margin
LEAD: Workers at the Ford Motor Company approved the recently negotiated labor contract with the company by a margin of nearly 3 to 1, the United Automobile Workers reported today.


For Young Fan, Fantasy Began in Section 31
LEAD: By the time a police car took him home from Yankee Stadium late Tuesday night, 12-year-old Michael Smith of the Bronx had lived a baseball fantasy.
He had met all the Yankees in the clubhouse after the game, received a bat autographed by Don Mattingly and eaten hot dogs in a luxury box with Joe DiMaggio.


Sales of Appliances Surpass Predictions
LEAD: Appliance manufacturers saw the boom coming as far back as 1973.
Every 12 to 15 years, in a replacement cycle as predictable as the seasons, Americans replace their refrigerators and ovens, dishwashers and dryers.
What manufacturers did not count on was a boom that kept coming, through the record year of 1985, through 1986 and now 1987.


Bork Panel Ends Hearings; Vote Scheduled on Tuesday
LEAD: Confirmation hearings on the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court ended today on an acrimonimous note.

LEAD: A Japanese country club operator said today that it planned to pay $250 million for the La Costa Hotel and Spa, a 400-acre resort in Carlsbad, Calif.
The proposed deal is the second in two weeks by the Sports Shinko Company, based in Osaka.

A surprisingly old friend: this week it turns 100.

LEAD: Merrill Lynch Mortgage Investors Inc. is offering $71.5 million of 10.20 percent mortgage pass-through certificates due 2002, at a price of 98.27, to yield 10.63 percent, or about 1.4 percentage points more than Treasury notes due 1992.


How Commodity Indicator Works
LEAD: As an example of how today's proposal to stabilize currencies would work, interest rates would rise if prices for commodities, including gold, move higher.


JACOB H. SINGER
LEAD: Jacob H. Singer, a cantor, died Sunday at the New York University Medical Center after a long illness.
Mr.
Singer was 70 years old and lived in Queens.


Late Adjustment for Pena
LEAD: When he appeared for work on Tuesday afternoon, Tony Pena of the St.
Louis Cardinals had a batting average of .210, a seat on the bench and a pair of eyeglasses.
The average had deteriorated steadily since the end of June.
The seat was an unpleasant, but not an unexpected result of his extended problems in the batter's box.

LEAD: California telephone operating company, said today that it would issue up to 15 million common shares in Pactel Personal Communications, the company's cellular telephone and paging unit.
Further details of the offering were not announced, pending the filing of a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange


Newmont Mining
LEAD: A Court of Appeals issued an injunction blocking the attempt of an investor group to take over the Newmont Mining Corporation.
The move by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit prevents the Ivanhoe Acquisition Corporation, led by T. Boone Pickens, from pursuing a tender offer or other efforts to try to gain control of the mining company until further court order.


Today's Artisans: In the Spirit of the Past
LEAD: IN farmhouses, studios and workshops across the United States, artisans are making a living by handcrafting furniture and accessories based on designs from earlier times.
They sell to architects, decorators and individual clients, as well as to museum shops and department stores.


F.B.I. Says Surveillance Of Writers Has Stopped
LEAD: The F.B.I. said today that it had stopped keeping files on American authors 11 years ago.
Documents on which two articles being published this week are based show that the bureau monitored the activities of such writers as Ernest Hemingway, William Faulkner and John Steinbeck.


Coffee Talks Deadlock
LEAD: International negotiations on new coffee export quotas to bolster falling world prices were stalled today, delegates at the meeting said.
The talks at the International Coffee Organization include both nations that produce coffee and those that consume it.


Belle Linsky, Philanthropist And Art Collector, Dies at 83
LEAD: Belle Linsky, an art collector and philanthropist, died Monday at her home in Manhattan.
She was 83 years old.

LEAD: On the road to Letoon - which runs among conical stacks of drying sesame and the peaked wooden frames over which Turkish farmers spread cover for winter-grown tomatoes - travelers suddenly discover the ruins of an ancient amphitheater seeming to rise from the white-tipped rows of a cotton field.

LEAD: Senator Jesse Helms has taken another swipe at his bete noire: the State Department.

On His Last Day, It's Hail to the Chef
LEAD: At 3 o'clock this afternoon, Henry Haller collected his knives and assorted utensils from the White House kitchen.
It was his last day as executive chef.
After preparing meals for five presidents over 21 years, Mr.
Haller is retiring ''to make some money,'' as he puts it.

LEAD: For Michael Schatz and his wife, Pat Iuto, the end came abruptly: A message on their answering machine that another family had been found for Mikey, the boarder baby they took into their home two months ago and had come to love with a tenacity that took them by surprise.

'BELLY OF AN ARCHITECT,' FROM PETER GREENAWAY
LEAD: STOURLEY KRACKLITE (Brian Dennehy), the central figure in Peter Greenaway's ''Belly of an Architect,'' is at one point seen reflected in the central panel of a triptych mirror in his Rome apartment, wearing a blood-red robe and flanked by multiple Xerox copies of classically sculpted abdomens, copies he has made from photographs of Roman statuary.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: The Los Angeles County Coliseum Commission filed a multimillion-dollar lawsuit against the Los Angeles Raiders, but a lawyer for the commission said the intent was not to block the team's move to nearby Irwindale.
Marshall Grossman, the attorney, said the commission was seeking more than $50 million in damages because the Raiders had violated their lease agreement with the coliseum by failing to construct luxury boxes as promised.

Waterhouse Sets New Unit
LEAD: Price Waterhouse said yesterday that it would establish an affiliate registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission that would act as an investment adviser to its executive clients.


Free Flu Shots in New York
LEAD: New York City will give the elderly and the chronically ill free influenz shots starting today, Health Commissioner Stephen C. Joseph has announced.
The vaccine protects against type A, or Taiwan and Leningrad flu, and Type B, or Ann Arbor flu.


Gold Drops After Baker Proposes a Price Watch
LEAD: Gold prices dropped about $5 an ounce in New York trading yesterday after Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d suggested that industrial nations monitor the metal's price levels as a guide to their economic policies.

Waldheim to Visit Pakistan
LEAD: President Kurt Waldheim of Austria will visit Pakistan Nov. 23-25, a Pakistani Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.
Mr.
Waldheim, the former United Nations Secretary General, has not received similar invitations from other countries, and has been placed on a list of foreigners barred from visiting the United States because of a furor over his World War II record.


Plane Crash Kills 6
LEAD: A twin-engine airplane with six people aboard crashed in heavy fog today while attempting to land at the Tijuana airport, killing everyone aboard, the authorities said.
The Mexican-registered Cessna 340 went down shortly after 8 A.M. on the United States side of the border.
The flight originated in Mexico, but United States officials could not say where.

LEAD: PUB-ROCK, the mid-1970's, back-to-basics wave of British rock, yielded one fiery songwriter, Graham Parker, and one ironic craftsman, Nick Lowe.

LEAD: With the National Football League players' strike well into its second week and games resuming Sunday after a one-week absence, fans around the country may find themselves with more to watch than they might have imagined.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in The Living Section on Aug. 26 about an exotic-game ranch in Texas gave an incorrect location for the Mansion on Turtle Creek, a restaurant.
It is in Dallas.

LEAD: Former United States Representative Howard W. Robison, who in his 17 years in Congress eventually became dean of New York State's Republican Congressional delegation, died of a heart ailment Saturday at his home in Rehoboth Beach, Del.

China Seizes Illicit Books
LEAD: The police detained 44 people and confiscated nearly 80,000 pornographic books and magazines in connection with an illegal publication ring operating in eastern China, an official report said today.
The ring was based in Nanchang, the capital of Jiangxi province, and had branches in 23 provinces, 470 wholesale outlets and 600 sellers, the state-run New China News Agency said.

LEAD: Two top aides resigned from the Presidential campaign of Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis today after the Governor acknowledged that one of them, his campaign manager, had given reporters a videotape that helped destroy the candidacy of a Democratic rival, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr.
The departure of John Sasso, the campaign manager, and Paul Tully, the Dukakis campaign's political director, dealt a serious blow to the candidacy of the Massachusetts Governor.


Music: History, A Trio
LEAD: HIGH-TECH, low comedy, John Cage, Spike Jones, the Carter Family and R. Crumb all filter through the History of Unheard Music, the group that opened the New Songs series Monday at Dance Theater Workshop.
For History of Unheard Music, the modern soundscape is a heap of rubble to be scavenged; when the trio uses a song form, it's like something heard from a distant, static-filled radio station, evoking a kind of addled nostalgia.

Ferries, Vindicated
LEAD: The idea that modern commuter boats charging premium fares could develop into more than a fair-weather novelty was untested in July 1986 when a private ferry operator inaugurated daily rush-hour service between Highlands, in Monmouth County, N.J., and Pier 11 near Wall Street.
Now it's clear that this modest experiment has succeeded, ushering in a promising new era for local waterborne transit.

LEAD: Gold futures fell to their lowest level in a month yesterday as the dollar continued to gain strength against foreign currencies.

LEAD: A lack of trained pilots has forced the Army to park dozens of new AH-64 Apache helicopter gunships, each costing $11.5 million, officials say.


HERS
LEAD: AUNT CEIL went through life thinking she got the small half.
She perceived hurts where there was no intent.
She wrote off people with abandon.
She was a self-made outcast, the perennial victim, and sooner or later everyone failed her.

LEAD: TAKING a longish tale, ''Babette's Feast,'' from Isak Dinesen's last collection, ''Anecdotes of Destiny'' (1958), Gabriel Axel has made a very handsome, very literary movie that does justice to the precision of the Dinesen prose, to the particularity of her concerns and to the ironies that so amused her.

Ozone Loss Over Antarctica Is Found to Worsen
LEAD: Man-made chemicals and local weather reduced the ozone shield over Antarctica last month to the lowest level ever recorded, the space agency said.
Data from Sept. 15 show the worst depletion at center, with less severe depletion indicated by successively lighter shades.

Stage: Billy Connolly
LEAD: BILLY CONNOLLY, a 44-year-old Scottish comedian who sold out the Vivian Beaumont Theater on Sunday night, has been toiling in the comedy world for nearly 20 years.
But it is only very recently that he has cultivated a large American audience for his brand of boisterous barroom humor.


Sending the Right Message to Iran
LEAD: The Senate was right to vote unanimously to bar imports of Iranian oil.
At the same time, it should be understood that an oil embargo - even one supported by our allies - won't have much effect on Iran's ability to sell oil and buy arms.
The embargo will simply mean slightly less profit for Iran and slightly higher costs for the United States.

LEAD: The United States and Canada have five days to make history.
Monday is their deadline for agreement to meld the world's largest trading partnership into a single zone of freer trade.
Success or failure will shape both countries' economic development and North America's role in the global economy.

Wisconsin Haven For Hand Weavers
LEAD: THIS tiny northern Wisconsin community (population 500 or so) has been turned into a hand weaver's haven by 87-year-old Walter E. Schutz.
He has created a thriving business in handmade looms, and from May through October, people arrive from all over the country to learn about weaving, spinning, quilting, basketry and silk-screening.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said yesterday that he thought the Soviet Union and China would endorse an arms embargo against Iran if further diplomatic efforts failed to get the Iranians to accept a cease-fire in their war with Iraq.

LEAD: The Soviet Foreign Minister, on a tour of Latin America, has assured his hosts that Moscow strongly supports the new Central American peace plan and will put no obstacles in its way, Brazilian officials said today.


Talking Deals; The Liquor Consolidations
LEAD: FACED with declining worldwide liquor consumption, the international liquor industry is turning to consolidation as a way to prop up sagging sales.
Indeed, analysts say that by the end of the decade the industry, traditionally the domain of small, independent operators, will consist of a handful of conglomerates.

LEAD:  International  An arms embargo against Iran may be endorsed by the Soviet Union and China if diplomatic efforts fail to get the Iranians to accept a cease-fire in their war with Iraq, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said.

LEAD: San Diego's Benito Santiago doubled to extend his rookie-record hitting streak to 32 games tonight, but Cincinnati's Tom Browning allowed eight hits and doubled in a run as the Reds beat the Padres, 3-1.

He was 83 years old and lived in Red Bank.


Antarctica Ozone Loss Is Worst Ever Recorded
LEAD: The ozone shield over Antarctica dwindled this month to the lowest level observed since measurements began more than a decade ago, researchers reported today.


Bid for Sakowitz
LEAD: Australia's Hooker Corporation would acquire 80 percent of financially beleaguered Sakowitz Inc., the Houston-based retailer, under an amended plan of organization filed in Federal Bankruptcy Court.
The remaining 20 percent share of Sakowitz, which went into reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws in August 1985, would go to certain creditors, according to the plan.

LEAD: David Checketts, president and general manager of the Utah Jazz, is trying to accommodate the trade demanded by Kelly Tripucka, but Checketts said no team had showed any interest.


Stage: 'Lenny Bruce Revue'
LEAD: ''THE Lenny Bruce Revue,'' at the Harold Clurman Theater, 412 West 42nd Street, is a biographical tribute to the late comedian that bills itself as ''a burlesque of comedy and dance.'' Written and directed by Fred Baker, the show presents a chronologically arranged sequence of Bruce monologues, dramatized by a nine-member ensemble and accompanied by slides and dancers.

LEAD:  The Economy


2 Farm Banks Need Bailout
LEAD: Two regional banks in the farm lending system could fail unless the Government steps in with a rescue package, according to a letter to Congress from the Farm Credit System.


YOUNG GUARD: PARTIES FOR A CAUSE
LEAD: It's fall in New York and the benefit party circuit is in full swing.
Men dressed in black tie and women in their evening regalia are showing up at galas to help the city's many cultural and charitable institutions.
Nothing unusual in that.
But what's different this season is the age of these revelers-with-a-cause, who are in their late 20's and early 30's.


Film: Dudley Moore In 'Like Father Like Son'
LEAD: ''LIKE FATHER LIKE SON'' has a road map of a plot: thanks to an Indian brain-transference serum, a middle-aged doctor and his teen-age son trade minds but not bodies.
It's easier to believe such a potion exists than to imagine anyone could make this movie live, but Dudley Moore and Kirk Cameron are so clever and charming as the mismatched pair that they turn a potential dud into a sweetly engaging film.


Art: 'Sculpture,' the Works of Five Women
LEAD: WITHOUT being polemical, the current exhibition at the Pat Hearn Gallery proposes some loose and interesting connections among the work of five artists who happen to be women.
The artists in question span several generations: Louise Bourgeois has nearly a 50-year career and a Museum of Modern Art retrospective behind her; Eva Hesse, who died in 1970 at the age of 36, made a lasting contribution to that personalization of form known as Post-Minimalism; Mary Heilmann, whose roots are in Post-Minimalism, has been exhibiting painting and ceramics in New York since the early 1970's, and

LEAD: Bob Welch continued his success against the playoff-bound San Francisco Giants tonight, pitching the third one-hitter of his career in a 7-0 victory by the Los Angeles Dodgers.

LEAD: The Rangers received a shock yesterday morning when they learned that Barry Beck, who was attempting a comeback, reinjured his left shoulder Tuesday night in Denver and almost certainly will not be able to resume his career.

Jackson's Swan Song?
LEAD: Stewart's teammate, Reggie Jackson, leaving no doubt about his intentions to quit, punctuated his final game at the Oakland Coliseum yesterday with a base hit off an 0-2 pitch as a pinch-hitter in the Athletics' eighth inning.
Jackson then threw waves and kisses to a standing, cheering crowd.
Jackson, 41 years old, said he was not making an official announcement of his retirement after 20 seasons, but he never made it so definite as he did yesterday.

Chip Industry Sees Big Gains
LEAD: Amid a recovery, the semiconductor industry projects sales growth of 17.9 percent in 1988, to $37.8 billion, an industry committee reported today.
Citing substantial growth in application-specific integrated circuits and other new technologies, the committee also forecast sales of $40.6 billion in 1989 and $45 billion in 1990.


The 3 Targets Of the Players
LEAD: The antitrust suit filed yesterday by the National Basketball Players Association called the league's college draft ''one of the longest running continuing restraints on competition for player services.'' A team owns the rights to a player it selects in the draft, and he cannot negotiate with another team.

LEAD: A four-foot-tall toy sheep is ensconced in an antique chair at the entrance to Susan Keane's living room.
Above the doorway hangs a lamb marionette.
Tiny sheep are tucked into peg holes in the overhead beams.
Wooden and ceramic versions stand on tables and windowsills.
The rug has a blackface sheep's image in the pattern.


Art Blakey
LEAD: Art Blakey, a drummer, and the Jazz Messengers are appearing tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785).
Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.


N.B.A. Target of Players' Antitrust Suit
LEAD: On the day the moratorium on signing draft choices and free agents ended, the National Basketball Association tried to go back to business as usual yesterday.
But the players' union took the unusual step of suing the owners.


Music: Blair String Quartet
LEAD: THE Blair String Quartet's recital at the 92d Street Y on Wednesday evening lasted well over two hours but seemed much longer.


They Might Be Giants
LEAD: They Might Be Giants will perform tonight at 9 and midnight, with Watchface opening, at the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets (475-5120).
Tickets are $10; information, and a sample song, at (718) 387-6962.

LEAD: As if the loss of the Senate, the Iran-contra affair, the troubled Robert Bork nomination and a lame-duck status were not demoralizing enough, the Reagan Administration must now try to plug an inevitable, but nonetheless debilitating, end-of-term loss of personnel.


Paquito D'Rivera
LEAD: Paquito D'Rivera, a Cuban alto saxophonist, will lead a trio tonight and tomorrow at Mikell's, 760 Columbus Avenue, at 97th Street (864-8832).
Sets are at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $7 minimum.


Powerful Forces Tug California Rim
LEAD: Although yesterday's California earthquake was a small foretaste of the big one that experts expect there, it apparently had little or no bearing on when that larger earthquake might take place.


About Real Estate; Rebuilding Century-Old Town Houses
LEAD: Like many of the tree-shaded side streets of Manhattan, the section of East 30th Street between Second and Third Avenues still manages to retain some century-old town houses tucked in between the taller, more modern buildings that dominate the streetscape.


POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
LEAD: The dB's,Go Betweens and Dash Rip Rock, the Ritz, 11th Street between Third and Fourth Avenues (254-2800).
The dB's play pop-rock with Southern roots and ''Rubber Soul''-Big Star influences; Go Betweens, from Australia, play their own thoughtful, gently lyrical pop-rock blend.
Both bands have plenty of indelible songs, and Dash Rip Rock, Georgia-based newcomers, have songs of their own, plus energy.


Atlanta Zoo Accepted
LEAD: Accreditation was returned to Zoo Atlanta today.
The American Association of Zoological Parks and Aquariums, which lifted the zoo's accreditation in 1984, restored it after the zoo met all the agency's requirements in an inspection last month.
Zoo Atlanta has spent millions of dollars on repairs and renovation, hired a veterinarian and made other changes.


U.S. PROTESTS TEST OF SOVIET MISSILES NORTH OF HAWAII
LEAD: The United States has protested two Soviet long-range missile tests this week that sent unarmed warheads into the Pacific Ocean about 600 miles northwest of Hawaii, the State Department said today.


1 Killed in Attacks on Ships in the Persian Gulf
LEAD: Crewmen aboard the 43,000-ton Pakistani tanker Johar showing damage after two Iranian speedboats opened fire with machine guns and rockets.
No casualties were reported and the damage was minor.
Two Japanese ships were attacked by Iranians on Wednesday.
In an attack by Iraqi warplanes, the Australian captain of a shrimp boat was killed when a missile struck his boat.


Novel Celebration of the Constitution
LEAD: While most celebrations of the United States Constitution involve a kind of self-congratulation, the celebration by the Smithsonian Museum, ''A More Perfect Union: Japanese Americans and the U.S.
Constitution,'' which opened today, is just the opposite.


64 Seized in Drug Raids
LEAD: Sixty-four people were arrested yesterday when narcotics officers raided five buildings on West 164th Street and Amsterdam Avenue in Washington Heights at about 4:30 P.M.
Most were charged with possession and sale of cocaine, the police said.
The raids were at 562, 559, 548 and 505 West 164th Street and at 2091 Amsterdam Avenue.


4 Die in Mexican Stampede
LEAD: Three girls and a woman were killed and 35 people were injured when thousands of fans stormed a gate at an outdoor concert, the city Attorney General's office said today.
The stampede took place late Wednesday afternoon before a concert by three of Mexico's most popular pop-music groups at the city's Sports Palace.


12 From Queens Picked for Jury In Black's Death
LEAD: The selection of the 12 jurors in the Howard Beach murder trial was completed yesterday as three more Queens residents were chosen to hear the evidence in the racially volatile case.


American Brands Units
LEAD: American Brands Inc., a diversified company based in Old Greenwich, Conn., said yesterday that it plans to sell its Sunshine Biscuits and Pinkerton's subsidiaries.


ART: WILLIAM TUCKER AND HIS GREEK TITANS
LEAD: IN his show at the David McKee Gallery, William Tucker has in effect turned his sculpture inside out.
In the abstract, largely geometrical works that established his reputation, an armature gave shape to a void inside it that eventually became more urgent than the armature itself.
Now the bony armature has become a support, and geometrical shapes are fleshed out around it in plaster.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: Jim Paxson of the Portland Trail Blazers, whose trade to Cleveland this summer was nullified because of an injury to the player he was exchanged for, will undergo toe surgery today. . . .
Pat Cash, the Wimbledon champion, has ruled himself out of today's Australia's Davis Cup tennis semifinal against India in Sydney because of a jarred right knee.


Philharmonic: Sanderling Conducts
LEAD: KURT SANDERLING first led the New York Philharmonic in 1984 and must have impressed someone in authority at that time.
The German conductor, much of whose career was pursued in the Soviet Union and East Berlin, returned to the orchestra last evening to begin a two-week guest engagement.
He is not by any means a keg of excitement.


G.O.P Thwarts Tax Bill Plans
LEAD: Efforts by the House Ways and Means Committee to begin drafting a tax bill today were scuttled after Republicans disputed the need to raise $12 billion from new taxes and refused to consider any specific revenue-raising proposals.


IT'S OVER FOR METS: CARDINALS CAPTURE DIVISION TITLE
LEAD: The tease was put to an end tonight.
The possible permutations and combinations that had taken place in and around Shea Stadium, the what-ifs and the wishful thinking, are now footnotes to a third St.
Louis Cardinal division championship in the last six seasons.


Phone Company To Issue 'Plain Language' Bills
LEAD: Telephone bills across New York State will be printed in ''plain language'' under an agreement reached between New York Telephone and the State Public Service Commission.

LEAD: Riverside Park needs green. Not green as in grass, but green as in greenbacks.


Bridge: France-Netherlands Match Had Award-Winning Play
LEAD: Some of the finest plays in the game are extremely simple, but since they run against instinct some creative imagination is needed.


Pork Climbs by Limit; Cattle Prices Fluctuate
LEAD: Pork futures climbed the limit allowed for daily trading yesterday while cattle futures fluctuated wildly.


Triple Steal For Braves
LEAD: Atlanta completed a triple steal in the fourth inning against the Houston Astros tonight.
With Jeff Blauser on first, Ken Oberkfell on second and Gerald Perry on third, the Houston catcher, Ronn Reynolds, threw the ball back to the pitcher, Danny Darwin, just as Perry broke for the plate.


Pope Opens Synod of Bishops on Role of the Laity
LEAD: Pope John Paul II opened a Synod of Bishops in St.
Peter's Basilica today by asking the prelates to address ''the proper and specific tasks'' assigned to ordinary lay people.


6 Die as Severe Earthquake Hits Los Angeles Area
LEAD: A severe earthquake shook the Los Angeles area today, tearing glass from skyscrapers, jolting cars on freeways, killing at least 6 people and injuring more than 100 in a half minute of violent tremors.


AUCTIONS
LEAD: ONE of the most important collections of Dutch and Flemish Old Master paintings formed in this country in recent years - including works by Frans Hals, Jan Davidsz de Heem, Jan Jansz den Uyl and Jacob van Ruisdael - will be auctioned at Sotheby's in January.


African Culture Month At History Museum
LEAD: A monthlong series of music and dance performances and seminars devoted to African culture begins tomorrow at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 79th Street.
Appearing tomorrow will be Kayraba, a West African dance company; Schroeder Cherry, a puppeteer, and Charlotte Ami Amezor, an artist.

LEAD: Are the Democrats going to throw away their chances in the 1988 Presidential election?


Senate Votes for Adherence to 1979 Arms Treaty
LEAD: Over the opposition of President Reagan, the Senate registered its support today for a proposal requiring adherence to weapons limits in the unratified 1979 treaty limiting strategic arms.


Alexander's Again Is a Trump Target
LEAD: Donald J. Trump, the New York developer, has quickly shifted his attention back toward Alexander's Inc., a chain of 14 department stores in the New York City area.


Dayton Proxy Fight Is Seen
LEAD: The Haft family said today that it hopes to wage a proxy fight in an attempt to gain control of the Dayton Hudson Corporation.


Minimum Pay Rises to $3.75 In Connecticut
LEAD: One of the highest minimum wages in the nation, $3.75 an hour, took effect in Connecticut today, along with a new law greatly expanding the kinds of jobs that 15-year-olds can hold.


Dollar Declines in U.S. While Gold Advances
LEAD: The dollar fell in trading in the United States yesterday after closing higher in Europe.


Wheat Crop Forecast
LEAD: The International Wheat Council has cut its estimate of this year's world wheat crop to 506 million metric tons from 518 million predicted in July, citing poorer harvest prospects in Western Europe, Canada and the Soviet Union.
The council, a trade body, put the world wheat crop at 535 million tons last year.


Senate Panel Passes Smoking Ban For All Flights of 2 Hours or Less
LEAD: The Senate Appropriations Committee today approved legislation that would ban smoking on all domestic airline flights of two hours or less and impose penalties on violators.


Stewart Seeks Honor
LEAD: The Oakland Athletics' Dave Stewart, who became the first 20-game winner in the major leagues this season when he beat the Cleveland Indians, 4-3, Wednesday night, said yesterday that he deserves the American League Cy Young award but doesn't expect to get it.
A castoff pitcher with a losing career record 17 months ago, Stewart has mastered a forkball in posting a 20-12 record.


Kuwaiti Company Leases U.S. Tanker In First Such Move
LEAD: The United States Government agreed today to charter a 264,000-ton oil tanker to the company that manages Kuwait's oil traffic in the Persian Gulf.
It is the first ship manned by American citizens to be added to the Kuwaiti vessels qualifying for naval escorts there.


U.S. Bureau for Water Projects Shifts Focus to Conservation
LEAD: The Interior Department's Bureau of Reclamation, which for 85 years built the dams and water projects that spurred the development of the American West, today announced a radical change in its mission.

2 Say They've Solved Jack the Ripper Mystery
LEAD: Jack the Ripper, the Victorian murderer who terrorized London 99 years ago and was never caught, was a failed barrister and schoolmaster named Montague John Druitt, two writers say in a book published today.

The program includes the ''Pathetique'' and ''Les Adieux'' sonatas.
Tickets are $12.50.
Information: 996-1100.

LEAD: Orders to factories fell 1.7 percent in August as lower demand for aircraft and military goods brought the first setback in manufacturing since January.

LEAD: Bottles of corn oil sold in New York groceries may have been diluted with soy oil and other substitutes as part of a multimillion-dollar nationwide scheme, state agricultural officials said today.

PING-HSUN CHANG
LEAD: Ping-Hsun Chang, a former Chinese diplomat and consul general of the Republic of China in New York City for more than a decade after World War II, died of a heart attack Sept. 14 at the Veterans General Hospital in Taipei, Taiwan.
He was 84 years old and lived in Taipei.


Study Assesses Women And Responses to Love
LEAD: A sampling of women's attitudes on their relationships with men by an author of best-selling books on sexuality has found that 84 percent of women queried were ''not satisfied emotionally'' with their marriages or romantic involvements.

LEAD: Canadian officials, on the verge of announcing a final collapse of free-trade talks with the United States, said today that a last-minute proposal by the United States had dramatically changed the situation, opening the way for a resumption of talks in Washington on Friday.

Stars are followed by the date of original publication.
Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.
ALO ALO, #1030 Third Avenue, at 61st Street (838-4343) - **(June 21, 1985) The whimsical dining room is in grand cafe style at this colorful and convivial East Side restaurant, and the glass fishbowl effect creates a glittery urban night.


IBP Completes Public Offering
LEAD: IBP Inc., the nation's largest producer of fresh beef and pork products, completed one of the largest initial public offerings on record, selling a 47 percent stake in the company for $408.5 million.
The Occidental Petroleum Corporation, which bought IBP, based in Dakota City, Neb., in 1981, will continue to maintain control of it.

LEAD: A suspect in the killing of the president of New York City's school custodians union died yesterday at Jacobi Hospital in the Bronx of complications after brain surgery, a hospital official said.

LEAD: The New York City Board of Estimate unanimously approved a program yesterday to turn over 58 city-owned buildings in the East New York section of Brooklyn to a group of squatters.

LEAD: A Federal inmate who was ordered back to prison after eating poppy seeds against regulations completed his term and was set free today.

LEAD: AS of this coming Sunday, Gluttony will hold court at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

LEAD: A 48-year-old South African, acting as a surrogate for her daughter, gave birth to three grandchildren today.


POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
LEAD: Betty Carter and her trio, the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-7880).
Betty Carter, the Brooklyn-based jazz singer with a rich, elastic alto and a be-bop background, never sings the same song twice in quite the same way.
Her iconoclastic interpretations turn familiar standards into psychic explorations in which bent notes, meditative pauses, lightning accelerated passages, and abrupt changes in timbre virtually reinvent the material.


Dance: Feld's 'Embraced Waltzes'
LEAD: ELIOT FELD'S ''Embraced Waltzes,'' which had its premiere Wednesday night at the opening of the Feld Ballet's new season at the Joyce Theater, 19th Street and Eighth Avenue, is one of the choreographer's especially imaginative responses to familiar material.

LEAD: New York officials videotaped trash in New Jersey and New Jersey officials threw plastic bottles into the Hudson River and other waterways today as both states tried to pinpoint the sources of recent Jersey Shore pollution.


Virginia Tech Report
LEAD: Two Virginia newspapers, citing unidentified sources, have reported that Coach Charles Moir could step down as early as tomorrow as basketball coach at Virginia Tech. ''That is a possibility,'' Moir said by telephone yesterday.
Since the university initiated an internal inquiry of the basketball program last spring, observers have predicted Moir would resign.

LEAD: The shares of the National Semiconductor Corporation rose sharply after Federal regulators cleared the way for its acquisition of the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation.
The stock gained $1.875 a share, to $20.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.


Vast Speedup of Data Transmission Is Hinted
LEAD: A small prototype device has shown that communications lines made from the new generation of superconductors can transmit data at speeds up to 100 times as fast as today's state-of-the-art optical fiber networks, scientists said yesterday.

No. 1: though the title character, a once-celebrated Czechoslovak actress (played by Sally Kirkland), lives amid the kind of gloomy decor in which one might expect to find an elderly lady, she emerges as a leggy, chic-looking creature.

California: Major Quakes
LEAD: The earthquake yesterday near Los Angeles registered as high as 6.1 on the Richter scale of energy released, a quake capable of causing severe damage.
An earthquake measuring 7.0 on the Richter scale is a major quake, capable of widespread heavy damage; 8.0 is a great quake, capable of tremendous damage.

LEAD: Pat Robertson, the television evangelist who gave up his ministry to run for President, formally declared his candidacy for the Republican nomination yesterday.

LEAD: Americans are growing older, on the average, with the median age reaching 31.7 years in 1986, up from 30 in 1980, the Census Bureau reports.

BENJAMIN GRUND
LEAD: Benjamin Grund, a former director and partner in Seidman &amp; Seidman, an international accounting firm based in New York City, died of a heart attack last Friday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 83 years old.
In 1920, Mr.
Grund was hired as a file clerk by a founding partner of the firm.
Two years later, he was made acting head of the New York office's tax department.


2 Rock Bands
LEAD: Glass Eye, from Austin, Tex., and Blue Movie, from San Francisco, will play a rock double bill tonight at 9 and 11 at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055).
Admission is $6.


Money Fund Assets Dip
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 400 money market mutual funds decreased $707.5 million, to $243.75 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 106 institutional funds were down $111.2 million, to $64.28 billion.
Assets of the 201 general-purpose funds were up $165.6 million, to $72.06 billion.

But I've always had a love-hate relationship with television.
There were periods when my parents didn't allow me to watch it.


In Air and Underground: 'It Seemed Like Forever'
LEAD: When the earthquake struck, Edward Fontaine was perched precariously 300 feet above downtown Los Angeles.
Sitting in the control cabin of a construction crane atop the framework of a new 26-story office building, he was thrown violently to one side as the crane began swaying ominously.

LEAD: A mobile home park can deny housing to families with children under 18 years old, the California Supreme Court ruled unanimously today.

Small Quake Felt in Utah
LEAD: A small earthquake was felt in Utah's remote western desert today, but seismologists said it was unrelated to the major quake that hit the Los Angeles area Thursday.
The epicenter of the quake, which measured 3.5 magnitude on the Richter scale of ground motion, was 22 miles west of Brigham City.


CITICORP SELLING PART OFFERS HEADQUARTER
LEAD: In another step toward recapitalizing itself after huge losses, Citicorp said yesterday that it would sell large parts of its headquarters complex to a Japanese insurer.


Pan Am, Aeroflot Plan Joint Venture
LEAD: Pan American World Airways Inc. and Aeroflot, the Soviet Union's national airline, have entered an agreement to begin jointly operating nonstop flights between New York and Moscow.
The agreement, which is subject to approval by the United States and Soviet Governments, would take effect on May 15, 1988, and begin with three round trips a week.

LEAD: Prices of coffee futures reached a four-month high yesterday on renewed speculation that the International Coffee Organization would end its London meeting with an agreement to reimpose export quotas.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Tennis  India Leads in Davis Cup: Behind Vijay Amritraj and Ramesh Krishnan, India took a commanding 2-0 lead yesterday over Australia, the defending champion, in their Davis Cup tennis semifinal in Sydney.
India, which has never won the prestigious international team trophy, can reach the final by winning the doubles match today or one of two singles matches tomorrow.

NEW FINDING MADE ON AIDS DETECTION
LEAD: A new study of gay men in Finland has found that some who became infected with the AIDS virus through sexual intercourse did not form antibodies for more than a year, far longer than most experts had expected.

LEAD: Police Officer Stephen Eakle reaching to open the door of a house yesterday in Peoria where a gunman identified as Stephen Thomas had held the police at bay for nearly seven hours.

Thomas shot Officer Eakle and was then killed in a hail of gunfire.

LEAD: A Federal judge has postponed until Oct. 14 a hearing initially set for yesterday over whether to remove from bankruptcy court the $2 billion dispute between the LTV Corporation and the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation.
The Federal pension insurance agency last week sued to move the dispute, centering on three ailing LTV steel division pension plans, out of United States bankruptcy court and into district court.

LEAD: AT some point after the check was handed to the teller, but before it reached its destination - the customer's checking account - the deposit was lost.

Did a computer gobble it up?

Film Festival; 'Anita - Dances of Vice' by von Praunheim
LEAD: Rosa von Praunheim's ''Anita -Dances of Vice'' is a surprisingly tame movie to be made by the German director responsible for ''It's Not the Homosexual Who Is Perverse, Rather the Situation in Which He Lives'' (1970) and ''A Virus Knows No Morals'' (made in 1985 and released here this year).
The former is a memorably savage satire on gay liberation conformism, while the latter is a grim examination of what might be called gay liberation's aftermath, in the era of acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

LEAD: Because of Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement, alternate-side parking is suspended in New York City today.
Other rules remain in effect.

Fannie Mae, Meet Farmer Mac
LEAD: Small rural banks, battered by the farm crisis, want a way to provide farm credit without bearing great risk.
Creditworthy farmers, shadowed by the sense of general rural depression, are eager for a link to investors willing to lend long term at relatively low, fixed rates.
Washington policy makers see benefit in spreading out the risks of gyrating crop prices and interest rates.

LEAD: The principal stockholder in the Central National Bank of New York was charged yesterday with defrauding the bank, which was declared insolvent and closed last month, of $31.4 million from customers' accounts, the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan said.

LEAD: Iran has probably obtained 110 heavy Austrian artillery guns destined for Brazil and Libya over the last two years, apparently in violation of Austrian law, the Austrian Foreign Minister said today.

Stocks Rise in Tokyo
LEAD: Prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange closed higher today, sparked by Thursday's rally on Wall Street, brokers said.
The market index gained 140.71 points, to 25,862.45, after falling on Thursday.
Turnover came to 850 million shares, down sharply from a heavy volume of 1.5 billion shares on Thursday.


Ushers Walk Out In Pittsburgh
LEAD: Ushers walked off the job tonight at Three Rivers Stadium in a dispute with their employer, Spectacor Management.

Democrats Lose Place on Ballot In L.I. Election

LEAD: Saddled with three straight losses this season and a 2-14 won-lost record since he took over last year as coach of the Kansas State football team, Stan Parrish made a plea for help from the Wildcat student body and the townspeople of Manhattan, Kan., in an open letter published yesterday by the Kansas State Collegian and the Manhattan Mercury.

Correction
LEAD: The Weekender Guide in Weekend yesterday misattributed a quotation - ''My candle burns at both ends'' -in a report about an exhibition at the New York Public Library.
The author was Edna St.
Vincent Millay.


Yellowknife Journal; For Faraway Places, Strange-Sounding Names
LEAD: With his bushy beard and muscled forearms, Randolph Freeman looks a little like one of the explorers who left their traces across the Canadian north.
The appearance is appropriate, since Mr.
Freeman, who is 35 years old, spends much of his time trekking across the same forbidding terrain in a quest as daunting, in its own way, as the explorers'.


U.S. Unemployment Rate Dips to 5.8%
LEAD: The unemployment rate edged down to 5.8 percent in September, the lowest level in nearly eight years, as a substantial increase in factory jobs pointed to a fresh, long-awaited source of economic growth.


What Value Education? Counting the Ways
LEAD: For high school students, graduating means $352 a month in extra earning power.
And students who finish four years of college earn $672 a month more than those who attend college but do not get a degree.


JUDGE REDUCES SENTENCE OF MAN IN BRINK'S CASE
LEAD: A Federal judge has reduced the prison sentence of a defendant convicted of hiding a key suspect in the 1981 Brink's armored-car robbery in Rockland County.


Iran Is Said to Have Executed 2 Members of Baha'i Religion
LEAD: Officials of the Baha'i International Community said yesterday that two members of their religion had been executed in Iran on Monday.


TV: CBS's 'Mistress,' And Series
LEAD: ''Mistress,'' the made-for-TV movie on CBS tomorrow at 9 P.M., opens with one of those little scenes that can make prime-time entertainment memorable.
Victoria Principal, formerly Pam Ewing on ''Dallas,'' is in acting class doing a scene from Chekhov's ''Cherry Orchard.'' The effort is excruciatingly inadequate but, this being television, the beaming teacher turns to Ms.


Berkshire-Salomon
LEAD: Salomon Inc. and Berkshire Hathaway Inc. said they had consummated their previously announced agreement for the sale of 700,000 shares of Salomon's series A cumulated preferred stock for $700 million.
The transaction was part of an agreement reached last weekend under which Berkshire Hathaway, based in Omaha, is acquiring a 14 percent stake in the investment banking firm.

The Front Line of Defense and Peace
LEAD: Unless Congress decrees otherwise, the United States will soon be closing 15 overseas diplomatic posts, including two embassies, and laying off 1,300 employees from a State Department payroll of 22,000.
Congress proposes to slash a crippling 23 percent, or $767 million, from the department's budget.


TIBETAN PROTEST FOR INDEPENDENCE BECOMES VIOLENT
LEAD: A march for independence by thousands of Tibetans turned violent Thursday, with demonstrators stoning the police and setting a police station afire, witnesses said today.
Six people were reported killed.

France Must Pay Greenpeace $8 Million in Sinking of Ship
LEAD: An international arbitration tribunal ordered France today to pay more than $8.1 million in damages to Greenpeace, an environmentalist and antinuclear group, for the deliberate sinking two years ago of the group's ship, the Rainbow Warrior.


RANGERS LEAVE BECK TO DRAFT
LEAD: The Rangers, increasingly known for surprising personnel moves, followed a more predictable course yesterday in submitting their list of protected players for next week's National Hockey League waiver draft.
As expected, the Rangers said that it was likely that Barry Beck would abandon his comeback attempt after reinjuring his left shoulder, and they left the defenseman unprotected.


Soviet Says Food Prices Will Rise
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said the Soviet Union must enact major food price increases to improve its economy, and he promised to use the results of such changes to improve social services.


TSB Offers $1.3 Billion To Acquire Hill Samuel
LEAD: TSB Group P.L.C., owner of the Trustee tee Savings Banks, which were formed 174 years ago as philanthropic savings banks for poor Scots, said today that it had agreed to buy Hill Samuel Group P.L.C., the beleaguered merchant bank, for $:777 million, or about $1.3 billion.

LEAD: Gleaming stainless-steel subway cars will have their debut today on the 42d Street shuttle, the latest attempt to spruce up a nearly 70-year-old line that opened to bad reviews and has mostly been getting them since.


COX TO OPEN PLAYOFF
LEAD: The St.
Louis Cardinals began their countdown to the National League playoff tonight when they named Danny Cox to pitch the opening game here against the San Francisco Giants next Tuesday, with John Tudor starting Game 2.


Legislature in Florida May Revise Gun Law
LEAD: Bad publicity and police complaints prompted supporters of Florida's new gun law to agree today to delay carrying out a provision allowing guns to be carried openly.


Bush Lauds Soviet Workers And Is Assailed by U.A.W.
LEAD: Marveling at the ability of Soviet mechanics, Vice President Bush said today that when they ran out of work in the Soviet Union, Moscow should ''send them to Detroit.''


Teachers Approve Contract
LEAD: New York City public school teachers have approved a new contract, with 86.5 percent of the members of the United Federation of Teachers who voted favoring the pact, a spokeswoman, Naomi Spatz, said yesterday.
The contract, which gives a starting teacher an annual salary of $25,000 in the third year of the pact, was approved by 50,000 of the 70,000 members eligible to vote, she said.

LEAD: Two New York City hospital employees asserted yesterday that a friend of theirs died after an ambulance failed to arrive at his Harlem home yesterday morning despite repeated calls for about 90 minutes to the city's emergency telephone number.

LEAD: The radio station of the Roman Catholic hierarchy, which was closed down by the Sandinista Government 21 months ago, resumed broadcasting today.

LEAD: A FEW years ago, Carol Contos, a Manhattan teacher, bought a $300,000 life insurance policy.
Instead of putting the ownership of the policy in her name, however, she set up an irrevocable life insurance trust and transferred the ownership to the trust.

Witness in Mob 'Pizza' Trial Says He Lied in Recanting Testimony
LEAD: The mob hit man who swore last week that he had lied in court testimony against a Mafia boss reversed his story again yesterday.
Appearing in Federal Court, the witness, Luigi Ronsisvalle, said that he had falsely recanted his court testimony because of death threats to his family.


Centronics in Deal
LEAD: The Centronics Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the Ekco Group Inc., based in Franklin Park, Ill., for about $124 million.
Ekco, which makes bakeware, kitchen tools, gadgets and other household products, is being sold by a leveraged buyout group led by Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen.
Centronics, based in Nashua, N.H., said the acquisition would allow the company to ''build a significant marketing-directed consumer products business.

LEAD: David W. Proffitt, a former leader of the United Presbyterian Church in the United States, died Wednesday at his home in Maryville, Tenn.
He was 96 years old.


For Tibet and China, a Turbulent History
LEAD: The mountainous region of Tibet, for centuries an important seat of Buddhism under successive Dalai Lamas, was an independent kingdom from the seventh to the ninth century.
It fell into disunity, but was reunited in the 17th century, and underwent periods of greater or lesser Chinese control until the Chinese Revolution of 1911-12, when the Chinese were expelled.

LEAD: The Coca-Cola Company's board has approved a plan to spin off its entertainment holdings and merge them with the much smaller Tri-Star Pictures Inc., which it helped to start five years ago.

The merger must still be approved by Tri-Star shareholders and Federal regulatory agencies.

LEAD: The Director-designate of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, William S. Sessions, will be released from George Washington University Medical Center Saturday, but he may rest for a week or more before going to work, law-enforcement officials said today.
Mr.
Sessions was hospitalized with a bleeding ulcer hours before he was to be sworn in Thursday.

FAY KOSHELLE
LEAD: Fay Koshelle, a founder with her husband of a children's camp in the Catskills, died Wednesday at the Hebrew Home of Greater Washington in Rockville, Md., where she was a resident.
She was 102 years old.
Mrs.
Koshelle, a onetime Bronx resident, and her husband, the late William Koshelle, founded the Maple Lake Camp in Livingston Manor, N.Y., in 1925, and operated it for more than 30 years.

New York City's Jobless Rate Falls to 17-Year Low
LEAD: The unemployment rate in New York City fell to its lowest monthly level in 17 years last month, dropping to 4.5 percent in September from 5.1 percent in August, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

FADING MEMORIES: ALBUMS DAMAGE PHOTOS
LEAD: The photo album, storehouse for the treasured memories of many of the nation's 64 million families, often damages the images it holds.
The materials and construction of many new imported albums, as well as millions of albums purchased in years past, create a harsh environment for photographic prints, research has shown.

TOKYO
LEAD: AN EVENING OUT IN Tokyo can be many things.
For Japanese from the provinces, where everything closes more or less at dusk, it may be the bright lights along the Ginza.
For Tokyo businessmen, especially if they are entertaining clients, it may be an evening at a geisha establishment followed, perhaps, by a visit to an expensive bar.

Baker, whose own innovative image had seemed to be fading along with Mr.
Reagan's, has dramatically transformed the look of economic policy.

At Home With Lord Vishnu
LEAD: AND WHERE WILL YOU BE FOR NEW Year's?'' people asked, as always. ''In Tiruchirapalli,'' we said in answer, holding tight to the six vowels and slithering over the consonants as best we could.
If pressed (which did not happen often) we got out the New Oxford Atlas and pointed to where the name, picked out in big black letters, was draped like a watch chain across the ankles of India.

LIVING WITH MS
LEAD: I am a 31-year-old woman who has lived with multiple sclerosis for six years, and I know some who have lived with it for 20.
I read with dismay Rand V. Araskog's article ''Award of Honor'' (About Men, Sept. 6).
Its depiction of MS was confusing and misleading.
MS is a neurological illness that varies considerably from person to person, and even within the same person.

LEAD: THE hackers who break into a company's computers are usually on the intellectual equivalent of joyrides.

TWO GERMANYS, MANY VOLUMES
LEAD: Germany: one people, two nations, a rich and tortured past.
How to grasp it all?
Start chronologically with the 19th century, I suppose.
Bismarck's memoirs were best sellers in their time and offered modern Germans a vision of what they would like to be.
Thomas Mann's ''Buddenbrooks'' portrays the self-confident German middle class before the catastrophes of the 20th century.

Ivory From the Eskimo Heritage
LEAD: MOST OF WHAT IS known about ancient Eskimo art has been discovered over the last 60 years.

A Simpler Way to Improve Bryant Park
LEAD: ''HE WHO HESITATES IS sometimes saved,'' was the moral at the end of one of James Thurber's ''Fables for Our Time,'' and so it has long been with Bryant Park.
Some years ago there was the temptation to add a few dollars to the city's coffers by permitting the construction of an underground garage beneath the park, and one can only be grateful for hesitation there.


Mysterious Tremor Strikes Miami
LEAD: Office towers in downtown Miami shivered in the sun this week.
Windows rattled and floors quivered several times a day.
The weather bureau was flooded with calls.
Workers were sent home early.
The National Earthquake Information Center in Colorado reported no earthquake activity in the region.
It noted that South Florida, unlike California, where a severe earthquake killed six people Thursday, is one of the most unlikely places in the United States for an earthquake.


The Interactive World of Toys and Television
LEAD: HE-MAN AND SHE-RA WILL BE fighting a host of invaders this month over market share - and children's attention - with the introduction of a number of serious rivals at home video stores.
The challengers include Disney's ''Lady and the Tramp''; the first video cassette of Barbie, the long-lived doll from Mattel and three ''battle training'' video cassettes for Captain Power, the hero of one of this season's new television shows, ''Captain Power and the Soldiers of the Future.

Miss Those Witch Hunts?
LEAD: ''Remember, there once was a Congress,'' said President Reagan last week to The Washington Times, ''in which they had a committee that would investigate even one of their own members if it was believed that that person had Communist involvement or Communist leanings.
Well, they've done away with those committees,'' he continued.

By dialing (212) 777-3380, they reach the Dial-a-Teacher program, which offers help in eight languages.

Fire at Reactor in Colorado
LEAD: A 15-minute fire caused minor damage at a turbine building at the Fort St.
Vrain nuclear power plant here today.
No injuries were reported and officials said no radiation had been released.

Reagan And the Russians
LEAD: President Reagan's decision to go for an arms agreement and an early summit meeting with Mikhail Gorbachev has left some of his faithful flock disgruntled.
Conservative Republican senators say they will try to block the arms treaty.
Right-wing commentators write gloomily about the menace of detente.


FICTION
LEAD:  CAFE NEVO.
By Barbara Rogan. (Atheneum, $19.95.) The Cafe Nevo is a seedy, dusty Tel Aviv bistro that operates as a stage for the handful of querulous artistic souls who regularly collect there to concoct literary schemes, flaunt extramarital liaisons and achieve respite from the omnipresent reality of the war in Lebanon as well as the past sorrows of the flight from Germany that carried many to the Middle East.


'Tosca' in Philadelphia
LEAD: Eva Marton will sing the title role in Puccini's ''Tosca,'' Tuesday at 8 P.M., when the Opera Company of Philadelphia season opens at the Academy of Music, Broad and Locust Streets.
Vladimir Popov is to sing Cavaradossi; the other leads are Sherrill Milnes as Scarpia and Italo Tajo as the Sacristan.

Bringing the Bounty into the Bank
LEAD: TODAY'S food banks rarely reflect their often-makeshift origins.
New Jersey's Community Food Bank, which found its first home in founder Kathleen DiChiara's automobile, has a new 43,000-square-foot warehouse.


Varmint Golf
LEAD: COYOTES are curious and at least one would appear to have a yen for golf.
Mary Hoover, who competed in the Women's Southwest Golf Association match play tournament at the 49er Country Club in Tuscon last week, said that after she hit a ball in Wednesday's round, a coyote came out of the rough, chased the ball until it bounced to a stop, then rolled on top of it and picked it up.


Where to Eat In Rangoon
LEAD: Because most tourists in Burma spend only a day or two in Rangoon - a byproduct of the seven-day limit on visas - many don't venture beyond the hotels for meals.
Most hotel dining rooms are not distinguished by either the atmosphere or the food.

LEAD: NOT as sensible or cheering, in selection or in execution, is the first production this season of the WPI Theater in Old Greenwich: the pseudomusical ''Quilters.'' This is a case of a small theater company, overextended.

LEAD: VICE PRESIDENT BUSH visited Poland last week, bringing gifts to encourage economic and political change and camera crews to record his trip for possible showing in his campaign for the Presidency.


IT'S TIME FOR THE JETS TO SACK MARK GASTINEAU
LEAD: IF the Jets hope to create the locker-room love that a Super Bowl contender needs, Mark Gastineau must be sacked as soon as possible.
He is no longer a ''teammate,'' if he ever was.
He must be shipped away, preferably in a trade that will enhance the Jets' future.


Madrid
LEAD: To the Editor: For a half-day outing in Madrid appealing to sightseers and art lovers alike, I recommend a visit to the Spanish Museum of Contemporary Art followed by a walk in West Park.
The museum is on Avenida Juan de Herrera in University City in the northwest sector of Madrid (not on the Paseo de Recoletos as reported in ''What's Doing in Madrid,'' July 5).


'THE DEADLY GAME,' A THRILLER
LEAD: ''THE DEADLY GAME,'' now at the Arena Players, is an adaptation by James Yaffe of a Friedrich Duerrenmatt's novel.
The play is a thriller that milks its chills not from dramatic action, but rather from the subtle interplay of warped intellects.
It is a drama that demands its audience pay attention to every word, because the tension builds with the slow, steady, intricate movement of a courtroom drama.

LEAD: More than 50 stations affiliated with ABC, NBC and CBS have scheduled a syndicated program, the two-hour premiere of ''Star Trek: The Next Generation,'' during prime time this week.

IN FAMILY COURT, HARD CHOICES
LEAD: THE proceedings of the Family Court in White Plains are generally closed to the public, but any rider on the County Courthouse elevator knows the stop.
It is where all the children get off.
The adults hold the doors an extra moment each morning so the children can wedge past the knees and bulging briefcases of the lawyers.

LEAD: IN A SMALL, SPARE STUDIO ON Lafayette Street, filled with folding chairs and four huge mirrors, 10 cheery vocalists are chirping the same show tune: ''One basic costume.
One unit set.
This is it, my dearies.
This is all you're going to get.''

MAYAN MYSTERIES
LEAD: When did it consciously begin, this delight in decayed or wrecked buildings?
Very early, it seems.
Since down the ages men have meditated before ruins, rhapsodized before them, mourned pleasurably over their ruination, it is interesting to speculate on the various strands in this complex enjoyment, on how much of it is admiration for the ruin as it was in its prime .

WHAT'S NEW IN FOOD BANKS
LEAD: ON Oct. 16, the seventh annual observance of the United Nations-sponsored World Food Day takes place.
Its purpose: to draw attention to the issue of hunger.
In the United States there is a growing number of people dedicating themselves to one partial solution to this problem at home.
They call themselves food bankers.

WHAT IS ART? IN OLD SAYBROOK, IT'S JUNK
LEAD: AT first glance, the heaps of tools, scrap iron, old hoses, nails and screws seem like, well, heaps of junk.
But, here and there, a car jack has sprouted eyes, or a pair of hedge clippers, claws.
These are not simply rusting old tools; all are in various stages of transformation from junk into creatures known as ''critters by Otis,'' as named by their creator, Theodore Otis

INSPECTING CHIMNEYS AND FIREPLACES
LEAD: SPRING is the best time to inspect chimneys and fireplaces.
The heating season is over, acids formed by combustion residues have not yet had a chance to corrode chimney parts seriously and plenty of time is available for repairs before cold weather sets in again.

Drop in Drama
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:


Food; AFTER QUICHE
LEAD: REMEMBER quiche Lorraine, that savory cheese and bacon tart that once spoke for all that was chic, French and gourmet?
Like many other perfectly decent and delicious French foods - boeuf bourguignon, fondue, the souffle - quiche simply wore out its welcome and became a cliche.
In time, America's favorite brunch food met its demise through pure and simple banalization.


MAKING USE OF END-OF-SEASON HARVEST
LEAD: FALL may have arrived but there is still plenty of ripe tomatoes, basil and summer squash around.
So when a weekend visitor recently announced his passion for vegetable soups, we set to work in the kitchen.
The result of our labor were three soups that were both attractive and refreshing and helped to use up the last of the summer crop.

PROSPECTS
LEAD:  The Compleat Forecast


LIVING WITH MS
LEAD: I am the friend with MS in Rand Araskog's story.
Perhaps the column should have been called ''About Woman.'' Dee has lived with my problem for 25 years plus, raised our four children, been gardner, handyman, etc., with few complaints.
With a disease like MS, it is really tougher on the partner.
Over 90 percent of MS marriages break up.


China Denounces Tibetan Leader As Responsible for Violent Protest
LEAD: China issued a harsh attack on the Dalai Lama today, two days after a crowd of Tibetans stoned and burned a police station in Lhasa and at least six people were reported killed.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Golf  Scotland vs.
England: Scotland beat the United States, 3-0, and England upset the two-time defending champion, Australia, 2-1, yesterday in the semifinals of the Dunhill Cup team tournament in St.
Andrew's, Scotland.
Nick Faldo, the British Open champion, sank a 15-foot birdie putt on the final hole to clinch England's place in the final after Rodger Davis of Australia, who had shot a course-record 63 Friday, squandered a three-stroke lead over the final three holes.

RAVENNA'S JEWELED CHURCHES
LEAD: RAVENNA IS A PLEASANT NORTHERN ITALIAN TOWN practically on the Adriatic coast.
The city and its surroundings are flat, which makes for easy walking and accounts for the city's bicycle cult.
Bicycles are parked thickly, leaving the streets comparatively free of standing cars.

New Orleans ... and All That Jazz
LEAD: IF YOU LIVE IN NEW ORLEANS, EXPECT guests.
My family and I moved here in 1985.
The guests came and there was never any problem entertaining them.
The city took care of that.
Though economically battered, New Orleans is still one of the world's great party towns - the result of a languorous climate, an abundance of food, especially from the sea, and a confluence of tolerant, somewhat exotic cultures on their unworried way to decadence.

LEAD: Army's chances appeared hopeless today when Tory Crawford, the Cadets' best runner and passer and the nation's second-leading scorer, went out with a knee injury early in the second quarter.

LEAD: THE Marine Bureau of the State Police has been described as an agency so underfinanced that it could not respond to many accidents, keep its own records or serve as a visible deterrent to crime on the state's waterways.

Photography
LEAD: Mark Feldstein has all the instincts of a street photographer but none of the usual reliance on inherited stylistic ideas.
Since giving up painting for photography more than a decade ago, he has progressed from an early fascination with the medium's ability to describe surfaces to a sophisticated understanding of the ways in which chance and ambiguity shape the meaning of images.

Music: 'Influence of Jazz'
LEAD: THE International Society for Contemporary Music opened its 1987-88 season Thursday at Symphony Space with a program tracing ''The Influence of Jazz'' in compositions for chamber ensembles, soloists, electronics and tape.
It was a diverse, uneven, but frequently illuminating evening, especially when composers and performers penetrated beneath the surfaces of jazz to grapple with some of the music's processes.

Saffron, Kashmir's Pot of Gold
LEAD: Kashmir is an emerald set in a ring of Himalayan mountains.
Here, in one of the world's most majestic settings, celestial benevolence has decreed that the world's most expensive spice should flourish.
At its current price in the United States, one ounce of saffron is literally worth its weight in gold.

Sitiveni Rabuka, who led a coup in the Pacific island state of Fiji, which, as a Commonwealth member, recognized the monarch as its nominal head of state.

Can the Contras Go On?
LEAD: THE AIRDROP CAME suddenly.
Bright parachutes popped open a few hundred feet above the cluster of bare thatched huts and green tents that served as the contras' border command post.
Within moments, the wooden ammo crates thudded to the ground.
Having dispensed another load of American bullets to the Nicaraguan contras, the rebel supply plane ducked over the jungle tree line and headed back to its C.I.A.

Paris When It Shimmers
LEAD: HOW WONDERFUL TO SEE RAINY STREETS once more, wrote the Goncourt brothers in their joint diary after a stay in intolerably sunny Rome.
The Paris winter sky reflects wet sidewalks, or seems to, gray on gray.
A photograph by Alfred Stieglitz, ''A Snapshot, Paris,'' 1913, has it, exactly.
There is a print of the photograph in the Musee d'Orsay.

ORIGINAL INTENT
LEAD: William Safire is in good company, but I'm not sure he's right (On Language, ''Hermen Eutic's Original Intent,'' Sept. 6).
Many writers have claimed a connection between Hermes and hermeneutics, but the evidence is in short supply.
Onions's etymological dictionary sees no connection, tracing hermeneutics back to the Greek hermeneuein, or interpret, and saving Hermes for the origin of hermetic (by way of Hermes Trismegistus, the author of occult science).

In the 19th century and perhaps before then, the adaptability of Long Island soil to grapery was already well recognized.

Correction
LEAD: An article on Sept. 20 about greeting cards incorrectly described the relationship between the American Greetings Corporation and Rousana Cards.
American Greetings bought certain distribution rights and inventories from Rousana, which remains an independent company.


PRE-COLUMBIAN SCULPTURES
LEAD: THE Lehman College Art Gallery's present attraction is a group of small sculptures, pottery and textiles.
Most are pre-Columbian, the rest are African or Melanesian and all were drawn from the college's Testut-Obstfield Collection.
On view through Oct. 24, it is a show with no title and precious little documentation and, confined to the smaller of the gallery's two spaces, it could easily be overlooked.

LEAD: AS a child I lived with my parents in a small modern apartment in a remote suburb of Paris.

Cody
LEAD: To the Editor: I read with interest Jim Robbins's article on Cody, Wyo. (Travel, July 26) and certainly share his enthusiasm.
When traveling the West, I always try to arrange accommodations at original hotels in the area.
In the case of Cody, Buffalo Bill constructed the Irma Hotel, named for his daughter.

Music
LEAD: The centerpiece of the operatic week is Friday night's opening of ''Das Rheingold'' at the Met.
This is the least outwardly exciting of the four operas that make up Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle, and it hardly ever sells out, so there is a good chance for late deciders to hear it, either this time or at one of the repetitions.

An Industry Built on Dubious Results
LEAD: THE Food and Drug Administration has been boasting that medical test kits for home use are 95 to 99 percent effective before they can be approved for sale.

1943 Draftee Retires
LEAD: Chief Warrant Officer Charles B. Russell, the last marine on active duty to serve in World War II, retired Friday.
The 62-year-old marine, who survived two South Pacific battles in World War II but was seriously wounded in the Vietnam War, was given the Marine Corps's meritorious service medal at his retirement ceremony.
