Fantastic Voyages
LEAD:  As Emily Dickinson would have it: 'There is no Frigate like a Book/ To take us Lands away . . .'  OZ  Follow the yellow brick road to the Emerald City, capital of the land mapped out by L. Frank Baum in ''The Wonderful Wizard of Oz'' (1900).
The Emerald Citizens, among them a vivacious Patchwork Girl and a loquacious Wogglebug, are friendly, but visitors to the colorful hinterlands are warned that enchantments abound.

LEAD: ALL the signs point to an American victory in the world team championship for the Bermuda Bowl due to begin in a week's time in Ocho Rios, Jamaica.
The United States has the same experienced squad that won two years ago in Sao Paulo, Brazil: Bob Wolff and Bob Hamman of Dallas, and four California players, Chip Martel of Davis, Lew Stansby of Castro Valley, Hugh Ross of Oakland, and Peter Pender of San Francisco.

LEAD: A shortage of space in drug treatment programs around the country is leading to expected waits of as long as a year, a problem not just for addicts but also for a society threatened by the spread of AIDS.


SHOWY FLOWER FOR A COOL SEASON
LEAD: HIGHWAYS and country roadsides boast plumes of wild flowers, seed pods and grasses that might be clipped and gathered in bunches to hang dry upside down.
They can be used later in floral arrangements for the house during winter.
Keep up with harvest from the vegetable and fruit gardens.
Finish digging, dividing and replanting the early-blooming perennials.


RAYMOND S. DINSMORE
LEAD: Raymond S. Dinsmore, a real-estate developer and world traveler who, in the late 1950's, was president of the Circumnavigators Club, an organization of travelers who have circled the globe, died Monday at the John F. Kennedy Memorial Hospital in Atlantis, Fla., of complications from a stroke.
He was 87 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

WOULD YOU WATCH STRIKE TEAMS PLAY?
LEAD: Absolutely not.
The idea is repulsive, revolting.
If we fans boycott the games, we really sock it to the owners.
Oh, how they deserve such sabotage.
Not that the players are any better.
Like most professional athletes, they earn far too much to complain about anything whatsoever.

Sibelius Isn't the Only Scandinavian Composer

THE GOD WHO HAS EVERYTHING
LEAD: ''EVERYTHING,'' AN operagoer who had just made first contact with Wagner's Wotan was overheard saying, ''is in there.'' The spontaneous exclamation resonates well with both the generalities and the particulars of the role, one of opera's richest and most difficult.
Wotan - the Norse god Odin, All-father, War-father - wants to shape the world and everything in it as Wagner wanted to remake not just music but all of art.

But the animation, the excitement and, of course, the showy upper class are long gone.

FICTION
LEAD:  FROM ROCKAWAY.
By Jill Eisenstadt. (Knopf, $15.95.) The misadventures of a group of going-nowhere teen-agers in Jill Eisenstadt's first novel, ''From Rockaway,'' would seem to confirm every parent's worst nightmares about what his or her children do when left to their own devices.
The book's central characters are a handful of college-age (though not necessarily college-bound) kids, for whom the tedium of their small, dreary world is relieved only by self-destructive rebellion and atavistic ritual.

GATHERING THE BIG ROSEBUD
LEAD: THE old metaphysical poet, John Donne (1573-1631), has achieved the ultimate sign of immortality.
There he was, paraphrased on the blackboard in the Detroit Tiger locker room, usually reserved for more contemporary quotes and imprecations.


CONNECTICUT GUIDE
LEAD:  YALE CONCERT  Eleazar de Carvalho, the Brazilian conductor and composer, will celebrate his arrival at Yale University by conducting the Yale Philharmonia in a free concert at 8 P.M.
Friday in Woolsey Hall.
In his new post as professor of music and conductor in residence, Mr.
Carvalho will teach advanced students and serve as conductor of the Philharmonia, succeeding Otto-Werner Mueller.


A LITERARY TRIUMPH: SCARSDALE'S BOOK FAIR
LEAD: IN the life of a book, a book fair is perhaps the final chapter.
Removed, perhaps still unread, from the dusty shelf on which it has spent most of its existence, the book joins many of its kind on a table where, under usually chaotic conditions, it is inspected and most likely sold at a fraction of its original retail value.


DEBATE INTENSIFIES ON WAYS TO CURB GROWING DEER POPULATION
LEAD: THE state's deer population, which is on the rise, is providing thrilling sights for nature lovers.
It is also causing annoyance to gardeners, economic problems for farmers and severe danger to motorists, particularly Fairfield County motorists.


INSPECTING CHIMNEYS AND FIREPLACES
LEAD: SPRING is the best time to inspect chimneys and fireplaces.
The heating season is over, acids formed by combustion residues have not yet had a chance to corrode chimney parts seriously and plenty of time is available for repairs before cold weather sets in again.


Arthur Carter
LEAD: To the Editor:


POSTINGS: Madison Planting; 63 Trees
LEAD: Move over Park Avenue.


Henry Ford 2d
LEAD: The death of Henry Ford 2d at the age of 70 is not expected to affect the management of the big auto maker, but it will leave a void in the corporate culture.
A man who believed the boss should be the boss, Mr.
Ford nevertheless was not one to dismiss counsel lightly; indeed, when he seized control of the company in 1945, he listened carefully to those who knew more about running it than he did, until he had a firm grasp of its operations.


NEW JERSEY GUIDE
LEAD:  DENVILLE FESTIVAL  The Morris County community of Denville annually attracts more than 50,000 visitors to its Harvest Festival, which this year will be held Saturday.
It is the major fund-raising event for St.
Clare's-Riverside Medical Center, a 401-bed hospital sponsored by the Sisters of the Sorrowful Mother.


Many States Return Tax Windfall to Citizens
LEAD: More than four-fifths of the windfall that states could have gained because of Federal tax revision in 1986 has gone back to state residents in the form of tax relief, a national survey has found.


Art
LEAD: ''History painting'' as a mode of contemporary art is the pretentious premise for a show of big figurative canvases at New York University's Grey Art Gallery (through Oct. 24).
The term refers to the highest genre of art from the Renaissance to the mid-19th century - the rendering of elevated themes from classical or Biblical sources that served as vehicles for moral commentary.

A SEASON OF GOLDEN CALM IN ANCIENT JERUSALEM
LEAD: Autumn in Jerusalem is a season of deep and generous pause in the ritual and agricultural life of this holy city.
Now the sun, the color of old burnished gold, hangs steady in the sky before beginning its slide into winter's silver depths.
Soon the sapphire-blue skies of the waning dry season, as if in response to autumnal prayers rising from synagogues the world over, will give way to mists, heralds of winter rains to soak the new-laid seeds and bring on the crops of spring.

Correction

The Washington Post first disclosed the links on May 12, 1985; The New York Times's reporting, which appeared the next day, confirmed that of The Post.

STILL HERE AT THE NEW YORKER
LEAD: IT is a common enough occurrence for news as it grows old to turn into history but in my experience it is rare for history as it grows old to turn into news.
Rare or not, something of the kind appears to have happened with respect to ''Here at The New Yorker,'' which, having been published back in 1975, may be said to have passed into history, but which has lately become news on the strength of the many changes that have been taking place at the magazine over the last couple of years.

GOLDEN CITY BY THE BAY
LEAD: I HAVE VISITED SAN FRANCISCO AT least once a year for the last 20 years, yet the trigger of memory still evokes that pristine vision: an ocean liner moving out into the Pacific against the bare hills of Sausalito and, above it, rising from the fog, mystic, wonderful as the sword Excalibur, the graceful red span of the bridge.





Elena Sofonova: From Russia, With Love
LEAD: ELENA SOFONOVA DOES IT ALL with her eyes.
She suffers with them, smiles with them, searches with them - now for love, now simply for self-respect.
Soft and deep-set above the high Slavic cheekbones, they seem by far the strongest of her tools as an actress.
For her last two films, first the 1985 Soviet film ''Winter Cherries'' and now the widely admired Italian-Soviet offering, ''Dark Eyes,'' they have given her a way to evoke eloquently and almost silently the emotions of a charming and charmable woman who wants something more out of life than charm.


Treasury's Blunder in Paradise
LEAD: TAX policy can be a riot of conflicting interests.
The Government wants to collect more taxes, individuals and companies want to pay less, and tax advisers get into the act to craft ways of keeping tax bills down.
Most of the time, Congress serves as the central battlefield.

Below the Skirts
LEAD: ACCEPTANCE of short skirts has been abetted to a large extent by the fact that in the beginning - last spring - they were almost always presented with opaque panty hose, usually black.
Many women switched in summer to sheerer stockings.
These continue to be important with short evening dresses, but another category of panty hose is coming to the fore as cool weather approaches: a heavier style that can provide some warmth.


ROME
LEAD: AN ENCHANTED EVENING IN ROME DEPENDS on convivial company and good food and drink.
As in France, eating out here tends to be a religious ritual, but generally it's low church rather than high, and occasionally closer to a fundamentalist revival than to a solemn benediction.
There is no hush of holy sacrament, no delicate gourmet sipping and pecking.

WESTCHESTER GUIDE
LEAD:  CONSTITUTIONAL PARADE  The village of Mamaroneck celebrates the bicentennial of the Constitution at 1:30 P.M. today with a parade.
According to the organizers, it replicates an impromptu parade on Sept. 17, 1787, when the citizens of Philadephia turned out in droves and marched through the streets in support of the Constitution, which had just been signed.

LEAD: TO PARAPHRASE GEORGE BER-nard Shaw, I have been to the Metropolitan Opera three times in a week and I still live.

Springsteen Looks at Love
LEAD: BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN doesn't trust myths.
For a decade, his songs have been whittling away at the notion that the American birthright is unlimited opportunity and rising expectations.
Now, with the new ''Tunnel of Love'' (Columbia 40999 LP, cassette and CD, scheduled for release tomorrow), he's confronting another illusion: the myth of love as perfect bliss and panacea.

A Tip of the Hat to Bob Fosse
LEAD: BEFORE THE DAY'S RE-hearsal of ''Dancin','' his 1978 Broadway show, Bob Fosse stopped to answer a few questions, but his mind was not on conversation; his feet wanted to work.
Then he put on a pair of white gloves and faced his dancers, all of whom were wearing identical white gloves and straw hats at a rakish Fosse tilt (over one eye, as if to ward off the glare of artificial light).

A SPICE OF BRAZIL: AMADO'S TALES
LEAD: Brazil is so large, so varied and so unfinished that books about the country, both literary and academic, tend to offer a glimpse of a region or a slice of the past rather than a global vision of the future or an all-illuminating insight into the present.
There are innumerable tomes about the Amazon, for example, but they principally mirror the country's chaotic rush to colonize and exploit its hinterlands.


NOTED WITH PLEASURE
LEAD:  Poetry at Play
To a fan, sport is poetry in motion - and for some, poetry too is a sport.
This is Robert Francis's ''Swimmer,'' from ''This Sporting Life'' (Milkweed), an anthology of American poems about sports and games, edited by Emilie Buchwald and Ruth Roston.
Observe how he negotiates his way  With trust and the least violence, making  The stranger friend, the enemy ally.

LEAD: THE Soviet Union is moving to repair its troubled relations with Iran and at the same time expand Soviet influence among the Arab countries.

FICTION
LEAD:  FIRST BORN.
By Doris Mortman. (Bantam, $17.97.) Doris Mortman, author of the best seller ''Circles,'' clearly believes that more of everything is better.
Her new novel's locales stretch from Phoenix to Paris, her descriptions of fashion and decors take up a considerable portion of the book's 674 pages, and she has created not one but four heroines, all named after the grandmother they share.

Troubling Signs Over Antarctica
LEAD: EVERY year when sunlight returns to the Antarctic, scientists can chart a thinning patch in the earth's ozone sunscreen.

He regards me with an open, frank expression - an unusual attitude for a novelist.

Often the broker or adviser has just such a fund at hand, which may be managed in-house or carry a generous sales commission.

INSPECTING CHIMNEYS AND FIREPLACES
LEAD: SPRING is the best time to inspect chimneys and fireplaces.
The heating season is over, acids formed by combustion residues have not yet had a chance to corrode chimney parts seriously and plenty of time is available for repairs before cold weather sets in again.

Big Spending for a Spent Fuel Bribe
LEAD: Washington has reached rock bottom in its five-year search for an underground site to store spent fuel from nuclear reactors.
The latest scheme, devised by Senator Bennett Johnston of Louisiana, would make Nevada the unlucky host, recompensed with a $5 billion bribe.
Congress's other ideas being even worse, this one deserves attention.


Caring For the Condor
LEAD: ''THEY'RE ALLOPREENING,'' says Donald J. Sterner, hopefully, of the two California condors shown above.
The endangered birds are circumspect breeders, a problem for Sterner, whose job it is, as lead condor keeper at the San Diego Wild Animal Park, to assist the perpetuation of the species.
Allopreening, a ritual that frequently precedes the male's formal courtship of the female, consists of ''bits of behavior that bring them closer, nibbling each others' feathers, head and neck rubbing,'' Sterner says.


Even Offstage, These Performers Are Onstage
LEAD: MARTHA GRAHAM HAS often told us that ''theater is not a noun, it is a verb.'' The term ''theater'' derives from the Greek, signifying a place where things are to be seen.
The connotations of activity and of display in these definitions are especially applicable to dance as a theatrical art.
Nobody feels constrained to use the word ''proscenium'' to define the essence of theater.

LEAD: THE Kentucky Housing Corporation, a state agency, is using surplus cash to provide home loans to families with incomes of less than $21,000 a year.


A Master at Touching Up the Masters
LEAD: IN JOHN BREALEY'S LABORATORIES, a spacious complex at the Metropolitan Museum of Art where dulled and damaged paintings are brought back to vivid pictorial health, a few dozen pictures on easels are surrounded by rooms crowded with such tools of the restorer's trade as computers, microscopes, centrifuges, spectrophotometers, racks of test tubes and rows of black rubber hoses springing from stoppered bottles.

LEAD: THE general managers of New York City's major television stations should be encouraged to vacation on the East End.

They could see the beauty of Long Island's farmland, luminous skies and sunsets by the sea.
And they could see some impressive regional television on newscasts emanating from across Long Island Sound and clearly received by viewers out


Alpaca Sweaters Woven in La Paz
LEAD: In a courtyard near El Prado, the main thoroughfare of La Paz, Bolivia, Isabel Mamani kneels on the floor as she grinds cochineal on a stone mortar, the kind of mortar used in most Bolivian homes to grind hot pepper, garlic and spices.
Cochineal, an insect that feeds on cactus, is also the name of a dye produced from female cochineal; a spectrum of reds, from scarlet to rust, is the result, and the colors are used to dye a line of scarves, sweaters and shawls produced by Artesanias Millma.


Lost Cities of Britain: The Quest for Camelot
LEAD: THERE ARE IN BRITAIN VANISHED cities, lost villages, disappeared kingdoms even, some with their names still on the map.
Trying to reach them isn't quite as hopeless as trying to reach the rainbow's end, but the point at which their legend and their geography meet is sure to be buried in a thicket of poetry.

Costlier Insurance Said to Cover Less Liability
LEAD: Liability insurance is costing more and covering less, a researcher on insurance law reports.


New Year Postponed
LEAD: The United States Naval Observatory says 1987 will run long, with one extra second being added to the end of the year.
The addition is known as a leap second and is being added to keep clocks in accord with the Earth's rotation, which has slowed ever so slightly.


Woody Herman Gravely Ill
LEAD: Woody Herman was in critical condition today at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, a hospital spokesman said.
The 74-year-old band leader was on a life-support system in the intensive care unit, the spokesman, Ron Wise said.
Mr.
Herman was hospitalized Thursday because of congestive heart failure, emphysema and pneumonia, said his attorney, Kirk Pasich.


Street Fashion; Some Spots, for a Change
LEAD: LEOPARD spots are certainly leaving their mark on New York.
The distinctive buff and black rosette patterns, which occur naturally on leopards, are now being reproduced artificially on all sorts of things.
They're woven into wool and chiffon, stenciled onto leather and calfskin, and even dyed on the top of closely shorn heads (that hairdo should be interesting as it grows out).


LONDON
LEAD: TWENTY YEARS AGO, THE BEST LONDON RES-taurants - and there weren't many of them - specialized in a kind of Edwardian-French cuisine: strong tastes, lavish portions and an emphasis on creatures that can be shot - in other words, classic cooking for the hungry squirearchy.
Then nouvelle cuisine arrived to decimate the portions, overrefine the flavors and generally ruin our fun in the name of preserving our waistlines.


USE, BUT NEVER ABUSE
LEAD: HEMLINES are rising, ties widening, lapels thickening.
We live, it seems, in a world of fashion, and photography is not immune to its influence.
Fashion is especially a factor when it comes to how we tote our cameras around.

Chicago Rating Raised
LEAD: Moody's Investor Service said today it had raised Chicago's general obligation bonds to an A rating, reflecting the city's economic growth and its determination to balance its budget.
The bonds had been rated Baa-1 since March 1984.
The change could save the city $5 million to $6 million in interest expenses per $100 million worth of bonds over 25 years, Chicago's comptroller, Ronald Picur, said.

LEAD: ''STAR TREK'' is back - not as a rerun or a feature film, but as a syndicated series called ''Star Trek: The Next Generation.'' Trekkies will eagerly recall that the original series had its premiere in September 1966.
In fact, the series was not terribly successful in terms of ratings.
But its hard-core fans were devoted and fiercely protective, fending off at least one cancellation of the series with a letters campaign.


Zambian, in Appeal, Says Son Died of AIDS
LEAD: President Kenneth D. Kaunda issued a plea today for more funds to fight acquired immune deficiency syndrome, saying his son's death last year was caused by the disease.

LEAD: Shortly after President Reagan asked Frank C. Carlucci to become his national security adviser last December, Mr.
Carlucci telephoned Lieut.
Gen.
Colin L. Powell at his post in West Germany to enlist the general as his deputy.


Over All Impressive in Matron Victory
LEAD: Over All continued her dominance of New York's 2-year-old fillies and gave her trainer a sweep of the weekend's Grade I juvenile stakes by scoring a 5 3/4-length victory in the $136,900 Matron Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park.


DOROTHY READ THOMAS
LEAD: Dorothy Read Thomas, the widow of James A. Thomas, the tobacco company executive, died Friday of cardiac arrest.
She was 96 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Kota Kinabalu Journal; Moslem Cause Celebre: A Good Christian Burial
LEAD: Seventeen years ago, Robert Din Hatt, also known as Robert Chua, decided to renounce Christianity and convert to Islam.
He called himself Rashid Din Hatt Bulanggan.

LEAD: Ripe red apples on the ground in many New York State orchards are a sign that difficult financial times may lie ahead for some farmers.


The Editorial Notebook; The Ages of Apple Cider
LEAD: The farmhands included a 5-year-old, a teen-ager, a middle-aged couple and a grandmother approaching 80.
City dwellers all, they had gathered in Columbia County, New York, for a rural ceremony: pressing cider from the first apples of the season.


CHINESE CURFEW IN THE TIBET CAPITAL
LEAD: The Chinese authorities imposed a curfew today and tried to stop at least one busload of foreign tourists from leaving this Tibetan capital after pro-independence demonstrations in which at least six people were reported killed.


Football Diagramed on a Supply-Demand Curve
LEAD: To the Editor:


Juilliard Concert
LEAD: The Juilliard Orchestra will open its concert season at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday, with a program of works by Barber, Rachmaninoff and Prokofiev.
The pianist Garrick Ohlsson will be soloist for Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto No. 3; Otto-Werner Mueller will conduct.
Tickets, at $8 and $5, are available at the Avery Fisher box office or through Center Charge, 874-6770.


Ferry Rock
LEAD: Fans returning from a concert by a British punk rock band knocked a state ferry out of commission early Saturday when they chopped apart tables and chairs with an ax and ripped tiles from the ceiling, the authorities said.
Five people were arrested.
The fans were returning from a concert by the British group GBH, which reportedly stands for Grevious Bodily Harm.


Bears Crush Eagles With Ex-Bartender
LEAD: The strike version of the Chicago Bears does not compare favorably with the regular Monsters of the Midway, but it got the same results today with a 35-3 rout of the non-union Philadelphia Eagles before only 4,074 fans.


GE/RCA UNIT LOSES BURNETT AS ITS AGENCY
LEAD: The Leo Burnett Company of Chicago announced Friday that it was resigning the account of the GE/RCA Consumer Electronics division because the client wished it to use a compensation system unlike those of its other clients.
Also, Burnett said it was unwilling to go through an agency review.

Jean Anouilh, the French Playwright, Is Dead at 77
LEAD: Jean Anouilh, one of France's most prominent and enduring playwrights, died of a heart attack Saturday at the Vaudois University Hospital Center in Lausanne, Switzerland.
He was 77 years old.

LEAD: Sri Lanka accused India today of not doing its part to end ethnic violence on the island.

Opera: 3 Chamber Works
LEAD: THE American Chamber Opera's triple bill Friday evening at the Marymount Manhattan College Theater offered a group of short scores that promised interest, but proved unfortunately somewhat dreary in the event.
None of the pieces sent one home eager for more, except in one sense: Putting them on the stage is the only real way to test new operas, and so the company's efforts are firmly in the right place.

LEAD: The brisk bond market rally on Friday afternoon was enough to reduce note and bond yields by nearly a fifth of a percentage point, even if analysts could not point to any change in economic conditions that justified the move.

EARLY SNOWSTORM COVERS NORTHEAST
LEAD: The earliest snowstorm on record struck New York, Connecticut and other parts of New England yesterday, burying some areas in more than a foot of snow that closed roads and airports, knocked out power to more than 300,000 homes and turned russet autumn to wintry solitude.

LEAD: The Soviet Union opened its chemical warfare center here to foreign disarmament negotiators this weekend in an effort to convince the West it wants to destroy chemical weapons.

The League Declares a War Against Its Brawlers
LEAD: THERE is a new peace movement afoot in hockey, one designed to eliminate the bench-clearing brawls.
Although they occur with just about a third of the frequency of baseball brawls, they are perceived by hockey administrators to perpetuate the myth of their sport as a wrestling match on ice skates.

11% Mortgage Rate by V.A.
LEAD: The Veterans Administration said Friday that it was raising its maximum interest rate for new federally backed V.A. home mortgages to 11 percent.
The rise, which will take effect Monday, will be the V.A.'s fourth rate increase this year.
The agency said it was making the change to bring its rate in line with the overall mortgage market, in which rates have risen in recent weeks.

LEAD: It took Dorothy Herman six months to find a contractor to remodel her kitchen and build a new deck on her home here.
Now she has to wait four more months before the contractor, whose work she likes, has time to renovate her bathrooms.

Stock Exchanges Strong in Quarter
LEAD: The world's stock markets continued to show strength in the sixth year of the bull market, although the pace of expansion slowed.
In the quarter ending Sept. 30, stock prices worldwide rose by 5.7 percent, according to figures compiled by Morgan Stanley Capital International.

LEAD: Calor Group P.L.C., a British heating gas distributor, rejected as inadequate a takeover offer of $:821 million, or $1.33 billion, made Monday by Burmah Oil P.L.C. and SHV Holdings N.V.
Burmah, a British oil company, and SHV, a Dutch energy group that is Calor's biggest shareholder, had conditioned their offer on Calor recommending it to shareholders.

Young Man: ''Who are we going to get for a President this time around anyway?'' Female Companion: ''I don't think any of the names who have appeared in the last year are capable of running the Government.'' Citicorp Stock Split
LEAD: Citicorp declared a 2-for-1 split on its common stock outstanding.
The company said the split would be in the form of a 100 percent stock dividend.
The dividend will be distributed Nov. 10 to shareholders of record Oct. 30, the company said.
Citicorp stock closed yesterday at $58.50, up 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

LEAD: The Army has delayed production of its premier unmanned surveillance aircraft after operators proved unable to use it effectively in a 17-week trial last summer.

More Oil Rigs in Action
LEAD: Thirty-three more oil and gas drilling rigs were working in the United States last week, bringing the total to 1,127, Baker Hughes said today.
The previous week, the oilfield toolmaker's rig count had dropped by 7, to 1,094.
A year ago the total was 818.

LEAD: Fashion is exploding in all possible directions.
Not too long ago audiences complained that Italian clothes looked alike; you couldn't tell the designers without a score card.
The arrival of short skirts has changed all that.
It has spurred a burst of inventiveness as designers tried to come to terms with the new proportions.

LEAD: Iraqi planes struck five tankers, one of them the world's largest, in raids Monday, on Iranian oil targets at both ends of the Persian Gulf, and Iran fired two a missiles into Baghdad, one Monday and one early today, for the first time in nearly eight months.

LEAD: Arkansas' first teacher strike ended Sunday and classes resumed yesterday for the 26,000 students in Little Rock, who missed six days of school.

LEAD: Twelve Tamil separatist guerrillas killed themselves today while in government custody on the Jaffna Peninsula in northern Sri Lanka, and other guerrillas attacked two Sri Lanka army camps in the area, a Government official said.


Bossy to Miss Entire Season
LEAD: Mike Bossy, with his hands in his pockets and his delivery unemotional, announced today that he has resigned himself to a season of physical therapy in place of an 11th year of professional hockey.
But even though the back ailment he has suffered with since last spring appeared to make his retirement a foregone conclusion, Bossy said emphatically that he was not ready to give up playing.

LEAD: The Atomic Energy Authority today announced the start of a cleanup operation at the plutonium-producing reactor that was the scene in 1957 of one of the world's worst nuclear accidents.

TV Reviews; 'Intimate Contact,' Devastation of AIDS
LEAD: TELEVISION drama is curiously reluctant to tackle, frankly and sympathetically, the devastating effects of AIDS on homosexuals. ''An Early Frost,'' broadcast nearly two years ago, was a notable exception.
Otherwise, television dramas about AIDS have preferred to focus on nonhomosexual victims of the disease.


Electronics Sales on Rise
LEAD: United States factory sales of electronic equipment, components and related products are expected to reach nearly $225 billion this year, a 5.3 percent increase over last year, the Electronic Industries Association said today.
Consumer electronics manufacturers were expected to realize the largest gains, with projected growth of 7.1 percent, the association said.


Justices Uphold F.D.I.C. On Bank Underwriting
LEAD: In a further breach of the half-century barrier separating the banking and securities industries, the Supreme Court today allowed state-chartered banks that are not members of the Federal Reserve System to underwrite corporate securities.


Court Refuses Suit by Women Over Fire Test
LEAD: The Supreme Court refused today to hear arguments on the legality of a test that has kept women from being hired as New York City firefighters since 1984.


Canada Split on Accord; Nationalism an Issue
LEAD: Canada was a sharply divided nation today as details of the free-trade agreement with the United States became known, with business generally supporting the pact and trade unions and nationalist groups adamantly against it.


The Snow Melts but the Pain Lingers
LEAD: A golden autumn sun melted much of the snow that Sunday's freak storm dumped across New York, Connecticut and other parts of New England yesterday, but thousands of homes remained without power, hundreds of schools and businesses were closed and road and air travel was still limited.


The Pendulum Slows
LEAD: The French campaign for next spring's presidential election may well turn out to confirm a watershed in the history of republican France two centuries after the revolution.

LEAD: The Bregmans and the Belzbergs, two of Canada's wealthiest families, have jointly purchased a 7.4 percent stake in the International Multifoods Corporation and said they might seek control of the Minneapolis-based concern.


Bustling on Both Borders; A Man for One of Mexico's Crises
LEAD: Mexico's incumbent President acted reasonably in choosing Carlos Salinas Gortari, an economist, to succeed him next year.
His country remains gripped by its worst economic crisis in a half century.
But the anointed technocrat will have to spend as much time attending to an equally severe crisis - the faltering political credibility of the PRI, the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party.

LEAD: If the Twins do not win the first two games of the American League championship series in Minnesota, they most likely will be in serious trouble.
The Tigers could then conceivably wrap up the playoff in Detroit.

LEAD: The House of Representatives today approved a package of consumer-protection measures for airline passengers.

Telling a Mollusk's Age
LEAD: THE search for a precise way to measure the rate at which the chambered nautilus matures has long frustrated scientists because of the difficulty of studying live specimens of the peculiar shellfish.
But with the help of fallout from nuclear bomb tests, biologists have at last tracked the life history of one of the creatures.

LEAD: Pacific Dunlop Ltd. said it had agreed to acquire 60 percent of GNB Holdings Inc., a battery maker based in Mendota Heights, Minn., for $173 million (Australian), or about $123 million (United States).
The purchase would increase the Australian company's presence in the United States and make the concern one of the largest producers of batteries in the world.

LEAD: The United States Virgin Islands, where the average temperature is in the upper 80's and the notion of snow is remote, will field a Winter Olympic team for the first time, a team spokesman, Bill Beer, announced yesterday.
The nine-member squad that will travel to Calgary for the 1988 Winter Games will consist of two bobsled teams, two skiers and two lugers.

More Imports by Pontiac
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation's Pontiac Motor division said today that it planned to increase imports of small cars from South Korea as part of an effort to reach its goal of a 14 percent gain in vehicle sales to 825,000 in the 1988 model year.
Pontiac's general manager, J. Michael Losh, said his division expected to sell 110,000 of its LeMans model imported from the Daewoo Motor Company of Seoul in the new model year, up from a previous forecast of an 85,000 annual selling rate.


One Out, One In
LEAD: While Jonathan Boyer was calling an end to his international cycling career when he finished 68th in the Nissan Classic tour of Ireland on Sunday in Dublin, Greg LeMond was using his 44th-place finish in the same race as a building block in a comeback from injuries and illness that ruined his 1987 season.


Angry Look at Colleges
LEAD: ''THE Closing of the American Mind'' by Allan Bloom has been on the New York Times best-seller list for 23 weeks.
Apparently this angry book has been mis-titled: if so many are reading it, the American mind must be wide open.


NICARAGUA INDIANS AGREE TO ACCORD
LEAD: One of the leading commanders of Miskito Indian guerrillas fighting in Nicaragua has agreed to end his campaign against the Sandinista Government.


Log of Earth's Climate
LEAD: A cylinder of ice nearly a mile and a half long, painstakingly drawn from the Antarctic icecap by a Soviet and French scientific expedition, has documented 160,000 years of the earth's climate, revealing a surprisingly precise connection between changes in temperature and in the amount of carbon dioxide in the air.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Caucus Room Farewell?
LEAD: When Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. dropped the gavel last week to conclude the hearings on the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork, he may have brought down the curtain on the last performance in the Senate Caucus Room, the scene of some of the most dramatic moments in national political history.


Polygram Issue
LEAD: N.V.
Philips said it plannned to issue 15 million shares next month in its wholly owned record-making subsidiary, Polygram N.V.
About 10.5 million shares will be issued in the United States.
But Philips will keep a controlling interest in the company, a spokesman said.


Opponents Disrupt U.S. Hearings On Seabrook Atom Plant's Future
LEAD: Opponents of the Seabrook nuclear power plant in New Hampshire today disrupted Government hearings that could determine whether the dormant plant will be allowed to operate.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''It is becoming increasingly difficult to avoid the conclusion that someone advising the President is trying to torpedo the peace process.''  House Speaker Jim Wright, discussing Central America.  [ A1:1. ]


Critic's Notebook; Odd Entries, Drunks and Stars in Film Festival
LEAD: NINETEEN EIGHTY-SEVEN will be remembered as a year in which the New York Film Festival, in the course of celebrating its 25th anniversary, went a little batty.
It offered ''Jackie Chan's Police Story,'' a work of karate-based comedy hardly in keeping with the festival's usual fare.
It presented a rock documentary and concert film (''Chuck Berry Hail!


Service America
LEAD: The Allegheny Beverage Corporation tentatively reduced the price of its Service America Corporation subsidiary by $50 million, to $450 million, in weekend negotiations with the management group seeking to buy the unit, Allegheny said.
Allegheny and the group, known as the Servam Corporation, reopened discussions on the price after receiving lower revenue estimates.


Stock Sale Set By Sotheby's
LEAD: Sotheby's Holdings Inc. may be most accustomed to selling Van Gogh landscapes and Chippendale chairs, but the parent of the world's largest art auctioneer said yesterday that it would sell part of itself in a public offering.


Bustling on Both Borders; Today Canada; Tomorrow the World
LEAD: For all the ominous drama of warships in the Persian Gulf and the promise of a new superpower missile treaty, America's workaday foreign relations still depend heavily on its neighbors.
Ronald Reagan acknowledged that in his speech opening his Presidential campaign in 1979; he talked at length about a ''North American accord.


The Football Riddle
LEAD: Turning the television channels Sunday in search of a football game, this reporter came across on the screen a man in a hurry who was carrying a small brown object that looked like a football.
Or was it a roasted chicken?


Dancers In Benefit For AIDS
LEAD: TWO years in the making, ''Dancing for Life'' turned out to be one of the smoothest-run benefit performances in New York history - thanks to Jerome Robbins's supervision -and also one of the most emotionally stirring.


Vehicle Sales Fell 4% in '87 Model Year
LEAD: Despite the cut-rate financing offered in late summer by the Big Three auto makers, the 1987 model year ended with total passenger vehicle sales about 4 percent below the record totals of 1986.


Hitler's Nonelection
LEAD: To the Editor:


Florida Moves to Shut Loophole in Gun Law
LEAD: The Florida House and Senate each voted unanimously today to close a loophole in a new gun law that allows people carry weapons openly in public The bills differed slightly, which means the issue will have to be addressed again Tuesday.


BARYSHNIKOV EXPLORES DEPTHS OF MARTHA GRAHAM'S DANCES
LEAD: When Mikhail Baryshnikov makes his first guest appearance with the Martha Graham Dance Company tonight, his initial gesture as a frontier farmer in ''Appalachian Spring'' will be to touch the wood on Isamu Noguchi's Shaker-inspired frame of a house.
What does the gesture mean?


S.I. Republicans, After Three-Hour Delay, Elect New County Leader
LEAD: Staten Island Republicans elected Olga Igneri as their county leader last night, six days after their first attempt turned into a shouting, shoving melee.


Stand-In Jets Are Still Eager
LEAD: The replacement Jets returned to practice today, wounded and bandaged but eager for another game.


PITINO STARTS KNICK WORKOUTS
LEAD: Rick Pitino made his debut as coach of the Knicks this morning by conducting the first practice for rookies and free agents.


Bailing Out Israel
LEAD: The Israeli-American discussions on the joint security assistance program being held this week are perhaps the most significant ever between both countries.
They represent a critical opportunity for America to minimize the hardship and dislocation that might result from Israel's cancellation of its


Change at Negro Ensemble
LEAD: The board of directors of the Negro Ensemble Company has named Leon B. Denmark producing director of the 20-year-old theater group, the chairman, Lucius P. Gregg, announced yesterday.
Mr.
Denmark, who formerly was managing director, takes over day-to-day artistic leadership from Douglas Turner Ward, the company's co-founder and artistic director.


New York Official Reports a Crisis in Psychiatric Care, With State Reneging on Aid
LEAD: On the eve of a new Koch administration effort to remove homeless people with severe mental disturbances from the streets, a New York City health official said that overcrowding in municipal psychiatric emergency rooms had reached crisis levels and that the state was not doing enough to help out.


Teen-Ager Gets Six Months in Father's Murder
LEAD: Cheryl Pierson being escorted from court yesterday in Riverhead, L.I.
She was sentenced to six months in jail for her role in planning the murder of her father, who she said sexually abused her.

Us Defines Its Readers
LEAD: A person who switches drinks depending on his mood, or who likes to experiment with fashion, or who buys expensive goods because he feels he's worth it - that's a ''fashion-focused'' person, as defined by a proprietary study done by Simmons Market Research for Us magazine.


WRIGHT, IN SHIFT, DENOUNCES REAGAN OVER SANDINISTAS
LEAD: The House Speaker, Jim Wright, who took the unusual step two months ago of agreeing to collaborate with President Reagan on a peace plan for Central America, today called the White House's latest Nicaragua strategy ''ridiculous'' and a creation of ''the extreme right wing.''

LEAD: Mayor Koch shaking hands with Donald J. Trump during ceremony celebrating Israel's 40th anniversary.
The two have been feuding publicly and the handshake occurred ''at the appropriate moment -when it was the thing to do,'' said the Mayor.
Both declined to repeat the act for photographers.

LEAD: A joint venture between two cable-television companies was announced yesterday, paving the way for about 180,000 homes in southern Queens to receive cable.

LEAD: A 17-agency contest for the Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey ad account has ended with Gianettino &amp; Meredith of Short Hills, N.J., as the victor.
Billings are expected to be about $4 million, the agency said.

LEAD: A forthcoming book identifies an airline steward from Montreal as playing a key role in the early spread of AIDS in North America.


A Hunt for Better Coal Plants
LEAD: The coal-burning electricity plant here, about 45 miles northeast of Buffalo, is considered ''state of the art.'' Federal regulators and environmental activists agree that the plant meets pollution standards for air and water.

LEAD: The Hooker Corporation, an Australian developer, said yesterday that it had purchased 58 percent of the retailing operations of B. Altman &amp; Company, the New York department-store chain with six units in the metropolitan area.

For a Southerner, it might be a platter of fried chicken.
Someone who grew up on the Eastern seaboard might crave a piping-hot bowl of clam chowder.

LEAD: A teen-age friend of a youth charged in a shootout at a Queens livery company is a prime suspect in the murder of a witness who had testified about the incident before a grand jury, senior police officials said yesterday.

Oklahoma Is Accused
LEAD: Some Oklahoma football players earned as much as $4,000 a season by selling their complimentary tickets to boosters in violation of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules, according to a published report.
The accusation was denied yesterday by Coach Barry Switzer.


Murder Case Against Scandal Informer Crumbles
LEAD: A murder case in Florida against Michael Raymond, a key Government informer in the corruption scandals that rocked New York and Chicago last year, appears to have fallen apart with the recantation of the chief witness against him.

LEAD: Because of a mechanical error, the Sports of The Times column by George Vecsey in some editions of SportsMonday this week included scrambled columns of type.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Trump Study Sees TV City As Disruptive
LEAD: Donald J. Trump's Television City project would increase the daytime population on the Upper West Side of Manhattan by more than 60,000 and so severely overburden public transportation that a second subway entrance would be needed at 72d Street and Broadway, according to a preliminary draft of an environmental impact statement prepared by the developer.

LEAD: Steffi Graf of West Germany, the top-ranked women's singles player, is suffering from serious sinus problems that will soon require surgery, according to her personal physician.

LEAD: DESPITE the rapid development of communications technology, American businesses and their customers still depend almost exclusively on the traditional postal system for sending documents between homes and companies - activity that accounts for 80 percent of all mail sent and delivered in the United


CONSTANCE MAROSELLI
LEAD: Constance Maroselli, who worked for the National Basketball Association for 36 years, died Saturday night of a heart attack while on a flight from New York to Phoenix, where she was to retire.
Miss Maroselli was 63 years old.
Miss Maroselli began working for the N.B.A. in 1951, when the league was in its fifth season.


MICROWAVE COOKING
LEAD: I SHAMELESSLY love garlic, particularly when thoroughly cooked to a nutty sweetness.


Charges Are Denied By a Florida Doctor In Death of Ill Wife
LEAD: A doctor who says in an unpublished manuscript that he gave his cancer-stricken wife fatal doses of drugs has pleaded not guilty to murder charges in connection with her death.


Kenneth S. Uston Is Dead at 52; Famed and Banned Card Player
LEAD: Kenneth S. Uston, one of the world's foremost blackjack players whose skills prompted casinos around the world to ban him from their card tables, died on Sept. 19 in Paris.
He was 52 years old and lived in San Francisco.


Testimony Begins in Insider Case
LEAD: In opening arguments yesterday in the trial of David W. C. Clark, a New York lawyer implicated in an insider trading ring, the prosecution and the defense painted contrasting pictures of a ''dishonest lawyer'' who stole millions of dollars from his clients and of a man who had been too trusting of a dishonest stockbroker.


George D. Aranow, Attorney And a L.I. Community Leader
LEAD: George D. Aranow, former chief counsel of the American Automobile Owners' Association of New York and a Long Island community leader through much of the post-World War II period, died Sunday at West Park Hospital in Philadelphia after a brief illness.
He was 93 and lived in a retirement home in Philadelphia.


British Publisher in Asia
LEAD: Robert Maxwell, the British publisher, is prepared to take a minority stake in a Chinese-language newspaper in Hong Kong, he said today.


Sotheby's Stake Under the Gavel
LEAD: In the last five years, the booming art market has paid off for many artists, collectors and dealers.
Now it is about to reward the well-known investors who bet on the potential of the staid Sotheby's auction house.


Lasorda Keeps Job
LEAD: Despite teams with 73-89 records the last two seasons, Tom Lasorda will return as manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers for a 12th season next year.
Lasorda, who turned 60 last month, has been a member of the Dodger organization for 38 years.


NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1987
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL A3-15  The Pentagon plans to test a missile with 12 warheads this year despite strong concerns within the Administration and Congress that such tests could complicate arms control talks with the Soviet Union and hamper military planning.
Page A1  Divergent positions on Tibet's unrest were taken by the White House, which voiced support for China's position, and the Senate, which voted without dissent to condemn China for its recent crackdown in Tibet.


Dining and Shopping in Ironbound Area
LEAD: THE Ironbound section of Newark is rich in Portuguese foods, available in the neighborhood's many shops and restaurants.
Unless otherwise noted, all are open seven days a week.
Most restaurants take credit cards; reservations are usually needed for dinner.
Following is a selection of some of the best.


Norway Hints Oil Delay
LEAD: Norway said today that some of its proposed North Sea oil and gas projects might have to be postponed because it does not want to make excessive investments.
The Government predicted that Norway's oil and gas output would total 76 million metric tons (oil equivalent) in 1988, 12 percent above this year's forecast of 68 million.


I.B.M. Upgrades Switches for PBX's
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday revamped its line of computerized switches for voice and data communications, introducing an array of private branch exchanges, or PBX's, that supersede the mainstay products of the Rolm Corporation, its telecommunications subsidiary.

LEAD: Donald W. Brooks, who led an unsuccessful attempt to take over the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation, has resigned as the company's president and chief executive.

Robber With Toy Gun Is Killed by Storekeeper
LEAD: A robber wielding what turned out to be a toy gun was shot to death yesterday by the 23-year-old owner of a Brooklyn grocery store, the police said.


An Improbable Star Does Job
LEAD: In his two major-league seasons, Greg Mathews had sharpened his routine into a ritual.
The days and hours before his assignments as a starting pitcher for the St.
Louis Cardinals had become clearly defined.


No Tax Shift Seen by Baker
LEAD: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said today that President Reagan remains firmly opposed to any new taxes and that any legislation to increase taxes could lead the nation into a recession.

LEAD: Everyone knows that a family that finds itself the possessor of a TV remote control channel changer immediately increases its penchant for flipping.
But how much?


New F.B.I. Director in Hospital Again
LEAD: William S. Sessions, the new Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was sent back to the hospital today suffering from a relapse of a bleeding ulcer.
The emergency forced an indefinite postponement of his swearing-in, bureau officials said.


Peruvian Rebels Kill 3
LEAD: Guerrillas ordered 40 passengers off a bus today and killed three policemen who were among them, the police said.
They said two men and a woman, carrying machine guns and thought to be Shining Path guerrillas, stopped the bus outside Ica, a city 200 miles south of Lima.

LEAD: The food got mixed reviews last weekend at the marathon meetings at the Treasury Department during which the Canadian-United States free trade pact was sealed.

Senate Protests Soviet Tests
LEAD: The Senate approved a non-binding resolution today condemning the Soviet test firing of intercontinental ballistic missiles last week within 600 miles of Hawaii.
The vote was 96 to 0.
Senator Malcolm Wallop, Republican of Wyoming and sponsor of the measure, called the tests a ''deliberate provocation.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration voiced support today for China's position in the unrest in Tibet, while the Senate voted without dissent to condemn China for its recent crackdown there.

Japan Will Aid Gulf Nations but Not Send Patrols

Digital Audio Tape Due in Germany
LEAD: The Sony Corporation's revolutionary digital audio tape players will be available for the first time outside Japan starting Oct. 15, a spokeswoman for the Japanese electronics giant said.The players will be sold in West Germany, selected by Sony for the first sales outside Japan of digital audio tape, which boasts almost-perfect sound reproduction.


POTAMKIN HITS A SNAG IN ITS SALE TO PENSKE
LEAD: The owners of Potamkin Cadillac are encountering difficulty in selling their dealership in Manhattan to the Penske Corporation, a company that is probably best known for its auto racing operations.
A major obstacle is a delay by the General Motors Corporation in giving its approval to the sale.

LEAD: Bulgaria, the Soviet Union's most orthodox disciple, has ended a period of apparent hesitation that followed the accession to power of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, and plunged into a far-reaching program of political and economic overhaul.

House and Senate Vote for a Total Ban on Iran Imports
LEAD: The House and the Senate, reacting to the continuing clashes in the Persian Gulf, today overwhelmingly approved a total ban on imports from Iran.


Baseball Notebook; History Gives Tigers and Giants Edge
LEAD: Detroit and San Francisco have never played each other in the World Series, but they will this year - if the primary playoff indicators are correct.
The only contribution the Tigers and the Giants have to make to their progression to the World Series is to score more runs than Minnesota and St.
Louis in four of the seven pennant-playoff games.

Reagan's Pilot Discounts Peril
LEAD: President Reagan was never in danger when a small airplane passed near his helicopter over the Presidential ranch near Santa Barbara, Mr.
Reagan's pilot has testified.


Teacher Strike Ends in Chicago
LEAD: Joyce Holmes leading her second-grade class in the Pledge of Allegiance yesterday at the Louisa May Alcott Elementary School in Chicago.
The 430,000 students in the nation's third-largest district returned to classes as the longest teacher strike in the city's history ended.
The 28,000 teachers in the district will get a 4 percent raise this year and another 4 percent next year, provided funds are available.

JOSEPH F. CONNOR
LEAD: Joseph F. Connor, a retired assistant chief of the New York City Fire Department, died of lung cancer Thursday at Staten Island Hospital.
He was 73 years old and lived on Staten Island.


Bonds Rise Abruptly in Final Hour
LEAD: Bond prices improved abruptly late yesterday as participants in the credit markets set aside their fears of a worldwide rise in interest rates and focused on the implications of a sharp drop in stock prices.

LEAD: A new Pentagon analysis contends that the revised budget-balancing law has confronted Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger with the choice of dismissing large numbers of military personnel or cutting sharply into funds for operations and weapons.


Twins Seemingly Two Different Teams
LEAD: The temperature seemed to drop as the day grew longer, but inside the climate-controlled Metrodome it felt like a balmy autumn day.
There were no chilling gusts, no threatening clouds, no swirling dust storms round second base.
The massive roof above provided protection from the elements.
The Minnesota Twins felt safe.

ON THE SUNNY SIDE OF THE STREET
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation's latest car model holds only one person and has a top speed of about 60 miles an hour, but the fuel economy is hard to beat.
The Sunraycer gets its power from a 90-square-foot array of 7,200 cells that convert sunshine into electricity.


Group Has 21.1% Of Cineplex Odeon
LEAD: A shareholder group including the Canadian billionaire Charles R. Bronfman said it had acquired a 21.1 percent stake in the Cineplex Odeon Corporation, the second-largest motion picture exhibitor in North America.
The group said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had bought the stake for investment purposes only.

Chrysler Incentives
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation said its buyer-incentive programs would expire Wednesday, the day before the planned introduction of its 1988 cars and trucks.
The programs offered by the American Motors Corporation, which Chrysler acquired in August, expired on Sept. 30, along with those of the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation.

LEAD: In a shift back from the major leagues to the college ranks, Mark Connor took over yesterday as head coach of the Tennessee baseball team after completing his second tour of duty as pitching coach for the Yankees.

Saudi Rumor Depresses Oil
LEAD: Oil prices plunged yesterday in heavy trading amid unconfirmed reports of a major shift in Saudi Arabia's pricing strategy, a move that analysts said could spark a widespread price collapse.


China Borrowing
LEAD: The Bank of China closed a $200 million syndicated term loan, representing the first time China has borrowed in the United States.
The loan was provided by a syndicate made up of 28 United States and foreign banks and arranged by IBJ Schroder Bank and Trust Company of New York.
Formal signing ceremonies between senior members of the Bank of China and representatives of the syndicate were held yesterday.


Threat of a Hostile Irving Bid
LEAD: The Bank of New York said yesterday that, if necessary, it would proceed with a hostile bid for the Irving Bank Corporation.
It was the first time the Bank of New York had formally said that it would go forward with its previously announced bid on an unfriendly basis.


The U.N. Today: Oct. 7, 1987
LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY


Farm Loan Aid Voted By House
LEAD: The House voted final passage today of a multibillion-dollar bailout of the Farm Credit System.
The legislation includes creation of a secondary market for farm mortgage loans.


Council Panel Rejects Koch Nominee for Tax Post
LEAD: In an unusual act of independence that hinged on a strange parliamentary dispute, a New York City Council committee yesterday rejected a nomination from Mayor Koch for the head of a city commission.


LIFE IN THE 30'S
LEAD: THE way he told it, it really was a funny story.
He was sitting at the kitchen table, his second beer in hand, talking about having his wisdom teeth out.
The dentist's office, he said, looked like a gathering of ghosts, with the dentist and his assistants draped, masked, gowned, gloved.
The trays, the floors, the chair, the counter tops: everything was swathed in white.


Home Equity Loans Studied
LEAD: The Federal Reserve Board may soon order banks and thrift institutions to give consumers more information about the terms and conditions of home equity loans, Martha Seger, a Fed member, said today.


Beverly Hills Hotel Is Sold
LEAD: A company controlled by the Sultan of Brunei, reportedly one of the world's richest men, bought the Beverly Hills Hotel from Marvin Davis, the Denver oilman, for $200 million, spokesmen for Mr.
Davis said today.


Officials Begin Crackdown on Truck Drivers' Licenses
LEAD: One after another, the big rigs bumped over the state truck scales alongside Interstate 55 here, a steady procession of car carriers and cattle vans, tankers and flatbeds, westbound for the Mississippi River bridges and the open plains beyond.


WILL MERCER COOK
LEAD: Will Mercer Cook, a former Ambassador to Niger and Senegal, died of pneumonia Sunday at the Washington Hospital Center.
He was 84 years old.


Give Thanks for Indian Summer
LEAD: Autumn is that lovely season between summer and winter, the one that starts in the latter part of September and ends three months later.
It's also known as fall, and last weekend it looked as if it had passed us by.

Raquel Welch Forsakes Glamour In Drama on Dying
LEAD: HAGGARD and wasted by disease, she slumps like a rag doll, paralyzed.
The tracheotomy that enables her to breathe has deprived her of the ability to talk; she can communicate only by blinking her eyelids or twitching her head.
Once an attractive woman with a full mental and physical life, she is now a drooling dependent sustained by machines, her existence reduced to only one wish: that she be allowed to die.

LEAD: In a case mixing emotionally charged constitutional issues with mind-numbing procedural technicalities, the Supreme Court heard arguments today on a New Jersey law requiring public schools to permit students a minute of silence at the start of the school day.

Louis Cardinals' attack in the opening game of the National League pennant playoff tonight, but the game turned on the base-path maneuvers of the slowest runner in the Cardinals' lineup.


Construction Work Up 5%
LEAD: Construction contracting rose 5 percent in August, to a record $268.3 billion on an annual basis, helped by strong building activity in the Northeast and North Central regions, according to a new study.


New Pipelines Are Reducing Persian Gulf's Strategic Role
LEAD: The construction of new oil pipelines by Iraq, Turkey and Saudi Arabia has significantly accelerated in the last six months.
These new pipelines, some of which are operational, are on their way to reducing the Persian Gulf's importance as the primary route for moving Middle Eastern oil to the West and Japan.

New York Might Be Getting New Revival-Movie House
LEAD: One month after closing the Regency Theater, a popular West Side revival-movie theater, the Cineplex Odeon Corporation is expected to announce today that another of its 18 Manhattan movie theaters, the New Carnegie, will be transformed into a revival house.


Goode and Rizzo Clash on TV
LEAD: Mayor W. Wilson Goode and former Mayor Frank Rizzo called each other liars tonight as they clashed in their only televised debate before the Nov. 3 election.


Insider Study in Tokyo
LEAD: The Finance Ministry has decided to set up a special group to study ways to revamp laws governing insider trading of stocks, a ministry official said today.
The ministry hopes to form the group, composed of academics and lawyers, by the end of this month, he said.
The Osaka Stock Exchange said today that some dealings in the stock of the Tateho Chemical Industries Company before the company announced huge losses were ''extremely problematic,'' but that insider trading could not be proved.


Health Chief in Jersey Details AIDS Testing
LEAD: The New Jersey State Health Commissioner, in outlining a program to combat the rise of AIDS in New Jersey, said today that some doctors and hospitals have been testing patients for the virus without consent.

LEAD: Last year, there were raised hackles in the locker room even before the Rangers embarked on their 47th consecutive season without a Stanley Cup.

DIA FOUNDATION, BACK FROM BRINK, OPENS NEW CENTER
LEAD: Two years ago, it looked as if the far-flung Dia Foundation, a major private financing source for certain contemporary artists, did not have much of a future.
Backed by millions of dollars from a single patron, Philippa de Menil Friedrich, it was overextended in its commitments to venturesome projects.


Reminiscent of Summer
LEAD: A young man reading yesterday as the early fall sun played on the cascading water in the fountain at Lincoln Center.
Today is to be cooler with showers likely. (NYT/Chester Higgins Jr.)


A Disk-Driven Drill Sergeant
LEAD: Peering at the image of an Army helicopter's control panel, the soldier reads the subtitles ordering him to prepare for takeoff and start the engines.
He taps the video screen.
If he has touched the right part of the complex panel image, the scene shifts and another order appears.
If not, an ''X'' appears over his choice and a circle shows where he should have pressed.

LEAD: The Actors' Fund of America, which is trying to make up large deficits, raised $150,000 Monday night at a gala benefit that brought together Washington politicians and Broadway stars.

LEAD: A Columbia County jury last night found a former high school honor student not guilty of murder charges in the Dec. 13, 1986, shooting deaths of four members of his household in their East Chatham home.

Tamils Kill 50 to 60 in Sri Lanka
LEAD: Ethnic Tamil separatists went on a rampage in the eastern Batticoloa District Tuesday and early today killing between 50 and 60 majority Sinhalese villagers, police officials said.


U.S. AIDS Guide for Schools Stresses Abstinence
LEAD: In a handbook that was cleared by the White House, the Department of Education today urged all parents and teachers to stress ''appropriate moral and social conduct'' as the first line of defense against the spreading AIDS epidemic.


Head of OPEC on Tour
LEAD: Rilwanu Lukman, president of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, left today to visit Persian Gulf oil states to bolster support for OPEC price policies.
Mr.
Lukman, who is also Nigeria's oil minister, told reporters that OPEC members must stay within their production quotas before oil prices can improve.

Ameruso Gets 16 Weekends On Rikers I.
LEAD: Anthony R. Ameruso, who was New York City's Transportation Commissioner for eight years, was sentenced yesterday to 16 weekends in jail and five years' probation for lying under oath to a panel investigating government corruption.

Chicago Merc Accepts Plan
LEAD: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange overwhelmingly approved a plan today to create an electronic trading system allowing investors worldwide to buy and sell financial futures and options around the clock.
An exchange spokeswoman, Julie Jacobs, said 3,939 exchange members, or 88 percent, voted in favor of the new system and 526 voted against it.


Japan Prince Sees Reagan
LEAD: President Reagan and Crown Prince Akihito of Japan discussed ties between their two countries during a brief meeting today at the White House.
The Prince, 53 years old, and his wife, Crown Princess Michiko, began a three-day visit to Washington on Monday.


Tenneco Stock Up
LEAD: Shares of Tenneco Inc. rose $1.375 yesterday, to $61.25, as rumors continued to circulate that the company was about to be taken over.
Trading in the stock was heavy, with about 3.2 million shares changing hands, leading to speculation that corporate raiders were accumulating shares and that the company would restructure itself in order to mount a defense.

PERSONAL HEALTH
LEAD: AFTER 10 weeks and seven additional pounds, the sports enthusiast is finally playing tennis again.
What happened to the summer - and to his waistline? ''My back went out,'' he said, ''and all I could do was lie around and eat.''

LEAD: A Federal judge yesterday upheld the Environmental Protection Agency's authority to override the Army Corps of Engineers and block a shopping mall from being built on a Massachusetts wetland.

LEAD: A former lawyer for a cable company tes-tified yesterday that John A. Zaccaro told him in October 1981 that a cable television franchise could be obtained in Queens for a substantial amount of money.


Multifoods Wary
LEAD: The International Multifoods Corporation, a diversified food processing company, warned a group of Canadian investors that further purchases above their 7.4 percent stake in the company would not be welcome.
Bregman Partners, a partnership that includes the Belzberg family, said late Monday that it had acquired a 7.4 percent stake in Multifoods and that it was considering seeking control of the company.

Brazil Asks for Aid for 58 Radioactivity Victims
LEAD: Brazil has appealed to international specialists to help treat 58 people who were contaminated by radioactivity in the city of Goiania, the Foreign Ministry said today.

Spiegel Pricing
LEAD: Merrill Lynch &amp; Company said it had priced at $16 a share an initial offering of stock in Spiegel Inc., a top mail-order retailer returning to Wall Street after 22 years.
The price was at the lower end of the indicated $16 to $18 range.
The offering of six million shares will raise $96 million for the company's capital expansion.

Commodore Unit Chief
LEAD: Commodore International Ltd. said yesterday that it had named Max Toy president and chief operating officer of its Commodore Business Machines unit.
Mr.
Toy formerly was senior vice president of sales and government products at Xtra Business Systems, a unit of the ITT Corporation.


Advice on Microwave-Oven Methods Disputed
LEAD: IN a new book on microwave cooking, a well-known food expert has been accused of giving advice that could be hazardous to consumers.
The expert, Barbara Kafka, is a consultant and cookbook author.
The disputed advice appears in ''Microwave Gourmet,'' published late last month by William Morrow.

NAVY JOB IN GULF: DIFFICULT MISSION
LEAD: The United States Navy task force in the Persian Gulf is being hard pressed by the difficult, tedious job of protecting oil shipping from attacks by Iran, according to naval personnel and diplomats in the region.


Guinness America Selling Some Units
LEAD: Guinness America Inc., Guinness P.L.C.'s holding company in New York, said it planned to divest itself of United States wine production assets, wine brands and the marketing company of its Somerset Group Inc. unit.
The company said the plans were consistent with its policy of concentrating on the spirits and brewing businesses.


Mozambican Rebels Step Up Raids in Zimbabwe
LEAD: Rebels fighting the Marxist Government of Mozambique have expanded their war into this lush region of sprawling tea estates.


TV Ministers Dispute Need for Tighter Regulation
LEAD: Facing Congressional scrutiny in the wake of the PTL ministry scandal, some prominent television evangelists today questioned whether there was any need for the Government to require greater financial disclosure by religious broadcasters and whether that would be proper.


One Author Is Rankling Two Chinas
LEAD: Bo Yang is a mild-mannered, bespectacled scholar who scribbles Chinese characters on notebooks in his small study, and infuriates people throughout the Chinese-speaking world.


Chip Sanction Held Effective
LEAD: The sanctions imposed on Japan by the United States in April following complaints that it had breached a semiconductor trade pact are working, an American industry spokesman said today.


Who's Political About the Court?
LEAD: ''Let's begin again,'' Senator Dennis DeConcini entreated the President yesterday as the Arizona Democrat joined in the lopsided 9-to-5 Judiciary Committee vote against the Supreme Court nominee Robert Bork.
Nothing doing, said Mr.
Reagan. ''There's no backing off.
I'm going all out.'' Unchastened, he passed the word that he was disappointed with Republicans and peeved at Democrats for ''politicizing'' the confirmation.


After Loss, Parcells Grim but Bearing It
LEAD: Little more than eight months ago, the Giants won Super Bowl XXI.
Now, in the new pro football season, they are 0-3 and sinking fast, and Coach Bill Parcells is openly unhappy about the quality, but not the effort, of his replacement team.


G.M. Job Transfers
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation has begun processing applications by workers at two Saginaw plants seeking jobs at Central Foundry division plants in Ohio and Illinois.
G.M. said 1,066 Saginaw Nodular Iron and Saginaw Grey Iron plant workers are seeking transfers to plants in Danville, Ill., and Defiance, Ohio.


Preliminary Trade Pact With Mexico Is Shaped
LEAD: The Reagan Administration, after concluding a sweeping trade pact with Canada, is about to sign an agreement with Mexico setting up machinery for settling trade disputes and opening negotiations to curb barriers to trade and investment.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''We shall win one way or another, either by confirming Robert Bork or making a political issue of this process in 1988 and 1990 and beyond.'' - Senator Gordon J. Humphrey, Republican of New Hampshire.  [ B10:1. ]


Succoth Mural Celebrates Israel's Independence
LEAD: Knox Martin and Ilana Ravivi in front of the mural they painted inside a succah on East 14th Street.
The painting of the mural, which marks the 40th anniversary of the State of Israel, coincides with the holiday of Succoth, which begins today.
The succah is a tent-like structure covered with bamboo in which Jews eat and sleep during the holiday.


SMITH COMMUNICATIONS IS PLANNING A MAGAZINE
LEAD: Smith Communications of Scarsdale, N.Y., which has since 1978 been supplying promotion support to marketing services companies, now plans to go into magazine publishing.
Kerry E. Smith in November expects to bring out the first monthly issue of Promo, a trade publication for the sales promotion industry, on which he puts a value of $100 billion in sales annually.


Mubarak Re-elected to Run Egypt
LEAD: Egyptians voting in a referendum gave President Hosni Mubarak, the only candidate, six more years in office by a majority of 97.1 percent, the Government said today.


Mob Figure Is Found Shot to Death in Brooklyn
LEAD: A reputed associate of the Bonanno organized-crime family was found shot to death early yesterday morning on a Brooklyn street in the latest of a series of gangland-style slayings, the police said.


Real Estate; 8 Blocks Of 5th Ave. Awakening
LEAD: ALTHOUGH home to two of Manhattan's most renowned department stores for more than half a century, the eight-block stretch of Fifth Avenue from the Empire State Building to the New York Public Library has never won much respect as an office district.

Taper Forum Awarded Jujamcyn Theater Grant
LEAD: A resident theater company in Los Angeles, the Mark Taper Forum, will receive the 1987 Jujamcyn Theaters Award.
The award, an unrestricted grant of $50,000, was announced yesterday by Rocco Landesman, president, and James Binger, chairman of the Jujamcyn organization, which owns five Broadway theaters.


Better Training for Teachers
LEAD: How can the best young people be attracted to the teaching profession?
More money and better teaching conditions, for sure.
But also a better education for teachers, and education planners have begun to focus on just that.


Citicorp Auction
LEAD: Interest rates rose modestly for the third consecutive week at Citicorp's auction of 91- and 182-day commercial paper yesterday.
The bank holding company said it sold $50 million of the 91-day paper at an average rate of 7.9688 percent, up from 7.54 percent last week.
Citicorp also sold $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 8.1420 percent, up from 7.8584 percent.


ITT to Sell STC Stake To Telecom
LEAD: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its 24 percent interest in STC P.L.C., a British manufacturer of telecommunications equipment, to Northern Telecom Ltd. for about $730 million.

Arnell/Bickford Gets European American
LEAD: After doing without an advertising agency for quite some time, the European American Bank has selected Arnell/Bickford Associates to fill the void.


100 Feared Killed As Migrants' Vessel Sinks in Caribbean
LEAD: Up to 100 people were feared killed today in the sinking of a wooden boat carrying Dominicans seeking illegal entry to Puerto Rico, officials here said.


House Moves to Combat Acts of Religious Hatred
LEAD: The House of Representatives passed a bill Monday that would expand Federal authority to fight crimes that damage religious property and obstruct the free exercise of religious beliefs.


Talks Under Way In N.F.L. Strike
LEAD: Labor leaders for the National Football League owners and striking players resumed negotiations yesterday afternoon, raising hopes that the strike might end soon, possibly before this weekend.


Yes, Keep Sanctions Against Pretoria
LEAD: President Reagan is the wrong person to assert the failure of economic sanctions against racial tyranny in South Africa.
Who thought that sanctions, weak or strong, would end apartheid?
They were meant to tell South Africans where America stands on a question of good and evil.
Congress voted for sanctions over the President's objections precisely because the signals he had sent Pretoria were mixed.

Ford Left Most of His Fortune To a Private Trust, Will Shows
LEAD: Henry Ford 2d left the bulk of his fortune, estimated at $250 million, to a private trust whose beneficiaries are unnamed, according to his will, filed here.


German Factory Orders
LEAD: Orders for industrial goods in West Germany rose 7.4 percent in August, but economists were not sure if the official figures signaled a rebound in the most powerful West European economy.
The Federal Statistics Office today attributed the rise partly to strong demand for machinery and electrical engineering goods.


60 Shout Out Dalai Lama's Name And Are Seized in Protest in Tibet
LEAD: About 60 people shouting the name of the Dalai Lama, Tibet's former civil and religious leader, marched today to a Government office, where armed Chinese security forces quickly arrested them.


FOOD NOTES
LEAD:  Abundant Whiting


LITTLE PORTUGAL: PAGE OF HISTORY IN NEWARK
LEAD: VISITORS to the Ironbound section of Newark enter a time warp.
Just three blocks from Pennsylvania Station here and a five-minute drive from Newark International Airport is an ethnic neighborhood of 40 or 50 years ago, where in the late afternoon, neighbors visit with neighbors, the women on their stoops, the men in the local bars.


COAST GUARD DUTY PLANNED FOR GULF
LEAD: The Reagan Administration plans to send four small Coast Guard patrol vessels and several search-and-rescue aircraft to the Persian Gulf to join the Navy there, Pentagon officials said today.


Sister Eleanor O'Byrne, 92, A Leading Catholic Educator
LEAD: Sister Eleanor O'Byrne, a leading Roman Catholic educator, died after a short illness Sunday at Kenwood Convent of the Sacred Heart in Albany.
She was 91 years old.


Lebanese Hijacking Suspect Is Arraigned on New Charges
LEAD: A Lebanese suspect arrested in international waters was arraigned today on four additional charges in the hijacking of a Jordanian airliner in 1985.

LEAD: THERE is rising optimism in magazineland, where publishers trained to detect the far-off sound of incoming money perceive a distant rustling.

LEAD: The Supreme Court was urged today to uphold a disputed legal theory that has been one of the Government's most effective weapons in its crackdown against insider trading on Wall Street.

FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
LEAD: Hydro-Quebec, the Canadian utility, borrows often in the American bond market.
Yesterday it offered $250 million of 10.70 percent bonds due in 2007 at a price of 99.106 to yield 10.81 percent through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.


Jury to Ponder Tax Shelters
LEAD: Charles A. Atkins, the New York financier accused of engineering one of the largest illegal tax shelter conspiracies in history, was described by prosecutors yesterday as a man who descended into a ''world of fraud'' because of his own ''greed and lies.''


Grey Gets Levolor
LEAD: Closer to home and slightly on the shady side, Grey Advertising, New York, has picked up the account of Levolor Lorentzen Inc. of Parsippany, N.J., maker of window blinds and similar products.
The billings, expected to exceed $5 million, formerly went through Muller, Jordan, Weiss.


Miller Has Surgery
LEAD: Keith Miller, the Mets' second baseman, underwent surgery yesterday to repair ligament and tendon damage to the little finger of his right hand.
Miller is expected to begin therapy next week.
He was recalled from Tidewater on June 16, but injured the finger sliding into third base during his first game and was placed on the disabled list June 29.


Farrakhan's Group Loses Bias Lawsuit In Javits Center Case
LEAD: A judge in Manhattan yesterday dismissed a lawsuit brought by the followers of the Rev.
Louis Farrakhan, who had charged that the operators of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center violated the Nation of Islam's rights by refusing to rent space for a religious rally this month.

LEAD: A former Washington lobbyist for the Wedtech Corporation pleaded guilty yesterday to a misdemeanor corruption charge stemming from his efforts to give a Federal official $10,000 in cash.


Corrections
LEAD: An obituary of Bob Fosse on Sept. 24 misstated, in in some editions, his involvement with the musical ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying.'' It was Abe Burrows who directed the Broadway production; Mr.
Fosse choreographed it.


House Panel Moves to Ease Restriction on Civil Servants
LEAD: A House committee voted Tuesday for a measure that would allow civil servants to run for office and to actively take part in politics, easing stern restictions that have stood for 48 years.

LEAD: The Strategic Air Command announced today that crew ejection systems in all B-1 bombers will be inspected before each plane is allowed to fly again, suggesting that a flaw was found after a crash in which three aviators died.
