Rangers Set for the Moment
LEAD: This morning, just one day before the season opener, Phil Esposito, the Rangers' general manager, ventured into the locker room of his club's training facility to tell the 24 players who survived camp that they had indeed made the team, and only by playing themselves off it would they lose their foothold here.


Basketry Becomes A Showcase Craft
LEAD: AFTER centuries on the shelf, the humble basket is now in the spotlight.
At auction houses, collectors vie for rare American Indian, Shaker and Japanese basketry; museums devote whole exhibitions to the craft, while contemporary craftsmen translate ancient basketry techniques into sculptural forms.

For Spring by Armani, A Softer Approach
LEAD: Continuing to focus on the jacket as the key to contemporary dressing, Giorgio Armani proved that fashion can be relevant without being ridiculous.
Obeying the law of moderation, he raised hemlines above the knee, softened the construction of his jackets and paired them with filmy chiffon skirts.
Using a pale watercolor palette, he made tailored clothes look feminine.


Indonesia Coffee Quota
LEAD: Indonesia, the world's third-largest coffee producer, said today that it was disappointed with the quota assigned to it in the accord struck Monday between coffee-producing and consuming nations.
The pact, intended to limit export quotas to lift world coffee prices, assigned Indonesia a 4.75 percent share of the market.


Syrian Diplomat Killed in Brussels
LEAD: Emergency workers trying to help Antanios Hanna after he was fatally wounded outside his home yesterday.
The first secretary of the Syrian Embassy was shot four times by a lone gunman who escaped. (Reuters)


Fetal Tests, Like Drugs, Need Cautious Screening
LEAD: To the Editor:


Democrats Draft Tax Changes
LEAD: With Republicans refusing to participate, Democratic members of the House Ways and Means Committee began working alone today on a bill to raise $12 billion in new tax revenue to meet 1988 budget needs.
Meeting behind closed doors for three hours, the Democrats tentatively approved a dozen tax changes that would meet about half of their goal.


Toll in Boat Disaster Is Estimated at 70 to 100
LEAD: Scores of people were still missing today in the sinking of a boat loaded with Dominicans trying to enter Puerto Rico illegally.
Estimates of the death toll in the Tuesday disaster ranged from 70 to more than 100.


Rockland Tax Break Backed
LEAD: The Rockland County Legislature unanimously endorsed in principle Tuesday a proposal to suspend the 1988 property tax by using, instead of tax revenues, a $50 million surplus accumulated in the last four years.
The suspension will come up for a formal vote when the county budget is considered in December.

Joseph B. Flavin Is Dead at 58; Lead Overhaul as Singer Chairman
LEAD: Joseph B. Flavin, chairman and chief executive officer of the Singer Company, died yesterday at Norwalk Hospital.
He was 58 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.


Brokaw Urges End To Strike
LEAD: Warning that ''the spirit of NBC is being sapped'' by the longest strike in the network's history, Tom Brokaw and 15 other NBC news correspondents sent a letter yesterday to the president of NBC urging him to end the strike.


MYERSON CHARGED WITH CONSPIRACY IN A DIVORCE CASE
LEAD: Bess Myerson was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday, accused of seeking to influence the judge who presided over her companion's divorce case.

LEAD: SINCE his return to the American concert stage in 1985, Vladimir Horowitz has become a documentary perennial. ''Vladimir Horowitz, the Last Romantic,'' celebrated his first recital in the United States in more than two years.
His much publicized visit to the Soviet Union was commemorated on television in ''Horowitz in Moscow.


Kohl Rejects U.S. Stance
LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl today rejected complaints that his country was not doing enough to spur the world's economy and warned against a ''trend toward protectionism'' in the United States Congress.


Communications to Tibet Cut And Foreigners Are Banned
LEAD: Little new information was available yesterday about the situation in Tibet as telephone and telex communications were interrupted and travel there by foreigners was banned.


Leeway Granted To Question Zaccaro Witness
LEAD: The key prosecution witness in the trial of John A. Zaccaro was declared a hostile witness yesterday, after testifying that he felt Mr.
Zaccaro had not tried to solicit a bribe from him.


Still the 'Uncle' Policy
LEAD: Good for Jim Wright, who rejects the Reagan Administration's demands on Nicaragua as ''ridiculous'' and as evidence that ''someone advising the President is trying to torpedo the peace process'' haltingly under way in Central America.


Libya Says Political Treaty With Algeria Is Near
LEAD: Libya and Algeria have reached agreement in principle on a treaty of political unity, Libya's chief delegate to the United Nations, Ali Treiki, said today.


Ansett Orders Jets As Australia Shifts
LEAD: Australia's largest domestic carrier, Ansett Airlines, said it had ordered 27 Boeing medium-range aircraft to increase its fleet to 93.
The announcement came a few hours after the Australian Government gave notice that it would move toward an ''open skies'' domestic aviation policy over the next three years, ending more than 30 years of strict regulation of the industry.


Margie Inman Is Dead at 76; Walked on Wings of Planes
LEAD: Margie Lynn Inman, who performed on the wings of airplanes in her youth and later battled local officials for the right to live in a lean-to with a menagerie of pets, has died at the age of 76.

LEAD: Americans on the whole think this is a better country because the Supreme Court has condemned racial discrimination, protected privacy and said that legislative elections must follow the rule of one person, one vote.
We are glad that the Court, in such bold decisions, interpreted the Constitution generously to protect individual liberty.

Cabaret: Anita Ellis At Ballroom
LEAD: ''I REMEMBER radio days and wish they were back,'' the veteran pop-jazz singer Anita Ellis mused from the stage of the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, on Tuesday evening. ''I loved the privacy of it all.
I could be whoever I wanted to be.
This is not where I belong.''


The Rev. Peter Halligan, 63, Maryknoll Missionary in Peru
LEAD: The Rev.
Peter J. Halligan, a Maryknoll priest who was a missionary in Peru for 33 years, died of a pancreatic disease Sept. 30 in Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan.
He was 63 years old and lived in Lima, Peru.


Dyncorp Bid Ends
LEAD: CJM Partners Inc. said it had withdrawn its $24-a-share bid for Dyncorp.
CJM Partners said Dyncorp and its advisers ''have already had more than two weeks'' to study the offer and have been unwilling to negotiate a binding agreement.
CJM Partners is a Delaware company owned by Jorge E. Carnicero, chairman of Dyncorp, and Elis S.


Curb on Eastern Bloc Envoys
LEAD: The Senate approved legislation today that would place stringent new travel and reporting restrictions on more than 2,000 diplomats and embassy personnel of seven Soviet-bloc countries.


Four Handsome Artemisias, and One Little Ugly Duckling
LEAD: ONE year it was sedums, and another it was alliums - 19 kinds of the former, and 14 of the latter.
From time to time, I like to plant several species within one genus close to one another, so I can get to know them as a group, observing the similarities and differences, much as one observes the same things in a family of people.


AILING F.B.I. CHIEF NEEDS MORE TESTS
LEAD: Judge William S. Sessions, the newly confirmed Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, must undergo further tests to determine what caused intestinal bleeding that led to his second hospitalization in a week, his doctor said today.


New Books On Herbs
LEAD: ''For a long time, people thought of herbs only as something dry, out of a jar,'' said Pamela Lord, editorial director of the Garden Book Club. ''But now they realize they can grow them in blooming borders.''


Latin America Inflation High
LEAD: Inflation rose by almost half in Latin America last spring, according to the International Monetary Fund, with annual rates topping 100 percent for the third world's three biggest debtors - Brazil, Mexico and Argentina.

Vatican Official Assails Method Of Fertilization
LEAD: A Vatican official told a group of medical professionals yesterday that test-tube fertilization reduces human beings to objects and degrades their ''being, value and dignity.'' But he was challenged by a leading gynecologist, a Roman Catholic who argued that the method permits devoted childless couples to have children.


Dance: Eiko and Koma
LEAD: THE collaboratively choreographed dances of Eiko and Koma have never been action-packed spectaculars.
Rather, each work by these Japanese dancers has contained only a few carefully chosen images evoking the forces of nature and the struggles of life.
One of the sparest of all their productions is ''By the River,'' which they presented Tuesday night at the Kitchen.


Music: 'Spectaccalo,' With Video and Sets for 'New Age'
LEAD: ''SPECTACCALO,'' a wordless 80-minute music-video-theater piece created by Peter Gordon, composer and saxophonist, and Kit Fitzgerald, a video artist, is a downtown New York expression of what might be called ''new age'' sensibility.


Homeless Girl to Go To School - Finally
LEAD: A homeless girl from Poughkeepsie, N.Y, is to attend school today for the first time this school year as a result of a Federal court ruling yesterday.

Foreigners Are Facing Limit on Transplants
LEAD: An organization of organ transplant centers has established a committee to assure that a limited number of organs will be allocated to foreigners, the panel's chairman said Tuesday.


Met Opera: A Debut In 'Ariadne'
LEAD: A SUCCESSFUL Metropolitan Opera debut was made Monday night by Barbara Kilduff, who took prizes in an impressive series of closely spaced vocal competitions last year.
The young coloratura soprano sang Zerbinetta in ''Ariadne auf Naxos,'' the same high-flying role that introduced her earlier this year in Vienna and Munich.


Bill Toward 'Fire-Safe' Cigarette Is Proposed
LEAD: A Congressman, remembering a Massachusetts family killed in a house fire caused by a cigarette eight years ago, proposed legislation today that would require tobacco companies to manufacture only ''fire-safe'' cigarettes.


Talley Industries Sets Restructuring
LEAD: Talley Industries said it plans to sell its apparel and clock-making operations to focus on its aerospace, industrial and real estate businesses.
The company said the restructuring would result in an unspecified loss for the year, its first in five years.
After a 30-minute halt in trading today on the New York Stock Exchange, Talley stock rose 87.5 cents to close at $22.625.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Mail From Farmers
LEAD: Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, has had some interesting reaction to his effort to limit the total subsidy farmers can get from the Government.


New Map of Genes May Aid in Fighting Hereditary Diseases
LEAD: Scientists have assembled a map of genetic signposts covering all 23 pairs of human chromosomes, an accomplishment that foreshadows a new era in the study of human heredity and the search for genes that contribute to many serious diseases.


Falwell Groups Fined for Illegal Transactions
LEAD: A religious corporation and a political action committee run by the Rev.
Jerry Falwell have both been fined $6,000 by the Federal Election Commission because of an illegal series of transactions between the two.


Leaders of AIDS Panel Quit Amid Feuds and Criticism
LEAD: The top leadership of the President's AIDS commission resigned abruptly today, further clouding the panel's ability to complete its assessment of AIDS programs on schedule.

Eurotunnel Financing
LEAD: Scandinavian banks said today that they were ready to lend $252 million to Eurotunnel, the British-French consortium that wants to dig a tunnel between Britain and France.
But the loan by 14 banks in Norway, Sweden, Finland and Denmark, as well as loans from other banks, depends on the outcome of a $1.21 billion public stock offering by Eurotunnel.

LEAD: In a White House ceremony today, President Reagan awarded Irving R. Kaufman, former chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, the nation's highest civilian honor, the Medal of Freedom.

LEAD: Reports on Capitol Hill have it that the White House is planning to nominate James H. Burnley 4th, the Deputy Secretary of Transportation, to succeed his former boss, Elizabeth Hanford Dole, as Secretary.


Dalai Lama Urges Peaceful Protest Against China
LEAD: The Dalai Lama, Tibet's exiled spiritual and national leader, urged his supporters today to continue their campaign against Chinese rule but to do so peacefully.

The recital begins at 8 P.M.

LEAD: Joseph Goldstein, who taught accounting and mathematics for 36 years at Julia Richman High School in Manhattan, died of pneumonia Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital.
He was 97 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Light Beam's Effect on Pilot Has Dissipated, U.S. Reports
LEAD: An Air Force pilot exposed to what the Pentagon believes was a Soviet laser last week did not suffer permanent eye damage, a Pentagon spokesman said today.

LEAD: Talks aimed at ending the 25-year-old civil war in Guatemala got off to a shaky start here today, nearly stalling after only a few hours.

LEAD: A Soviet Politburo member met with President Reagan today and conveyed what he called a ''very positive'' message from Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, about potential progress in American-Soviet relations.

OPEC Hints Policy Change

Brisk Sales For Mums Of Autumn
LEAD: SHOPPERS along Columbus Avenue have been briskly buying up oversize chrysanthemum plants at the Korean fruit and grocery markets in the neighborhood.
The sidewalks outside the markets are flooded with the intense colors of the plants, which are the size of small bushes.
The chrysanthemum, a symbol of autumn's arrival, comes in taxicab yellow and a range of Victorian mauves.


Tax Holiday Ending for Many Cruise Lines
LEAD: To the Editor:


Inventive Design for a Bath Showroom
LEAD: THERE are no neatly rolled-up towels, no shell-shaped soaps spilling out of silver dishes, no huge bouquets of flowers standing next to bubble-filled tubs and no perfectly appointed scenes of dream bathrooms surrounded by landscapes of shiny ceramic tile.

HBM Sells Office
LEAD: HBM/Creamer, a subsidiary of the WCRS Group of London, is selling its Providence, R.I., office to Potter Hazlehurst of East Greenwich, R.I., effective Nov. 1.
HBM/Creamer has a large Boston office and has been troubled by account conflicts with Providence.
The Rhode Island office ended last year with about $17 million in billings but has had some account losses since then.


Mitsubishi Ruling Is Upheld
LEAD: The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation said that a Court of Appeals in Washington had upheld a lower court ruling favorable to it in a suit brought in 1984 by the Tandon Corporation.
Tandon had appealed last year's ruling by a Federal District Court in Los Angeles, which found that Mitsubishi had not infringed on Tandon's double-sided disk drive technology.


Child Poverty
LEAD: To the Editor:


Craig Looks Good On Pena Blunder
LEAD: Not everything was the way it seemed in the second game of the National League playoff today.


Saatchi and Omnicom Plan Consolidations
LEAD: Both Britain's Saatchi &amp; Saatchi and America's Omnicom Group have announced a wee bit of consolidation.


San Francisco Journal; With Giants and Heat, Quakes Are Forgotten
LEAD: She stands like an urban seductress, San Francisco does, a stunningly beautiful city of steep hills on the bay, attracting newcomers like a Venus flytrap.
They come, they stay, even with the knowledge that the city sits atop a seismic time bomb that could explode into a fearsome earthquake at any time.


Smooth Transition Seen for Rockwell
LEAD: There were no surprises yesterday at the Rockwell International Corporation as the big military contractor announced plans for changes at the top.
Robert Anderson, who will be 67 years old next month, recommended to the board at a meeting in Atlanta that he step down as chairman and chief executive in February and be replaced by Donald R.


Political Marketing; Madison Avenue Comes Back to Politics
LEAD: Political advertising, which was lent new prestige and allure by President Reagan's campaign in 1984, is again drawing Madison Avenue image makers away from selling soft drinks and computers and into a Presidential race.


Film Festival; 'Yeelen,' Based on Myths From Mali
LEAD: IN ''Yeelen'' a writer and director from Mali, Souleymane Cisse, re-creates the pre-modern world of the Bambara culture, where the only hint of the industrial age is the presence of a blacksmith.


Topics of The Times; How Low Is 'Low Fat'?
LEAD: A Federal task force on cholesterol advises consumers who want to reduce the risk of heart disease to drink skim milk or milk with 1 percent milkfat.
But many who find those products unappetizing choose tastier ''2 percent'' milk, also labeled ''low fat.'' How much riskier can that be?


Philadelphia Electric In Dual Bond Offering
LEAD: The Philadelphia Electric Company is offering $200 million of bonds, equally divided between 10-year and 29-year maturities.
Both issues were sold competitively.


BankAmerica Confirms Investment by Japanese
LEAD: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it would sell $350 million of new securities to Japanese financial companies, an action that will strengthen the ailing bank.


RIGHT TO ATTORNEY IS CITED IN VERDICT
LEAD: The constitutional right to an attorney was the crucial point that resulted in the acquittal of a teen-ager who confessed to killing four members of his family, the defense attorney said today.


Frazier in Broadcast Job
LEAD: Walt Frazier, the former Knick guard who was inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame this year, will serve as analyst on selected Knick cable television and radio broadcasts over the Madison Square Garden network this season.
Frazier will discuss the Knicks' opponent and game strategy as the pregame studio guest of Greg Gumbel, the broadcast host, on telecasts.


TV Review; A Century Of Health Research
LEAD: ''THE HEALTH CENTURY'' finds medical research at work in different places -creating new parts for the human body, for example, or listening to the songs of male canaries.
The four-part series, which marks the centennial of the National Institutes of Health, celebrates 100 years of health care.


Contracts Awarded On Hypersonic Jet
LEAD: From the start, the idea has captured the imagination of aerospace scientists around the nation: an experimental craft, perhaps a successor to the space shuttle, that takes off like a plane and booms into space at hypersonic speed.


Daniels Fined $600
LEAD: Lloyd Daniels, the former Nevada-Las Vegas recruit and New York City high school basketball star, has been fined $600 in Las Vegas after pleading guilty to attempting to possess rock cocaine.
Prosecutors said he failed to abide by terms of a plea bargain under which charges would be dismissed if he completed a drug diversion program and did not use cocaine.


Corrections
LEAD: A Washington dispatch in Business Day on Tuesday, about opposition to the confirmation of C. William Verity as Commerce Secretary, misstated the position of Senator Robert Kasten.
The Wisconsin Republican has not participated in placing the nomination on ''hold,'' and he says he does not intend to participate in any strategy to delay a final vote.


An Honor for Journalists Killed Covering Wars
LEAD: Kara Ulizio, 11 years old, and her brother Ryan, 10, looking for their grandfather's name on a plaque that was unveiled last night during a ceremony at the Sheraton Centre Hotel.
Their grandfather, James J. McElroy, was killed covering the Battle of Iwo Jima in 1945.
The ceremony was attended by correspondents and photographers who covered World War II, Korea, Vietnam and other conflicts.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Elusive Adjournment
LEAD: All members of Congress would mark one date on the calendar if they could.
That is the elusive date for adjournment for the year.
At the start of each session, their leaders set a target date, which is rarely met.
This year it was early October, but all hope for that goal was abandoned long before the summer recess.

Concert: Music Today
LEAD: MUSIC TODAY, Gerard Schwarz's series that opened its seventh season Tuesday night at the Merkin Concert Hall, offers a valuable alternative to most other Manhattan new-music forums.
It is certainly no wild-eyed ''downtown'' presentation.
But it is also more deliberately conservative than the fiercer uptown contemporary-music groups.


Union Official Faces Contempt In Fraud Inquiry
LEAD: A longshoreman's union official was cited for contempt of court yesterday and ordered to appear for questioning into whether union funds are being illegally channeled to a former union leader, Anthony M. Scotto.


Cedric Phatudi Is Dead; Leader in South Africa
LEAD: Cedric Phatudi, who rejected South African Government attempts to make his tribal homeland of Lebowa an independent nation, died today.
He was 75 years old.


Guilty Pleas Entered by 11 In Smuggling of Marijuana
LEAD: Eleven members of one of the nation's largest marijuana smuggling rings have pleaded guilty to drug charges and more indictments are pending, a Federal prosecutor said Tuesday.


The Pleasures of Freelancing
LEAD: For a writer, freelancing can be a frustrating, uncertain and unprofitable effort, but, occasionally, it provides a windfall.
The odds are perhaps a little better for a freelance hunter.


Bork Weighs Withdrawing Name As Reagan Aides Say Cause Is Lost
LEAD: Administration strategists conceded today that Judge Robert H. Bork had no chance of winning confirmation to the Supreme Court, and, despite a plea from President Reagan to keep fighting, the judge told supporters he might ask for his nomination to be withdrawn before it reaches the Senate floor.


Haitians Suing U.S. Over Treatment in Detention
LEAD: A civil suit against the Federal Government in which 30 Haitian men contend that their breasts became enlarged because of their treatment in Federal detention has ended its third day.


Honda Raises Acura Prices
LEAD: The American Honda Motor Company said today that prices of its 1988 Legend models would increase by an average of 4.4 percent, or $1,016 a car.
The new Legend, which is sold by Honda's Acura division, ranges from $21,010 for the basic sedan to $29,127 for the LS coupe with automatic transmission.
The sedan carries the new engine that was introduced in last year's coupe.


HERS
LEAD: THERE are three kinds of women in the world: those who wear makeup, those who don't and those who try to look like they don't but do.


George Garvy Is Dead; Ex-U.S. Bank Official
LEAD: George Garvy, a former vice president and senior adviser of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, died Tuesday at his home in Manhasset, L.I., after a long illness.
He was 74 years old.


Swiss Vote Insider Curb
LEAD: Swiss legislators voted overwhelmingly today to outlaw insider trading, removing a longstanding source of tension with the United States.

REPH Debt Plan
LEAD: The REPH Acquisition Company, which bought the Republic Health Corporation in August, said it had approved a recapitalization plan that includes itself and Republic Health.
The principal purpose of the plan is to reduce the company's future cash debt service obligation through an exchange of its outstanding indebtedness for new debt and equity securities.


Two Roads Await Mexico's Next Chief
LEAD: The magic that moves Mexico has worked its wonders again.
A political system strained by six years of economic stagnation, high inflation and a dramatic drop in the standard of living of millions has nevertheless emerged successfully from a crucial test.
For the 10th straight time in more than half a century, political power is to be transmitted peacefully and on schedule.


Jersey City Indian Community Protests Rash of Racial Attacks
LEAD: Leaders of this city's Indian community disrupted a mayoral news conference today, demanding action to halt a rash of attacks on Indians here.


S.E.C. Files Brief Backing Pickens
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission has filed an amicus brief with the Court of Appeals in San Francisco supporting an investment group led by T. Boone Pickens Jr. in its battle for control of the Newmont Mining Corporation.
Newmont Mining had filed suit in Federal court in San Francisco seeking to block a tender offer by the group, Ivanhoe Partners, on the ground that the sale of $1.1 billion in ''junk bonds'' by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which would be used by Ivanhoe to purchase the


Bechtel, Utility Set Up Venture
LEAD: The Bechtel Power Corporation of San Francisco and the Consumers Power Company of Jackson, Mich., said today that they had agreed to establish a joint venture to own and operate the Palisades nuclear power plant in South Haven, Mich.

LEAD: As the parties of the second part, the dueling Bobs have taken an early lead in baseball's latest battle of nerves.
When Vince Coleman of the Cardinals reaches first base in the National League Championship Series between St.
Louis and San Francisco, Bob Brenly and Bob Melvin, the catchers for the


Computers Let a Thousand Publishers Bloom
LEAD: Toby Rowland-Jones, a former caterer and fund-raiser, decided that the Bay Area needed a calendar of charity fund-raising events.
So, about a year ago, he began to publish a magazine called Benefit using a computer in the basement of his home.


No Way to Treat the Homeless
LEAD: The New York City Board of Estimate's approval of the Koch administration's proposal to build 11 transitional residences for homeless families and individuals ranks as one of the largest boondoggles in the city's recent history.


The U.N. Today: Oct. 8, 1987
LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY


Airbus Gets Orders In Belgium, Korea
LEAD: Airbus Industrie, the four-nation European consortium, said it had won two orders to build a total of seven planes for airlines in Belgium and South Korea.
The Belgian state-owned airline Sabena said in Brussels that it had ordered five long-haul A340-300 aircraft from Airbus to be delivered in 1993 and 1994.


Celebrating 100 Years At Pratt
LEAD: A hundred years ago, Charles Pratt opened a school in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn to train students who were interested in design.
The first class, in drawing, had 12 students.

Arianespace In Big Order
LEAD: Europe's Arianespace group said today that it would order 50 of its big, new Ariane-4 rockets from suppliers to put heavy satellites into space in the 1990's, in competition with United States rocket companies.
The satellite launching consortium is in a jubilant mood after an Ariane carried a payload aloft last month, ending a 15-month pause in operations after a rocket failed.


Bergesch, Rose Kept
LEAD: Marge Schott, the Cincinnati Reds' owner, says she intends to retain Bill Bergesch, the general manager, and Pete Rose, manager, for 1988 but she expects better results.


Malaysian Trade Gains
LEAD: Malaysia's trade surplus has risen sharply this year, providing evidence that the economy is rebounding from its recession in 1985 and 1986, officials and economists said today.
The trade surplus rose 39 percent, to 5.8 billion ringgit, or about $2.32 billion, in the first six months of 1987, from 4.18 billion ringgit, or $1.67 billion, a year earlier.


7 Indicted in Texas Savings Fraud
LEAD: Seven Texas businessmen were indicted by a Federal grand jury here today on charges of participating in a scheme that gained more than $100 million from five savings and loan associations through the use of fraudulent real estate loans.


Boxer Has an Unusual Style
LEAD: Not long ago, Michael Olajide Jr. was anticipating the impact his entrance would have when he steps into the ring Saturday to fight Frank Tate for the vacated International Boxing Federation middleweight title.


Monkey Rampage Threatens Soviet Satellite
LEAD: A monkey aboard a Soviet research satellite is creating such havoc that the mission may have to be aborted, the Soviet news agency Tass said today.


Familiar Cast Aims to Erase Memory of Last Year's Finale
LEAD: Terry Simpson sat in a seat halfway up an empty Nassau Coliseum last month, his hooded eyes staring out over the unpopulated ice.
Five months had passed since his Islanders lost in seven games to the Philadelphia Flyers, ending an exciting playoff run with a disappointing 5-1 sleepwalk in the final game.


Devils Acquire McPhee
LEAD: The Devils acquired George McPhee from the Winnipeg Jets yesterday for a fourth-round draft pick in 1989.
The move came a week after McPhee, a 29-year-old forward, had been sent to the Jets by the Rangers.


Fields Decides to Rejoin Jets
LEAD: The striking Jets suffered another serious breach to their unity yesterday when Joe Fields, the senior offensive player known respectfully as the General, rejoined the team.


HERBERT A. STEINBERG
LEAD: Herbert A. Steinberg, a portrait painter and muralist, died of a heart attack Sunday in Exeter, N.H.
He was 59 years old and lived in Roosevelt, N.J.

LEAD: KITARO, the Japanese composer and synthesizer technician, who sold out Radio City Music Hall on Monday evening, is one of the biggest stars of the ''new age'' musical movement, that broad genre of mystically inclined mood music that embraces such disparate personalities as the pianist George Winston and the Swiss electro-acoustic harpist Andreas


Music: Ursula Mamlok
LEAD: ON Monday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, the New York Women Composers sponsored a program of works by one of its charter members, Ursula Mamlok.
Mrs.
Mamlok, who has since the mid 1970s taught composition at the Manhattan School of Music, is a kind of miniaturist composer, crafting delicate, artful pieces on a small scale.


Troubled Troy Music Hall to Reopen
LEAD: After a harrowing month that threatened not only its season but also its survival, the venerable Troy Music Hall is to reopen tomorrow night with a concert by the Albany Symphony.


Violin: Kavakos
LEAD: AN estimable young violinist, Leonidas Kavakos, was introduced by the 92d Street Y Tuesday evening in a recital with Anne Epperson, a pianist.
He began with the enormous Chaconne from Bach's D minor Partita, and identified himself at once as a player of clean, severe lines, concentrated energy and secure technique.

Awards Group Plans National Book Week
LEAD: The National Book Awards, a nonprofit literary and educational organization, has designated Nov. 8 to 14 National Book Week and plans readings and receptions in New York and Washington.
Winners of awards for the best fiction and nonfiction books of the year will each receive $10,000 at a dinner at the Pierre Hotel at 8 P.M.


HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: POLYURETHANE foam in pressure cans is a relatively recent product that home and apartment dwellers should know about.


Howard Beach Jurors Hear Divergent Views
LEAD: With graphic detail, the prosecutor in the Howard Beach murder trial said yesterday that three black men desperately sought to flee a gang of white youths who mercilessly chased one of the blacks to his death on a busy highway and savagely beat another victim.


Administration Softens Medicare Appeals Plan
LEAD: Under harsh criticism from members of Congress and advocates of the elderly, the Reagan Administration today backed away from its plan to substitute telephone hearings for face-to-face hearings in most disputes involving Medicare benefits.


The Student Loan Scandal
LEAD: Federal payments for defaulted student loans reached $1.3 billion last year.
That's more than the $1.13 billion the Department of Education allotted to Head Start.
In fact, it constitutes the third largest expenditure of Federal education funds.
It's also a national scandal.


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
American Standard Inc., a supplier of air-conditioning, heating and plumbing equipment, announced that Richard H. Francis had resigned as senior vice president and chief financial officer.
James C. Huntington Jr. will replace him.


'Into the Woods' Postponed
LEAD: The opening of the new Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical ''Into the Woods'' has been postponed.
No date has been set for the new opening.

Yield Rise Is Expected
LEAD: Yesterday's increase in the prime lending rates at a number of leading banks and thrift institutions, the second rise in just over a month and the fifth this year, sets the stage for another round of yield increases for certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts.


160 Die in Sri Lanka; India Vows to Curb Attacks
LEAD: More than 160 people were killed Tuesday night and today in a series of attacks by ethnic Tamil guerrillas in Sri Lanka, prompting India to warn that its forces would use ''all the force at our command'' to stop further violence there.


Imperial Oil in Deal
LEAD: Imperial Oil Ltd., the Canadian oil company that is 70 percent owned by the Exxon Corporation, agreed to pay $680 million (Canadian), or $523 million (United States), for the assets of Sulpetro Ltd., a natural gas company in receivership since June.
The Calgary, Alberta-based natural gas concern was hard hit by the slump in oil prices that followed its 1981 purchase of the Candel Oil and Gas Company.


Corrections
LEAD: The Economic Scene column in Business Day last Friday misstated the range at which advocates of gold, like Robert A. Mundell of Columbia University, believe that its price should stabilize.
The range is $400 to $500.


Hughes Institute Opens New Grant Program
LEAD: The Howard Hughes Medical Institute announced $45.5 million in awards yesterday under a new 10-year program that will eventually provide $500 million for education in the medical and biological sciences.


Russians Urging U.N. Be Given Greater Powers
LEAD: After many years of treating the United Nations primarily as a convenient forum for berating the capitalist West, Soviet officials have begun to advocate a powerful new role for the organization.


Data General Joins N.T.T. in Venture
LEAD: The Data General Corporation announced an usual alliance yesterday with the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, the Japanese communications giant, to jointly develop a digital switching technology for sale in the United States and Japan.


Zeffirelli Told to Halt Film by Lisbon Court
LEAD: A Portuguese court has ordered Franco Zeffirelli to stop filming scenes in Lisbon for his film ''The Young Toscanini'' because of charges of plagiarism, legal sources said today.


Baylor Uses Bat, Not Body
LEAD: When Don Baylor, that 38-year-old, ambulatory brick building, came to the plate with the game on the line in the bottom of the eighth inning tonight, it wasn't too much to expect that he might try to win it not so much with his bat as with his body.
It wouldn't have been the first time.
The score was 5-5 in this first game of the American League championship series, and the bases were loaded with one out when Baylor was called in by the Twins' manager, Tom Kelly, to do damage.


Official of Suitor Gets Top Guinness Peat Post
LEAD: Grant Adams, deputy chairman and co-founder of Equiticorp Holdings Ltd., was named chairman of Guinness Peat P.L.C. yesterday, succeeding Alastair Morton, who resigned Monday night.

Interest Rates Edge Upward
LEAD: Short- and long-term interest rates rose slightly yesterday as securities dealers were disappointed by weaker than expected demand for new seven-year Treasury notes.


Scientists Link an Activated Gene to Lung Cancer
LEAD: Scientists have found evidence that a gene long associated with cancer development in laboratory experiments is activated in lung cancer tissues and, in its active state, may be a factor in development of the malignant disease.


2-Year-Old Dies in Area Riven by Chilean Strike
LEAD: A 2-year-old child was shot and killed tonight in an area where a number of protests were occurring as part of a general strike called by a labor group against the regime of Gen.
Augusto Pinochet, the police reported.


Democrats Resolve Dispute With 2 States on Delegates
LEAD: The Democratic National Committee today resolved its fierce dispute with Minnesota and South Dakota over the scheduling of their nominating contests.

LEAD: If the old homestead doesn't look quite like a castle anymore, remodeling might be the answer, or perhaps it's time to look for a new place.
Either way, the Government has booklets that can help.


5 Citadel Cadets Indicted Over Racial Hazing
LEAD: A county grand jury has indicted five cadets at the Citadel military college on a misdemeanor charge of illegally wearing a mask in connection with the hazing of a black classmate last year, a prosecutor says.

Where Adults Play
LEAD: WHEN they're not eating power lunches, where do some business executives go from noon till 1?
To play at Burlington Antique Toys. ''We get a lot of C.E.O.'s of Fortune 500 companies that like to get away from the pressures,'' said Steve Balkin, who has owned the store for 10 years.


Stage: 'Holmes and Hands of Othello'
LEAD: HAVING matched wits with Moriarty and other Napoleons of crime, Sherlock Holmes now attacks racism in the performing arts.
At least that is one of the themes of Alexander Simmons's ''Sherlock Holmes and the Hands of Othello,'' a new melodrama at the Westbeth Theater Center.

LEAD: Energy futures advanced on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday after the Saudi Arabian Government denied reports that it planned to link its petroleum price to the spot market, said Peter Cardillo, an analyst in New York for Josephthal &amp; Company.


Saying No to Bork, Southern Democrats Echo Black Voters
LEAD: The opposition of Southern senators to Judge Robert H. Bork reflects a crucial political reality in the region: the electoral fortunes of many Southern Democrats depend on overwhelming support from blacks.


Booklet Describes 26 Trees
LEAD: The Long Island Lighting Company is offering a free booklet on planting trees and shrubs.
The guide describes 26 trees that will grow to heights of 30 to 80 feet and have a mature spread of 12 to 60 feet.


4 Palestinians and an Israeli Killed in a Shootout in Gaza
LEAD: Four Palestinian guerrillas and an Israeli security agent were killed in a shootout Tuesday night in the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip, an army spokesman said.


Unlock Their Cuffs
LEAD: To the Editor:


REAGAN ADAMANT IN VOWING TO PUSH MORE CONTRA AID
LEAD: President Reagan said today that he would fight for $270 million in renewed aid for the Nicaraguan rebels that would continue until a cease-fire is in place ''and full democracy is established.''


In Connecticut, Progress Yields To Dirt Roads
LEAD: At nightfall, when the sun slips behind the tall maples and hickories on Long Mountain, George Clahr can amble out to the dirt road in front of his 200-year-old farmhouse and hear nothing but crickets, tree frogs and the gurgling of a nearby stream.


Report In Manila Of New Coup Plot
LEAD: President Corazon C. Aquino ordered at least three radio stations closed today because she said they had broadcast right-wing propaganda; and hundreds of soldiers took up positions around the presidential palace as the Government warned of a new plot to topple it.


A Separate Workshop Might Control Clutter
LEAD: ''I WONDER how many people keep their car in their garage,'' said Oliver Cope, an architect with David Handlin &amp; Associates, Cambridge, Mass. ''The problem with the typical two-car garage is that half is used for the car and half for junk.''


Change at Negro Ensemble
LEAD: The board of directors of the Negro Ensemble Company has named Leon B. Denmark producing director of the 20-year-old theater group, the chairman, Lucius P. Gregg, announced this week.


Meet Me in St. Louis
LEAD: Let's meet by the Musial statue, at the corner of Broadway and Walnut, an hour and a half before the game.


Issue From Maine
LEAD: The Maine Municipal Bond Bank is offering $59 million of revenue bonds via underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities.
Yields on the double-A issue range from 5.50 percent for bonds due in 1988 to 7.30 percent in 1994, 7.60 percent in 1997, 8.10 percent in 2002 and 8.60 percent in 2007.


Control of Denver Schools Eased
LEAD: Denver's public schools have moved a step toward autonomy with a Federal judge's decision to reduce court control over the school district for the first time in an 18-year-old desegregation case.


Indian Rebels Out of Jungle In Nicaragua
LEAD: Armed and uniformed soliders are a common sight in this Caribbean town, but over the weekend it was difficult to tell whether the armed men were Sandinistas or rebels.


FINANCE BRIEFS
LEAD:  Debt


3 Giants Return, But Not for Long
LEAD: Lawrence Taylor, Leonard Marshall and Jeff Hostetler, three of the Giants' striking players, rejoined the team today, but not for long.
They changed their minds and left separately, and it seemed unlikely that any would return for at least another week.


Unesco Chief Falters in Balloting
LEAD: Although he outpolled the eight other candidates, Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow, whose tenure as director general of Unesco has divided the organization, failed to receive a majority when the 50-member executive board voted tonight on a new leader.


Stand Up for Decency in Tibet
LEAD: Don't be too supportive of the uprising in Tibet, the State Department insists, for it comes just as China has been easing a tradition of repression.
Reacting to Congressional condemnation of Beijing, the Reagan Administration points out that too much empathy for the Tibetans and too little for China's policy will undercut that moderation.

LEAD: Almost two months after Nathan Quinones announced his early retirement as Schools Chancellor, the search for his replacement formally began yesterday.
The Board of Education met for the first time with its advisory panel on the search.


Goode and Rizzo Claim Victory in Mayoral Debate
LEAD: Both sides claimed victory today after Mayor W. Wilson Goode and former Mayor Frank L. Rizzo called each other liars and worse in the only televised debate of the mayoral campaign.

LEAD: Troublemaker, a monkey aboard a Soviet research satellite, was reported to have freed an arm, allowing it to play with everything within reach.

Stocks End Mixed in Wild Day
LEAD: Stocks ended mixed yesterday in volatile trading as the market found itself trapped between buyers hunting for bargains and sellers fearful of higher interest rates.

LEAD: Eleven present and one former employee at the Kingsboro Psychiatric Center in Brooklyn were arrested yesterday on charges of sale and possession of cocaine and marijuana or the abuse of patients.


G.E. Profit Rises 16.4% In Quarter
LEAD: The General Electric Company, buoyed by strong gains in its financial services, aircraft engine and medical systems divisions, said yesterday that earnings in the third quarter rose 16.4 percent despite roughly flat sales.

Washington Talk: The Bork Hearings; For Biden: Epoch of Belief, Epoch of Incredulity
LEAD: To borrow a phrase from Dickens, it has been the best of times and the worst of times for Joe Biden.


Dance: Graham, With Stars
LEAD: THE idea of two fellows from Leningrad being able to portray quintessential American Yankees might stretch the imagination.
But that is what Mikhail Baryshnikov and Rudolf Nureyev actually pulled off Tuesday night through their first-ever joint performance in Martha Graham's ''Appalachian Spring.''


Oil Tanker Spills 15,000 Barrels West of Canada
LEAD: A supertanker caught in a storm in the Gulf of Alaska last weekend spilled about 15,000 barrels of Alaska crude oil into the sea 200 miles west of Canada's Queen Charlotte Islands, the United States Coast Guard said today.


Little Wagner Has Big Hopes in Football
LEAD: One of every six men at Wagner College plays football for the Staten Island school.
That is not a ratio typical of successful programs and not just at the large Division I schools with huge student bodies but also at the Divison III level where Wagner plays.


Alexander's Standstill Pact
LEAD: Acting to quell speculation that they would compete for control of Alexander's Inc., the New York retail chain, Donald J. Trump and Interstate Properties announced a standstill agreement yesterday under which they would act jointly on expanding or selling their interest totaling 43 percent in Alexander's.


City Opera: New Cast In Twin Bill
LEAD: An alternate cast is now taking its turn at presenting the New York City Opera's version of the shabby-shocker twin bill of Mascagni's ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and Leoncavallo's ''Pagliacci.'' The production itself was reviewed in these pages after its premiere this past summer, and perhaps the less said about it the better.


Cruise Line to Goodby; Seagram Wines to Grey
LEAD: There have been two account switches of national interest involving San Francisco agencies this week.
Goodby, Berlin &amp; Silverstein has boarded the Royal Viking Line, and Grey Advertising found its cup running over courtesy of the Seagram Classics Wine Company.


FRANK KLEINHOLZ
LEAD: Frank Kleinholz, a painter known for his realistic depictions of city life and city dwellers, died Saturday in Miami Beach.
He was 86 years old.


Talking Deals; Sale of Bowery: The Debate
LEAD: THE small group of investors that took over New York's Bowery Savings Bank have cause to celebrate.
Less than two years after spending $100 million to acquire the once-troubled Bowery, the owners will double their money by selling the savings institution to H.F.
Ahmanson &amp; Company of Los Angeles for $200 million.


Detective Is Arrested As Sexual Molester Of 2 Homeless Boys
LEAD: A police detective was arrested yesterday on charges that he sexually molested at least two 16-year-old homeless boys at his Brooklyn apartment, a police spokesman said.

Gross Says He Sees 'No Reason to Resign'
LEAD: Dr.
Elliot M. Gross said yesterday that he would not resign as the Chief Medical Examiner of New York City, despite a recommendation by a mayoral advisory committee that he be replaced.

LEAD: A report in the Advertising Column of Business Day on Monday incorrectly reported the new position of William S. David.
He has been named publisher of Sports Afield.

LEAD: Jimmy Springs, who was lead singer of the Red Caps for three decades, died Sunday.
He was 75 years old.


Topics of The Times; A Budget Gimmick Outlawed
LEAD: One of Congress's traditional tricks for making budget deficits look smaller has been to shift expenditures by 24 hours, so that they fall on the first day of a new fiscal year, Oct. 1, instead of the last day of the old one, Sept. 30.
A year ago, for example, the Sept. 30 distribution of revenue-sharing grants to states was put over to Oct.


Consumers Held Confident
LEAD: American consumers' confidence in the economy rose to the highest level in almost 15 years in September as people were cheered by the declining jobless rate, the Conference Board said yesterday.

Rock: Pink Floyd at the Garden
LEAD: LASERS flashed.
Spotlights swiveled.
U.F.O.-shaped light trusses swooped across the stage.
Surreal film clips lighted up a circular screen.
And, incidentally, Pink Floyd played new and old songs Monday at Madison Square Garden, opening a sold-out three-night stand; the show goes to the Brendan Byrne Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., Saturday through Monday.


Dodger Doctor Busy
LEAD: Dr.
Frank Jobe, the Los Angeles-based orthopedic surgeon who performs operations on most ailing Dodger baseball players, had a busy day Tuesday at Centinela Hospital Medical Center in Inglewood, Calif.
He removed cartilage from the right knee of Orel Hershiser, the pitcher; from the back of the left shoulder of Dave Anderson, the shortstop; from the front left shoulder of George Hinshaw, a minor-league outfield prospect, and examined Ken Howell, the pitcher, before performing a bone scan on his right shoulder today.

LEAD:  The Economy


The Vast Flexibility Of Designs in Metal
LEAD: MARIO VILLA, a Nicaraguan who is now based in New Orleans, is a 33-year-old architect who combines metals in the chairs, tables, lamps and cabinets he designs. ''Furniture From New Orleans,'' a display of his work, opens today at the Gallery of Applied Arts.

LEAD: The visit here this week by Deng Pufang, son of the Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping, is labeled ''unofficial,'' but his appointment calendar could not look more official.

LEAD: The crowds are pouring in, and John K. Howat, the Metropolitan Museum of Art curator who organized the exhibition of paintings that is attracting them, thinks he knows why.


JANE C. MURRAY
LEAD: Jane C. Murray, director of communications and development for the Alan Guttmacher Institute, died of cancer of the pancreas and liver Monday at her home in Manhattan.
She was 48 years old.


Mathura Journal; Is the Raja Ready for War, or Losing His Steam?
LEAD: It had all the trappings of a political rally, except that the organizers insisted their cause was nonpolitical.
In speech after speech, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi was attacked by some of his most prominent former allies as tens of thousands of listeners applauded.

LEAD: While the Knicks continued their feverish efforts to make changes for the coming season, Bernard King said he was keenly disappointed that the first of those changes appears to have brought his once-brilliant career with the team to an end.


CORPORATION CITES HIRING OF JACKSON
LEAD: A national chain of business schools said yesterday that it had hired a new spokesman, the Rev.
Jesse Jackson, who is also a candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination.


PANEL SAYS JUDGE SOUGHT A BRIBE
LEAD: A report by a special judicial panel released today says there is ''clear and convincing evidence'' that a Federal district judge in Miami conspired to solicit a $150,000 bribe and should be impeached by Congress.


Twins Jump in Front of Tigers; Giants Tie Series, 1-1; Giants 5 Cardinals 0
LEAD: Dave Dravecky continued to pitch zeros in postseason play today when he mastered the St.
Louis Cardinals on two singles and pitched the San Francisco Giants to a 5-0 victory that squared the National League playoff at one game apiece.


RISE IN CONSUMER DEBT IS LARGEST IN 10 MONTHS
LEAD: Americans took out $4.66 billion more in credit than they paid off in August, the biggest rise in consumer debt in 10 months, the Federal Reserve said today.


JOHN McCARTHY
LEAD: John McCarthy, a former senior vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, died yesterday in London, where he was undergoing treatment for cancer of the throat.
He was 55 years old and had been living in Porto Ercole, Italy, since his retirement a year ago.


Glasnost as Frankfurt Book Fair Opens
LEAD: It is common wisdom here that no one ''big book'' can dominate the mammoth Frankfurt Book Fair in the way that used to be possible before the age of instant communications.


Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. As a result of an accident a board in our living room floor is badly split and warped.
The floor is tongue-and-groove oak and I don't want to rip up all the boards between this one and the wall.
Can I replace this one board?
A.
Yes.
First split up the damaged board with a chisel so you can remove the pieces without damaging the boards on either side.

LEAD: Thirty-five more players - including some of the National Football League's top performers - broke ranks with striking teammates yesterday to rejoin their clubs in time to play this weekend's games.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  TENNIS  Lozano Upsets Mayotte: Jorge Lozano of Mexico upset second-seeded Tim Mayotte, 6-4, 6-3, yesterday in the second round of the $303,400 World Championship Tennis Scottsdale Open in Arizona.
Sixth-seeded Kevin Curren and seventh-seeded Eliot Teltscher both won. ''I just didn't play very well,'' said Mayotte, the 15th-ranked men's player in the world.

On the mound, they were facing a pitcher of perfection.
In the eighth inning, they were staring at a defeat.

LEAD: The Rev.
John Urban, who was kept alive for nearly 11 days by an artificial heart before receiving a human heart and kidney, died after multiple organ failure Tuesday at the Milton S. Hershey Medical Center of the Pennsylvania State University.
He was 51 years old.
Mr.
Urban was the third recipient of the Penn State artificial heart.

Toxic Materials Found in Truck in Lower Manhattan
LEAD: Some of 75 drums that were discovered yesterday in a truck parked on Chrystie Street.
The street was closed until 6 P.M. while the drums, which contained nitric acid, paint waste, adhesives, phosphoric acid and other chemicals, were removed.
The truck was stolen last month and recovered in Paterson, N.J., but its cargo was not inspected until yesterday.

Concert: The Royal Philharmonic
LEAD: LONDON has more major resident orchestras than New York, but they are organized differently from the New York Philharmonic - more like the American Symphony, which is made up of freelancers who gather together with considerable but not absolute consistency from concert to concert and go off to other jobs in between.

Bulgaria competed this year for the first time, and the Soviet Union remains almost the only absentee.

U.S. SAYS COPTERS, ANSWERING SHOTS, SANK 3 IRAN BOATS 1081&gt;
LEAD: American helicopter gunships sank three small Iranian patrol boats near the center of the Persian Gulf tonight after at least one Iranian vessel opened fire on a patrolling helicopter, the Pentagon said.
At least two Iranians were killed.
The American helicopters were not damaged, and there were no American casualties, the Pentagon said.

Pact for Fregosi
LEAD: Jim Fregosi has been rehired with a multiyear contract as manager of the Chicago White Sox.
Fregosi, 45 years old, who took over as manager June 22, 1986, after Tony LaRussa was dismissed, gave no other details of the agreement.
The White Sox went 45-51 under Fregosi for the rest of the 1986 season, then posted a 77-85 record in 1987, finishing fifth in the American League West.

Art: Serra Sculptures At Pace and Castelli
LEAD: RICHARD SERRA as a sculptor can be all delicacy, all nuance, all finesse.
Few things now on view in New York are as subtle as his ''Even Level'' at the Pace Gallery.
It is built with two identical beams of hot rolled steel.
They measure 72 inches by 8 by 4.
One of them sticks out from the wall at an angle of 90 degrees and a height of 6 feet, give or take a few inches.


A Tribute To a Pioneer Of Folk
LEAD: MOSES ASCH ran Folkways Records from an office cluttered with records, books and African masks and sculpture until shortly before his death in 1986.
He was the company's founder and president, produced and edited recordings for release, did the sound engineering, designed the record covers, and often filled orders and answered the telephone.

LEAD: The Carnegie Deli, the Seventh Avenue emporium whose very name evokes certain alimentary truths about New York City, has opened a branch on the edge of Washington's Beltway, in a northern Virginia suburb.


A Goose Is Guest on a School Outing
LEAD: Fourth graders feeding straw to Heckyl.
The goose, usually in residence at the Central Park Zoo, was on exhibit during ''A Day for Ducks'' at Inwood Hill Park.
The event, sponsored by the Parks Department, included workshops and demonstrations for the students. (NYT/Sara Krulwich)

POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
LEAD: Derek Bailey, Roulette, 228 West Broadway, at White Street (219-8242).
Free improvisation, not tied to any idiom but the connection of sound to sound, has one of its most articulate champions in Derek Bailey, an English guitarist who rarely performs here.
Mr.
Bailey makes his guitar generate noise rather than melody - clinks and scrapes, bongs and crackles, an occasional chord - but from those noises he builds music with its own moment-to-moment drama.


SOVIET CLUBS STEP ON OFFICIAL STAGE
LEAD: Representatives of several unofficial Moscow political clubs took a halting step onto the official stage tonight, appearing at a news conference sponsored by a Government press-feature syndicate in an odd, sanctioned show of political independence.

Oil Prices Turn Steady As Saudi Rumors Ebb
LEAD: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products steadied on world markets yesterday in quiet trading as the oil community contemplated this week's surprising rumors that Saudi Arabia was considering selling its crude oil at discount prices.

Dining Out Guide; New Downtown
LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times.
Stars are followed by the date of original publication.
Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.
ARQUA, 281 Church Street (334-1888) - **(April 24, 1987) Housed in a former industrial space, this minimalist TriBeCa restaurant has ocher-toned walls and Art Deco sconces and a balanced Italian menu.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 398 money market mutual funds increased $1.82 billion, to $245.56 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 104 institutional funds were up $520.5 million, to $64.81 billion.
Assets of the 201 general-purpose funds were up $1.03 billion, to $73.08 billion.


Raphael Drawings At Morgan Library
LEAD: ''Raphael and his Circle,'' an exhibition of more than 90 drawings by the Renaissance painter and his closest followers, opens today at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street.
The show runs through Jan. 3.

Market Place; The Setbacks In Retail Sector
LEAD: THE recent flurry of takeover proposals in the retail industry has proved of fleeting interest to investors.
The stocks of three target companies - Dayton Hudson, Zayre and Alexander's - rose on the takeover announcements but have lost value in the last few days.


Senate Votes to Close A New Soviet Embassy
LEAD: The Senate, upset at both the Soviet Union and the State Department, voted today to order the Russians to move out of their new Washington embassy and rebuild it in an area where it can't be used as a base for espionage.


More Names Are Quietly Studied For Nomination to Supreme Court
LEAD: There seemed to be no obvious front-runner today as Justice Department officials, outwardly vowing to fight on with Judge Robert H. Bork's apparently doomed nomination for the Supreme Court, sifted names of other possible nominees.


Hellenic Festival
LEAD: The Fourth Annual Hellenic Cultural Festival will be held from 6 to 11 tonight, and from noon to midnight tomorrow through Monday, at Public School 85 on 29th Street, between 23d Road and 24th Avenue, in Astoria, Queens.
There will be a traditional taverna, serving Greek foods, as well as a pastry booth and additional stands with regional specialties.


'Depressing' Painting Removed From House Committee Room
LEAD: Representative Ben Nighthorse Campbell watching as workers removed an 1868 painting by Gen.
Seth Eastman depicting the scalping of a white man by an Indian.
The Oklahoma Democrat, the only American Indian member of Congress, said the painting was offensive and depressing. (AP)


Tribal Chief Acquitted In Killing of a Panther
LEAD: The chairman of the Florida Seminole tribe was acquitted today of state charges of killing an endangered Florida panther.

LEAD: THERE once was a time when musicians, dancers and actors confined themselves mainly to theaters and concert halls, auditoriums and nightclubs.
But, in the age of outdoor happenings and offbeat ''performance spaces,'' performers have seemingly usurped every conceivable nontheatrical nook and cranny.


A Tale of Lions, Tigers and Garretts
LEAD: When Columbia plays Princeton here tomorrow, the three Garrett brothers will be Tigers rather than Lions only through circumstances beyond their control.


N.F.L. TV Ratings Drop
LEAD: The final television ratings for the National Football League games last Sunday - the first games using replacement players - showed declines of about 20 percent from the pre-strike games.


Suns Sign Top Pick
LEAD: The Phoenix Suns have signed Armon Gilliam, their top pick in the collegiate draft in June and the second player chosen over all.
Gilliam, a 6-foot-9-inch, 245-pound forward, is expected to contend immediately for a starting position with the Suns.
He led Nevada-Las Vegas to a 37-2 record last season, averaging 23.2 points and 9.3 rebounds a game.

LEAD: President Reagan today nominated James H. Burnley 4th as Secretary of Transportation, declaring his rise from North Carolina trial lawyer to a member of the Cabinet in six years ''a remarkable Washington success story.''


Michigan Star Honored
LEAD: Jim Abbott, the University of Michigan pitcher who was born without a right hand but was an outstanding hurler for the Wolverines and for Team USA last summer in the Pan American Games, received the Golden Spikes Award yesterday as the nation's outstanding amateur baseball player.
Abbott, a 20-year-old junior from Flint, Mich., who dreams of winning the College World Series with Michigan and of pitching in the 1988 Olympic Games, was honored by the United States Baseball Federation at the Downtown Athletic Club.

Labor Accord at G.M.

LEAD: The White House abandoned plans today to sell Saudi Arabia 1,600 Maverick antitank missiles, seeking to insure Congressional approval of the remaining $1 billion in a pending Saudi arms-sale package.

LEAD: A panel of Episcopal bishops has dismissed charges that Bishop John S. Spong Jr. of Newark violated church doctrine by expressing doubts about the divinity of Jesus and endorsing premarital sex and quasi-matrimonial rites for homosexuals.

LEAD: The Rothschild family has decided to sell a small piece of its bank in Geneva to private investors in a bid to attract talented bankers and expand the institution, Baron Edmond de Rothschild said.
The offering could be worth as much as $105 million, according to officials of the Banque Privee Edmond de Rothschild S.A.

Hewlett Offers Severance Plan
LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company, saying it no longer needs as many manufacturing employees, is offering a voluntary severance plan to up to 259 workers at plants in Colorado and New Jersey.
The Palo Alto, Calif., company said it expects about 200 people to accept the offer, which includes payment of 6 to 12 months' worth of salary and benefits, but could handle the departure of as many as 259 employees.

LEAD: The apparent failure of Judge Robert H. Bork's nomination to the Supreme Court has touched off a Republican hunt for scapegoats.
Within the Reagan Administration, two factions that have struggled for power for almost seven years - conservative purists and moderate pragmatists - have been blaming each other for days.

LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua invited the United States today to resume a dialogue with his Government after a Central American peace plan goes into effect.


GEORGE R. SWIFT Jr.
LEAD: George R. Swift Jr., a former sailboat racer for the Vanderbilts and the Morgans, died Wednesday at his home in Asheville, N.C., after a long illness.
He was 68 years old.
Mr.
Swift, a member of the New York Yacht Club for most of his adult life, was manager of Luders Marine Construction Co. in Stamford, Conn., from 1935 until 1952.


AIDS Virus Found in Second Lab Worker; Cut in Hand Cited
LEAD: A second laboratory worker has become infected with the AIDS virus, apparently through a cut in a hand, after handling highly concentrated solutions of the virus, officials at the National Institutes of Health said today.


Another Man Is Slain In a Mob-Style Killing
LEAD: A man with a police record and possible ties to organized crime was shot and killed on a Brooklyn street yesterday afternoon by two gunmen who fled in a car.
The police said the killing was similar to a series of gangland-style murders in Brooklyn in recent months.


Poland, Planning Many Changes, Calls a Referendum on Economy
LEAD: Gen.
Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, said today that the Government would hold a national referendum by the end of the year to seek popular backing for several governmental and economic changes that could lead to belt-tightening for many Poles.

John the Divine (112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue).
The performances are part of the Italy on Stage festival.

LEAD: France and Britain are increasingly concerned that a Soviet-American treaty eliminating medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles might lead West Germany to agree to the abolition of battlefield nuclear weapons under NATO command, according to senior officials in various capitals.

Film: 'Dogs In Space'
LEAD: A BETTER title for ''Dogs in Space'' might have been ''Sid and Nancy Meet the Secaucus Seven.'' This is a story about 60's survivors in 1978, drugged-out musicians who look and sound as if they're straight from the 80's.
The large cast of men and women live in a communal house in Melbourne, a 60's relic where garbage fills the fireplace and huge joints are passed around.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Golf  Mahaffey Leads on Birdies: John Mahaffey sank long birdie putts on his last two holes yesterday to cap a five-under-par 66 and take the first-round lead in the Pensacola Open.
The 16-year PGA Tour veteran had seven birdies and made putts of 30 and 20 feet on his last two holes to take a one-shot lead over Bobby Cole, Jeff Sluman, Phil Blackmar, Danny Edwards and Trevor Dodds on the 7,154-yard course at the Perdido Bay Resort.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration today liberalized the rules for illegal aliens seeking amnesty under the new immigration law and predicted that at least 100,000 aliens would benefit from the change.

A consummate impresario and choreographer, he is forever refining his international act known as Le Cirque.
Like any showman riding a long-run hit, the Italian-born owner brings changes to his production ever so carefully.

Film: 'Ami de Mon Amie'
LEAD: SPECIFIC places, at specific times of year, have always been key to the methods and the manners of Eric Rohmer's splendidly singular comedies.
In ''My Night at Maud's,'' the wintry, non-picturesque streets and chilly apartments of the city of Clermont-Ferrand had the effect of prompting characters to argue long into the night, as if to stay out of cold, lonely beds.

Walker in Role Vacated by King
LEAD: Although Kenny Walker has been on the Knicks' roster for almost a year, he remains a considerable unknown.
He was the team's first-round draft pick in 1986, a respected prospect from Kentucky who was known for his diligence and hard work.
But a succession of injuries to his back and hamstring limited him to sporadic appearances last season - 68 largely forgettable games - as he struggled to cope with playing with pain.

So You Want to Appeal a Traffic Court Decision
LEAD: To the Editor:


Film: '3 o'Clock High,' a Showdown
LEAD: ''THREE O'CLOCK HIGH,'' which opens today at Loews New York Twin and other theaters, is as well made as a film about a schoolyard showdown can be.
It's even better made than that, which is precisely the problem.
The director, Phil Joanou, has turned every shot into a portentous marvel, from the close-up view of an earring going into an ear to the 360-degree spin around the schoolyard as the nice-guy hero (Casey Siemaszko) awaits his dreaded confrontation with the mean-spirited bully (Richard Tyson).

Washington Utility Suits
LEAD: Washington's Supreme Court today ordered a trial on some aspects of bondholder suits against the Washington Public Power Supply System, its professional advisers and others involved in the system's $2.5 billion bond default on two defunct nuclear power plants.


New AIDS Policy Proposed
LEAD: Michigan health officials proposed today that the state collect names and addresses of the estimated 25,000 residents who have been exposed to the AIDS virus.
They also said they want doctors and other health workers to notify the sex partners and those who share needles with persons testing positive, because they also may be at risk.


48 Flamingos Killed By Zoo Coyote Pack
LEAD: A ravenous pack of coyotes attacked 86 flamingos at the Los Angeles Zoo after keepers left the birds' pen open Tuesday night, and by morning only 38 birds were still alive, officials said.

Memphis Mayor Wins
LEAD: Mayor Dick Hackett easily defeated five challengers today to win a second four-year term in office.
With 98 percent of the city's precincts reporting in the nonpartisan election, Mr.
Hackett had 96,021 votes, as against 36,626 for his closest challenger, City Councilwoman Minerva Johnican.
Ms.
Johnican, who is black, had made a campaign issue of a police shooting in which four white officers killed an emotionally disturbed black man.

LEAD: The stock market fell back sharply yesterday amid continuing worries over inflation, interest rates and the economic data due out next week.

Taylor Appears At Striker Practice
LEAD: Lawrence Taylor made his first appearance today at the daily informal workout held by the striking Giants, a development that was greeted with muted praise by his teammates.
Leonard Marshall, who had attended several such morning exercises, did not show up, a development that was met with stony silence by his teammates.


A BREAK FOR THE THIRD WORLD
LEAD: WASHINGTON - A significant crack has opened in the official stance on third world debt.
The major international lending agencies now admit that some very poor, very weak developing countries cannot service their debts and simultaneously resume economic growth.
The agencies are asking industrial country governments to forgive debts outright, and commercial banks to accept some inevitable losses.

Revenue in the quarter ended Sept. 30 totaled $298.6 million, up 7.4 percent from $277.9 million a year ago.

Middleweight Motion
LEAD: When Sugar Ray Leonard, then the World Boxing Council middleweight champion, announced his retirement from the ring in May, the the middleweight crowns of all three governing bodies of the sport were vacated.
Today, Michael Olajide and Frank Tate will fight for the International Boxing Federation's version of the middleweight title - the first of the three championships expected to be filled this month.


Clare Boothe Luce Dies at 84: Playwright, Politician, Envoy
LEAD: Clare Booth Luce, whose richly varied career encompassed the editorship of Vanity Fair magazine, the writing of hit Broadway plays and service in Congress and as Ambassador to Rome, died yesterday morning at her home in Washington.
Mrs.
Luce, who was 84 years old, had been gravely ill with cancer for some time.

Larry Phillips Is Dead at 50; Started Brooklyn Arts Center
LEAD: Larry Phillips, the founder and director of the Thelma Hill Performing Arts Center in Brooklyn, died last Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness.
He was 50 years old.
Mr.
Phillips had pneumonia when he died.
Born in Chicago, Mr.
Phillips received a bachelor's degree in early childhood education from the City College of New York and studied dance for 13 years with Thelma Hill, a noted New York modern dance teacher.


F.A.A. Fines Braniff $512,000
LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that it had imposed a civil penalty of $512,000 against Braniff Inc. for ''operational and maintenance deficiencies.'' The airline will review the findings before paying the fine and may appeal it.

The Tragic Number Is 35
LEAD: Columbia-Princeton would be just another Ivy League game, but for Columbia on Saturday, this is one last chance to avoid going into the National Collegiate Athletic Association's record book as the Division I college with the most consecutive losses.

WILLIAM B. BERGEN
LEAD: William B. Bergen, a retired aerospace executive, died yesterday at his home in St.
Michaels, Md., of cancer of the lung and esophagus.
He was 72 years old.


Rangers Sighing After A Tie
LEAD: Although the Rangers failed to resolve a 4-4 tie with the Pittsburgh Penguins in an overtime period, the coach and players agreed that getting through their home opener Thursday at Madison Square Garden without a loss was no insignificant feat.


New Rocket for Shuttle Passes Another Trial
LEAD: The third in a series of tests on a joint for the redesigned booster rocket for the space shuttle has been declared a success by officials of Morton Thiokol Inc., the maker of the rocket.


Germany Sets Tax on Gains
LEAD: The West German Government agreed today to introduce a 10 percent withholding tax on investment earnings to help finance a multibillion-dollar tax reform.


Mazda Export Plan
LEAD: The Mazda Motor Manufacturing Corporation said it might export cars from its Flat Rock, Mich., plant to Japan.
A spokesman said the Probe model, a car Mazda is to build for the Ford Motor Company, was being considered for distribution by Autorama, a Mazda subsidiary in Japan that specializes in Ford nameplates.


Koch Offers Inducement To Keep Museum in City
LEAD: Mayor Koch has offered to have the city pay 25 percent of the annual operating costs of the Museum of the American Indian if it moves from Washington Heights to the old United States Custom House at Bowling Green, instead of relocating to Washington.


Stanford Professor Seen In Lead for Sprinkel Job
LEAD: Michael J. Boskin, a Stanford University economist, has emerged as a leading contender to become the next chairman of President Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers, White House officials said today.

LEAD: The Defense Department, complaining that it will be able to launch even fewer military payloads from the space shuttle than it had expected, is planning a major expansion of its capacity to launch medium and heavy satellites with its own rocket fleets, officials said yesterday.

Bork's Decision Is Called Both Personal and Judicial
LEAD: After carefully considering withdrawal, Judge Robert H. Bork decided to push ahead with his nomination to the Supreme Court in the hope of counteracting what he considers politicalization of the confirmation process and of vindicating his reputation.


Former L.I. Policeman Pleads in Case Fixing
LEAD: A former Suffolk County police sergeant pleaded guilty today to charges that he tried to obtain a reduced sentence for the son of a former police official.

Regime in Cambodia Offers Top Post to Prince Sihanouk
LEAD: The Vietnamese-backed Government of Cambodia has offered a top political post to Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the head of an opposition coalition recognized by the United Nations, as part of a drive for national reconciliation.


SALOMON EXAMINING BOND UNIT
LEAD: Faced with exceptionally stiff competition from leading New York banks, Salomon Inc. is seriously considering closing its entire municipal bond operation, Wall Street executives said yesterday.


Busch Steps In at Quarterback
LEAD: Last summer, the Giants took three new quarterbacks to training camp.
Of the three, Dave Walter was waived after one week, Mike Busch was waived after two weeks and Jim Crocicchia made it until the final cut.

H.R.A. Urges Using Ships as Shelters
LEAD: The Koch administration announced yesterday that it was seeking proposals for ''floating shelters for homeless adults'' to be built on surplus troop ships, ocean liners, oil rigs or barges and moored at waterfront piers.


Japanese Prince Visits Harlem
LEAD: Surrounded by tinsel streamers and heavy security, the Crown Prince of Japan was honored in Harlem yesterday - a community he insisted on visiting so he could ''meet as many people from as many walks of life as possible.''


SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
LEAD: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week.
Answers appear on page 64.


Autopsies on 6 in Slain Family
LEAD: The bodies of six murder victims will be exhumed from a rural cemetery this weekend so that autopsies can be performed to confirm the cause of their deaths, J. E. Blinn, the Webster County Coroner, said today.





Irving Sets Defense and Rejects Bid
LEAD: The Irving Bank Corporation formally rejected the Bank of New York Company's takeover offer yesterday and, in a move to foil the bid, said it would issue options to its shareholders that would allow them to buy stock in the acquiring company at half the market price.


Alix Leslie Harper Weds Film Maker
LEAD: Alix Leslie Harper, a daughter of Mrs.
Maurice O'Reilly of Akron, Ohio, and Orange, Va., and Francis A. Harper of Santa Barbara, Calif., was married yesterday to Aleksander Rosenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Juda Rosenberg of Ellenville, N.Y., and North Miami Beach, Fla.
Richard A. Goldberg, an acting State Supreme Court justice, officiated at the New York Junior League building in Manhattan.


Edelman Begins Telex Offer
LEAD: Asher B. Edelman began a $65-a-share cash tender offer yesterday for the Telex Corporation, a telecommunications company based in Tulsa, Okla., that is already about 8 percent owned by a group led by the financier.


CARDS STRIKE LATE AND TAKE A 2-1 LEAD OVER GIANTS
LEAD: For a while tonight, it looked as if the St.
Louis Cardinals would have to settle for small consolations.
In the third game of the playoff for the National League pennant, they finally stole a base, and Jack Clark finally appeared as a pinch-hitter.

LEAD: ''It is, to say no more, unsatisfying to be a target of a campaign that by necessity must be one-sided, a campaign in which the 'candidate,' a sitting Federal judge, is prevented by plain standards of his profession from becoming an energetic participant.'' - Judge Robert H. Ione Gaul Walker, a Painter, Art Dealer and Patron, Dies
LEAD: Ione Gaul Walker, a painter, arts patron and former art dealer, died of cancer of the throat on Monday at her home in Provincetown, Mass.
She was 72 years old.


Good '88 Seen By Executives
LEAD: Executives of the nation's largest corporations predicted today that the economy would weather rising interest rates and higher inflation and be strong through the 1988 Presidential election.


Time to Think
LEAD: George Steinbrenner has apparently not made up his mind whether to bring back Lou Piniella as the Yankee manager next season, but he said yesterday he may arrive at a decision in the not-too-distant future.

LEAD: The first truce in the two-decade war between environmentalists and the beverage industry has begun in California, and many people on both sides say it may point the way nationally to a solution to the litter problem.
