S.I. Man Is Indicted in Slaying
LEAD: A Staten Island man, already facing charges in connection with the rape of a 15-year-old girl, was indicted yesterday for the kidnapping and murder of a 26-year-old Staten Island woman.


Bridge; World Team Championship Opens Tomorrow in Jamaica
LEAD: The opening ceremonies in the world team championships take place here Saturday, with play scheduled to start Sunday.
But not all those involved are accommodated at the Mallards Beach Hotel, where the games are played.


3 Killed, 8 Hurt As Blaze Guts Jersey Building
LEAD: At least three people were killed and eight people, including two firefighters and a police officer, were injured early yesterday when a fire gutted an apartment building in Hoboken, N.J.


Survivor of Airline Crash Released from Hospital
LEAD: Cecelia Cichan shortly before her release yesterday from the University of Michigan Medical Center in Ann Arbor.
Cecelia was the only survivor of the Northwest Airlines crash last August that killed her parents, her brother and 153 other people.
The 4-year-old was released from the hospital to the custody of relatives.

Buyer Is Sought For Executive Life
LEAD: The First Executive Corporation said it is seeking a buyer for its Executive Life Insurance Company of New York, which analysts estimate could bring between $600 million and $900 million.
In March, the unit was fined $250,000 by New York regulators, who disallowed $151.5 million in reinsurance contracts, under which insurers pass on some risks to other carriers.

College Football Notebook; Harvard a Surprise, Even to Its Coach
LEAD: The competition in the Ivy League this season is so keen that there still is no favorite. ''The closest race since I've been around the league,'' said Joe Restic, now in his 17th season as Harvard's coach.


Film: Scott Glenn in 'Man on Fire,' Thriller
LEAD: Agents and accountants around the world must be cackling mischievously and counting up their fees: here is a thriller set and shot in Italy, with a French director and American stars.
You might not expect much from this commercial contrivance, but the first line of ''Man on Fire'' is even sillier than you'd guess.


Avis Europe Bid
LEAD: Avis Europe P.L.C., a car rental agency, said it had made an offer for C. D. Bramall P.L.C. that values the northern England garage group at about $:94 million ($155 million).
Shareholders have pledged 57.6 percent of Bramall's stock to Avis so far.
Avis is offering five of its shares for every three in Bramall, valuing each Bramall ordinary share at 698 pence ($11.52).


START OF A LIFETIME FOR STRAKER
LEAD: The smile on his face said one thing: he was simply glad to be here.
His past had been littered with injuries and disappointment, but now the rookie was finally in the big leagues, his odyssey over.


Newmont Ruling Deferred by Court
LEAD: A Federal appeals court panel deferred judgment after hearing arguments about whether to block an investor group's hostile takeover bid for the Newmont Mining Corporation.
Newmont is appealing a ruling that rejected its claim that the group violated Federal disclosure requirements in its $72-a-share tender offer.

Withdrawal Agonies in Afghanistan
LEAD: Mikhail Gorbachev continues looking for a relatively painless way out of Afghanistan, just as Lyndon Johnson and Richard Nixon looked for a way to escape Vietnam.
He wants to leave without seeming to abandon a vulnerable client regime.
Thus Soviet diplomats talk about forming an interim regime including Afghanistan's former King, and with non-Communists holding half the cabinet posts.

Bullets Sign Bogues
LEAD: The Washington Bullets said yesterday that they have signed their first-round draft choice, Tyrone Bogues, the 5-foot-4-inch guard from Wake Forest and Dunbar High School in Baltimore.
The Bullets also came to terms with two veteran free agents, Michael Adams and Ennis Whately.
No terms were disclosed.

Founder of Weekly Reader Dies at 94
LEAD: Eleanor M. Johnson, founder of The Weekly Reader, which has brought the news of the world to schoolchildren for nearly six decades, died of cancer Thursday at a nursing home in Gaithersburg, Md.
She was 94 years old.


Steve Kuhn
LEAD: Steve Kuhn, a pianist, is leading a trio tonight and tomorrow at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037).
Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.


Ellen Reasoner Is Wed to a Chef
LEAD: Ellen Reasoner, a daughter of Harry Reasoner of Westport, Conn., and the late Kathleen Carroll Reasoner, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Larrabee, a son of Mary Louise Larrabee of Fairfield, Conn., and the late Rockwell John Larrabee 3d.
The Rev.
Thomas J. Driscoll performed the ceremony at St.
Luke's Roman Catholic Church in Westport.

CABBIE IS SLAIN BY 3 WITH BASEBALL BATS IN A DISPUTE ON S.I.
LEAD: Three men wielding baseball bats beat a driver for a car service to death yesterday in an apparent traffic dispute on Staten Island, the police said.


ARGENTINA DEVALUATION RENEWS INFLATION FIGHT
LEAD: President Raul Alfonsin's Government devalued the austral by 11.5 percent today as it prepared to begin a new drive in a two-year-old campaign against Argentina's relentless inflation.


Charge in Reagan Incident
LEAD: A Federal grand jury has indicted a pilot on charges of making false statements to Federal agents after flying a small plane near President Reagan's helicopter.
The pilot, Ralph William Myers, 32 years old, who at the time was an Army private absent without leave, is said to have told investigators that the Aug.


Music: Partch's Theatrical 'Revelation' in Philadelphia
LEAD: Harry Partch is a name known to those interested in American experimental music, and he made a few records that capture his sometimes bizarrely appealing, sometimes just bizarre musical vision.
But few can claim to have actually seen one of the major works of music theater that he produced in the last decades of his life (he died in 1974).


Wearever Officials End Buyout Offer
LEAD: Wearever-Proctorsilex Inc. said yesterday that a management group had withdrawn its offer to acquire the company after failing to reach an agreement.


Albany Tells of Sources for Blood In Plan to Measure AIDS Epidemic
LEAD: The State Health Department identified yesterday where it will collect blood samples for a large-scale test to measure the extent of the AIDS epidemic in New York.


RULING ON BOARD OF ESTIMATE PUTS FOCUS ON REVAMPING IT
LEAD: The latest Federal court ruling that the New York City Board of Estimate is unconstitutional - and the one-year deadline imposed for correcting the problem - have focused new attention on ways to revamp it, or the possibility that it should be abolished.


Flea Market Raises Funds For Students
LEAD: It is surely one of the best-kept secrets in town: a flea market that has been going on for 15 years.
Many people don't know about it because it's hidden away between two buildings of the Fashion Institute of Technology, on 27th Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.
It occurs maybe seven times a semester, with no fanfare except among students, staff and alumni of the institute.


Advanced Micro Has Big Loss
LEAD: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. reported a large loss today that it attributed partly to production problems and slow sales of memory chips.

Transactions
LEAD: BASEBALL


'Intolerable Position'
LEAD: On Dec. 24, 1986, when Pat Quinn signed an agreement to become president and general manager of the Vancouver Canucks, effective June 1 of this year, he was still under contract to coach the Los Angeles Kings until May 31, 1987.
John Ziegler, president of the National Hockey League, testified in British Columbia Supreme Court in Vancouver on Thursday that the conflict of interest created by the signing had placed his league ''in an intolerable position for this kind of business,'' and that ''Quinn had to be taken out as coach.

LEAD: The Transit Authority is confronting a question that seems more suited to a medieval theologian than an engineer or a bureaucrat: how many riders should fit in a New York City subway car?

U.S. Links an Iran Envoy to Terrorism
LEAD: The State Department said today it has evidence that the new Iranian Ambassador to West Germany was one of the student militants involved in the 1979 seizure of the American hostages at the United States Embassy in Teheran.


OPERA: A NEW 'RHEINGOLD' AT THE MET
LEAD: In this era of daringly trendy reinterpretations of the ''Ring,'' there ought to be room for a brilliantly untrendy one.
Despite a slow start, the Metropolitan Opera could be building just such a welcome oddity, judging by the premiere performance last evening of ''Das Rheingold.'' The promise that was never quite delivered last season by a somewhat confused ''Die Walkure'' was fulfilled in this stylistically coherent new production.


Weekend Holidays
LEAD: Columbus Day is Monday, and closings vary.
Following are holiday schedules.
NEW YORK  Parking: Because of Succoth, the Jewish Feast of Tabernacles, alternate-side parking is suspended today; it is also suspended on Monday, for Columbus Day.
Parade: Starts at 11:15 A.M. on Monday at Fifth Avenue and 44th Street, moving north to 86th Street, then east to Third Avenue.


HAIR DRYER SAFETY STANDARDS
LEAD: THE numbers have been in for some time.
From 1977 through 1986, 172 people in the United States were electrocuted after hair dryers that were turned off fell into bathtubs or sinks.
Most were small children.


Advanced Systems, Deltak to Merge
LEAD: The National Education Corporation, a fast-growing diversified company in vocational education, said it plans a stock merger valued at $300 million with a competitor, Advanced Systems Inc., of Arlington Heights, Ill.
Advanced Systems is known for its interactive videotaped instruction.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Oct. 2 about Pat Robertson's declaration of his candidacy for President incorrectly described a protest at the announcment in Brooklyn.
The protestors who carried signs saying ''Silence Equals Death'' were denouncing discrimination against homosexuals.


Large Offering Is Set by B.P
LEAD: The British Petroleum Company said that it would issue 458.6 million new shares to be sold later this month along with the British Government's 31.5 percent stake in the company.


Faulkner Manuscript Is Bought
LEAD: The University of Virginia's Alderman Library has bought 45 handwritten pages of William Faulkner's ''Mosquitoes,'' the author's second novel, which was previously thought to have been composed on a typewriter.


Air Force Study Finds No Unusual Health Problems Among Agent Orange Handlers
LEAD: Recent medical examinations for volunteers participating in a 20-year study have failed to uncover any unusual health problems among pilots or ground personnel who handled the defoliant Agent Orange in Vietnam, the Air Force says.

Bonds Continue to Fall; Traders Still Pessimistic
LEAD: Bond prices slumped further in active trading yesterday, pushing yields to their highest levels in nearly two years, as dealers remained deeply pessimistic about a wide range of economic issues.


Surimi, the Poseur For Costly Seafood
LEAD: In a run-of-the-mill diner in New Hampshire a traveler recently asked for a cup of brewed decaffeinated coffee.
And he got it.
On the same trip, the customer found that menu after menu in restaurant after restaurant requested that patrons ''refrain from smoking pipes and cigars.''


Guatemala Peace Parley Is Over
LEAD: Negotiations between the Guatemalan Government and rebels on ending a 25-year-old civil war broke up late today.
The participants issued a statement calling the talks satisfactory, but there were no indications of progress.


Energy Prices Higher; Orange Juice Up Limit
LEAD: Energy futures edged higher yesterday, with crude oil contracts finishing near the day's highs.
Heating oil futures and unleaded gasoline futures also rose slightly.

Asia's Nuclear Danger
LEAD: The spread of nuclear weapons capacity has been slower than most experts thought likely when the nuclear nonproliferation treaty was signed in 1968.
But it has spread, largely under a veil of secrecy because the treaty created a climate of international disapproval that states prefer not to flout openly.

LEAD: A day after he excoriated President Reagan in a fiery speech at the United Nations, Daniel Ortega Saavedra went to the South Bronx yesterday and made a firm resolution.

LEAD: The World Music Institute is presenting Ajoy Chakraborgi, a northern Indian classical vocalist, at the Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street (206-1050).

POLAND FOSTERS PRIVATE SECTOR
LEAD: On the edge of Cracow, in a suburb called Nowa Huta, stands the immense Lenin Steel Works that 38 years ago represented a radical experiment in industrialization.
In its peak year of 1979, 40,000 workers turned out 6.7 million tons of crude steel.
Today, its workers number only 32,000 and its output is about 5.5 million tons.


Tulane Appoints Panel
LEAD: A 16-member committee has been appointed by Eamonn Kelly, the president of Tulane University, to determine whether the university, which dropped its basketball program in April 1985 amid a scandal over gambling and violations of other rules, should resume the sport.
Kelly said he hoped the committee's report would be ready by January and that its recommendation would then be forwarded to the university's senate and board of administrators.


Amid Autumn's Glory, Power Woes Persist
LEAD: The fall foliage is deceptively beautiful here this weekend.
Beneath a canopy of crimson and gold maple leaves is a carpet of fallen trees, broken limbs and downed power lines, the legacy of the sudden, devastating snow storm that struck last Sunday.

Rowan and Mr.
Martin $4.6 million, the decision was later overturned by the judge, Kenneth J.

LEAD: The Cooper Companies, formerly known as Coopervision Inc., said today it had signed a letter of intent to sell its contact lens solution business to the Ciba Vision Group, a subsidiary of Ciba-Geigy Ltd., for about $155 million.
Sale of the unit, which is expected to be completed by Nov. 30, does not include Coopervision's worldwide contact lens business.

LEAD: A powerful explosive placed in a Volkswagen went off near a mosque in Kabul, the Afghan capital, killing 27 people and wounding 35, Radio Kabul reported today.

Borland said the division, which will be managed by Ron Posner, vice president, sales, will cooperate closely with Apple on distributed data base and office-systems products using Apple's data communications technology.

Ford's Steel Unit To Upgrade Plant
LEAD: The Rouge Steel Company, a subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company, said it would spend more than $100 million to upgrade plant operations.
The improvements will begin immediately and continue through 1988, the company said.
Most of the money will go toward improving facilities and processes in the steelmaking operations, but about $7 million will be spent to convert coal-fired boilers to natural gas.

LEAD: A worldwide watch has been posted for a convicted spy for the Soviet Union who was given so much privacy during a conjugal visit that he walked away.

Film Festival; 'Fire From Mountain,' on Nicaragua
LEAD: As long as ''Fire From the Mountain'' stays close to Omar Cabezas's notable book, subtitled ''The Making of a Sandinista,'' the documentary makes a forceful case in behalf of the Nicaraguan revolution.
Firing off news clips that document Mr.
Cabezas's vigorous prose, the movie, which plays at 6 o'clock tonight at the New York Film Festival, contrasts the poverty of Nicaragua's campesinos with the gaudy display of the Somoza set that ruled the country for decades.

LEAD: After listening to arguments yesterday in Federal District Court in Newark, Judge Dickinson R. Debevoise set Nov. 23 as the date for a hearng on whether the National Basketball Association's college draft, the right of first refusal on free agency and the salary cap violate antitrust laws.

Norman H. Johnson remembers ''a small childlike voice'' on the telephone asking whether the veterinarian could visit a sick cat in an apartment on Sutton Place.
Dr.

India Policy Shift: Tamil Conflict Poses New Risks
LEAD: This week's sharp new violence in Sri Lanka has forced India to shift its position dramatically in the island's long ethnic conflict and side militarily with the Colombo Government.
After years of sympathizing with ethnic Tamil rebels, India now appears ready to train its own guns on them.

Warhols Rising
LEAD: Two paintings by Andy Warhol were sold Wednesday at Sotheby's in an auction of contemporary art, for prices far in excess of expectations. ''Flowers: Four Panels,'' estimated before the sale to bring up to $70,000, was sold for $220,000, and ''Portrait of Liz,'' which had a pre-sale estimate of up to $55,000, was sold for $176,000.


My Weekly Reader Loses Its Founder
LEAD: Eleanor M. Johnson, founder of My Weekly Reader, which was first published on Sept. 21, 1928, died Thursday in Gaithersburg, Md.
She was 94 years old.


Best Advice for the Russian Traveler: Stay Home
LEAD: Aeroflot flight 3868 was ready for takeoff from Irkutsk, eastern Siberia's largest city.


BELMONT PAIR HARD TO BEAT
LEAD: Who is the bigger cinch at Belmont Park today, Java Gold in the $1 million Jockey Club Gold Cup or Groovy in the $200,000 Vosburgh?


A London Designer Leaves Poverty Behind
LEAD: In conversation, Bruce Oldfield sometimes uses the royal ''we.'' This is not surprising from a fashion designer whose customer list is topped by the Princess of Wales.
But it is somewhat unexpected from a man who was born, as a book he helped write puts it, ''poor, black and illegitimate.''


Florida Stiffens Gun Law
LEAD: Gov.
Bob Martinez signed a new law into effect today making it illegal to carry guns openly in Florida.
The law closes a loophole in legislation liberalizing the ownership of guns, which went into effect Oct. 1.
That law allowed citizens to apply for a $125 state license to to carry concealed weapons.

FICTION
LEAD:  ALL MY TRIALS.
By John William Corrington. (University of Arkansas, Cloth, $22.95; Paper, $10.95.) ''Shreveport is not a contemporary city to me; it is a . . . transparency through which I can see to an overarching past,'' confesses the narrator of this brace of skillfully constructed novellas.
He is Albert Sidney Johnston Finch, a recent widower and a retired Louisiana judge whose nostalgic vision of his hometown makes clear the route that John William Corrington (the author of ''Shad Sentell'' and other novels) has chosen to follow here.


Police Identify Livery Driver Who Was Beaten to Death
LEAD: The police yesterday identified the driver of a car service who was beaten to death with baseball bats on Staten Island Friday night.


Liszt, Liszt, O Liszt! From the Grave
LEAD: SOME YEARS AGO, YOU MAY OR may not remember, hard-nosed skeptics throughout the musical world diverted themselves immensely by making fun of a British medium named Rosemary Brown.
An amateur pianist, she had entered into communication with Mozart, Liszt, Beethoven and others of like fame, all of whom transmitted posthumous works and sometimes friendly messages through her.

Kanas, ''our employment has grown from about 200 to about 450.
We're adding almost geometrically to support the growth we've had.

LEAD: For at least one of the teams playing along the northern end of the New Jersey Turnpike, the football strike ended last week.
Not for the Jets or the Giants, but certainly for the Minutemen of Elizabeth High School, who play in the shadow of the oil refineries near Exit 13.

MASSACHUSETTS 'MIRACLE' WORKER: Ira Jackson; The Tax Man Goeth - But His Policies Live On
LEAD: PATRONS at Sullivan's Tap, in the shadow of the Boston Garden, were settling down on a June day last year to watch their beloved Celtics on television when agents from the Massachusetts State Revenue Department burst in, snapped off the T.V. and, before anyone could say ''Red Auerbach,'' shut Sullivan's for tax evasion.

Cohn Cleared of Conspiracy in Divorce Case
LEAD: A judge has ruled that the late Roy M. Cohn did not participate in a conspiracy against a client - the wife of one of New York City's major property owners - in a divorce action in 1984.

Thatcher Plans Reshaping of Britain
LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher used the annual Conservative Party conference here to outline her grand design for reshaping the landscape of British politics during her third term.


The Myth Becomes Man
LEAD: LAST November, when he knocked out Trevor Berbick in two rounds, Mike Tyson, at age 20, became the youngest heavyweight champion in boxing history - and, at the time, a most feared one.

THE MOSCOW BOOK FAIR: GLASNOST HAS ITS LIMITS
LEAD: DURING the Moscow International Book Fair last month more than 150 writers and publishers - Russians and Americans - attended an unusual reception in a Moscow restaurant held by the Association of American Publishers and its International Freedom to Publish Committee.
The mix was extraordinary; prominent Soviet publishing officials and establishment writers mingled with members of the dissident Soviet intelligentsia, including a number of writers who, only a few months before, had been in


Head of AIDS Commission Pledges Quick Reorganization of Panel
LEAD: The new chairman of the President's commission on AIDS pledged today to get the panel reorganized and indicated that he would be filling a key staff post early next week.


The Job Outlook Across the Nation; FAR WEST
LEAD: THE Silicon Valley has cooled off as California's occupational hot spot.
Today, Los Angeles leads the nation in creating new jobs, and the fastest-growing job category in the state is for secretaries.
New job opportunities will remain abundant in the nation's most populous state, which added 350,000 jobs last year, according to a report by M/PF Research Inc., of Dallas.


CELEBRATING THE CONSTITUTION
LEAD: I am puzzled that the case of the St.
Louis high school newspaper was ever granted an appeal (''From Hazelwood to the High Court,'' by Mark A. Uhlig).
Calling a public-school publication a ''public forum'' is sheer varnish.
Do pupils buy the newspaper or is it subsidized by the board of education?


FOR YIDDISH, A NEW BUT SMALLER DOMAIN
LEAD: ON a recent afternoon in a Riverside Park playground, a slender, dark-haired man was introducing his 2-year-old boy to hopscotch.
The scene was classic American father and son, except that they were speaking Yiddish.


OTTAWA DEBATES U.S.-CANADIAN TIES
LEAD: Hardly a day has gone by lately without a bitter clash over Canadian-American relations in the House of Commons, a paneled chamber where scurrying messengers in black breeches are one of many reminders of Canada's British past.


Why the Intense Interest in the Moscow Ballet?
LEAD: A LITTLE-KNOWN BALLET TOUR-ing company from the Soviet Union directed by a well-known Bolshoi star has elicited an unusual amount of interest from within the American dance public.
After the Moscow Ballet, led by Vyacheslav Gordeyev, recently opened its current two-month American tour in Baltimore, a cascade of inquiries and comments, from New York to Anchorage, flowed back in response.

Ousted Teacher With AIDS Fights in Court to Get Job Back
LEAD: A teacher has brought a legal challenge to being removed from his classroom because he has AIDS.

LEAD: When are men like Simmons going to grow up?
I read ''A Sense of Drama'' and could feel my stomach turn with disgust at yet another example of today's ''I-gotta-be-me'' mentality.

LEAD: SOUPS for early fall that take advantage of the continuing harvest of vegetables and herbs should also be hearty and well-flavored.
The three suggested here comply with these requirements.

LEAD: 'We won the Super Bowl because we were all together.
The tighter we stay as a team, the better chance we have to dig ourself out of this hole.' - Jim Burt, New York Giants nose tackle, after discouraging teammates from crossing picket lines.


Basques in Spain Tense After French Ouster
LEAD: Policemen and demonstrators clashed across northern Spain this week as supporters of E.T.A., the radical Basque separatist organization, took to the streets to protest a crackdown on members of the group across the border in France.


The Job Outlook Across the Nation; NEW ENGLAND
LEAD: THE GOOD NEWS for workers in New England is that salaries and wages are rising rapidly; the bad news, for their employers, is that there are generally not enough able bodies to fill job openings.


Be Practical With World Cup
LEAD:  To the Sports Editor:


CORRECTION
LEAD: An article last week about a novelist and his role in the Sag Harbor Initiative misidentified him.
He is William Demby.


Bus Strike Over, Union Says
LEAD: Union officials announced an agreement early today on a new contract for Boston school bus drivers and said the buses would begin rolling Tuesday morning, ending a monthlong strike.
William J. Foley, New England district director of the United Steelworkers Union, which represents the drivers, declined to disclose the details of the agreement, but said it was signed immediately by the union and representatives of private school bus operators that serve the public schools.


ETHICS CODE FOR OFFICIALS STIRS DEBATE ON THE BOARD
LEAD: A PROPOSED new ethics code for county officials - including disclosure of financial affairs - has become the focus of an election-year political struggle on the County Board of Legislators.


Eastern Nuclear Dump
LEAD: The Department of Energy will resume its search for a dump in the East for high-level radioactive waste, but not aggressively, a spokesman has said.
The agency will review 60,000 public comments it received in response to a draft report on the search, a process that could take two years, the spokesman said earlier this month.

LEAD: PARTIES WITH A PURPOSE  Dinners Around Town


REMODELING - WITH A HAPPY ENDING
LEAD: ''YOU don't know what you're in for,'' a friend who had recently renovated her kitchen said.
We had just told her that we were contemplating some renovations of our own. ''The contractors are very independent,'' she went on. ''They have so much work these days that after they get started with you they disappear to go on another job and don't show up again for ages.


Free Tickets
LEAD: The hottest tickets in town have cooled off considerably since the players strike led National Football League clubs to assemble replacement teams of dubious quality.
In Denver, where Bronco games have been sellouts since 1971, the club's community relations director, Charlie Lee, came up with a way to avoid acres of empty seats at Mile High Stadium when the Broncos take on the Los Angeles Raiders tomorrow night.


Question Of the Week; How Should The Series Use the D.H.?
LEAD: It shouldn't!
Last week's great pitching duel between the Blue Jays' Flanagan and the Tigers' Morris was a typical game that magnifies why the d.h. is wrong.
Just imagine the intricacies that were lost in that big game alone.

LEAD: IT took a lot of foreigners to get British art started: Germans, Lowlanders, Italians, Frenchmen and strays from as far afield as Rostock and Prague.
Most came as mercenaries and many stayed to become citizens.

LEAD: In order to keep peace and satisfy the traditionalists, why not allow the teams participating in the Series to use their own judgment?
In other words, the respective managers will have the option of using the d.h., or playing a good- hitting pitcher.
National League fans and owners always argue ''there is no strategy, with the d.h.

LEAD: Frank Tate, a gold medalist at the 1984 Olympics, knocked down Michael Olajide twice today on his way to a unanimous 15-round decision and the vacated International Boxing Federation middleweight title at the Indoor Sports Pavilion at Caesars Palace.

LEAD: From the top of the huge concrete bins of the Albert City Elevator Company in northwest Iowa, combines can be seen this in the fields as the harvest of the most expensive corn crop in the history of Federal farm programs gets under way here and around the country.

LEAD: Benefits for nurses at the Veterans Administration Medical Center here include the usual: medical insurance, paid vacation, sick leave and a pension plan.
But in an effort to alleviate a nursing shortage and retain staff, the hospital has added a new benefit: a free college education.

LEAD: LAST winter, a company that makes a machine for quickly measuring how much cholesterol people have in their blood offered tests for $3 in downtown Indianapolis and at four suburban shopping centers.

OUT OF A DARKNESS
LEAD: EVERYONE WHO HITS BOTTOM seems able to pinpoint the moment it happened.
Mine occurred during an agitated depression a year and a half ago.
I woke up one night obsessively aware of the gun that lay in a box under my bed and of my desire to place that gun in my mouth and pull the trigger.

OF BURGLARS, VANDALS AND THINGS THAT GO BUMP IN THE NIGHT
LEAD: ONE hot summer night not long ago there was at the window near my pillow a sudden racket.
I leaped from the bed and grabbed a petrified stick I keep behind the door. ''Who is it?
What do you want?
Get out of here!'' I shouted.
My wife awakened, startled.
There was no answer from the outside, just the same strange noise.


AN ESCALATING WAR OF WORDS OVER NICARAGUA
LEAD: IN his three-day visit to New York last week, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua evinced the air of a man watching events play out to his satisfaction.


SITE RULED OUT FOR WAR MEMORIal
LEAD: NEXT year, when this Camden County township dedicates its memorial to the veterans and dead of four wars, it will be on a site other than the one originally proposed - a traffic island - because, according to veterans here, no one wants to dodge traffic to get to the memorial.


Panda-Watching In a Chinese Zoo
LEAD: Ideally, the bashful, solitary giant pandas should be seen on their own turf, in the remote bamboo forests of central China.
But even scientists have difficulty finding the reclusive and increasingly rare animals.


Killing Covered By Insurance
LEAD: AFTER fatally shooting her husband in 1984, Constance Y. Moorehead of Linthicum, Md., was accused of manslaughter, but the charges were dropped.
Investigation showed that he had beaten her often and that she had acted in self defense.


Clothing and Crafts in Cairo
LEAD: Cairo's exotic Khan el Khalili bazaar is an obligatory stop for visitors, but not necessarily the best place to spend money.
Crowded, cluttered and chaotic, it is a bit like the old New York store S. Klein-on-the-Square, a place where customers must pick through mounds of junk before finding something worth taking home.

ONSTAGE IN THE GLOBAL VILLAGE
LEAD: TWENTY YEARS AFTER MARSHALL McLuhan's heyday, and a decade after he might have seemed passe, what he said seems to have come incontrovertibly true.
We really do live now in a ''global village'' where nearly everyone - or at least the more sensitive among us, meaning our artists - is affected by everyone else.

POSTINGS: $350 Million Ski Project; Big Vanilla
LEAD: Since last December, when a development team from New Jersey and New York bought a foundering Catskills ski area, called Davos, $7 million has gone into improved trails, as well as a new lodge, chairlifts and a snow-making system.
Now 121 town houses - the first of 2,000 units that are planned - are rising at the resort, which will cover 1,000 acres on Davos Road near Route 17 in Fallsburg, N.Y., 85 miles northwest of


U.S. APPEALS COURT GETS RARE SPY CASE
LEAD: That Samuel Loring Morison was not a classic spy of the John LeCarre mode has never really been in dispute.
But two years ago Mr.
Morison, a former civilian naval analyst, was convicted under national espionage laws of disclosing classified documents to the press.


Opera: New 'Rheingold' At the Metropolitan
LEAD: IN this era of daringly trendy reinterpretations of the ''Ring,'' there ought to be room for a brilliantly untrendy one.
Despite a slow start, the Metropolitan Opera could be building just such a welcome oddity, judging by the premiere performance Friday evening of ''Das Rheingold.'' The promise that was never quite delivered last season by a somewhat confused ''Die Walkure'' was fulfilled in this stylistically coherent new production.


U.N. GROUP TO HONOR 110 CONNECTICUT WOMEN
LEAD: THE United Nations Association is hoping that a program in Connecticut that will honor 110 women this week for their work in peace and equality will be copied around the country.


TALKING: Street Trees; A Request May Bring One Free
LEAD: FEW amenities add more charm to the setting of a home than a well-tended street tree or two lining the curb.
On a densely built city block with only tiny front yards, a street tree can also provide welcome privacy from neighboring houses and a shield from the hot summer sun.


Zoo Condor Dies in 60's
LEAD: The oldest resident of the Milwaukee County Zoo, an Andean condor believed to be 66 years old, has died.
Zoo officials said Friday that an examination showed the bird, a male named Connie, died Wednesday of heart artery collapse related to old age.
In 1922 Milwaukee's city engineer, George F. Staal, brought Connie and another young condor here from Argentina in 1922 and gave them to the zoo.

LEAD: To stand at the foot of South Boulevard in Houston is to look down what is perhaps the most magnificent residential street in America.

LEAD: McBurney, playing its first home game ever and celebrating its first homecoming, rallied to gain a 14-14 tie with Wheatley yesterday.


Marshall Mason Explores A New Stage
LEAD: IT IS MORE LIKE A LONG-RUNNING marriage than many marriages. ''I'll start a sentence and Lanford will finish it,'' says Marshall Mason. ''With the two of us in rehearsal, you have two heads.
The problem is, of course, having two mouths.
Keeping him quiet while I'm trying to give notes to the actors is quite a job.


Students Take to Ramparts at Bastion of Decorum
LEAD: A notoriously docile generation of college students has found something to protest at a tiny school in Maine: rules barring dormitory visits by the opposite sex.


Third Death in Chile Strike
LEAD: A third person has died after being shot this week during a 24-hour strike called by opponents of the military Government of President Augusto Pinochet, the victim's family said on Friday.
The victim, Carlos Valdebenito, 19 years old, was shot in the head in clashes on Wednesday.


EARLY LINE: THE '88 FIELD IN NEW YORK
LEAD: With Governor Cuomo dismissing talk of supporting slates of favorite son or uncommitted delegates that could be transformed into Cuomo delegates, New York Democrats are now confronted with making choices among the six current Democratic Presidential candidates.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article July 26 on Bay Ridge incorrectly described its two Lutheran schools.
The Lutheran Elementary School of Bay Ridge and Leif Ericson Day School both cover nursery through eighth grade.
The article also omitted one private school, Adelphi Academy.


CHICKEN FAT AND ALL
LEAD: I REMEMBER it was 2 A.M.
I had just come home from a date and was very thirsty.
Everyone was sleeping.
I opened the refrigerator and saw this glass of orange juice.
I gulped two fast swallows and realized this was not orange juice, but unsettled chicken fat my mother had placed in the ''icebox'' after cooking chicken.


CELEBRATING THE CONSTITUTION
LEAD: In your special issue, you neglected to discuss the relationship between the United States Constitution and the American Indian.
Indeed, you failed even to mention this problematic aspect of United States history.
Your oversight was irresponsible and inexcusable.
MARK S. WEINER  Stanford, Calif.


TV Books' Debut Opens Media Battle
LEAD: SCRIPTWRITERS could have a field day with this plot: Two media giants come together to discuss a joint project.
The talks fall apart.
Each agrees to go its separate way, but then one company hires a key employee away from the other.
The battle is on.
Both organizations race to get their product out first, and within a week of each other the products are unveiled.


Tigers Got More Than Their Money's Worth From Evans
LEAD: LAST winter the Detroit Tigers ignored the 29 home runs and 85 runs batted in Darrell Evans produced, looked at his salary instead and decided they were in no hurry to tender him a contract for this year.
Evans thus became a free agent, but no one but the Tigers expressed interest in his services.


Another Uptick In Interest Rates
LEAD: Up, up and away went the prime rate, as banks raised the key barometer to 9 percent, from 8 3/4.
The increase was the fifth so far this year, and, although it was expected, it still sent a chill down the spines of the people who had been thinking about borrowing money.
Short-term interest rates have been on the rise - indeed, yields in the bond market have been at or near two-year highs - and the prime has followed suit.


A LA CARTE
LEAD: SOME of the best food on Long Island is found not in restaurants or even your grandmother's kitchen, but at a private club.
Traditionally, clubs have been known for their lackluster food.
Most members join for the golfing, boating and tennis.
Dining is a distinct afterthought required of members.


Oregon Surprises Southern Cal, 34-27
LEAD: Bill Musgrave, the redshirt freshman who entered the game as the No. 2 passer in the nation, threw for three touchdowns to help Oregon stun Southern Cal, 34-27, and move into a first-place tie in the Pacific-10 Conference today.


Reagan Sends Letters on Gulf to Congress Leaders
LEAD: President Reagan sent letters to Congressional leaders today advising them that American military forces in the Persian Gulf took ''limited defensive action'' last week when they fired on Iranian gunboats.


CLOSING THE DOOR ON HEAT LOSSES
LEAD: ALTHOUGH poorly sealed windows generally are touted as the greatest source of heat leaks in an insulated home, weatherstripping a main entrance door can have the same effect as sealing several windows.


Boston Plans Help for Illegal Aliens
LEAD: The city government here has launched an effort to help illegal Irish immigrants with their legal problems, prompting questions from representatives of other immigrant groups.


South Africa Seizes 16 More Linked to Banned Congress
LEAD: The South African police today announced the arrests of 16 more black members of the outlawed African National Congress.


Suspect in Botched Robbery Is Wounded by Police
LEAD: A 19-year-old man who was accused of taking a hostage in a botched holdup at a convenience store was arrested after he was shot and wounded as he fled, the police said today.

A LITTLE SUGAR, BUT NO SALT
LEAD: In a letter to the Long Island editor headed ''How Sweet It Isn't''  [ Sept. 20 ] , Ebinger's is taken to task for providing ''large quantities of sugary, pasty, greasy 'goodies'.'' The Brooklyn-based bakery also made a product much appreciated by our family.

'The Bretts': Backstage Life In 1920's London
LEAD: THE YEAR 1927 WAS WHEN LONdon theater-goers turned on that enfant terrible, Noel Coward, heckling two of his new plays into premature oblivion.
It was the year Rodgers and Hart's ''Girl Friend'' arrived from Broadway, and everyone seemed to be humming ''My Heart Stood Still,'' the song they'd contributed to a West End revue called ''One Dam Thing After Another.

Correction
LEAD: A caption last Sunday in The Sophisticated Traveler, part 2 of The Times Magazine, misidentified a landmark in San Francisco's financial district.
The pyramidal tower is the headquarters of Transamerica Corporation.
The Bank of America World Headquarters, which includes the Carnelian Room restaurant, is a 52-story polished granite slab.


New &amp; Noteworthy
LEAD:  A SUMMONS TO MEMPHIS, by Peter Taylor. (Ballantine, $4.95.) The story of Phillip Carver, called to Memphis by his sisters to stop their widowed father from remarrying, won the Pulitzer Prize.
As in his past works, Peter Taylor writes about the ways we use conventions and manners to circumscribe the world, making it an easier, if duller, place to live.


Calling In the Smile Designers
LEAD: DO you dream of having a cover-girl smile?
Dr.
Jeff Golub of New York can create one for you.
Or he can give you the smile of a barracuda - as he recently did for a film actor playing a cannibalistic visitor from outer space.

Ban Chemical Weapons. But How?
LEAD: Soviet and American officials boast that they are near agreement on banning chemical weapons.
Ridding the world of these repulsive weapons would truly represent progress for humankind.
It is far from clear, however, that the ban can be effective and verifiable - even though the two sides now accept provisions for on-site inspections.

Television Tests Its Limits
LEAD: INGENIOUS.
THAT'S ONE WORD FOR THE NEW television season.
Efforts by the three commercial networks to get around once-rigid taboos in what is supposed to be family entertainment have become terribly inventive.
On CBS's ''Jake and the Fatman,'' for instance, William Conrad plays a crotchety district attorney who is partial to salty language.


Maine Dam Stymies Fish and Anglers
LEAD: The story goes that the Pleasant River, a narrow strip of water not much bigger than a stream, once was so full of Atlantic salmon that a fisherman could walk across the river by stepping on the backs of fish.

LEAD: IN WHAT is believed to be the first suit filed under a year-old state statute, the former national sales manager of a Japanese-owned electronics company in Mount Laurel has asserted he was dismissed for complaining about defective computer parts that the company knowingly shipped to dealers and sold to the public.

SCHOOLCHILDREN AND STANDARD TESTS
LEAD: A way to improve standard tests is to correctly identify the recipients of the scores.
The Connecticut Mastery Tests should be called Tests for Teachers When teachers use tests as curriculum goals, they invariably begin to teach to the test.
The test results become the evaluation of effective teaching.


Horse Laughs Last
LEAD: THE horse, a pacer known as Dewey Dynamo, had managed only 1 victory in 21 starts and had been ill for a month with a mysterious ailment.
So when it came time for the third race at Freehold Raceway in New Jersey Friday night, his owner-driver, Jim Pfeiffer, didn't bother to waste $2 on a futile bet.

LEAD: In recent years, no rivalry in pro football has been more intense than the one between the Giants and the Washington Redskins.

Still a New Yorker
LEAD: The case of Guarini vs.
New York may have lacked the emotional impact associated with courtroom custody battles, but it was undeniably a monumental dispute.
It ended last week when the United States Supreme Court denied a claim by two Garden State politicians that New Jersey, not New York, should have sovereignty over Liberty Island and the statue thereupon of Miss Liberty.


Democrats Debating About Debates
LEAD: After debating about foreign policy, economics and other issues in Iowa, New Hampshire, Florida and Washington, the Democratic candidates for President are now debating about debates.


CAREFUL SHOPPER
LEAD: A Copious Marketplace At Van Cortlandt The Marketplace at Van Cortlandt Manor in Croton-on-Hudson is in full swing in celebration of the fall colors today and each Saturday and Sunday through Oct. 25 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.
Browsers and buyers will find a country scene with fresh farm produce, breads, preserves, woven willow baskets and handcrafted items such as stained-glass ornaments, hand-stenciled scatter rugs, wooden welcome signs and Blue Sponge and Rinney Pottery.

LEAD: A 29-year-old jockey, Joy Scott, has become the first woman to boot home a winner in the 19-year-history of the Oak Tree Racing Association meet at Santa Anita Park.
Scott also did it the hard way, winning the first race on Friday aboard Smooth Bid, a 75-1 shot. . . .

Next Week; Should The Knicks Try to Keep King?
LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036.
Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: Under attack by farm groups, the Fish and Wildlife Service has asked the Environmental Protection agency to postpone plans to protect endangered species by limiting pesticide use in about 900 counties around the country.

LEAD: THE buying and selling of commercial buildings in Manhattan has fallen to its lowest level of the decade, according to real-estate experts.
They say that high taxes and even higher hopes have prompted owners to cling to their Manhattan holdings.


TAKING RISKS
LEAD: I'm all for taking chances; I'm all for risks.
But isn't the purpose of a risk to reach a goal, or is the purpose of a risk risk itself?
I can understand perfectly Simmons's exhilaration in action, his sense of testing, but doesn't testing imply a conclusion to be reached, a new understanding, something of value gained?

GORBACHEV'S GROUNDWORK FOR SUMMIT No. 3
LEAD: AS a chilly rain lashed Reykjavik exactly a year ago, the second summit between Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Reagan ended in failure.
It has taken 12 months to reassemble the pieces that nearly fell into place that weekend.
This time around, with more careful preparation, both sides appear to have a more realistic idea of what they want and how to get it.


Cuba Has Plan to Raid U.S. Base in Case of Attack, Defecting General Says
LEAD: A Cuban Air Force general who defected to the United States five months ago says Cuban combat pilots regularly practice for retaliatory strikes against an Air Force base in Florida.


Stamford Becomes State's Venture Capital Capital
LEAD: WITH fewer than 105,000 residents, the city of Stamford, in southwestern Connecticut ranks fifth in terms of the state's population.
But when it comes to cash, it ranks first.
Of $1.3 billion in venture capital available in Connecticut, for instance, $1 billion of it is in Stamford, which ranks fourth in the nation in terms of venture funds.

Japanese Resurgent in Experiments on Particles

CELEBRATING THE CONSTITUTION
LEAD: I hope Yale Kamisar's faulty comparison of AIDS testing with illicit drug testing, dragnet searches at airports and regulatory searches for health and safety violations will be cautiously avoided by those with judicial power (''Drugs, AIDS and the Threat to Privacy'').
A person harboring the AIDS virus has not committed a criminal act by virtue of being infected, and, furthermore, poses no risk to other individuals who themselves refrain from unsafe behavior.


The Price of Ideology
LEAD: It is a new experience for Americans to live under a Government driven by ideology.
We have had activist Presidents, but not ones fastened to a theory.
Franklin Roosevelt, the modern exemplar of vigor, was an utter pragmatist.
Richard Nixon went to China.
Lyndon Johnson urged us to reason together.

LEAD: King Hussein, opening a new session of Parliament, said today that he was postponing elections to the lower house for two years.

8 Arrested for Drugs on L.I.
LEAD: Eight people were arrested on drug-related felony charges after the Nassau County Police conducted a sweep of the Nassau Road area.
Officers from the county's Bureau of Special Operations swept through the street about 10 P.M.
Friday, recovering 43 vials of crack, a large bag of crack, $2,000 in cash and assorted drug paraphernalia, according to a police spokesman, Officer Peter Franzone.

LEAD: SLOW, TERRIBLE DEATH, GRISLY EXPERI-ments and seemingly irrevocable pollution of the environment are hardly things about which audiences automatically want to hear.
But Carole Langer's ''Radium City'' hooked the crowd anyway, and when that happens, the film maker deserves as much praise for tact as for technique.


TAKING RISKS
LEAD: Thomas Simmons's celebration of life at the edge carries the implication that the rest of us are leading tame, backwater lives.
For a person whose mind and senses are open, a ''sense of drama'' and ''joy in action'' are everywhere: running down a country road, watching a flower unfold or watching a cat play with its tail.

TURKISH ELECTION IS UNDER JEOPARDY
LEAD: A Turkish court has ruled that part of the country's new election procedure is unlawful, jeopardizing a general election scheduled in three weeks.


CELEBRATING THE CONSTITUTION
LEAD: William Safire's assertion that the war power ''has been wrested back and forth through two centuries, and the answer seems to lie in the inability of either branch to dominate the other'' (''Tug-of-War'') seriously misstates the true nature of the power over war.
In fact, as we celebrate our Constitution's bicentennial, the power to initiate and risk war has moved steadily and inexorably into the hands of the President alone.


At Car Rental Companies, the Owners Come and Go
LEAD: TRYING to get a fix on the $9 billion-or-so car rental industry is like carving an ice statue on a hot day.
You can do it - but it's not going to hold its shape for long.


The Extravagant Desserts of Sicily
LEAD: Sicilian desserts are the kind that children might dream up.
Thick, rich and sugary sweet concoctions made with unstinting proportions of cream, sugar, chocolate, fruit and nuts, all oozed into crispy pastry rolls, spread onto spongy layer cakes or hidden inside soft pastry pockets.
Then there are the mounds of buttery cookies, the fooled-you marzipan lookalike fruit and vegetables, the ice mountains of fruit- or coffee-flavored granitas, and ice cream that barely begins with vanilla, chocolate and strawberry.

Question Of the Week; How Should The Series Use the D.H.?
LEAD: The usual rules of hospitality should prevail - the host determines the rules, quite simply.
In the A.L. ball park, there will be a d.h.
In the N.L., there will not.


Penn St. Romps Over Rutgers
LEAD: Penn State ran up a 28-7 lead on Rutgers today and then relaxed.
But Scott Erney kept throwing the football for the Scarlet Knights and put a little fear into the mind of Joe Paterno, the Nittany Lions' coach.


Condom in College Newspaper
LEAD: The University of Vermont's student newspaper inserted a free condom in 5,000 of its Oct. 1 issues.
The condoms were part of a ''safe sex'' package that included two pamphlets, one on venereal diseases, another on AIDS.


ANSWERING THE MAIL
LEAD: Q. The walls inside my house are covered with rough-sawn knotty pine.
Because of some leaks, the wood along the bottom is stained dark in an irregular pattern that looks like a stock market graph.
The leaks are cured, but the stains remain.
How can I remove them?


Hofstra Beats Wagner in Showdown
LEAD: Hofstra took advantage of Wagner's listless defense in the first half to build a 24-0 lead today, then had to withstand Wagner's relentless offense in the second half for a 35-28 victory in a match of unbeaten teams.
The victory gave Hofstra a record of 5-0; Wagner dropped to 5-1.

LEAD: Creme Fraiche won the $1 million Jockey Club Gold Cup yesterday at Belmont Park by stealing an easy lead through staggeringly slow fractions that allowed him to post a 4 3/4-length victory over Java Gold.

Reversing Rural Blight in the Catskills
LEAD: FOR a century, the Beaverkill Valley in the Catskills has been a mecca for naturalists drawn by the great floral beauty covering the mountains, for sportsmen attracted by abundant turkey and deer, and especially for anglers who cast into its streams for the maddeningly elusive rainbow trout and then touted the region as a world-class fishing spot.


Philharmonic: Ohlsson Is Sanderling's Soloist
LEAD: THE latest guest conductor in the New York Philharmonic's young season is Kurt Sanderling.
Mr.
Sanderling is a German who apprenticed under Furtwangler, Klemperer and Kleiber in the 1920's but who also spent a third of his life in the Soviet Union.
His program at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday afternoon seemed a convergence of these experiences.


Far Above Par
LEAD: A MAN who spent his career building golf courses and a woman who spent hers tearing them up have been inducted into the PGA-World Golf Hall of Fame.
At ceremonies in Pinehurst, N.C., Robert Trent Jones, the 81-year-old golf course designer, was honored Friday along with Betsy Rawls, the 59-year-old former champion.


CAR MADNESS IN MANHATTAN: CURE SOUGHT
LEAD: EVERY workday 3.4 million people converge on Manhattan in movement so massive that the city's transportation commissioner, Ross Sandler, says it can only be compared to the tides.
It falls to Mr.
Sandler to smooth out the eddies and maintain the flow as best he can.
That task has grown progressively harder since the mid-70's, when the number of commuters started to climb.

LEAD: THE triumph of the Peronists in Argentina's congressional and provincial elections last month weighs almost as heavily on the victors as on President Raul Alfonsin and his party, the Radical Civic Union.

CRIME
LEAD: Time was when private eyes were anything but thinking men.
Their brains resided in their fists, just as the brains of so many pianists are located in their finger tips.
Today things are different.
Most private eyes are depicted as sensitive plants, with emotional problems just like ours.
They spout philosophy.

LEAD: ONE problem for cosmetic dentists has been that patients have trouble visualizing the results of cosmetic alterations - and often back off because of uncertainty.

Ancient Places That Anchor Yeats's Poems
LEAD: Like many unreconstructed English majors, I have a weakness for literary pilgrimages, a form of travel based on the principle that homage must be paid to genius.
So I have found myself at Ernest Hemingway's house in Key West, Mark Twain's boyhood haunts in Hannibal, Wordsworth's cottage in the Lake District and Karen Blixen's house on the outskirts of Nairobi.


In 2167, Mule Train Is the Way to Go
LEAD: It is the year 2167.
Mom, Dad, the kids and Bruno the dog lounge around the simulated sun room of their life-support pod in Westchester.
A heap of brochures litters the carpet.
The family vacation looms a few weeks away.
They have already decided to visit New England, where the nitrous oxide count is lower.

LEAD: IN his 1975 novel ''The Autumn of the Patriarch,'' Gabriel Garcia Marquez imagined a Latin American despot so aged that he was ''older than all old men and all old animals on land or sea.'' LONG ISLAND GUIDE
LEAD:  ALL'S FAIRS  As if one full-fledged, traditional fair - the Long Island Fair at the Old Bethpage Village Restoration - wasn't enough this weekend, here comes the Riverhead Country Fair today to entice suburbanites with a taste of what used to be in really rural America.
So from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M., the parking lot at the Peconic River will be the scene of the customary fair activities - old-fashioned contests like spelling bees (and one new-fangled mini-marathon), rides, games, exhibits and, naturally, agricultural competitions.

Correction
LEAD: A front-page article in the Arts and Leisure section today about the new television season includes an outdated passage about the CBS-TV series ''Jake and the Fatman,'' derived from a videotape of the pilot episode supplied by the network for review.
In episodes that have been broadcast, the dialogue has been rewritten to use language that is not offensive; no words are bleeped out.

Question Of the Week; How Should The Series Use the D.H.?
LEAD: Use both the d.h. and let the pitcher hit.
By doing so, it allows the d.h. to take his spot in the lineup, keeping A.L. strategies intact, while ''old-fashioned'' N.L. baseball would still be a part of the fall classic.
Of course, fans would see less of their top- and middle-of-the-lineup favorites, but this would be offset by the inherent fairness to both teams.

The Job Outlook Across the Nation; MOUNTAIN
LEAD: UNEMPLOYMENT RATES have been a puzzling indicator of economic health in the Rocky Mountain West during the last year.
In Idaho, Montana, Wyoming and Colorado the number of people out of work has dropped, but state labor specialists do not call the change an improvement.
Meanwhile, Utah's unemployment rate inched upward to 6.6 percent in August, though John Mathews of the Utah Department of Employment Security sounds more optimistic than his counterparts.

MAMET MAKE A DEBUT WITH 'HOUSE OF GAMES'
QUITE early in ''House of Games,'' David Mamet's entertaining, deadpan, seriocomic melodrama about con artists, there's a back-room poker game that sets the tone for everything that comes after.
Though the players could withdraw at any point, they don't, this being a serious game.
Raises are seen, and raised again.
The pot accumulates. ''Everybody stays.
Everybody pays,'' says the dealer.
Tensions mount and tempers shorten like fuses burning in slow-motion.
Somebody must be bluffing, and somebody must lose, though there's nothing in the book that says the bluffer must lose or that the best hand wins.

LEAD: The d.h. ought to be eliminated not only from the World Series but also from the American League regular season as well.
If for no other reason than it isn't fair to compare the earned-run averages of current A.L. pitchers with those of the N.L. and past American League pitchers.

Frank Stella Finds Space for Cosmic Reliefs
LEAD: FROM THE TIME HE FIRST ELEC-trified the New York art world with a series of paintings consisting of black stripes on raw canvas, Frank Stella has been an artist who always seems to be working on the leading edge of contemporary art.
The black-stripe paintings of 1959 were avatars of Minimalism; the mid-70's series of painted reliefs called ''Exotic Birds'' heralded the return of decorative painting; the increasingly three-dimensional series that have followed have spoken to grafitti art and neo-Expressionism, among other trends.

Folk-Rock: R.E.M. And 10,000 Maniacs
LEAD: SOMETIMES the late 1980's seem to be the late 1960's turned inside out.
Consider folk-rock.
In the 1960's, it was a commercial hybrid; in the late 1980's, it has become the style of choice for iconoclasts, nonconformists and oddballs.
Foremost among them is R.E.M., a band from Athens, Ga., whose asymmetrical, often obscure songs are so tuneful and its concerts so galvanizing that the band is fast reaching the mainstream pop audience almost despite itself.

IRAN EMBARGO: THE MAIN IMPORT IS POLITICAL
LEAD: THERE are no illusions either within the Reagan Administration or on Capitol Hill that an embargo against Iranian imports will have a serious economic impact.

T.W.A. Pays $252,000 Fine
LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration has reported that Trans World Airlines has paid $252,000 to settle a civil action.
Federal inspectors had cited the carrier for technical violations of F.A.A. maintenance and operational rules.
The penalty, like one of $512,000 against Braniff, is small by comparison with the record $9.5 million penalty that Eastern Airlines agreed to pay earlier this year after a special F.A.A.

Develop Those Existing Technologies
LEAD: IN the Samuel Beckett play, ''Waiting For Godot,'' the central characters await the arrival of a special person - who never comes - while they watch the world pass by.
The analogy with United States manufacturing management is startling.
Manufacturers are waiting for new technology that will make them competitive in the global market without any risks or modifications in the way they currently do business.

No Longer Foiled
LEAD: As swords go, the foil is a gossamer weapon, a nearly weightless ribbon whose scoring touches are a fencer's caresses.
Derived from the courtier's delicate dress sword, the foil, by chivalric tradition, has been the only weapon wielded by female fencers.

Nomination Welcomed In Mexico
LEAD: Last Monday, one day after Mexico's ruling party named Carlos Salinas de Gortari as its standard-bearer in next year's presidential election, the stock market here rose 7.5 percent in the first 90 minutes of trading.
Twice during the day the Government had to suspend trading briefly to prevent what it called a ''disorderly'' surge by the market.

'Default' Is Not in Bankers' Stars
LEAD: No industry has experienced more rapid change in recent years than international finance.
New financial instruments become obsolete from one year to the next.
Bank strategies for coping with the debt crisis are as disposable as yesterday's newspaper.
And regulations once considered the bedrock of the financial system are virtually ignored as bankers leap from one loophole to another.

At 5-0, Syracuse Football Is Back in the Game
LEAD: NO one is quite prepared to describe events here as an advanced case of Orangemania.
Chances are, some people would think you were talking about a new soft drink, anyway.
There is, however, no denying the Growing interest in the Syracuse football team.
It is evident in the pink message slips multiplying on Dick MacPherson's desk when the coach returns from lunch or a meeting, and in the recent involvement of the city fathers, who have scheduled a pep rally for Friday evening at the city hall, in preparation for Saturday's showdown against Penn State.

Slow Growth in Europe
LEAD: The European Community's economy will expand by 2.3 percent in 1988, well below expected growth rates for the United States and Japan, the community's commission said.
It said in a report on Friday that the United States and Japanese economies would probably grow by 2.7 percent and 3.5 percent, respectively, in 1988, compared with 2.3 percent and 2.9 percent this year.

BOOKS OF THE TIMES
LEAD:  ZERO GRAVITY.
By Richard Lourie. 284 pages.
Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $16.95.
THE framework of Richard Lourie's new novel, ''Zero Gravity,'' is amusing enough.
The Soviet Union decides to send a poet to the moon. ''Theme of Project: humanization, not militarization of cosmos.'' A Polish general suffers ''severe gastric distress'' at the idea.

When Prosecutors Violate Confidentiality
LEAD: A significant number of prominent criminal cases have recently been characterized by a troubling breakdown in confidentiality.
Simply put, prosecutors and their agents have selectively leaked to the media damaging information about subjects of grand jury investigations and other legal proceedings that are supposed to remain secret until disclosed in open court at the appropriate time.

He is still out there in the satiric combat zone, flailing sacred cows (and sitting ducks) with his caustic wit.

Louis Armstrong's Archives
LEAD: When Louis Armstrong performed, he wore a smile that seemed a mile wide.
He punctuated his singing by repeatedly mopping the sweat from his brow with a pocket handkerchief; when he played the trumpet he pointed the bell heavenward, and reflected stage lights danced in the horn's polished brass.
To some, Armstrong was a great musician first and foremost; to others he was an entertainer, a clowning Southern bumpkin.

LEAD: TWELVE days after he suffered an accident while working on his car, Lloyd M. Crenshaw had to have his right foot amputated.
Mr.
Crenshaw's insurer, the Bankers Life and Casualty Company, refused to pay a $20,000 benefit under his policy for loss of limb.
The company insisted that the amputation was not covered by the policy, saying it resulted from a degenerative disease.

LEAD: While hundreds of earthquake victims jammed disaster relief centers today seeking funds to rebuild or relocate, a small aftershock jolted the metropolitan area.

Doctors Indicted in Brazil
LEAD: Three doctors who owned an abandoned radiation therapy clinic have been charged in the release of radioactive material that contaminated 40 people, 10 of them critically.
Orlando Teixeira, 37 years old, Criseide Dourado, 40, and Carlos Bezzerril, 43, directors of the Goiania Radiation Therapy Institute, were indicted Saturday on charges of causing grave injury to 10 people.


An Unusual Course
LEAD: A golfer making his first outing at the Malibu Golf Course, a private links north of Los Angeles, may come back raving and ranting.
The raves would be for the 6,205-yard course's challenging layout, its rolling beauty and its well-maintained fairways and greens.
The rants would be for what might be regarded as a bizarre emphasis on golfing decorum.

Topics of The Times; The Luce Touch
LEAD: Obituaries dutifully describe the obvious and the copious about Clare Boothe Luce.
Almost till her death at age 84, she starred as a playwright, politician and diplomat.
What doesn't get into print, indeed what eludes print, is how she was able to disarm those she well knew were disposed to dislike her, especially males determined not to be taken in by a woman they believed to be too smart and ambitious to be up to any good.

It does not promote ''the right to die'' but sensibly extends people's right to take charge of their lives.

Opera: 'Rake's Progress'
LEAD: FOR the opera ''Rake's Progress,'' Stravinsky transformed Hogarth's engravings of a downwardly mobile young gentleman into tragic Faustian drama.
The New York City Opera's production, revived Sunday evening in its first performance of the season, employed the vivid David Hockney sets first seen here three years ago, which are drawn in crosshatching to evoke the quality of the etchings and which, in their flattened-out, stylized way, perfectly evoke the chilly tone of Stravinsky's brilliant Neo-Classical score and of W.

Oil Production Outlook
LEAD: This nation's crude oil output will decline again in 1988 but at a slower rate, the Independent Petroleum Association of America said today.
Production will average 8.17 million barrels a day, compared with this year's estimated 8.3 million, it said.
The decrease of 130,000 barrels a day would be less than the decline of 330,000 barrels a day for the last two years.

Tom Wolfe Tries New Role: Novelist
LEAD: ''It's outrageous the way people conduct their lives in New York,'' Tom Wolfe said. ''And yet I don't want to live anywhere else.
I don't despair, because I find the comedy so rich.
At the same time that people do vile things, they also create hilariously funny spectacles.
The city dominates you if you're a player, but it never fails you if you're a viewer.

4 OPEC Nations Vow To Stabilize Oil Price
LEAD: Eighteen months after the collapse of oil prices shook the American oil and banking industries, landed a few third world countries in default and upset the world's economy, Saudi Arabia and three other OPEC nations say they will strive to hold prices at the current level of $18 a barrel.


Psychiatrist Is Cleared in Ethics Case
LEAD: A MARYLAND psychiatrist did not commit a ''legal violation or ethical impropriety'' when he appeared on a television program and advised patients not to take prescribed drugs under certain conditions, the Maryland Commission on Medical Discipline has ruled.

Long-Running Debate on AIDS: How Well Did Americans Respond?
LEAD: Was the nation's initial response to the AIDS epidemic a remarkable triumph of modern science?
Or was it a failure to mobilize against a disease that has primarily ravaged outcast groups like male homosexuals and intravenous drug users?


Washington Talk: The Military; Now Hear This: Navy Gets Memorial
LEAD: In this city of monuments and memorials, the Army has Pershing Square on Pennsylvania Avenue, the Marine Corps has the Iwo Jima statue just north of Arlington Memorial Cemetery across the Potomac, and the Air Force dominates much of the National Air and Space Museum.
The Navy has never enjoyed a comparable place of institutional honor in the capital.


Gold Called Aid to New Economic Order
LEAD: Despite the turbulence in the financial markets and the barbs of skeptics, many economists find that the United States and other leading countries are making headway in a fit-and-start effort to regain control of the world economy.


Software in the Mail
LEAD: PUTTING considerations of cost and convenience aside, probably the best source for buying software for the home or small business is a large computer products store with a knowledgeable staff.
If you're laying out major money for a full-featured word processor, spreadsheet or other bread-and-butter program, and especially if you're fairly new to the world of computing, you need all the help you can get.

Washington Talk: Briefing; Whither Ziegler?
LEAD: In the where-are-they-now department, Ron Ziegler, the White House press secretary in the Nixon Administration, is leaving his post as president of the National Association of Truck Stop Operators, having been chosen chairman of the board of the National Association of Chain Drug Stores.


Twins Batter Tigers and Capture the Pennant
LEAD: Even as the Minnesota Twins celebrated today, the players who happily doused themselves with champagne could not forget the sad times.
Many of them had been together through the difficult years of the decade, learning as they lost and hoping that the losing would come to an end.


Bond Acquires 91% of Heileman
LEAD: Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd., the Australian brewer, said it had acquired 91 percent of the G. Heileman Brewing Company and plans to buy the remaining 9 percent of the Wisconsin-based concern.
The $1.22 billion buyout creates one of the world's largest brewers.
Bond said its Amber Acquisition Corporation subsidiary had accepted 21.8 million Heileman shares under a previously announced tender offer of $40.75 a share.


Chemical Will Drop 170 in London
LEAD: The Chemical New York Corporation said yesterday that it would lay off 170 people in London, or 18 percent of its British work force.

JAMES W. CARROLL
LEAD: James W. Carroll, a senior editor of the Encyclopedia Americana and a former editor with United Press International, died of heart failure Friday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y.
He was 61 years old and lived in Pleasantville.

Wendy's Buffet
LEAD: Wendy's International Inc. said it plans to invest $35 million to expand its Superbar program, a new all-you-can-eat hot and cold food buffet.
Robert L. Barney, chairman and chief executive, said that incremental sales gains averaging 15 percent in Superbar company stores had encourgaed Wendy's to expand the test program.


Pact With G.M. Backed By Auto Union Council
LEAD: The tentative agreement between the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers took an important step toward ratification today as it was overwhelmingly approved by the union's 300-member G.M.
Council.


Detroit Tour Canceled
LEAD: The Detroit Symphony Orchestra has canceled its performance next Tuesday at Carnegie Hall as well as its East Coast tour.
The Detroit orchestra's musicians have been on strike since shortly after the beginning of the season.

Susumu Tonegawa, who works at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, with son Hidde in Newton, Mass., after hearing of the award, given for work on immunological defenses against disease.

Publishing: Plans For Myerson Book
LEAD: Newmarket Press has scheduled a first printing of 35,000 copies and a 14-city tour for the author, but otherwise its plans for a book it is to publish on Nov. 9 are somewhat unsettled.
The book is ''Miss America, 1945 - Bess Myerson's Own Story,'' by Susan Dworkin, and Miss Myerson was recently indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges that include conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice.


Who Torpedoed Judge Bork?
LEAD: Robert Bork is an honorable man with an impressive record as a professor, lawyer and judge on the United States Court of Appeals.
Yet a Senate majority seems lined up against his nomination to be a Supreme Court Justice.
Why?
Judge Bork angrily blames a campaign of sordid distortion of his positions.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.H.L.
Nordiques 5, Canadiens 2: In Montreal, Michel Goulet scored three goals and added an assist last night to lead a five-goal third-period rally for Quebec.
Goulet, whose six goals tie him with Washington's Mike Gartner for the league lead, broke a 2-2 tie with 5 minutes 44 seconds to play with a shot from the slot that beat the goaltender, Patrick Roy.


Utah Battles With Harvard In Bid to Obtain Indian Relics
LEAD: Nearly 60 years ago, an archeologist unearthed thousands of Indian artifacts in Utah and gave them to a Harvard University museum.
Now Utah wants the artifacts returned.


Area Stores In Sales Gains
LEAD: New York's largest department and specialty stores had an average 8.6 percent gain in sales in the city in September over the same month a year ago, a spot-check indicated yesterday.
For the metropolitan area, which includes the suburbs, the average increase in sales was 9.5 percent.

LEAD: Bo Jackson, the Heisman Trophy-winning running back from Auburn, who chose baseball as his profession after leaving college, is scheduled to report on Thursday to the Los Angeles Raiders' training camp amid conflicting reports of what his future with the team will be.

NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1987
LEAD:  International A3-19


ROBERT PRICE
LEAD: Robert Price, the American who led a local group that bought General Motors South African after G.M.'s divestment, died of a heart attack Saturday.
He was 61 years old.
Mr.
Price, who joined General Motors Corporation in 1951, retired last year as president of G.M.'s Motors Trading Corporation subsidiary.


Careers; Engineers Get Broad Curriculum
LEAD: THE Massachusetts Institute of Technology is overhauling its curriculum to give the humanities greater emphasis and to integrate engineering education more fully with science, manufacturing technology and economic, political, social and environmental factors.


Sessions Is Out of Hospital; Swearing-In Due Next Week
LEAD: Judge William S. Sessions, designated as the next Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was released from the hospital today after being treated for internal bleeding.
He said he expected his delayed swearing-in to be next week.

For New U.N. Envoys, Work Is a Way of Life
LEAD: At 7:30 A.M., Gopala Menon of Singapore starts his three-mile jog on the East Side; an hour later, Stefan Noreen hurries to his office to phone Stockholm.
By 10 A.M., Grethel Vargas of Nicaragua is lobbying among her colleagues on the Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee.


Broncos Defeat Raiders
LEAD: Joe Dudek ran for two first-quarter touchdowns tonight to lead the Denver Broncos to a 30-14 victory over the Los Angeles Raiders before 61,230, exceeding by more than 20,000 the largest crowd in two weekends of replacement games.


Rothschild Bank
LEAD: Baron Edmond de Rothschild's private Swiss bank, founded in 1924, made its first public issue of shares today.
Banque Privee Edmond de Rothschild S.A. has been privately held since it was founded.
The baron is a member of the French branch of the famous banking family and has led the bank since 1985.


Robinson Speculation
LEAD: One week after the Baltimore Orioles' owner, Edward Bennett Williams, discharged General Manager Hank Peters and Tom Giordano, the farm director, published reports suggested that Frank Robinson, the Baseball Hall of Fame outfielder who is now an Orioles coach, would be named to replace Peters.
Robinson would become the first black man to head a major league baseball organization.


Tax Dispute In Florida
LEAD: Lawmakers trickled back to the Capitol today to try again to resolve a dispute over a new services tax, as one legislator filed suit contending the Governor is holding the Legislature hostage and has exceeded his authority.

Wilkinson Sword
LEAD: Friedman Benjamin Inc., a year-old agency, has been assigned the shaving products of Wilkinson Sword, a subsidiary of Allegheny International Inc.
Although Leading National Advertisers, the independent media measuring company, shows little Wilkinson activity in 1986, it is expected to increase its budget this year, the agency said.


M.I.T. Scientist Wins Nobel Prize for Medicine
LEAD: DR.
Susumu Tonegawa, a 48-year-old Japanese scientist working at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, was awarded the Nobel Prize in medicine yesterday for his discoveries of how the body can suddenly marshal its immunological defenses against millions of different disease agents that it has never encountered before.


Radiation Accident in Brazil Stirs Misgivings Over Nuclear Program
LEAD: Brazilian scientists have questioned the Government's ability to manage an independent nuclear energy program after what they described as an inadequate response by the authorities to an accident two weeks ago involving highly radioactive material.


Dance: Graham's 'Rite'
LEAD: AMID Martha Graham's allegories for our time, ''The Rite of Spring'' stands out by its expression of cruelty.
Her treatment of Stravinsky's well-known score is distinct from other versions, which look decorative and even likable in comparison.

LEAD: Donna Vohnoutka passes her hours at the Pilgrim nuclear power plant fighting the boredom that comes with the job of staring into space to see if a fire will erupt.


Tax Plan Roils Germany
LEAD: West Germany's financial markets could suffer a huge flight of capital if Bonn goes ahead with a plan to impose a new 10 percent withholding tax on interest earnings in 1989, analysts said today.


Amid Inquiries, Albany Changes Job Practices
LEAD: Amid indictments and investigations, the New York State Legislature has changed longstanding employment practices that encouraged payroll padding and blurred responsibility for hiring decisions.


Why Some Katydids Don't Sing
LEAD: Katydids in Panama have learned to dance to avoid being eaten by bats, researchers say.

EMPLOYERS PLAN SMALLER RAISES
LEAD: Despite rising profits and lower joblessness, employers intend to give lower raises next year, according to a survey of companies with labor contracts expiring in 1988.


City of Future Splits Over Homeless
LEAD: A proposal to convert an unused building at the city animal shelter to house the homeless has upset many people here in Orange County's city of the future.


No Choice But Reform for Poland
LEAD: Desperation, as much as the Soviet example of reform, spurs the far-reaching economic moves announced by Poland last week.
Six years after crushing Solidarity, Poland remains mired in the same economic swamp that spawned past protest movements.
Price structures remain irrational, coordination between centralized productive units poor and worker morale and productivity minimal.
