ELIZABETH REMSEN
LEAD: Elizabeth Remsen, the daughter of the founder of Remsenburg, L.I., died Saturday at her home in Remsenburg.
She was 90 years old.
Miss Remsen's father, Dr.
Charles Remsen, founded the town near Speonk in Suffolk County in the 1890's, when he decided to build a red brick Presbyterian church to commemorate a young son who had died.


Jackson Apologizes For Remarks on TV
LEAD: The Rev.
Jesse Jackson told Mayor Koch yesterday that he apologizes if he insulted New Yorkers in a remark Sunday on CBS-TV, a mayoral spokesman said.


PLAYERS OFFER TO RETURN IF TALKS GO TO MEDIATION
LEAD: The striking National Football League players tonight offered to return to work for the rest of the season if the owners would agree to negotiate with a mediator for six weeks, and then submit issues still unresolved to binding arbitration.


GORBACHEV'S MESSAGES
LEAD: Western experts on East-West affairs who gathered here to discuss ''the implications of Soviet new thinking'' showed consensus on what Mikhail Gorbachev is trying to do.
The debate is moving on now to what the U.S. and the West in general should do about it.


Washington Talk: Briefing; The Bork Chase
LEAD: Judge Robert H. Bork, the embattled Supreme Court nominee, learned first hand last week the role of new technology in journalism.
As he moved about Washington amid speculation that he would withdraw his nomination, his automobile was trailed by two motorcyles and a second car.
On his way from the State Department to his office at the United States Court of Appeals, Judge Bork drove past the White House.


As Mars Beckons, U.S. Is Wary and Indecisive
LEAD: IN the next decade or two Mars will be explored again - by the Soviet Union at least, probably with the cooperation of Europeans.
But what role will the United States play?


Striking Starter Rejoins Jets
LEAD: Joe Walton was cheerfully philosophic this afternoon as he discussed the Jets' 6-0 loss Sunday to the Indianapolis Colts.
In fact, compared with his blue mood Sunday, Walton was practically gregarious.


No Way Out
LEAD: In Washington one enchanted evening, a handsome young American Navy officer spots this beautiful young woman.
They eye each other hotly and soon exit to her limousine, where they proceed to tear each other's clothes off in the back seat.
An excellent time is had by both.
Afterwards, as they say, he asks her name.

Westinghouse Profit Up 8.7%

Sales totaled $2.59 billion, up less than 1 percent from $2.57 billion.

They thought it was the Japanese.


Washington Talk: Briefing; A Fizzler
LEAD: Unauthorized disclosures of information are dreaded by Republican and Democratic administrations alike.
But many such ''leaks'' don't work out the way the leaker expected.
Here is the course of one: In his Administration's latest effort to control leaks, President Reagan ordered that all Government employees with access to secret information sign a Classified Information Nondisclosure Agreement.


Coke Invests In a Film Deal
LEAD: A group of five entertainment industry veterans, including Rob Reiner, the producer, said today that they had founded a new film venture called Castle Rock Entertainment that will receive $30 million in start-up money from the Coca-Cola Company, which will become a 40 percent shareholder in the new company.

LEAD: FALSE predictions and wrong notions about what the American people want have led to major distortions in education policies.
In his new book, ''Inside America,'' Louis Harris, the public opinion analyst, describes his findings about what Americans really expect from their educational institutions.

LEAD: Some conservative Republican senators are pressing the Reagan Administration to charge Moscow with a new arms-control violation, the opening salvo in their campaign to block approval of an emerging agreement to ban medium- and shorter-range missiles.

LEAD: WHOEVER decided to make computers beige ought to be condemned to eat nothing but raw bean curd for the rest of his or her life.


Girl Mauled by Lion Undergoes Surgery For Damage to Brain
LEAD: An 8-year-old girl, mauled by a lion that was on display at a flea market, underwent a second operation today for a cracked skull.
Doctors said she faces years of follow-up treatment for brain damage.

Union Pacific Cuts
LEAD: The Union Pacific Railroad said it would eliminate about 100 jobs in restructuring its marketing and sales department.

The marketing and sales department now has about 870 people worldwide.

LEAD: A WOMAN, a paranoid schizophrenic, ate all her meals in restaurants because she was convinced someone was poisoning her food at home.
Her 12-year-old daughter developed the same fears and likewise ate in restaurants.
Her 10-year-old daughter would eat at home if her father was there, but otherwise went along with her mother.

Gov. Casey Out of Hospital

Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania went home from the hospital today, 11 days after undergoing quadruple-bypass surgery.

Casey, 55 years old, had a five-hour operation Oct. 1 at the Milton S. Hershey Medical Center to bypass blockages in arteries leading to his heart.
Doctors said Mr.
Casey would probably return to work full time in about six weeks.

LEAD: Steel production fell to 1.792 million tons in the week ended Saturday, a decrease of 1.9 percent from the previous week's 1.827 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 83 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 84.6 percent in the previous week.

Seville Journal; Was Columbus a Whiner? You Could Look It Up
LEAD: Christopher Columbus was a chronic whiner.
Cervantes asked the Crown for permission to travel to the New World to escape debt that dogged him throughout his life.


Family Says German Was Slain
LEAD: The widow and brother of the West German politician Uwe Barschel, who was forced from office because of an election scandal, asserted today that he had been murdered after meeting a mysterious informer who promised help.


Poll Finds Job Satisfaction
LEAD: Three out of every five Americans questioned in a recent poll said they were satisfied with their jobs but were less kind when commenting about their wages, pensions and promotion opportunities, the Conference Board said in a study to be released today.

LEAD: ''SET FREE,'' which was shown Sunday night at the Nikolais-Louis Choreospace, concerned forces of liberation and repression.

She was 80 years old.

LEAD: An Amtrak passenger train, the California Zephyr, slammed into a railroad crane today, knocking the locomotives and 11 cars off the tracks and injuring at least 126 people, officials said.

Puzzling 'Boomerang'
LEAD: The boomerang seems as Australian as ''Waltzing Matilda,'' but the oldest specimen may have come from a far distant part of the world -Poland.
Scientists there have found a 23,000-year-old piece of curved mammoth tusk that some ancient artisan carved and polished into the aerodynamic shape of a boomerang.

Metzenbaum Is Taken Ill
LEAD: Senator Howard Metzenbaum, Dempocrat of Ohio, was taken to Toledo Hospital today after complaining of dizziness, and doctors ran tests to determine the cause of his flu-like symptoms.
Mr.
Metzenbaum, 70 years old, became ill while eating breakfast at the University of Toledo with the school's president, James McComas, and was treated by a physician at the university before going to the hospital.

Fragments of friezes are chipped and mottled.
Ducts are exposed.

Opera: Piccinni Work, 'The Accomplish'd Maid'
LEAD: IN the 1770's, late in his career, Niccolo Piccinni had the bad fortune to find himself the unwitting champion of the operatic faction that opposed Gluck in Paris.
Since Gluck stood for all that is noble, progressive and reform-oriented in opera, history has been disinclined to consider the possible merits of his unintended opponent.


Oil Rig Tally Dips by 23
LEAD: The number of oil and gas drilling rigs working in the United States fell to 1,104 last week, down 23 from a week before, Baker Hughes said today.
A year ago the total was 814.
It is expected to top 1,200 by December.


Dollar Declines Abroad, But Inches Up in U.S.
LEAD: The dollar turned in a mixed performance yesterday, slipping against most major currencies in subdued trading in Japan and Europe but inching generally higher in the United States.

LEAD:  Tennis  Cash Overpowers Evernden: Pat Cash of Australia overpowered Kelly Evernden of New Zealand, 6-3, 7-6, yesterday in the opening round of the Australian indoor tennis championships at the Sydney Entertainment Center.
The 22-year-old Australian, who is seeded third in the event and is ranked eighth in the world, put on an impressive display of serving and volleying to beat Evernden, the winner of the Queensland Open in Brisbane last week.

What Housing Fines Could Buy
LEAD: At the urging of President Andrew Stein, New York's City Council has voted steep raises in fines for serious building code violations - the first such increase since 1972.
It's a welcome step in the right direction.
But the deterrent effect of the elevated penalties depends on bolstering the city's capacity to collect.

He was 92 years old and lived in Westfield.

Year-Round Schooling Is Voted in Los Angeles
LEAD: In a move certain to be watched closely by educators, parents and operators of summer camps around the country, the Los Angeles board of education has voted to put all its 618 schools and 592,000 students on a year-round schedule.


5 Shot to Death in Car Shop
LEAD: Two gunmen burst into an auto body shop and opened fire tonight, killing five men and wounding a sixth, the police said.
Two men were later taken into custody for questioning in the shootings, said Police Chief Don Francis.
He said the victims were working on a car inside the shop on the city's east side when two men entered, looked around and went back outside.

Corrections
LEAD: An obituary of Alfred M. Landon in some editions yesterday misstated the year in which a Democratic or Republican Presidential candidate first won fewer states than Mr.
Landon did in 1936.
It was 1972, when George McGovern carried only Massachusetts and the District of Columbia.

Music: Riverside Group
LEAD: AN artist need not be original to be important.
It is, in fact, rare that a major composer breaks new ground.
Against the few genuine originals such as Gluck, Wagner, Ives and Schoenberg stands the more imposing group of those whose genius was expressed in refining rather than redefining the musical culture into which they were born.

LEAD: Indian troops using heavy mortars, tanks and armored personnel carriers were battling their way through fierce Tamil guerrilla resistance today along four routes into Jaffna town, an Indian official said.


Group Lifts Stake In Bell &amp; Howell
LEAD: A group led by Robert M. Bass of the wealthy Fort Worth family said it had raised its stake in the Bell &amp; Howell Company to 11.1 percent, from 9.6 percent.
The move makes the Bass group the largest shareholder and set off new takeover speculation about the business-equipment manufacturer.
Its stock rose by $2.75, to $70.50 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.

LEAD: John H. G. Pell, a historian and financial consultant, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home on the grounds of Fort Ticonderoga, N.Y.
He was 83 years old and also had homes in New York City and Newport, R.I.

LEAD: A car-bomb explosion wounded 18 people, 5 of them seriously, at a suburban Harare shopping center today.
The Zimbabwean Government blamed South Africa.

Corning Wins Case On Patents
LEAD: A Federal district judge ruled yesterday that Sumitomo Electric Industries of Japan had infringed on two product patents held by Corning Glass Works for optical fiber, the thin glass wires used in telecommunications.


Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about a United Press International contract with the Reagan Administration misstated the news service's relationships with The Wall Street Journal and CBS News.
While both organizations sent notices saying they intended to cancel their U.P.I. contracts, they later renewed some parts of the agreements and continue to receive some U.P.I.

Jazz: Gruntz Concert Band On Tour
LEAD: GEORGE GRUNTZ, a Swiss jazz pianist, composer and arranger, has been touring the United States with an orchestra of American and European musicians, many of whom are band leaders and recording artists in their own right.
Last Thursday, in the first of four performances at Greenwich House, the George Gruntz Concert Jazz Band sounded more like a road band than a one-time aggregation of star soloists and studio professionals.


Bonnett Out for Season
LEAD: Neil Bonnett, the 41-year-old Nascar driver who broke his right leg Sunday at Charlotte Motor Speedway in Concord, N.C., when his car struck a wall during the running of the Oakwood Homes 500, will probably be sidelined for the remainder of the Winston Cup season.
Dr.
John Wassel, an orthopedic surgeon, operated on Bonnett Monday and discovered a four-inch piece of bone split off the upper femur.

LEAD: An advisory jury hearing a Federal suit brought by 30 Haitian men who developed enlarged breasts while in detention camps in 1981 found today that the Government had not been negligent.

Clippers Sign Wolf
LEAD: The Los Angeles Clippers have signed two of the three first-round selections they made in the National Basketball Association college draft last June.
The Clippers are still negotiating with their first choice, Reggie Williams, the 6-foot-7-inch Georgetown swingman, but yesterday they reached an agreement on a three-year contract with Joe Wolf, a 6-11 forward from North Carolina.

LEAD: A missile fired from Iran exploded next to an elementary school here this morning as pupils filed into the building for classes, and 32 people were killed and 218 wounded, nearly all of them children, officials said.

COSTA RICA LEADER WINS NOBEL PRIZE FOR PEACE PLAN
LEAD: President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica, the driving force behind the regional peace plan signed by five Central American countries two months ago, was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize today.


New Movies Battle for Theaters
LEAD: Dozens of movies are trying to elbow their way into theaters this fall, and the jostling means both peril and opportunity for the film industry.


With Tamil Conflict, Myths Die Out
LEAD: As heavy fighting once again ravages the Jaffna Peninsula of Sri Lanka, forcing people who had just begun to enjoy peace back into precarious shelters, many Sri Lankans and Indians are also witnessing the destruction of myths and the ethnic alignments they supported.


Homes Evacuated as Christmas Toys Burn on Long Island
LEAD: Officials checking the smoldering ruins of the Lexony International Corporation building in Farmingdale, L.I., for poisonous gases.
Christmas-ready plastic toys, dolls and stuffed animals, were destroyed when a fast-moving fire swept through the building early yesterday.
Officials said 2,000 people were evacuated from their homes when noxious smoke from the burning plastic drifted over a residential area.


Dance: Maya, Flamenco
LEAD: THE Mario Maya Flamenco Dance Theater Company is a fine troupe of Spanish dancers.
Yet it is not necessarily seen at its best in New York.


Underwater Volcano Erupts, Shaking Ship of Researchers
LEAD: An undersea volcano in the south-central Pacific Ocean erupted directly beneath a California-based research vessel on Sunday, causing a fearful clamor as large bubbles of steam and gas shook the ship, bursting under her hull and in the surrounding water.


State Judge Says Plant Must Cut Radiation Level
LEAD: A judge ordered the owners of a radium factory in Queens yesterday to comply ''forthwith'' with a state requirement to reduce radiation emissions outside the building to permissible levels.


Atlanta Planning a Dome
LEAD: In a move to keep the Atlanta Falcons from moving out of the city, a group of business and government leaders will announce plans Wednesday to build a $158 million domed stadium in downtown Atlanta.

Prizing Peace, and Promoting It
LEAD: Bernard Shaw once lamented that Nobel Prizes were like life preservers thrown long after the recipients had escaped drowning.
That reproach surely does not apply to this year's Peace Prize.
The award honors, and furthers, the cause of peace in Central America.

LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY


5 Carpenters' Union Leaders Indicted in Extortion
LEAD: Five high-level officials of the carpenters' union were indicted yesterday on charges of extorting more than $100,000 from contractors.


Ready, Set, Taxes!
LEAD: The Internal Revenue Service is spending $7.6 million to send brochures to more than 90 million taxpayers to tell them, in the words of an I.R.S. official, ''why they should start thinking about their taxes earlier than ever before.''


Law Upheld On Disclosure By Landlords
LEAD: New York State's highest court yesterday upheld a New York City law requiring the owners of the city's most valuable residential and commercial buildings to file annual statements of their property's income and expenses.


Developer Says He Will Reduce 59th St. Project
LEAD: Plans for office towers on the western arc of Columbus Circle seemed certain to be scaled back yesterday as the developer, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, said he would reduce the bulk of the buildings to resolve lawsuits against the project.


WINE TALK
LEAD: WHILE grape picking is under way in vineyards, consumers have begun autumn ''cherry picking'' in wine stores.
Cherry-picking is wine-buff jargon for bargain-hunting.
A guide to such browsing is useful, which means it is time to update the Wine Talk vintage chart.

LEAD: Representative Jim Wright, the House Speaker, said today that the awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize to President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica today insured that Congress would not approve the Reagan Administration's request for new aid for the Nicaraguan rebels.


Suns Drop Gondrezick
LEAD: The Phoenix Suns released three players yesterday, including Grant Gondrezick, who averaged 5.5 points a game as a rookie last season and was one of three players indicted last spring in a drug scandal.
The 6-5 guard pleaded guilty to a witness-tampering charge and was sentenced to three years' probation.


Youmans Enters Clinic
LEAD: The Montreal Expos confirmed yesterday that Floyd Youmans had entered a drug rehabilitation clinic, but the team denied the pitcher was forced to do so by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth.
There had been reports that Youmans was threatened with a one-year suspension by the commmissioner if he did not take part in a rehabilitation program.

JULIUS SELIGSON
LEAD: Julius Seligson, the national intercollegiate men's singles tennis champion in 1928 and winner of 65 straight college matches, died yesterday of a malignant melanoma at his home in Westport, Conn.
He was 77 years old.
Mr.
Seligson's streak for Lehigh University ran from 1928 until his final match in 1930, when he was defeated by Cliff Sutter, a sophomore from Tulane, to fail in his bid for an undefeated undergraduate tennis career.

Executive Director Named for President's AIDS Commission
LEAD: President Reagan's AIDS commission, staggered by the recent resignations of the two top panel members and two staff members, today announced the appointment of a new executive director to supervise the staff and its functions.


WALTER BRATTAIN, INVENTOR, IS DEAD
LEAD: Walter H. Brattain, who shared the 1956 Nobel Prize in physics for the invention of the transistor, died yesterday of Alzheimer's Disease in a nursing home in Seattle.
He was 85 years old.


Beck May Retire
LEAD: Barry Beck has scheduled a meeting with reporters in his agent's office this afternoon, at which he is expected to announce his retirement from the Rangers.
Beck, a 30-year-old defenseman, has been plagued by injuries since 1985, particularly to his right shoulder, which was reinjured in an exhibition game early last week.


A Guess on Game at Syracuse
LEAD: Rutgers, having lost to both, is the measuring stick for Saturday's match between Penn State, the perennial Lambert Trophy champion as the best in the East, and Syracuse, which is undefeated after five games for the first time since 1959.


Knicks Still Hoping to Acquire Green
LEAD: The posturing over the future of Sidney Green has stretched to new levels.


Yields Up to 9.323% Set By Puerto Rico Agency
LEAD: The Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority is offering yields of well above 9 percent for new long-term bonds underwritten by Prudential-Bache Securities.


Rates Rise Sharply For Citicorp Paper
LEAD: The surge in short-term interest rates generally in the past week led to increases of nearly half a percentage point at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper yesterday.

LEAD: Miriamne Fields, a student at Columbia University, was joined by a pigeon yesterday as she studied on the steps at Low Memorial Library. (NYT/Keith Meyers)

LEAD: Tandem Computers Inc. said it had agreed to acquire the Atalla Corporation, a privately held company that make transaction systems for financial concerns and retailers.
Terms of the deal were not disclosed.
Atalla, of San Jose, Calif., will operate as a subsidiary of Tandem, a manufacturer based in Cupertino,


HAITIAN CANDIDATE KILLED BY GUNMEN
LEAD: A Haitian presidential candidate was shot to death this morning in front of the police headquarters in Port-au-Prince as he delivered a speech demanding the release of a prisoner, witnesses and diplomats said.


Polish Economic Program Poses Risk to Jaruzelski
LEAD: At a time of considerable economic and political uncertainty, Poland's leadership has thrown its weight behind an ambitious program of economic change that bears broad political risks for the regime of Gen.
Wojciech Jaruzelski.


A Soft Swipe
LEAD: In the supersensitive new politics, negative campaigning is becoming such a touchy area that even the simple citing of an opponent's voting record requires a disclaimer.


Tudor Makes One Run Count
LEAD: His dugout was filled with aching bodies and slumping hitters.
The St.
Louis Cardinals had been handed one run in the sixth game of the National League Championship Series.
And the thought had occurred to John Tudor, the Cardinal pitcher whose job it was to make that run count, that there may not be many more.


Reports of Parasites Rekindle a Debate About Raw Fish
LEAD: ABOUT 10 years ago, Americans began eating significant amounts of sushi.
Ever since, there have been nagging doubts about the wisdom of consuming raw fish - doubts intensified by occasional reports of fish parasites.
Yet America's love affair with sushi has continued unabated.

Giants Wallowing In Anger, Anxiety
LEAD: Anxiety, anger and animosity against the owners were evident in the eyes of most of the 34 Giants who emerged from a meeting here this morning that Robbie Jones described as heated.


Economic Scene; Glum Outlook On Trade Gap
LEAD: AS an indicator of a trend, the August deficit in American trade, to be announced this morning, has little value.
The deficit might rise, as it did in June and July, or it might decline - the most likely scenario.
But whatever the August inning, the outcome of the game should remain the same: The nation's huge deficit in merchandise trade is not likely to shrink much in this decade.


Unesco Leader Almost Wins Enough Votes for Re-election
LEAD: Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow of Senegal, whose tenure as Unesco's Director General has divided the organization, came close to winning a new six-year term today, but still fell three votes short of a majority.


Cronkite Criticizes Rather Over Walkout
LEAD: Walter Cronkite has said that Dan Rather deserved to lose his job for walking off the set of a sports-delayed newscast last month, and that there was no excuse for forcing the network to ''go black'' for six minutes.


Suburban Pioneers Adjust in a Rural Jersey
LEAD: The meadows where dairy cows once grazed and where Sam Einstein spent his boyhood hunting pheasants and Indian arrowheads are filled now with a new housing development.
As its residents forge new ways of life in the countryside, they speed the reshaping of this old farming town.

Mortgage Agency Adopts New Pool
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation yesterday announced its first issue of participation certificates backed by a pool of convertible adjustable-rate mortgages.
The corporation said it was the first of the quasi-Government mortgage agencies to issue securities backed by a pool of such mortgages.


RIGHTS OF CITIZENS AND SOCIETY RAISE LEGAL MUDDLE ON AIDS
LEAD: States around the nation are finding themselves in a legal muddle about how to control the spread of AIDS, and specifically how to balance the civil rights of people with AIDS against the goal of protecting public health.


BankAmerica Sale
LEAD: A group of 26 Japanese banks will sign a final agreement on Friday to buy $250 million in subordinated notes that the BankAmerica Corporation is offering to help rebuild its weakened capital base.
Kenichi Kamiya, president of the Federation of Bankers' Associations of Japan and head of Mitsui Bank Ltd., said the agreement would be signed in London.


A Speedier Chip Finally Gets a Lift
LEAD: WHEN Cray Research Inc. last month canceled a project to develop an advanced supercomputer, the company's stock plummeted.
For companies making gallium arsenide chips, however, the announcement was good news.

Shamrock Offer For Wherehouse
LEAD: Shamrock Holdings Inc. said it is seeking to make a friendly $14.25-a-share takeover of Wherehouse Entertainment Inc., a music and video retailer with 200 outlets.
Shamrock, the Roy E. Disney family's investment company, said it already owns 6.65 percent of 8.5 million Wherehouse shares outstanding.


U.S. and French Plays
LEAD: ''Double Visions: France-U.S.A.,'' a series of play readings and discussions, will begin on Monday at Ubu Repertory Theater, 149 Mercer Street.
The program centers on the works of contemporary French playwrights who have lived in the United States and of contemporary American playwrights who have lived in France.


600 in Gay Demonstration Arrested at Supreme Court
LEAD: Hundreds of gay men and women deliberately subjected themselves to arrest today by attempting to enter the Supreme Court building to protest a 1986 decision upholding a Georgia sodomy law's enforcement against homosexuals.

LEAD: Israel paid millions of dollars to the Rumanian Government over several decades to permit emigration of Jews, according to a senior Rumanian intelligence official who defected in 1978.

LEAD: President Oscar Arias Sanchez said today that he was convinced that his Nobel Peace Prize would greatly improve prospects for the Central American peace accord he wrote and sponsored.

LEAD: President Reagan acknowledged today that Judge Robert H. Bork would almost certainly not win confirmation to the Supreme Court, but he vowed to appoint a new nominee who upsets Democrats ''just as much'' as Judge Bork did.

LEAD: Merrill Lynch &amp; Company bucked the trend of harder times on Wall Street and turned in slightly improved third-quarter results yesterday.

LEAD: The economy's long-ailing industrial sector is rebounding smartly, but there is still no evidence of significant inflationary pressure, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, said today.

LEAD: The Supreme Court, seeking to gauge the extent of students' free speech rights, heard a challenge today to a principal's censorship of a high school newspaper.

LEAD: The old man in the rumpled sport coat smiled when someone stopped him in the lobby of the Minnesota Twins' office to offer congratulations.

He responded briefly, then stepped into a waiting elevator and disappeared behind its doors.

Centennial Exhibition Celebrates Marianne Moore
LEAD: An elegant centennial exhibition that opens at the Grolier Club today celebrates the poetic vision of Marianne Moore, who was born in Kirkwood, Mo., 100 years ago come Nov. 15.
Until her death in 1972, Moore, with her Mary Poppins innocence and wisdom, flowing cape and trademark tricorn hat (''I like the shape - it conceals the defects of the head''), was the unofficial poet laureate of the boroughs in which she lived, wrote and flourished most of her life - in Brooklyn, at 260 Cumberland Street, and in Manhattan, at 35 West Ninth

Music: The Winans, Gospel
LEAD: IT is commonly and falsely assumed that the black gospel music out of which emerged secular ''soul'' in the early 1960's has languished as a revered period genre.
But as the popular Detroit gospel group the Winans demonstrated at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening, there is as much vitality, talent and contemporaneity in today's black church music as in the secular sphere.

B. Jay Becker Dies; A Bridge Champion And Record Holder
LEAD: B. Jay Becker, one of the leading bridge players in the world, died Friday at his home in Flushing, Queens.
He was 83 years old.
Mr.
Becker won two world championships for the Bermuda Bowl as a member of United States teams -against Italy in 1951 and against Sweden in 1953.
He represented the United


BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 14, 1987
LEAD:  COMPANIES  Public Service of New Hampshire moved closer to bankruptcy when its board voted to skip a $37.5 million interest payment due tomorrow.
The missed payment will automatically begin a 30-day grace period after which the company could be declared insolvent.
Public Service has been driven to the brink of insolvency because of its $2.1 billion investment in the Seabrook nuclear power plant, which may be blocked from opening.


Kodak Introduces Disks With Teflon
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company introduced floppy disks coated with Teflon to protect them from spills, smudges or stains.
Floppy disks store computer information, but can easily be damaged.
Kodak said its new Teflon-coated Data Life Plus disk would prevent data loss.
Teflon, created by E. I. du Pont de Nemours &amp;


Pitcher Unable To Move 4 on Base
LEAD: Dave Dravecky, one of the in-season additions to the San Francisco Giants' pitching staff, left no doubt again tonight about his ability from the mound end of the 60 feet 6 inches that separates pitcher from batter.
However, when he stood at the other end with a bat in his hands, he left his ability and his judgment open to serious question.

Safeway Sells Unit; Shift Set at Lucky
LEAD: Safeway Stores Inc., which is based in Oakland, Calif., said today that it had agreed to sell its Oklahoma division to a new company formed by Clayton &amp; Dubilier Inc., a New York-based leveraged buyout firm.
The deal, which is contingent upon the execution of a new labor contract, includes a distribution center, three supply plants and 106 supermarkets in Oklahoma, southern Kansas and Texas.


Security Pacific
LEAD: The Security Pacific Corporation is offering $150 million of 9.55 percent notes due 1989 at a price of 99.954, to yield 9.575 percent, through Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.
The noncallable issue is rated Aa-3 by Moody's and AA by S.&amp;P. and yields about 46 basis points more than Treasury notes with a similar maturity.

LEAD: New York State announced yesterday that it would set aside a 50-bed unit at the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens for homeless people with severe mental illnesses who are hospitalized involuntarily by New York City.

LEAD: A bomb exploded today outside the United States Consulate in this Mediterranean port city, wounding eight Spaniards and seriously damaging the building, the police said.


Body of a Woman Found on S.I. Beach
LEAD: The body of a young woman, wrapped in a rug bound with rope, was found early yesterday on a Staten Island beach along Upper New York Bay, the police reported.

LEAD: Labor Secretary William E. Brock has scheduled a news conference for late this morning to announce he is resigning from President Reagan's Cabinet to be chairman of Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign.

Juilliard Chamber Group
LEAD: The Juilliard Chamber Symphony will play the Faure and Sibelius settings of the Pelleas and Melisande legend in a free concert next Thursday at Alice Tully Hall.
Sixten Ehrling will conduct.
Mozart's Symphony No. 41 (the ''Jupiter'') is also on the program.
Although there is no charge, tickets are required; they may be obtained at the Juilliard Concert Office, 144 West 66th Street, Monday through Friday from 11 A.M.


HERS
LEAD: MOST of my girlfriends happen to be black, smart, ambitious, idealistic, over the age of 30 and professionals.


Texas, to Settle Suit, Will Increase Spending for Mentally Retarded
LEAD: After being found in contempt of court this summer over conditions at its facilities for the mentally retarded, Texas has agreed to a settlement of a 13-year-old lawsuit that will cost the state an estimated $80.6 million over the next three years.


Stuart Cohen for Civil Court Judge
LEAD: Last month's Democratic primary in Manhattan's First Municipal Court District was too close to call: the difference between vote totals for the incumbent, Judge Lester Evens, and the challenger, Stuart Cohen, was smaller than the number of questionable ballots.
That's why registered Democrats go to the polls next Tuesday for a rerun.

HCA Income Climbs 24%
LEAD: The Hospital Corporation of America said today that its third-quarter earnings rose 24 percent, to $66.5 million, or 80 cents a share, up from $53.8 million, or 65 cents a share, a year ago.
Revenue declined to $1.16 billion from $1.24 billion.


U.S. Official Defends Stance on Turmoil in Tibet
LEAD: The leading State Department expert on China today denied charges by lawmakers from both parties that the Administration had taken China's side in the recent unrest in Tibet.


Ballet: Graham's 'Persephone'
LEAD: ''PERSEPHONE,'' Martha Graham's newest work, has the prettiness of a greeting card.
It is not deep, but it is inventive.
The message, entwined in myths of fertility and rebirth, will be familiar to Graham audiences.
Yet there is a great deal of the unfamiliar - in the very choice of music and in the window dressing.

Where $100 Goes a Long Way
LEAD: There have always been questions about how much American foreign aid actually trickles down to the poor.
Too often, it seems the funds disappear into bureaucratic channels, or pockets.
By contrast, private voluntary organizations have built an impressive record of reaching poor people abroad -and doing so with remarkably small amounts of money.

From Far and Near, Designers Flock to a New York 'Saturday'
LEAD: FOUR Japanese designers with three mysterious boxes flew from Tokyo to New York last Wednesday for the start of Designer's Saturday.
They opened their boxes in the Poltronova showroom of the International Design Center, New York, and assembled what turned out to be sinuously curved cast-aluminum chairs with screwdrivers.

LEAD: The State Department has given the Washington office that represents the Palestine Liberation Organization a six-week extension on an order that it be closed, a spokesman said today.

LEAD: John A. Zaccaro was acquitted yesterday of trying to extort a bribe from a cable television company that unsuccessfully sought a franchise in Queens.


Gunmen Kill 5 in Pasco, Wash.
LEAD: Two gunmen walked into an automobile body shop and opened fire with automatic weapons Tuesday evening, killing five men and wounding a sixth, who hid under a vehicle until the assailants left, the police said.


Collectible Crib Quilts: Miniature Artworks
LEAD: THE passion for full-scale American quilts, which has continued apace since the 70's, has spawned an avid interest in crib quilts as well.
Today, the miniature size of crib quilts -generally 30 to 45 inches square -has made them increasingly desirable as wall hangings.
In fact, these miniatures may at times outshine versions of more imposing size.

Emily Mumford, Sociologist Known for Medical Studies
LEAD: Dr.
Emily Mumford, a sociologist known for her work on the effect of psychotherapy in lowering later medical care costs, died of complications of a brain tumor Oct. 3 at her home in Manhattan.
She was 66 years old.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An Oslo dispatch yesterday about the 1987 Nobel Peace Prize misstated the year in which the prize was given to an anti-nuclear physicians' organization.
The group, the International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War, received the prize in 1985.


Opposition Split Alienates Many In South Korea
LEAD: A widening split in the opposition has embittered many South Koreans, who say they resent what they regard as potentially ruinous intransigence by opposition leaders who have failed to agree on a presidential candidate.


DR. GERALD EHRLICH
LEAD: Dr.
Gerald Ehrlich, a former City College professsor and former chief psychologist at Bronx Community College, died of congestive heart failure Oct. 5 at Peekskill (N.Y.) Community Hospital.
He was 75 years old and lived in Putnam Valley, N.Y.

Talking Deals; Latitude Seen In G.M.'s Pact
LEAD: THE labor contract that the General Motors Corporation has tentatively worked out with the United Auto Workers appears to handicap G.M.'s efforts to cut costs because the terms include a moratorium on plant closings.
But a careful reading of the contract and talks with people close to the union suggest that the agreement may be less restrictive than it initially appeared.

Acquisitions Down 37%
LEAD: The number of mergers and acquisitions announced in the third quarter fell 37 percent, to 568, from a record 908 a year ago, W. T. Grimm &amp; Company, the consulting firm, said today.
The company said the total value of announced deals rose 93 percent, to $70.2 billion, from $36.4 billion last year.
An increase in the number of deals valued at more than $1 billion accounted for the higher total value, it said.


Warn AIDS Patients' Partners, Health Official Urges
LEAD: Proposing a sharp break from established policy and state regulations, New York City's top health official said yesterday that physicians and public health authorities should warn the sex partners of people infected with the AIDS virus of their substantial risk of infection.

LEAD: Jesse Barfield, the Toronto Blue Jays' outfielder, underwent arthroscopic surgery yesterday to have a small cartilage tear in his left knee repaired.

Few Models Seen for Los Angeles School Plan

Jazz: Weston Trio
LEAD: Randy Weston's roots are in the music of Duke Ellington and Thelonious Monk, but his music also reflects the years he spent living in Africa.
In traditional African music, rhythms are layered vertically, and each layer of rhythm is given its own specific timbre, its own voice.
This is a difficult concept to translate into ensemble jazz, which uses independent voices to both reinforce and elaborate on a common pulse.

NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1987
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL A3-19  Nicaragua must end its refusal to negotiate a cease-fire with its guerrilla opponents, according to Oscar Arias Sanchez, the President of Costa Rica and the winner of the 1987 Nobel Peace Prize.
Page A1  U.S. strategy in Central America is now based on the expectation that Managua will not negotiate a cease-fire with insurgent leaders, Administration officials say, and could support an effort for contra aid.


Quick Senate Debate on Bork Rejected
LEAD: Republican senators, insisting that they needed time to present a fairer view of Judge Robert H. Bork to the public, today refused repeated requests by the Democratic leadership for a quick debate and vote on President Reagan's Supreme Court nominee.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An obituary of Julius Seligson, the longtime championship tennis player, omitted his survivors yesterday.


Vacuuming Woes
LEAD: SOME of the things Solomon Sumner and Richard Miller have discovered clogging vacuum cleaners: stockings, wine corks, toys, thumbtacks, nails, neckties, Christmas tree decorations, plant leaves, underwear and shoelaces.

CANDIDATE'S DEATH TROUBLES HAITIANS
LEAD: Election officials and other political leaders said today that they believed the killing Tuesday of a presidential candidate was part of a plan by loyalists of the deposed Duvalier regime to intimidate candidates and voters.


Holiday Parking
LEAD: Because of the Jewish holidays of Shemini Atzereth and Simhath Torah, which conclude the harvest festival of Succoth, alternate-side parking will be suspended in New York City today and tomorrow.
Other rules remain in effect.


Q &amp; A
LEAD: Q. During heavy rain, water leaks into our basement and leaves large puddles in the corners.
A waterproofing contractor said to install a drain around the inside of the foundation, and a sump pump to remove the water.
What is your opinion of this drain-pump method?


BUSH OFFENDS CYSTIC FIBROSIS GROUP
LEAD: A chance misstatement by Vice President Bush has demonstrated the phenomenal capacity of high-level Government officials to influence the fortunes of others, even a charitable organization dedicated to helping sick children.


Sears Unit to Close 40 Savings Offices
LEAD: Dean Witter Financial Services Group, a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company, said it would close all 40 Sears Savings Bank branches in Sears stores in California.
Sears Savings Bank would keep its headquarters office in Glendale, Calif.
The 40 branches represent deposits of about $280 million out of the savings bank's total deposit base of $3.9 billion.

LEAD: For the members of the Norwegian Nobel Committee charged with selecting winners of the annual Peace Prize, the criticism and controversy that have so often accompanied the award are an integral part of the job - and perhaps part of the fun.


Chemical New York Has Loss
LEAD: The Chemical New York Corporation, parent company of the Chemical Bank, reported a loss yesterday of $66.4 million in the third quarter.

RJR Nabisco in 19.4% Gain
LEAD: RJR Nabisco Inc. said today that third-quarter earnings rose 19.4 percent, to $320 million, or $1.24 a share, from $268 million, or 97 cents a share, a year ago.
Sales rose 4.6 percent, to $3.83 billion, from $3.66 billion.


Manila Hotel Bomb Wounds 10
LEAD: A bomb exploded today outside one of the capital's most popular hotels, wounding at least 10 people slightly.
Officials ordered extra security at hotels and restaurants to prevent more attacks.

Summit and Ultra Set Bank Merger
LEAD: The Summit Bancorporation said it had agreed to acquire the Ultra Bancorporation of Bridgewater, N.J., in a tax-free exchange of stock valued at $250 million.
The deal, subject to shareholder and regulatory approval, would create New Jersey's fifth-largest bank holding company.
Assets would total $3.9 billion.

MARKETS PLUNGE
LEAD: The nation's trade deficit shrank in August from its record level, but the improvement was only half as much as expected and sent prices sharply lower in the financial markets.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Boxing  Witherspoon Wins by Decision: Tim Witherspoon won a 10-round split decision last night against previously undefeated Mike Williams in a battle of heavyweights in Atlantic City.
It was the second victory for Witherspoon since he lost his World Boxing Association heavyweight title to James (Bonecrusher) Smith last December in a one-round knockout.


New K Mart Team Focuses Marketing
LEAD: Executives at the K Mart Corporation, the second-largest retailer in the world, have always been a bit coy when asked whether the company was trying to overtake Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company as No. 1.
But its announcement yesterday of a new marketing group may be at least one indication that an effort is under way to close the $3 billion gap between them.

Gannett Net Up by 7.6%
LEAD: The Gannett Company today reported a 7.6 percent gain in third-quarter earnings, reflecting continued strength in its newspaper operations.
Net income was $70.5 million, or 44 cents a share, compared with $65.5 million, or 41 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter.
The company's revenues rose 9 percent, to $751.1 million, from $689 million.


Test of Freedom
LEAD: The Reagan Administration has taken an important step to bring American law into line with our professions of faith in freedom.
It has recommended dropping from the immigration laws the sections that exclude aliens because of their beliefs or writings.

The U.N. Today: Oct. 15, 1987
LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY


Chemistry and Physics Nobels Hail Discoveries on Life and Superconductors; 2 Get Nobel for Unlocking Superconductivity Secret
LEAD: With a swiftness that echoed the rush of discovery over the last few months, the Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded yesterday to two scientists in Switzerland whose breakthrough just last year has touched off a torrent of research in the long-dormant field of superconductivity.


U.S. Move: Stress Parley With Rebels
LEAD: Reagan Administration officials said today that they are basing their latest strategy in Central America on the expectation that the Nicaraguan Government will not negotiate a cease-fire with the leaders of the rebels.


PEPSICO PROFIT CLIMBS 25.2%
LEAD: Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings rose 25.2 percent, to $189.9 million, or 72 cents a share, from $151.7 million, or 58 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.

LEAD: President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica, the winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, says Nicaragua's Government must end its refusal to negotiate a cease-fire with rebel guerrilla leaders.


Armand Hammer in Afghan Role
LEAD: Armand Hammer, the American industrialist who has maintained close ties with the Soviet Government since its early days, said today that he was shuttling between the Soviet Union, Pakistan and Afghanistan in hopes of producing a settlement to the Afghan war.


Prefight Rhetoric Pulls No Punches
LEAD: There was name-calling and general nastiness today - a rhetorical club fight, so to speak - in the final news conference preceding Mike Tyson's heavyweight title defense against Tyrell Biggs here Friday.


New Pan Am Plan Asks Big Union Concessions
LEAD: A group of airline experts representing Kirk Kerkorian has presented to a coalition of unions a proposal to take over Pan American World Airways that requires greater concessions from its workers than current management has asked.


Crossing The Line
LEAD: National Football League players who crossed the union's picket lines yesterday.


Auto Sales Fall 33.5% In Period
LEAD: Sales of American-made cars and light trucks declined 33.5 percent in early October, after the end of most of the Big Three auto makers' incentive programs.


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
Danaher Corp., Washington, a maker of automotive products, instrumentation and precision components, named Arthur P. Byrne and John A. Cosentino Jr. to the newly created position of group executive.


Problem in Shuttle Engine
LEAD: One of the three main engines scheduled to power the first space shuttle flight since the shuttle disaster in January 1986 might have sprung a leak in test firing, a spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.
The spokesman said the firing of the engine on Saturday appeared to be normal but that a detailed check of the engine indicated a potential leak in the oxidizer heat exchanger.


AMR Profit Down 27.9%
LEAD: The AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines, said yesterday that it had earned $87.1 million, or $1.41 a share, in the third quarter, down 27.9 percent from $120.8 million, or $1.98 a share, in the period a year ago.

LEAD: IT isn't often that the fate of a sports franchise might rest on one game, but that was the weighty prospect for the San Francisco Giants as they lost the National League pennant last night, 6-0, to the gallant Cardinals.

LEAD: AFTER the army of sales agents moves on to greener territory, the developer of a condominium is often left with an obsolete sales tool: the model apartment.


France Bans Export of A Zola Work
LEAD: The French Minister of Culture, Francois Leotard, said in Paris yesterday that the manuscript of Emile Zola's ''J'Accuse,'' the author's celebrated defense of Capt.
Alfred Dreyfus in 1898, would not be allowed to leave France.
The 39-page letter is the most important document in the Zola family archive, which is to be auctioned by Sotheby's in Monte Carlo on Dec.


Stock Soars on Cable Unit Deal
LEAD: The stock price of American Cablesystems soared more than 60 percent today after the company announced it would be acquired and taken private by its Boston-based competitor, Continental Cablevision Inc., for $481.7 million.

LEAD: A recent conversation here with two writers, Dmitri Volcheck and Arkadi Dzagomoshehenko, and a theater director, Eric Gorashevski, offers a close-up of how glasnost, Mikhail S. Gorbachev's program of ''openness,'' is affecting three people on or beyond the fringes of the Soviet cultural establishment.

Guinness Case Bail at $825,000
LEAD: Gerald Ronson, one of Britain's richest men, was remanded on $:500,000, or $825,000, bail today on eight charges stemming from the Guinness P.L.C. takeover of Distillers P.L.C.


Jacksonville Scouted
LEAD: Bud Adams, the owner of the Houston Oilers, paid a visit yesterday with his wife, Nancy, to Jacksonville, Fla., a city that is attempting to woo the Oilers away from their home in the Astrodome.
The civic leaders of Jacksonville, the home of the Gator Bowl, gave the Adamses a tour of the city, and the main topic of conversation was a $125.8 million offer from the Jacksonville business community to Adams to move his team.


G.O.P. Groups Fight Subpoenas for Records
LEAD: In the first challenge to the authority of the new State Commission on Integrity in Government, New York Republican leaders are resisting subpoenas for their confidential party financial records.


Mitsubishi Motors
LEAD: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation said it had suspended output of four-wheel-drive Pajero vehicles intended for October shipment to the United States because American customs officials had proposed changing the Pajero's classification.
A company spokesman said the Custom House in Long Beach, Calif., had proposed classifying the model as a car rather than as a commercial vehicle.

Republican Missiles
LEAD: On Tuesday Vice President Bush challenged his rivals for the Republican Presidential nomination to support the proposed intermediate-range missile treaty with the Soviet Union.
The challenge put Mr.
Bush in two places he wanted to be: for President Reagan and for arms control.

Fiery Crash in Brooklyn - for Art's Sake
LEAD: A burning truck flying off the 38th Street pier in Brooklyn yesterday during the filming of the finale of ''Troma's War.'' The film, a tongue-in-cheek look at Americans fighting terrorism, is scheduled for release early next year.
It is being produced by Troma Inc. of New York. (NYT/Bill Rhoden)


JAMES A. DWYER
LEAD: James A. Dwyer, a former president of Dwyer Lighterage Inc., a tugboat and barge business in New York Harbor, died Tuesday at the Albany Avenue Nursing Home in Kingston, N.Y.
He was 92 years old.


Chrysler May Add Plant
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation is considering building a stamping plant for its St.
Louis mini-van assembly operations, the trade journal Metalworking News reported in this week's issue.
The journal said the stamping plant would cost between $100 million and $150 million, and would ease the burden on Chrysler's stamping plants in Warren and Sterling Heights, Mich., and in Twinsburg, Ohio.


Argentina Reins In Economy
LEAD: Argentina today announced a series of drastic economic measures, including a wage and price freeze, in the apparent hope of increasing confidence in the beleaguered administration of President Raul Alfonsin.


A.&amp;P. in New Bid For Delchamps
LEAD: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company said that it had offered, for the second time in a year, to acquire an operator of Gulf state supermarkets, Delchamps Inc., in a deal worth about $175 million.
If it can overcome the stated opposition of a major Delchamps shareholders group, the deal would continue the drive by A.&amp;P.


Chemistry and Physics Nobels Hail Discoveries on Life and Superconductors; Three Share Prize for Synthesis of Vital Enzymes
LEAD: Two American researchers and a French scientist were awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry yesterday for wide-ranging research that has included the creation of artificial molecules that can mimic vital chemical reactions of the processes of life.


'Aides' Dropped Over AIDS
LEAD: The Noble School District is dropping the word ''aide'' from job titles for district employees because of anxiety associated with AIDS.
The superintendent, Bill Martin, said Tuesday that he has issued a staff memorandum to replace the word ''aide'' with ''assistant'' in the titles of teacher and library aides.


Northeast Governors Think They're on the Right Track With Turbo Train
LEAD: The trip from Boston's Back Bay to midtown Manhattan is a choice between a 35-minute flight that air and highway traffic can stretch to four and a half hours, and a ride on a train that is almost sure to arrive on schedule as promised by Amtrak - in four and a half hours.

KARPOV BEATS KASPAROV IN 32 MOVES
LEAD: Anatoly Karpov, in a stunning upset, won the second game of the world chess championship match today, defeating the titleholder, Gary Kasparov, after 32 moves.
The 36-year-old Karpov, himself a former world champion, now leads the match by a score of 1 1/2- 1/2 points.

LEAD: Rabbi Menachem Schneerson, head of the Lubavitcher Hasidim, offering a honeycake to a young participant in the celebration of Succoth yesterday at the Lubavitch headquarters in Brooklyn.
About 6,000 people took part in the traditional Jewish celebration of the harvest. (NYT/Alan Zale)


2 Die in Plane Crash; Man Jumps and Lives
LEAD: A passenger apparently leaped from a small airplane as it crashed into a residential backyard, killing two others on board.

Bush Calls for Big Cut in Tax On Individuals' Capital Gains
LEAD: Vice President Bush, detailing the economic agenda he would pursue as President, called today for cuts of nearly half in the maximum capital gains tax for individuals.


Floating Point Gets Chairman
LEAD: Floating Point Systems Inc., a supercomputer maker based in Beaverton, Ore., said that C.N. (Norm) Winningstad, the company's principal founder, had been elected chairman.
He has been vice chairman since October 1986, and also serves as chairman and chief executive of the Lattice Semiconductor Corporation.


Landon Honored in Kansas
LEAD: An honor guard saluting over the flag-draped coffin of Alfred M. Landon in the rotunda of the State Capitol in Topeka.
Hundreds of visitors paid their respects to the former Governor, Presidential candidate and Republican elder statesman who died Monday at the age of 100. (AP)

LEAD: Two more suspects were arrested yesterday and charged with murder in the slaying last month of a midtown Manhattan nighclub operator, the police said.

LEAD: A police officer responding to an emergency was killed yesterday when his patrol crashed into a telephone pole, the police said.


Film Festival Head Asked to Resign
LEAD: The longtime director of the New York Film Festival, Richard Roud, has been asked to resign, according to Alfred Stern, the president of the Film Society of Lincoln Center.


Budget Aide Moves
LEAD: Edwin L. Dale Jr., top press aide at the Office of Management and Budget since David A. Stockman became budget director at the start of the Reagan Administration, is moving out.
Mr.
Dale, once a reporter for The New York Times, is to become a counselor to C. William Verity, whom the Senate confirmed Tuesday as Secretary of Commerce to succeed the late Malcolm Baldrige.

Jesse Jackson has taken Israel to task for selling arms to South Africa, accusing the the Israeli Government in a magazine article of being ''in complicity with the South African regime.''

LEAD: The Western Auto Supply Company said it had tentatively agreed to gain control of NTW Inc., a tire retailer that is operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings.
NTW, based in Dale City, Va., would be the second tire retailer acquired this year by Western Auto, an automotive supplies retailer and wholesaler based here.

LEAD: Dick Van Arsdale, the first player chosen by the Phoenix Suns in their 1968 expansion draft and interim head coach for the team's final 26 games last season, was named yesterday as the club's vice president.
The team was sold Monday for $44.5 million to a group headed by Jerry Colangelo, the general manager throughout the Suns' history.

LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's emphasis on domestic reform is the most important new fact in East-West relations.

Republicans Join the Roster Of Arizona Governor's Foes
LEAD: In his first 10 months as Governor of Arizona, Evan Mecham's rhetorical style and conservative politics have provoked sharp controversy among blacks, homosexuals and other minorities here.
Along with many Democrats, they have mounted an ambitious campaign to recall the maverick Republican from office.


Yeager Flight 40 Years Old
LEAD: Chuck Yeager's hometown today celebrated the 40th anniversary of his historic flight that broke the sound barrier.
On Oct. 14, 1947, Mr.
Yeager became the first man to break the barrier, about 700 miles an hour.
Today, Mr.
Yeager returned the salute in a jet fighter, taking a few low passes and a parting barrel roll overhead.


Colgate Announces Cutbacks
LEAD: The Colgate-Palmolive Company yesterday announced several actions it would take in an effort to increase profitability, decentralize decision making and focus on its consumer products business.


U.S., With U.N. Files, Tracks Down Nazi Suspect
LEAD: The United States Justice Department has for the first time used the archives of the United Nations War Crimes Commission to track down and charge an American citizen accused of war crimes, according to officials involved.


Destination Baghdad
LEAD: State Department officials said yesterday that, for the first time ever, a woman was about to be named as the United States ambassador to a Middle Eastern country.


5 Children Who Prefer Foster Parents to Mother Seek Court's Help
LEAD: Five children are being held hostage by state officials who dragged them from a foster home they loved in order to force an unwanted reunion with an abusive and disturbed mother, the children's lawyer has told the Iowa Supreme Court.

Hudson Valley Site to Be Dropped for A-Smasher
LEAD: The Cuomo administration, bowing to opposition in the mid-Hudson Valley, will withdraw its proposal to locate the Federal Super Collider project near Wallkill in Orange County, government officials said today.


Astros' Wagner Quits
LEAD: When Dick Wagner, the president and general manager of the Houston Astros, submitted his resignation yesterday to John McMullen, the owner, Wagner became major league baseball's third chief front-office executive to vacate his position in the last 10 days.
Had he not resigned, it appeared he would have suffered the fate of Hank Peters of the Baltimore Orioles and Bill Bergesch of the Cincinnati Reds, general managers who were dismissed.

LEAD: Anthony R. Ameruso, the former New York City Transportation Commissioner who was to begin the first of 16 weekends at a Rikers Island jail tomorrow for a perjury conviction, was granted a stay of the sentence yesterday by an appeals court judge in Manhattan.

Slaney Returns Jan. 23
LEAD: Mary Slaney has decided to begin her comeback Jan. 23 at the Pacific Northwest Bell Indoor meet in Portland, Ore.
Slaney was ranked first in the world at 1,500 and 3,000 meters in 1985, but has not been in a major competition since then.
She took a year off for the birth of her child, Ashley, and is recovering from Achilles' tendon surgery last June.


N.F.L. NEGOTIATORS NEAR AGREEMENT
LEAD: The chief negotiators for the owners and the players came close yesterday to reaching an agreement on how to end the 23-day-old strike against the National Football League.


Cardinals Win Right to Face Twins in the World Series
LEAD: Jose Oquendo of the Cardinals leaping onto a pack of his teammates after they beat the Giants last night in St.
Louis.
Oquendo's three-run homer helped propel the Cardinals to a 6-0 victory that gave them the National League pennant.
The World Series opens Saturday in Minnesota.

LEAD: A two-alarm fire in Woodhaven, Queens, destroyed five houses and left 12 families homeless yesterday, fire officials said.

City Hospitals Overcrowded, Officials Say
LEAD: New York City's municipal and voluntary hospitals are suddenly overloaded, with emergency rooms backed up, hundreds of patients awaiting beds and ambulances being diverted from one institution to another, officials testified yesterday.

LEAD: An Iranian gunboat fired on a tanker today, shipping officials reported, and Iraq said its warplanes raided a ship near Iran's main oil terminal in the northern Persian Gulf.

LEAD: The General Assembly overwhelmingly adopted a resolution today that deplores the Soviet-backed Vietnamese occupation of Cambodia and demands Vietnam's withdrawal from that nation.

Austrian Bid on Trade
LEAD: Austria's Foreign Minister, Alois Mock, said today that his nation wanted ''full participation'' in the European Community's tariff-free internal market without formally joining the trade bloc.
Mr.
Mock spoke at a news conference during a visit to the Netherlands.
The European bloc's 12 nations will deregulate all internal trade by 1992.


Fokker Stock Falls
LEAD: Shares in N.V.
Fokker, the Dutch aircraft maker, fell sharply on the Amsterdam Stock Exchange on news of major cash problems and costly delays in the introduction of two new aircraft.
The stock, barred from trading Tuesday when the company announced it was seeking extra cash from the Government and banks, sold today for as low as 37.70 guilders, or $18.43, down more than one-third from Monday's closing price.

Nuggets Sign Moore
LEAD: Andre Moore, Denver's top draft pick, signed with the Nuggets and began practicing at their training camp yesterday.
The 6-foot-8-inch, 215-pound forward from Loyola of Chicago had threatened earlier this week, through his agent, George Andrews, to play this season in Europe if he could not come to terms with the Nuggets.


Tokyo Journal; Sweet Dreams of a Home and the Sour Awakening
LEAD: For more than 25 years, Japanese have talked of ''mai homu,'' an expression adapted from ''my home'' that became a symbol of how far Japan had come from postwar poverty.
But because of soaring land prices, young Japanese in the nation's capital have all but given up hope of ever owning a home.

Deep Spending Cuts Forecast In '88 Under New Budget Law
LEAD: Military programs in the 1988 budget will have to be cut by more than 10 percent and domestic spending by almost 9 percent if $23 billion in automatic spending cuts are put into effect this year, the Congressional Budget Office said today.


DR. CARL RICHARD WISE
LEAD: Dr.
Carl Richard Wise, a former medical officer of Columbia University and retired assistant vice president of Presbyterian Hospital, died Wednesday at the Brandon Woods nursing home in South Dartmouth, Mass.
He was 79 years old and lived in Somers, N.Y.

U S Sprint Plans To Cut 2% of Jobs
LEAD: The U S Sprint Communications Corporation, the struggling long-distance phone carrier owned by the GTE Corporation and United Telecommunications Inc., said it planned to cut 2 percent of its 13,500 employees, primarily through attrition, as part of a major reorganization.

STILL NO TREATY, SHULTZ DECLARES
LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that a treaty with the Soviet Union eliminating medium- and shorter-range missiles ''isn't buttoned up yet'' and that a summit meeting should be postponed if unexpected obstacles prevented the conclusion of the accord.


AUCTION
LEAD: TWO large white diamonds of exceptional color and clarity are the most important stones among hundreds of gems to be auctioned Monday through Wednesday at Sotheby's and Christie's.
The sales will offer works estimated by the auction houses to bring about $60 million - the highest total ever for any three-day period of jewelry sales.

Early this morning, Mrs.
Cangialosi gave birth to five of them.

LEAD: In flat tones that contrasted sharply with the graphic scene he described, a young black man testified yesterday that 10 white youths wielding a baseball bat and other weapons confronted him and two other blacks in what the authorities say was the start of the Howard Beach racial assault.

It was made by Paul J. Massey Jr. of Coldwell Banker Commercial Real Estate Services, not by Bert Meers of LaSalle


Retail Sales Down 0.4% in September
LEAD: Retail sales fell by four-tenths of 1 percent in September after a strong summer, the Government said today.
Economists said the weakness was likely to continue as debt-laden consumers cut back spending.

Film: Nolte in 'Weeds'
LEAD: THE nicest bunch of guys you could ever hope to meet turn up inside San Quentin at the start of ''Weeds,'' which at first has the look of a prison drama.
And Nick Nolte makes quite an entrance, appearing in the film's first scene as a would-be suicide who leaps from a balcony, breaks both his wrists and then tries hard to hang himself in the scene after that.


Baby Sitter Charged in Death
LEAD: The police charged a baby sitter today in the Oct. 7 death of a 2-year-old boy who they said was left unattended and ran into the path of a school bus.
The sitter, Geraldine Clark, 42 years old, was charged with risk of injury to a minor and operating a day-care center without a license, the police said.

LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times.
Stars are followed by the date of original publication.
Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An Oslo dispatch on Wednesday about the awarding of the 1987 Nobel Peace Prize misidentified one member of the prize committee.
He is the Rev.
Dr.
Gunnar J. Staalsett, general secretary of the Lutheran World Federation.
He is not a former head of the World Council of Churches.


Two Fast Colts in Champagne
LEAD: Now is the time of the 2-year-olds, and Belmont Park's final Saturday of racing tomorrow will feature a pair of Grade I stakes races at a mile that should clarify the shape of things to come.


Spinnato to Leave, Koch Says
LEAD: Mayor Koch said yesterday that Fire Commissioner Joseph E. Spinnato would soon be leaving his job as head of the Fire Department.


Toddler Trapped in a Texas Well Cries and Sings as Rescuers Dig
LEAD: A frightened toddler trapped for more than a day 22 feet down an abandoned well talked to her mother and cried today as rescuers pounded through solid rock with jackhammers.

Cannon Falls Short
LEAD: Cannon Group Inc. said an $11.7 million interest payment to two sets of bondholders would go unpaid for now.
However, the financially troubled movie maker said it expected to pay the interest before a 30-day default period lapses.
Last week, Cannon appeared to have obtained the cash to stave off a default on its debt payments.


Harvard Criticizes Book On Its Business School
LEAD: Lawyers have briefed faculty members of the Harvard Business School about libel law as part of a counterattack on a new book that paints an unflattering portrait of the school and its faculty, people at the school said yesterday.


Hughes Contracts
LEAD: The Hughes Aircraft Company, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, said it had received three contracts totaling $766 million from the Defense Department.
The company said the largest of the three, a $495 million contract, calls for Hughes to produce nearly 3,300 thermal imaging systems and 1,560 laser range finder units plus spare parts for the Army's M1 Abrams battle tank over the next five years.

The 19-year-old shortstop was placed on probation in January after pleading no contest to battery and resisting arrest during an incident involving Gooden and Tampa police officers in December.

Walbro-UIS Accord
LEAD: The Walbro Corporation, a maker of engine fuel systems based in Cass City, Mich., said today that UIS Inc. had agreed to drop a hostile takeover bid it began five weeks ago in return for the right to distribute Walbro's electric fuel pumps.
UIS, a privately held concern in New York City, also agreed to sell half its holdings of Walbro stock to Walbro for $25.50 a share, $2 less than UIS had offered for them.


INSIDE
LEAD:  British Furor Over Gun Laws





Medicare Tax Cap Is Target
LEAD: Democratic tax writers in the Senate today proposed making all of an employee's wages subject to the Medicare portion of the Social Security payroll tax.
At present, the 1.45 percent hospital insurance tax, paid by both employees and employers, is imposed only on the first $43,800 of an employee's annual wages.


POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
LEAD: Randy Weston, Mikell's, 769 Colum-bus Avenue, at 97th Street (864-8832).
Randy Weston is a nomad.
As a youngster, he traveled by subway, accompanying Thelonious Monk to house parties, studying the master's playing and awaiting his own turn at the keyboard.
He gave some of the first concerts tracing the evolution of jazz from African sources, which led to a mid-60's African tour and a period of residence in Morocco.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 407 money market mutual funds grew $1.16 billion, to $247.18 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 107 institutional funds fell $30.5 million, to $65.08 billion.
The 207 general purpose funds rose $763.2 million, to $74 billion.

About Real Estate; In Connecticut, a Home Design Contest
LEAD: When landowners consider selling tracts near their homes, their business goals may be in conflict with a desire to preserve their environment.
Reconciling the conflict may be especially difficult in an area with an unspoiled rural character where most of the residents want it to be retained.


U.S. Companies Want Their Tankers Protected
LEAD: Worried that their oil tankers are now more susceptible to attacks by Iran, American companies owning or chartering ships in the Persian Gulf that fly foreign flags have asked the Reagan Administration to consider protecting them as it does American-flagged Kuwaiti tankers.


Company Agrees to Cleanup Of Radium Plant in Queens
LEAD: A radium-supply company in New York City said yesterday that while its radioactive plant in Queens posed no ''current'' public health risk, it was prepared to meet with government agencies to devise a way to close and decontaminate the 33-year-old building ''as quickly as possible.''

A Complex Trade Gap
LEAD: Although the raw numbers show little improvement in the nation's trade deficit, Reagan Administration officials and other analysts paint a more more optimistic picture.
They note, for instance, that the import totals have been swollen by price increases that conceal an underlyingshift favorable to the United States.


Psychics Meet Wall Street
LEAD: An excursion boat called the Dolley Madison became a ship of seers Wednesday night as 120 young professionals from Wall Street, Madison Avenue and Seventh Avenue signed on for what was billed as a three-hour psychic business cruise.
Some said it was no coincidence that the Dow Jones industrial average had plunged 95.46 points a few hours before.

How We've Corrupted Our NATO Allies
LEAD: To the Editor:


Study Sees Tough Battle For Swing Vote in South
LEAD: Voters in the South who helped elect and re-elect Ronald Reagan to the Presidency but also helped the Democrats retake control of the Senate last year show signs of voting Republican in substantial numbers in the 1988 Presidential election, a major new study said today.


No Excuse Not to Register
LEAD: Most New Yorkers readily express their outrage at political corruption and misspent tax dollars.
Far fewer follow through at the ballot box: fully 40 percent of the city's five million eligible voters don't bother to register.
In Queens, less than 55 percent sign up to vote.
Mayor Koch deserves praise for a new drive to improve the record.


EXPERIMENTAL WORKS AND CLASSICS IN THEATERS
LEAD: Outside the Times Square-Theater Row axis, Chelsea has the highest density of theater activity of any New York neighborhood.
The area is notable especially for performance spaces that present quality dance and avant-garde performance.


A.T.&amp;T. Executive To Head Data Unit
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has granted Vittorio Cassoni what he has been seeking: his own sales force to sell the company's computers.

STAGE: A MUSICAL, 'LATE NITE COMIC'
LEAD: ''LATE NITE COMIC,'' the new Brian Gari-Allan Knee musical that opened last night at the Ritz Theater, is the first musical comedy in which the hero longs to be Rodney Dangerfield - and in which the heroine dreams about dancing at the Metropolitan Opera House, rather than, for example, with the New York City Ballet.


Wherehouse Veto
LEAD: Wherehouse Entertainment Inc., a 200-store music, video and software retailer, rejected a $121.5 million takeover bid from Shamrock Holdings Inc., saying the company can achieve ''higher value'' by remaining independent.
Shamrock, meanwhile, said it had increased its stake in Wherehouse to 10.17 percent, from 6.65 percent.

LEAD: OUT ON THE RIM. By Ross Thomas. 314 pages. Mysterious Press. $17.95.


Biggs Sees Signs of an Upset
LEAD: Not long ago, from a speeding car on the outskirts of this city, Tyrell Biggs saw a billboard with his name and that of the heavyweight champion, Mike Tyson, in monumental letters. ''TYSON-BIGGS,'' it said.
In that automobile, as he focused on TYSON-BIGGS, Biggs did some subliminal editing so that what he registered as the car sped by was: TY BIG


No Need for Regulation, F.A.A. Chief Tells Panel
LEAD: The head of the Federal Aviation Administration testified today that despite a ''crisis of public confidence'' in air safety, he did not believe regulation should be reimposed on the industry for safety reasons.


Pickens Loses Newmont Plea
LEAD: A state court ruled today that an investment group led by T. Boone Pickens Jr. cannot stop Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C., a British company, from using its recently acquired controlling interest in the Newmont Mining Corporation to block Mr.
Pickens's takeover bid.


Diner's Journal
LEAD: A ROUSING new production called Encore, Encore has opened in the Broadway theater district.
Housed in a dark stage set pierced by pinpoint lighting aimed at red carnations, this six-week-old venture is turning out some splendid contemporary American food at relatively moderate prices.


Brock Will Leave Cabinet Nov. 1 To Join Dole's Presidential Effort
LEAD: Labor Secretary William E. Brock announced today that he would leave President Reagan's Cabinet on Nov. 1 to run Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign, saying Mr.
Dole's ''extraordinary personal leadership'' and his appeal to independent voters made him the most formidable Republican candidate for the 1988 election.

AIDS VIRUS FOUND SLOWER TO SPREAD
LEAD: The spread of the AIDS virus has slowed dramatically among homsexual men in San Francisco, according to preliminary results of a blood-testing program by the Federal Government.


RISKY WORKS FROM STELLA AT THE MUSEUM OF MODERN ART
LEAD: THE first thing to be said about ''Frank Stella: 1970-1987'' at the Museum of Modern Art is that it is a masterpiece of presentation.
Not even the dungeonlike rooms to which the museum consigns its temporary exhibitions can spoil it, and what is waiting for us at the bottom of the escalator is an hour of euphoric buffeting that left this visitor amused, fortified and exhilarated.


Smoke-Free Places At Federal Offices Termed Inadequate
LEAD: Federal agencies have failed to adopt policies that adequately separate nonsmoking employees from those who smoke, according to a federally commissioned report released today.


Film: 20th 'Tournee of Animation'
LEAD: AS Mondrian-like bars of color race up and down walls, and Matisse-inspired dancers sail across the screen, it becomes clear that the ''20th International Tournee of Animation'' is not a kiddy cartoon festival.
An annual compilation of the best short animated films from around the world may sound hokey or stuffy, but this year's selections are stylish and sophisticated.

Merrill TV Deal
LEAD: The United Broadcasting Corporation said it had agreed to sell its three television stations for about $114 million to a fast-growing communications company backed by Merrill Lynch &amp; Company.
The stations being acquired by ML Media are KARK, an NBC affiliate in Little Rock; KDBC, a CBS affiliate in El Paso, Tex., and WTOK, an ABC affiliate in Meridian, Miss.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Tennis  Becker Struggles to Gain: Boris Becker of West Germany, the defending champion, moved into the quarterfinals of the $345,000 Australian indoor championship in Sydney yesterday, beating Sammy Giammalva of the United States, 6-3, 6-4.
Becker, seeded second, had some difficulty coping with the powerful and accurate returns of Giammalva and had to vary his play throughout the 41-minute first set.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article about the trade deficit yesterday, as well as a stock market report in Business Day and an accompanying chart, misstated the ranking of Wednesday's 95.46-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average.
In percentage terms, the 3.81 percent loss was the 125th-largest decline in the 73 years that the average has been kept.

Sampson Signs
LEAD: After spending half the regular season injured and most of the summer talking about testing the free-agent market, Ralph Sampson signed a six-year agreement with the Houston Rockets yesterday that will pay him $12 million.
The Rockets now have the Twin Towers under long-term contracts.
Akeem Olajuwon signed a 12-year contract last season that will pay him an average of $2.5 million a year.


A Million-Contract Day
LEAD: For the first time in the history of the Chicago Board of Trade, more than a million futures and options contracts were traded during a single session, the exchange said today.
The record-breaking day came Wednesday, when 1,031,714 contracts changed hands, surpassing the previous mark of 918,411 contracts set April 9.


Top-Secret Plane Is Said to Crash; Air Force Confirms Death of Pilot
LEAD: A Stealth aircraft, designed to elude radar, crashed Wednesday night at an Air Force base in Nevada, Government officials said today.


Marconi Contract
LEAD: Marconi Communications P.L.C., a subsidiary of the General Electric Company of Britain, said it had received an initial development contract from the United States Navy worth more than $450 million.
The contract, which will be worked on an equal basis with the Rockwell International Corporation's Collins Defense Communications Systems division, is for the development of a high-frequency anti-jam communications system.
