REV. WILLIS A. BAXTER
LEAD: The Rev.
Willis A. Baxter, pastor of Christ's First Presbyterian Church in Hempstead, L.I., from 1951 until his retirement in 1974, died of cancer of the liver Sunday at the Lehigh Valley Hospital Center in Allentown, Pa.
He was 79 years old and lived in Orefield, Pa.


DAVID DELAHANTY
LEAD: Brother David Delahanty, president of Lewis University in Romeoville, Ill., a private institution run by the Christian Brothers, died of cancer Tuesday at the De La Salle Hall of Lincroft, N.J., a Christian Brothers medical facility.
He was 52 years old.
Brother Delahanty had been president of Lewis since 1982.

LEAD: With Bob Sauve, one of the two regulars, out with a separated left shoulder, the Devils are playing musical chairs with their goaltenders.
Craig Billington was brought up Monday from the team's top affiliate, the Utica Devils of the American Hockey League, to back up Alain Chevrier in Wednesday night's 3-1 victory over Hartford.

U.S. Rules on Ex-Judge's Prison Term
LEAD: A former State Supreme Court Justice in Queens, who has served 19 months of a five-year Federal prison term for taking bribes to fix cases in his court, must serve at least three years before becoming eligible for parole, the United States Parole Commission has ruled.


American Symphony
LEAD: The American Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Jose Serebrier, is to perform works by Shostakovich, Mussorgsky and Ravel and the premiere of Morton Gould's ''Flares and Declamations,'' Sunday at 3 P.M. in Carnegie Hall.
A preconcert recital at 2 P.M. is to be given by Ben Holt, baritone.
Tickets are $6 to $21.


Can the AIDS Panel Now 'Pull It Together'?
LEAD: President Reagan's AIDS commission is off to a stumbling, acrimonious start, raising disturbing questions as to what has gone wrong and what can still be accomplished.

Booties and Jobs: A Club to Help Young Fathers
LEAD: There's a lot of fun stuff for a 17-year-old like Alex Fernandez to do at the Y. He enjoys shooting hoops and lifting weights, and he likes the Teen Fathers club.
It's a bunch of regular guys, and you can talk to Manny Cardona, the leader, about your feelings.


Russians See Moscow Vs. Washington on TV
LEAD: Millions of Soviet television viewers woke up this morning to hear their country portrayed as the world's worst violator of human rights in an unusual two-hour broadcast that broke a bit of new ground for glasnost.


Uganda Leader Awaited
LEAD: President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, who assumed power almost two years ago after leading a five-year resistance movement from the bush, is expected to arrive Saturday for a three-day private visit, the first visit to Washington by a Ugandan head of state, according to Ambassador Elizabeth Bagaaya Nyabongo.

New Reagan Policy to Cut Benefits For the Aged, Blind and Disabled
LEAD: The Reagan Administration has adopted a new policy that will reduce welfare benefits for many elderly, blind and disabled people who receive free food, shelter, firewood or winter clothing from churches and charitable organizations.

LEAD: The Soviet Union announced today that it was paying all its outstanding debts to the financially troubled United Nations, including $197 million for peacekeeping operations it has long refused to support.

The Hypocrisy Industry
LEAD: There is such a large measure of hypocrisy, falsehood and double-dealing in the relations among nations that we hardly notice when one more case crops up.
That's life, so just walk on by.


Royals Changes
LEAD: Four coaches, including Hal McRae, who late last season passed up an offer to become manager of the Kansas City Royals and the fourth black manager ever in the major leagues, will not return to the Royals as batting coach in 1988.
The pitching coach, Gary Blaylock, the third-base coach, Jose Martinez, and the first-base coach, Joe Jones, will also leave.


Corrections
LEAD: A chronology on Wednesday recounting recent events in the Sri Lanka conflict misstated the month in which Sri Lanka and India signed an accord on Tamil autonomy and Indian peacekeeping forces began to land in northern Sri Lanka.
The events occurred in July.


Queen, Expressing Sadness, Accepts End to Rule Over Fiji
LEAD: Queen Elizabeth accepted the end of more than a century of British sovereignty over Fiji on Thursday, expressing sadness at the military takeover of power in the South Pacific nation.


Mafia Runs Fulton Fish Market, U.S. Says in Suit to Take Control
LEAD: Federal prosecutors filed a lawsuit yesterday seeking to seize control of the Fulton Fish Market in lower Manhattan, declaring that it is dominated by the Mafia.


CHELSEA: WHERE THE AVANT-GARDE RUBS SHOULDERS WITH OLD NEW YORK
LEAD: CHELSEA has perfected one of the great tricks of cultural geography: how to hide a 75-square-block neighborhood on the edge of midtown Manhattan and Greenwich Village.
For years, the area has been touted as ''up and coming,'' yet, to the relief of many longtime residents, it has remained in the shadows of its more glittery neighbors.

The Public's Right to Speedier Justice
LEAD: The bicentennial of the Constitution and the attention focused on Judge Robert H. Bork's Supreme Court nomination have given us reason to look once again at the state of the judiciary as a whole.
On this subject, however, debate has been overly intellectual and rarified.
We have avoided the critical problems that plague participants in the legal system - judges, lawyers and litigants.

Their careers.

Art: 1980's History on Canvas, in 'Morality Tales'
LEAD: IF ''Morality Tales: History Painting in the 1980's'' sets out to praise contemporary history painting, the exhibition may end up burying it.
In traditional history painting, every detail is meticulously, often overly, planned.
The show at the Grey Art Gallery is sloppy in concept, selection and execution.

LEAD: Nobody in the National League has experienced anything like the Dome.
That's the Metrodome, home of the Minnesota Twins.
If there's one factor that could give the Twins an edge in the World Series, that's it.


Santa Fe Receives Bids for Southern Pacific Unit
LEAD: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation received several bids yesterday for its Southern Pacific Transportation Corporation, including one from the railroad's employees.


Mandatory Retirement Age For Elected Judges Is Upheld
LEAD: The State Court of Appeals today upheld New York State's law requiring elected judges to retire at age 70.


Film: Brazilian 'Vera'
LEAD: ''VERA,'' the first feature film by a new young Brazilian director named Sergio Toledo, is about an unhappy young woman, reared in a Sao Paolo orphanage, who becomes convinced she is a man inhabiting a female body.
The tone of the film is serious, matter-of-fact, even-tempered.


British Labor Is Bogged
LEAD: The rule of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has become so firm, so unshakable that even some Tory supporters are coming to bemoan ''the lack of any real opposition.''


Film: Christo, in 'Islands'
LEAD: ''ISLANDS'' offers, among other things, a case history of the politics of esthetics, the case being Christo, the artist whose fancy it is to swathe large areas in fabrics of various hues.
Albert Maysles, Charlotte Zwerin and David Maysles put their lightweight cameras and sound equipment to humorous use as they accompanied Christo into lobbying sessions with the West German Social Democratic leader Willy Brandt (about covering the Reichstag), with the Mayor of Paris, Jacques Chirac, who has since also become Prime Minister (about covering the Pont Neuf), and with


Celtics Look at King
LEAD: Bernard King, the Knicks' free agent who has played only six games in the last two seasons because of an injured knee, has passed a physical examination with the Boston Celtics.
Dr.
Arnold Scheller, Boston's team doctor, rated King's surgically reconstructed knee ''good to good plus.'' But before the Celtics can offer King an offer sheet, they must do some creative financing to get under the salary limit.


W.R. Grace Profit Soars
LEAD: W. R. Grace &amp; Company said yesterday that its profit soared more than ninefold in the third quarter to $41.5 million, or 97 cents a share, from $4.3 million, or 10 cents a share, a year earlier.
Third-quarter revenue rose 21.8 percent, to $1.1 billion, from $903.1 million a year earlier.
Lower interest expenses, favorable tax adjustments and improved performances by its specialty chemicals, natural resources and general business units all contributed to the improvement, the company said.


Iran Missile Hits A Gulf Tanker Owned in U.S.
LEAD: An Iranian missile struck an American-owned tanker in Kuwaiti waters today, causing a huge explosion and setting the tanker ablaze, the Pentagon said.
But the Reagan Administration ruled out a response because the ship was not flying the American flag and was not in international waters.


Mile-Square Reef Is Begun
LEAD: The building of the nation's biggest man-made rock reef, to be spread over a mile-square section of ocean bottom, began Wednesday.
Biologists said the reef, to be completed in about 10 days, would reestablish the Santa Monica Bay as a thriving fish breeding ground.
Tractors began shoving quarry rock brought by barge from Santa Catalina Island into the sea a mile off Will Rogers State Beach.


Film: 'Blue Monkey,' Larva Tale
LEAD: ''BLUE MONKEY'' isn't much more than a standard angry-larva story, but it has been cleverly directed by William Fruet, who knows how to give it a new look.
To be sure, what happens in the film is essentially familiar, as a slimy little abomination appears, grows, hatches and goes on to terrorize everyone it meets.


Rates Up In Wild Trading
LEAD: After a day of wild gyrations, short- and long-term interest rates moved higher yesterday as the financial markets remained fearful about the effects of a weaker dollar.


Burkino Faso Leader Ousted In Coup Led by Chief Adviser
LEAD: A group led by the chief adviser of President Thomas Sankara of Burkino Faso declared him a ''a traitor to the revolution'' today and seized the Government, the West African nation's official radio announced.


Shortage of Housing Keeps Children in Foster Care

Philip Morris Widens Profit
LEAD: The Philip Morris Companies, producer of Marlboro cigarettes, Miller beer, Oscar Mayer foods and Post cereals, said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings climbed 21.4 percent on an 9.3 percent revenue gain.
Net income rose to $502 million, or $2.11 a share, from $414 million, or $1.74 a share, a year before.

Seabrook Utility
LEAD: New Hampshire's largest power company skipped a $37 million debt payment today, as expected.
Public Service Company of New Hampshire directors met to discuss possible bankruptcy protection.
A spokesman, John Cavanagh, refused to comment on the meeting but said the directors did not decide to seek voluntary protection immediately under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

Aftermath of Milwaukee Fire That Left Six Dead
LEAD: Police officials outside the burned house on the city's North Side where an early morning fire Thursday left six children dead.
Officials said that an electric space heater may have sparked the blaze.
Twelve people died in another house fire in Milwaukee last month.
The City Council yesterday approved an ordinance that would make owners of buildings with one or two units responsible for providing smoke detectors.

LEAD: Why is it that healthful, nutritious food, the so-called spa cuisine, seldom tastes good?
Most of the time this food, designed to mimic what is served at many health spas, is simply bland and dry.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  FOOTBALL  Hoosiers Edge Gophers: Dave Schnell, the Indiana quarterback, scored two touchdowns last night to lift Indiana to an 18-17 Big Ten victory over previously unbeaten Minnesota.
The game was played in Minneapolis.
Anthony Thompson added 160 rushing yards, helping Indiana, 5-1 over all and 3-0 in the conference, take sole possession of first place in the Big Ten.

LEAD: For a long time, just a few groups dominated the small quartet scene, many of them European or at least steeped in the Central European tradition.
Now, several young American ensembles with a different outlook on the same repertory have begun to join the standard-bearers, sharing prominent spots on major concert series and winning contracts with the principal record companies.

Domenic Di Clerico, An Ex-Union Official
LEAD: Domenic Di Clerico, a former president of a transportation union local, shot and killed himself Monday while playing Russian roulette with a .38-caliber postol, the Philadelphia police said.
He was 64 years old.
Mr.
Di Clerico was found by his son John on the floor of his basement apartment in Philadelphia, the police said.

Recital: Vladimir Krainev
LEAD: In several ways, though not necessarily the most important ones, Vladimir Krainev is an extraordinary pianist.
Like many other Soviet musicians, he remains relatively unknown in this country, despite having won the Gold Medal in Moscow's prestigious Tchaikovsky Competition 17 years ago.
Mr.
Krainev, now 43 years old, performed works by Chopin, Ravel, Scriabin and Prokofiev before a small audience in Town Hall Wednesday evening.

LEAD: A concert of Italian Baroque vesper music will be presented today at 8 P.M. at the Middle School in Hudson, N.Y., in Columbia County by the Hudson Valley Choral Society of the Clarion Concerts Orchestra.
Admission: $7.50.
Information: (518) 325-3847.

LEAD: The Lear Siegler Holdings Corporation said it had agreed to sell three aerospace units for $97 million to the BFM Aerospace Corporation, a new company whose principals include Robert M. Bass, the Texas financier.
The units are the Lear Siegler Romec Corporation of Elyria, Ohio, and the Lear Siegler Energy Products Corporation and the Lear Siegler Transport Dynamics Corporation, both of Santa Ana, Calif.

LEAD: Administration officials say intelligence has established that the Stinger missile parts found on an Iranian attack boat in the Persian Gulf this month were part of a batch supplied by the United States to Afghan guerrillas, who lost them to Iranian forces in June.


Treasury Bill Rates Plunge
LEAD: Treasury bill rates fell sharply yesterday as the steep drop in stock prices led many speculators and investors to put their funds in the safest securities they could find.


Company news; Adams Is Buying Five TV Stations
LEAD: The Adams Communications Corporation, which owns Chicago magazine, has agreed to acquire five television stations, including one in Peoria, Ill., from the Wesray Capital Corporation, officials said.
Adams, based in Tampa, Fla., will buy the stations for $126.5 million from Wesray's Forward Communications Corporation, based in Wausau, Wis.

LEAD: The opening week of the world chess championship has been marked by political and promotional bantering reminiscent of the prelude to a Muhammad Ali fight.

LEAD: The dramatic 108.36-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday reflected not only the fears and hopes of the ordinary investor, but the workings of big institutional investors guided by computer-aided analytical tools.


Correction
LEAD: An article yesterday about the parole eligibility of former Justice William C. Brennan of State Supreme Court in Queens misstated the role of a lawyer, Paul Bergman.
He was the attorney for Mr.
Brennan's appeal, not for the trial on racketeering charges.

Rev. Dennis J. Comey; Settled Labor Disputes
LEAD: The Rev.
Dennis J. Comey, a Jesuit priest who, as the arbitrator of dock disputes in the Port of Philadelphia in the 1950's became known as the Waterfront Priest, died Wednesday at Lankenau Hospital in Philadelphia.
He was 91 years old.
Father Comey was the arbitrator of the Philadelphia port from 1951 to 1959, handling dock grievances and averting work stoppages.


Farm Workers Win a Ruling on Immigration Law
LEAD: A Federal district judge here has ordered that immigration officers who detain farm workers must assure that those eligible to remain in the United States under amnesty do not unwittingly accept deportation as illegal aliens.

Miami Upgrades
LEAD: Administators at the University of Miami, who think faculty leaders are opposed to lenient standards for athletes, are proposing to toughen academic requirements.
Among the proposals, which may take effect on Nov. 1, are requiring freshmen to pass a six-week program called the Freshman Institute before gaining admission; elimination of certain academic majors such as physical education and recreation; using a score below 900 on the Scholastic Aptitude

LEAD: Michael A. Nussbaum, a friend and political associate of the late Donald R. Manes, was sentenced yesterday to one to three years in prison for soliciting a $250,000 bribe from a cable television executive.


Pickens to Appeal
LEAD: T. Boone Pickens said that he would appeal a court ruling that allows Consolidated Gold Fields to maintain control over the Newmont Mining Company, a takeover target of Mr.
Pickens's Ivanhoe Partners group.
Ivanhoe had bid $6.3 billion for Newmont, but the company was rescued by Consolidated, a big London-based mining company that is Newmont's biggest stockholder.

LEAD: Under a hail of criticism, the Administration quickly retreated today from its policy of reducing welfare benefits for elderly, blind and disabled people who receive free food, clothing or shelter from churches and charities.

A single winner would supplant Michael Wittkowski of Illinois as the biggest lottery winner.

Draw in Chess Tourney
LEAD: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov agreed to a draw today after 29 moves in the third game of their world championship chess match.

BankAmerica Fee Credits
LEAD: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it had agreed on a settlement with plaintiffs in a decade-old class-action suit challenging its bank overdraft fees.
Under the proposed settlement, current checking account customers would receive credits to obtain overdraft protection if they do not already have it.


Stage: Fornes's 'Abingdon Square'
LEAD: White walls, tall French doors, spare furniture, a feeling of elegant coolness in early-20th-century New York - this could be the setting for a Merchant-Ivory film.
Against the pristine background, Maria Irene Fornes tells a story swirling with undercurrents of sexuality.
In ''Abingdon Square'' (a Women's Project production at the American Place Theater), what appears to be languid is actually stifling.

Chip Maker's Profits Surge
LEAD: Texas Instruments Inc., reporting strong orders in both semiconductors and military electronics, said today that its third-quarter profits jumped sharply, to $69.1 million, or 79 cents a share, from $14 million, or 14 cents a share, a year ago.
Sales rose 13 percent, to $1.42 billion, from $1.25 billion.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: The Arizona Board of Regents has approved a four-year contract for the Arizona State baseball coach, Jim Brock, and approved a salary increase for Steve Patterson, the basketball coach.
Brock, entering his 16th season, will have a base salary of $55,000, and Patterson, beginning his third season, will be paid $79,000 annually.


Man Held in Shooting of an Ex-Police Officer
LEAD: A suspect in a shootout with a retired police officer was arrested yesterday at Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx where he had come Thursday with a gunshot wound to the abdomen, the police said.


Why Not Put Gold in the Basket?
LEAD: Treasury Secretary Baker set pulses racing at the recent World Bank meetings by suggesting that international financial policies be guided in part by the price of a ''basket'' of commodities, including gold.
It's not a bad idea.

LEAD: A Palm Beach Circuit Court jury in Florida found former Brian Spencer not guilty of first-degree murder.

DOWN TO THE GREAT SHIP
LEAD: WHERE COMES A TIME when the nature of one's interest in a tragedy becomes historical, to use the word loosely; not human, to use that word loosely.
When I was 13, I was taken to Pompeii, and the guide spoke about the phenomenon and dealt only macrocosmically with the human tragedy.
The people who died because Vesuvius belched up its firestorm of molten lava were entirely anonymous ''victims,'' like the victims of Napoleon's march on Russia, the men slaughtered day after festive day in the Roman Colosseum, or the cavalrymen who charged in the Light

LEAD: Barbara Tuchman cites examples of incompetence during the Reagan Administration to suggest that the United States is in decline.

LEAD: For most of this year, one of London's most photographed monuments, the statue of Lord Nelson in Trafalgar Square, has been wrapped in scaffolding.

By the end of this month, amid much hoopla, the 144-year-old statue will be unveiled again, with the cracks in Nelson's brow and sword newly plugged with epoxy resin.

THE AGE OF ABANDON: FINDING IT EASIER TO JUST GET RID OF IT ALL
LEAD: ON a recent drizzly morning, a plague descended on our neighborhood, ravished the territory for a while -picked it clean, then was swept away on the late summer wind.
It was caused by the most unnatural of creatures, yet increasingly common: the Tag Sale People.


Going On in the Northeast
LEAD:  MOZART AND FRIENDS


Youthful Dealers, Old Treasures
LEAD: The stereotype of antiques dealers is that they have too much in common with their wares.
Or, as Wheelock Whitney, a 38-year-old Manhattan art specialist who still looks like a prep-school boy with loafers and no socks, puts it, ''They're all antiques themselves.'' But in recent years, Whitney and a host of other dealers in their 20's and 30's have entered the field, proving that it doesn't require decades of either expertise or earnings to develop a business and an eye for quality.


Unesco Director Withdraws Bid For Re-election
LEAD: Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow, whose 13 years as Director General of Unesco have split the organization, announced tonight that he wanted to withdraw from his race for re-election.


A Conference for L.I. Sound
LEAD: ALTHOUGH Richard Taracka has seen many unusual sights while diving beneath the waters of Long Island Sound, nothing, he said, compares with the current scene.


Maysles: Filming the Impossible
LEAD: ''THE WHOLE THING IS based on faith,'' Albert Maysles said, ''the most outlandish faith.''


Primer Offers Tips on PAC's To Candidates
LEAD: Politicians may be expert at running up large campaign bills, but one Republican consultant here says many lack the skills needed to persuade prospective donors, particularly political action committees, to give them money.


Europe Under Wraps; Scaffolding: A New Esthetic...and a Report by 6 Times Correspondents Athens
LEAD: The Athens skyline is supposed to bristle a little with antiquity.
These days, the bristling comes more from the ravages of modernity on older things, symbolized in the gantries and scaffolding atop the Acropolis, which in recent years have grown to enfold the Parthenon.

SHOULD THE KNICKS TRY TO KEEP KING?
LEAD: Bernard King is a tenacious player, a team leader, the kind of captain the Knicks desperately need.
When I think of the inspirational qualities of Bernard King, I am reminded of the play of Willis Reed (who rose above the circumstances of his injured knees to lead the Knicks to two championships).


IN CASTRO'S GULAG
LEAD: IN THE EARLY AFTERNOON of Jan. 24, 1965, four armed men, their uniforms and shoes in tatters, rested wearily on a rugged mountain slope in eastern Cuba.


Health Insurance
LEAD:  To the Editor:


THIS NEW WATERPROOF ONE EVEN HAS A 'BRAIN'
LEAD: TWO trends in contemporary camera design have converged in the Minolta Weathermatic Dual 35.
As the name suggests, it is a 35-millimeter, automatic camera impervious to the elements.
It can be submerged to a depth of 16 1/2 feet and it offers a choice of two focal lengths.
While there are a multitude of 35-millimeter cameras with one or the other of these features, this is the first camera to have them both.


ZEN BAKERY BEGINS TRAINING PROGRAM
LEAD: THE Greyston Family Inn, a nonprofit service organization begun in Yonkers a year ago by the Zen Community of New York, has started a job-training program this month for a small group of Yonkers residents.
Most members of the group are homeless and unemployed.


Rev. W. H. Brewster, Gospel Song Composer
LEAD: The Rev.
W.
Herbert Brewster Sr., a leading gospel composer, died of a heart attack Wednesday at St.
Joseph Hospital in Memphis, where he lived.
He was 90 years old.
Two of his compositions, ''Move on Up a Little Higher'' (1946) and ''Surely, God Is Able'' (1949) were the first black gospel recordings to sell more than one million records, according to The New Grove Dictionary of American Music.


Harvard Swamps Dartmouth
LEAD: Tom Yohe passed for three touchdowns and Tony Hinz and Dave Bunning scored two each today, leading Harvard to a 42-3 victory over hapless Dartmouth.


WHAT'S NEW IN COLLEGE RECRUITING
LEAD: COLLEGE recruiters were once recent graduates just past acne who were given a credit card and a late-model car and pointed in the general direction of St.
Louis.
Their brochures described the 110 rolling acres above the Missouri, Ohio or Colorado River, the 10.5 million bound volumes in the college library, and the minimum test scores needed to enroll.


A FOND FAREWELL
LEAD: FEW men, or women, leave this world having provided pleasure to people in many countries.
This claim can certainly be made for Victor Mollo, who died last month in London at the age of 78.
For more than 20 years bridge players everywhere have chuckled over the adventures at the Griffins Club of the Hideous Hog, the Rueful Rabbit and other strange denizens of that fictional locale.


In the Middle Is the Only Place to Be
LEAD: I WOULD like to give a cheer, a resounding huzza for that generally considered dubious position of ''being in the middle.'' By that I refer to the very comfortable circumstances of being neither at the top nor the bottom of whatever it is that you do or are.


Soviet Invites Inspection of Atom Power Plant
LEAD: To allay fears about the safety of its reactors after the Chernobyl disaster, the Soviet Union has invited an international team to inspect safety arrangements at a civilian nuclear power plant, according to officials involved.


Turkey's Leader Wins An Election-Law Test
LEAD: Despite an opposition walkout, Prime Minister Turgut Ozal overcame his most serious parliamentary challenge early today, mustering a majority of deputies to win a victory in a crisis over procedures for a national election.

Why Soccer Can't Make It

WHAT'S DOING IN FRANKFURT
LEAD: The city has many names: Bankfurt, Krankfurt, Angstfurt, Mainhattan.
All are pejorative and allude to Frankfurt-on-Main's postwar reputation as the city Europe loves to hate.
Why?
Because it became West Germany's commercial center, the country's business and financial capital.


U.S. IS REASSESSING RESPONSE ON TIBET
LEAD: Some senior Reagan Administration officials have concluded they may not have reacted strongly enough to China's crackdown on recent unrest in Tibet.


In Jerusalem of the 1800's
LEAD: In Jerusalem, a city first settled some 5,000 years ago, little at tention was paid to 19th-century architecture until a few years ago, when several historically important buildings were torn down by developers.
Suddenly, the charm of those century-old structures was recognized, and now many of them have been renovated and turned into galleries and restaurants and even a small theater.


For Better Quality, Listen to the Workers
LEAD: A LARGE part of the growing trade problem facing us today has occurred simply because the American people continue to show that they will go anywhere for quality.
Unfortunately, ''anywhere'' often means straight to a department store or auto dealer to buy products or services from one of our offshore competitors.

ANSWERING THE MAIL
LEAD: Q. The paint on my bedrooms walls had alligatored, so the painter scraped and spackled the alligatored areas, then painted with latex.
As he finished, areas that had not been spackled started to alligator.
The painter says that there are three layers of paint on the wall and the bottom layer was probably oil paint, and that is why his latex paint alligatored.

LEAD: Gary Wilkos set a Monsignor Farrell school record yesterday when he passed for 378 yards in Farrell's 35-7 victory over St.
John the Baptist.
He completed 27 of 36 attempts in the Catholic High School Football League game as Farrell improved to 4-0.
Four of Wilkos's passes were for touchdowns, and Farrell's other touchdown came when Wilkos ran the ball in.

A TASTE OF SECRET PLACES
LEAD: I KNOW where the beach plums grow.
Down a side road near a solitary, sandy beach.
Behind a lonely stretch of dune.
In a privately owned garden close to the seaside.
On Long Island, the wild beach plums are getting scarce.


A MELLOWING TAIWAN SEES A DIFFERENT MAINLAND
LEAD: WHEN the Manchus toppled China's Ming Dynasty in 1644, supporters of the Ming emperors fled to southern China and the island of Taiwan, vowing that they would soon recover the mainland.
They never did, of course, although the invading Manchus were gradually assimilated into Chinese society and culture.


RECITAL: DANIEL WAITZMAN
LEAD: DANIEL WAITZMAN'S flute recital Thursday evening in Alice Tully Hall set out to prove a point: Mr.
Waitzman sees the history of 18th-century music as divided into two strains - what he describes variously, in an extensive and sometimes puzzling program note, as the North German, Protestant, Romantic school, and the Southern Austro-Bohemian, Catholic, Classical school.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  BLACK ROBES, WHITE JUSTICE.
By Bruce Wright. (Lyle Stuart. $15.95.) As a judge in the New York State courts for 17 years, Bruce Wright has never minced his words about the almost inevitable racism of white Americans, and that has often led to accusations that he hates all whites.
Justice Wright, now on the New York State Supreme Court, finds that somewhat ironic since his mother was white.


Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article about bottle laws in The Week in Review Oct. 4 misstated the status of legislation in California.
A recent California law, designed to encourage recycling, involves no deposit but gives consumers a penny per container turned in.
It represents a compromise between the beverage industry and environmentalists.

A NATION IN DECLINE?
LEAD: Barbara Tuchman's article successfully delineates the malaise afflicting this country.
The New York Times Magazine itself is a prime example of our illness.
Mrs.
Tuchman's article should have been the cover and the lead story in the magazine.
Instead, you featured Marcello Mastroianni - a perfect example of the use of image over substance and shallowness over relevance, and a significant indication that The Times will not make the effort to ''raise the level of public understanding from frivolity to a readiness to take serious things seriously .

A NATION IN DECLINE?
LEAD: I was disappointed by Barbara Tuchman's article.
Though the title teased us with an analysis of a society in decay, Mrs.
Tuchman failed to deliver: the essay was little more than an invective against the incompetencies of the Reagan Administration.
Surely the problem is not as simple as that.
Decline involves not merely the failures of a single administration.

FICTION
LEAD:  SAINTS AND SCHOLARS.
By Terry Eagleton. (Methuen, $14.95.) ''Having a pain in my foot, in short, isn't the same as having a mongoose down my trousers.'' So argues an off-the-deep-end Ludwig Wittgenstein in this first novel by the noted Marxist critic Terry Eagleton.
Other characters include the Irish labor leader and revolutionary James Connolly, Wittgenstein's sidekick Nikolai Bakhtin and, in a delightful cameo, Joyce's Leopold Bloom.

Headliners; Ingrate
LEAD: When Stig Bergling, Sweden's best-known spy, broke out of prison recently, he did not have to carve a gun out of soap or tunnel under a wall.
Mr.
Bergling, a former intelligence officer who was sentenced to life in prison in 1979 for selling state secrets to the Soviet Union, simply walked out of his wife's apartment, where he had been left unguarded for an overnight visit.


Study Says South Africa Prisons Breed Illness
LEAD: South Africa has the world's highest per capita prison population, with chronic overcrowding, widespread brutality by prison guards and conditions that are frequently harsh and unhygienic, according to a survey by a South African lawyer who spent time in prison.

TALKING: Clubhouses; Leasing Facilities to Outsiders
LEAD: THE idea of outsiders wandering through a co-op building, a condominium or a homeowner association complex has always been troubling to the residents.
That is why the rental of a facility, like a clubhouse or a community room, for use by nonresidents has long been controversial.

LEAD: JUST half a mile or so north of Wall Street, the Federal District Court in Manhattan has long been home to business and commercial disputes.
But rarely has it seemed so much like an annex to a securities trading floor as this month, with the opening of two high-profile trials involving allegations of high financial chicanery.

CHER'S NEXT ACT
LEAD: IN CHER'S BEDROOM, there is seating for maybe a dozen.
Opposite a wall of floor-to-ceiling windows that overlook one of the Beverly Hills is a long banquette.
In front of the bed two enormous armchairs don't quite surround a vast ottoman.
Like the walls of the living room downstairs that, reminiscent of an ancient tomb, open up to let visitors in from the driveway; and like the huge, supposedly mystical, crystal mounted in the family room, the bedroom arrangement seems reasonable.

LEAD: IT has been 32 years since the Stanley Cup resided in Detroit.
It has been 22 years since the Red Wings captured a regular-season title.

The Red Wings posted a 34-36-10 record last season, but they have unfurled a banner from the rafters at Joe Louis


Trade Data Set Off A Market Plunge
LEAD: A brutal week for stocks gave the bull market its first serious correction since 1984 and even provoked some traders to start writing obituaries for the bull.
The Dow Jones industrial average plummeted 235.48 during the week, to close at 2,246.73.
The daily action was even more spectular with what was thought to be a record plunge of 95.46 on Wednesday, followed by a 57.61-point dive on Thursday and then the real topper, a plummet of 108.36 on Friday.


The Glory of Raphael, The Grace of Boucher
LEAD: IN EXHIBITIONS, AS IN MANY AN-other department of life, there is no mistaking the hand-sewn look.
Hand-sewn tailoring calls for exceptional skills, long experience, superfine materials and fine judgment at every stage along the way.
Hand-sewn work looks right, feels right, is right, and it cannot be counterfeited.

SHOULD THE KNICKS TRY TO KEEP KING?
LEAD: The Knicks must sign King.
He appears much more capable of helping the Knicks win than Kenny Walker, who was himself injured last year.
Salary is hardly an issue.
After all, the Knicks pay Bill Cartwright, who can neither rebound nor play defense, a million dollars, and Pat Cummings, who can't do much of anything, $800,000.


Boy, 4, Slays His Sister, 3
LEAD: A 4-year-old boy, playing at an uncle's security company office, picked up a .38-caliber revolver and shot his 3-year-old sister to death, the police said Friday. ''It appears to be totally accidental,'' a police spokesman said.
The shooting occurred Thursday night when the boy, David Dallas, and his sister, Maggie, were at Dallas Security Patrol while relatives prepared guards for a night shift.

Rob Reiner Applies the Human Touch
LEAD: HE MADE HIS DEBUT AS A DI-rector in 1984 with an affectionate ''rockumentary'' that chronicled the last screeches of a fictitious -and loud - heavy-metal band.
He then turned to a teen-age romance that recalled vintage Frank Capra more than the brat pack.
His third effort was set in the 50's - but instead of trading on nostalgia and the Big Bopper, it focused on four boys in search of a corpse.


My Life as a Boy
LEAD: THE greatest menace while I was growing up came from abroad, from the Germans and the Japanese, our enemies because we were American.
I still remember my terror as a 9-year-old when, running in from playing on the street after school, I saw the banner headline ''Corregidor Falls'' on the evening paper in our doorway and understood that the United States actually could lose the war it had entered only months before.


Columbia Fails To Stop Streak
LEAD: Columbia scored two touchdowns yesterday, one on a faked punt early in the game and the other with eight seconds left, and blocked a couple of kicks.
But the team's overall picture continued to be a nightmare.


POSTINGS: 1901 Elegance;
LEAD: In 1901, a little-known architect named William H. Boylan designed and built the Powellton - an elegant apartment building on the Upper West Side - for only $275,000.
Today, under a co-op conversion plan sponsored by the Ziegelman Organization, individual apartments in the 54-unit residence are going for a considerably greater price.

IS FASHION DESTINY? ASK CINDERELLA
LEAD: EVERY time I return from clothes shopping, no matter how little or how much I buy and regardless of the amount of money I spend, I almost immediately sink into a state of depression.
Based on my readings of self-help articles in women's magazines, I have unearthed many plausible explanations for this ''post-shopping depression syndrome.


Rembrandts by Invitation Only
LEAD: With scholars now disputing the authenticity of many museum paintings long attributed to Rembrandt, the treasures of an unmarked house in Amsterdam are of particular interest.
No one is likely to cast suspicion on the portraits of Jan Six, a 17th-century Mayor of Amsterdam, and his mother, that hang in the front parlor.


Challenger To Martinelli Stresses 'New Leadership'
LEAD: COUNCILMAN Nicholas C. Wasicsko sees himself as a ''David'' in this year's mayoralty race against the nine-term ''Goliath'' and incumbent Mayor Angelo R. Martinelli.
But the 28-year-old challenger has won such a seemingly uneven battle before, in his only previous election effort.


3 Stabbed in Brawl Near Police Headquarters
LEAD: Three youths were hospitalized with stab wounds after a brawl across the street from the New York City Police Headquarters on Friday, the police said.


In Game 3 of Chess Match, Conservative Tactics
LEAD: Quiet, stalking play by Anatoly Karpov was met by wary resistance from Gary Kasparov to produce a draw in the third game of their world championship chess match in Seville, Spain, Friday.

LEAD: FIVE Port Chester officials, including its Mayor, the Police Chief and the Village Manager, are being charged with a breach of ethics for buying condominiums before they were made available to the public at The Landmark, the former Lifesavers factory in the village.

LEAD: The resignation of Edward Klein, the editor of The New York Times Magazine since 1977, has been announced by the newspaper's executive editor, Max Frankel.

NATIONAL STAMP SHOW WILL OPEN ON THURSDAY
LEAD: THE National Postage Stamp Show, sponsored by the American Stamp Dealers' Association (Asda) convenes Thursday through Sunday at New York City's Madison Square Garden.
Hours Thursday are noon to 7 P.M., Friday, 11 A.M. to 7 P.M., Saturday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. and Sunday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.
Admission is $3.75 daily for adults; children under 14 are admitted free.


Playing Fair With Gastineau
LEAD: To The Sports Editor:


A Classical Addition To a Contemporary House
LEAD: Rather than setting out to make their mark in a large city like many young architects, Alan P. Shope and Bernard M. Wharton chose to open their office above a restaurant in Greenwich, Conn.
But like most new firms, they began small - renovating antiquated kitchens and bathrooms and adding bedrooms over a garage or onto the back of a house.


Entertaining Innovations
LEAD: It is quite safe to make long-range forecasts.
By the time reality catches up with you, everyone has forgotten what you said.
It is short-term predictions that often leave you with egg on your face.
Luckily, home electronics is an exception to this rule.
Even short-range prophecy is relatively risk-free, because the future is so close its main features are already clear, even if details and timing are not.

LEAD: BEADS - THE MOST basic and enduring adornments known to man -are the subject of an absorbing exhibition of exotic and familiar craft expressions, at Tambaran Gallery, 957 Madison Avenue (at 75th Street) through Nov. 15.

Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about physics experiments in Japan misstated the nature of electrons and positrons, elementary particles of matter.
Although apparently without internal structure, both have mass.

3 DAYS AT THE FEET OF MASTER CRAFTSMEN
LEAD: A CURATOR at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts has praised a sculptural settee by Sam Maloof, a California woodworker, as being among ''a half-dozen most beautiful examples of seating made by a contemporary American craftsman.''


Giants Get Help at Last
LEAD: Replacement football received major-league replacements today when the Giants activated Lawrence Taylor and Jeff Rutledge for Sunday's game here against the Buffalo Bills.


COPING WITH AUTUMN'S GLORY ONCE IT FALLS
LEAD: WHILE denizens of Connecticut's hills revel in the annual explosion of autumn color, for municipal officials the view is muted by the knowledge that in a few weeks thousands of tons of leaves will be awaiting curbside pickup.


BUSH'S RIVALS TRY TO FAN A DISQUIET AMONG VOTERS
LEAD: TO his Republican Presidential rivals, Vice President George Bush is a political paradox, a clear front-runner who seems teasingly vulnerable.
Their problem is finding strategies to fuel voters' uneasiness - as shown in national polls - about Mr.
Bush's strength and independence.


Jazz
LEAD: Although Clare Fischer has been prominent in the jazz world as a composer, arranger and keyboard artist for more than 30 years, he has done most of his work in studios close to his home in California.
There have been a few periods when he left the studios to travel, notably as pianist and conductor of the singing group the Hi-Lo's in the 1950's and in the mid-70's with Cal Tjader's Latin combo.


NEBRASKA ROLLS ON BY 35-0
LEAD: Nebraska netted 617 yard, led by the quarterback, Steve Taylor, and the tailbacks, Ken Clark and Keith Jones, to extend its domination of Oklahoma State to 26 years with a 35-0 trouncing today in a Big Eight Conference game.
Oklahoma State entered the game 5-0 record, its best start in 42 years.


ANSWERING THE MAIL
LEAD: Q. The paint on my bedrooms walls had alligatored, so the painter scraped and spackled the alligatored areas, then painted with latex.
As he finished, areas that had not been spackled started to alligator.
The painter says that there are three layers of paint on the wall and the bottom layer was probably oil paint, and that is why his latex paint alligatored.


AH, YOUTH: WHEN ANYTHING GOES
LEAD: SO what's the matter with youngsters today?
When it comes to clothes, they seem to have this idea that it's O.K. to be a free spirit, to show some imagination, to break the rules.
Or worse, to make up their own rules.
Some of them look as if they reached into a dark closet and put on whatever they grabbed first.





Mathematics And Magic
LEAD: FROM THE DAWN OF HISTORY, sages have intertwined numbers with magic to create the gods, demons and world views needed by the rest of us to make existence seem comprehensible.
The resulting lore has led to vast bodies of superstitious rigmarole, but it has sometimes spawned the luminous visions that draw scientists toward truth.

Lofty Plans for a Growing Family
LEAD: Walter Chatham is an architect who prides himself on the unconventional: His two-year-old sleeps in an industrial-size laundry bin, his dining room has columns but no walls and he treats cheap building materials such as salvaged pillars and corrugated steel with the same kind of reverence as he would hand-gilded cornice moldings or imported marble.

LEAD: The Rangers didn't play well enough tonight to stave off a desperate charge by the Capitals, who earned a 4-3 victory on the strength of obstinate offense in the game's waning moments.
The loss was the first of the season for the Rangers, whose record is 2-1-2, and it stunned them.

LEAD: A radium-supply company in New York City, under fire for radiation-safety violations since 1983, pledged last night to empty its radioactive plant within two months and to accept full legal responsibility for decontaminating the premises.

LEAD: A map of Switzerland on Aug. 23 located the town of Kilchberg incorrectly.
It is on the western shore of Lake Zurich.

Hotel Rooms for $100 a Night; London
LEAD: Despite inflation in Europe and the dollar's tumble from its high in early 1985, it is still possible to get a decent hotel room in London, Paris and Rome for about $100 a night for two people.
You may have to go off the beaten path, and you will not find such amenities as full room service, free air-conditioning or on-premises parking.

A BROKEN COUNTRY
LEAD: Henry Kamm has made a crucial point that needs emphasis (''A Broken Country,'' Sept. 20): eight years after the killing fields, Cambodia today is still a broken country inhabited by broken-hearted, underfed and uneducated people with little hope and practically no help from the rest of the world.

One Flew Over the Chicken Nests
LEAD: HERE in Ossining, only 40 minutes by train from the heart of New York City, my neighbor Carole keeps hens.
In her lingo, they are the ''girls,'' a modest flock of them.
There are just enough birds to supply eggs for her family of three plus a few friends.
And the eggs are not really the payoff.

Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD:  Forcing a Buyout  Question: Three siblings and I each own a one-quarter interest in a house on Long Island that was left to us by our late mother.
We have seven years left on the mortgage and a $25,000 equity loan that two of my siblings took out to pay some bills.
I am a co-signer of the loan, but I am not using the money or making payments.

LEAD: THE 1965 act that established Medicare began with the ringing declaration of a principle that the American Medical Association considers as fundamental as the separation between church and state: Nothing in this law shall be construed to authorize any Federal employee to ''exercise any supervision or control over the practice of medicine'' or over the compensation of any person providing health services.

VOLUNTEERS: BEACONS IN WORLD OF THE DEAF-BLIND
LEAD: YOU stay where you have been asked to sit for a minute.
You are blindfolded and wear padded earmuffs that exclude sound.
For all practical purposes, you are blind and deaf.
You sit there in utter darkness and stone silence, confident that the promise will be kept, that you will be retrieved in a minute.

Management must continue to build round these players and not around question marks.

O'Connor in ''The New Deal for Art'' of 1972, found that knowledge and appreciation of the subject went no farther west than the Alleghenies.

Today's Interest in The Gardens of The Past
LEAD: In the world of gardening, no word is more peculiar than new.
Mail-order nursery catalogues, especially the more sensational ones that like to promise miracles, tend to use it a lot, in boldface type followed by an exclamation point, or maybe three.
But if a catalogue lists something as new, it generally means only that the plant so described is new to that particular nursery.

Law and Medicine: Easier Access
LEAD: NOW may be the time to go to medical or law school.
Applications are down significantly, and the schools are scrambling for candidates.
In 1974, when medical school applications peaked, there were 2.8 applicants for each available slot; now there are just about 2 prospects for each seat.
The peak for law schools was not until fall 1980, but the valley is just as deep.

Vienna
LEAD: To the Editor: In ''Vienna's Love of the Trolley'' (Travel, Aug. 23), Paul Hofmann says, ''The Schotten in Vienna place names were medieval Irish missionaries whom the local people called Scots.'' The reason they called them that is that they were Scots.
The country of Scotland, formerly Caledonia, got its name from the invading tribes of Ireland, then called Scotia, who settled in the Highlands (bringing the prefix Mac) and were known as


An Ill Wind in France
LEAD:  To the Editor:


Switzerland
LEAD: To the Editor: The article about Swiss lake travel gives the wrong train station for the Ballenberg Freilicht (Outdoor) Museum.
It's not Brienz - it's Brienzwiler, about three miles away, from which there is a forest path going uphill from the lakeside station to the museum.
There are no taxis at Brienz.

LEAD: COLD weather and German food are made for each other.
October's nippy air calls for hearty food rather than summer's lighter fare.
The Smithtown Haus doesn't have an Oktoberfest extravaganza, but it has added a special item to the menu and labeled it Oktoberfest.

Europe Under Wraps; Scaffolding: A New Esthetic...and a Report by 6 Times Correspondents Paris
LEAD: For the next 15 months, two pale yellow boxes will migrate around the Place de la Concorde in Paris.
The official euphemism for these giant crates is architecture of protection, but they are in fact esthetically acceptable coverings for scaffolding that will progressively envelop eight statues of women representing eight cities of France: Lille, Rouen, Strasbourg, Marseilles, Lyons, Nantes, Brest and Bordeaux.

By Angus Roxburgh.
Illustrated. 285 pp.
New York: George Braziller. $19.95.

Maine Indian Tribes Revive Bingo Under New State Law
LEAD: Hundreds of people jammed a tribal community center as the Penobscot Indians played high-stakes bingo games for the first time since the practice was halted four years ago.
Many paid $50 to get into the $10,000 jackpot games.
Nobody won the grand prize.

China
LEAD: To the Editor: My wife and I recently returned from a four-week trip to China and Tibet.
On several occasions we flew on China Airways.
On two flights we flew in what are called military charters, which I understand are special sections.
These planes were clean, modern and comfortable.

LEAD: Tony Rice, a sophomore option quarterback who started his first collegiate game today, ran for two first-quarter touchdowns, and Tim Brown provided an insurance score with a 74-yard punt return in the final period as Notre Dame routed the Air Force Academy, 35-14.

LEAD: Brunswick improved its record to 5-0 yesterday with a 20-0 victory over Dalton.
A second-quarter touchdown gave Brunswick the lead as Tom Demas ran 3 yards to finish a 41-yard drive.
Geoff Headington led the offense in the second half, running 4 yards and 8 yards for scores.
Pieter Hartong kicked the extra points on the first two touchdowns.

NEWS SUMMARY/SUNDAY, OCTOBER 18, 1987
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL/3-25


POSTINGS: R.S.A. Seminars; The Rights Of Owners
LEAD: The Rent Stabilization Association - the major trade group for New York City landlords - is sponsoring a series of seminars meant to help building owners, property managers and co-op and condo boards comprehend the city's tangle of housing rules and regulations.


Lebanon's Militias Providing Social Services
LEAD: Lebanon's political and religious militias, which after 12 years of civil war have virtually replaced the central Government as the effective authorities in most of the country, have started their own networks of social services ranging from providing textbooks to operating buses.

LEAD: Betsy Finley Ashton, the personal finance correspondent of ''The Morning Program'' on CBS-TV, and Jacob Berry Underhill 3d, a former president of the New York Life Insurance Company, were married yesterday in Greenwich, Conn., at the summer home of the bridegroom's mother, Mrs.
Howard Brougham Major of Palm Beach, Fla.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs.
Mark S. Kaufmann of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Susan Helen Kaufmann, to Alan Edward Lewis, the son of Bernard J. Lewis of Sunrise, Fla., and the late Sylvia Lewis.


Scaled-Down Equipment for A Home Office
LEAD: If American homes undergo a radical change in the coming decades, it will almost certainly be the addition of a new room or area: an office.
In fact, according to several government and industry estimates, some 10 to 20 million workers have already moved home.
Although their offices' design may become of increasing concern, current considerations involve the selection of telephones, computers, copiers and other instruments of commerce.


The Score On Chamber Music
LEAD: I HAVE WONDERED ABOUT STATISTICS EVER since I took a course from a professor who spent much of the semester explaining that the poll takers who predicted Dewey's defeat of Truman were right.
They had simply misinterpreted their own valid data.
So, my instinct when any statistical analysis comes to hand is to hold it at arm's length.


Festival '87 Was High on Style
LEAD: AT THE AGE OF 25, THE ANNUAL New York Film Festival, which closed one week ago tonight at Lincoln Center, has been running almost as long as Johnny Carson's ''Tonight Show,'' possibly for many of the same reasons.
It has no overwhelming personality that turns audiences into fanatics who either love it or hate it.


Small Space for a Grand Collection
LEAD: Some designers pride themselves on soup-to-nuts decorating - buying everything for their clients from sofas and paintings to wastebaskets and bath towels.
Not Hermes Mallea and Carey C. Maloney, the three-year-old architect-designer team who call themselves the M (Group).
Many of their clients are auction house experts, art dealers or collectors who have strong ideas of their own on furnishings and art.


THE LEGACY: GOOD MOVE IS NOT GOOD ENOUGH
LEAD: EMANUEL Lasker's favorite piece of advice was: When you see that you have a good move, look around before playing it; there may be an even better one.

Art
LEAD: In ''Henri Cartier-Bresson: The Early Work,'' at the Museum of Modern Art through Nov. 29, Peter Galassi, a curator in the museum's department of photography, has changed our way of seeing an artist we thought we knew.
He has done so by focusing attention on the work Cartier-Bresson did in the early 1930's, before the photojournalism for which he is best known.

In Cuba
LEAD: Joanne Chesimard, a fugitive black radical leader who was convicted of murder a decade ago, surfaced in Cuba last week.
Now 40 years old, she has changed her name to Assata Shakur and is about to publish her autobiography, according to an interview that appeared in Newsday.

ANSWERING THE MAIL
LEAD: Q. The paint on my bedrooms walls had alligatored, so the painter scraped and spackled the alligatored areas, then painted with latex.
As he finished, areas that had not been spackled started to alligator.
The painter says that there are three layers of paint on the wall and the bottom layer was probably oil paint, and that is why his latex paint alligatored.

Opera: 'Tosca' at the Met With Eva Marton
LEAD: FRANCO ZEFFIRELLI'S two-year old production of ''Tosca'' lumbered onto the stage of the Metropolitan Opera again on Friday.
It is a monument to men's need to create things larger than themselves.
Indeed, people seemed somewhat puny next to the soaring Baroque interiors, gargantuan castle parapets and a jail cell that rose and descended - Otis-elevator-like.


Hotel Rooms for $100 a Night; Rome
LEAD: Despite inflation in Europe and the dollar's tumble from its high in early 1985, it is still possible to get a decent hotel room in London, Paris and Rome for about $100 a night for two people.
You may have to go off the beaten path, and you will not find such amenities as full room service, free air-conditioning or on-premises parking.

What is going on there?
Do you have information about nearby resorts and about flights and groups? - P. L., New York  Answer: The village of Medjugorje in southwestern Yugoslavia has become a center of religious pilgrimages since 1981 when four young people said that they had seen a vision of the Virgin Mary.


SHOULD THE KNICKS TRY TO KEEP KING?
LEAD: Definitely not.
For two years he made laughingstocks of Dave DeBusschere and Scotty Stirling by taking the huge sum of $874,000 from the Knicks each year and not having the decency or courtesy to show his face at Knicks games to lend moral support.
During this two-year period a portion of the $3,400 I paid each year for my four courtside seats helped defray Captain King's salary while he was doing his disappearing act.

LEAD: Dutch aristocrats have lagged behind their English and French cousins in opening their castles and manor houses to the public.
But the same motivation that led the nobility in other countries to turn their estates into tourist attractions - namely the financial strain of maintaining historic properties despite some Government subsidies for their restoration - has caught up with titled families in the Netherlands.

LEAD: Robert A. Heinlein turned 80 this year.
The title of his latest book, TO SAIL BEYOND THE SUNSET (Ace/Putnam, $18.95), comes from the conclusion of Tennyson's ''Ulysses,'' where that retired hero proclaims his desire to go down to the sea once more in search of adventure and ''a newer world.''

Collier of the SUNY branch at Albany.

Rediscovering Thrift, or a New Look At the Old Ways
LEAD: I grew up in a household dominated by old-fashioned principles of thrift. ''To buy'' was not a verb my mother liked; ''to save'' was preferable.
Browsing through downtown department stores was never her habit, although no one doubted her eye at an antiques shop.
She ran a tight ship -lights out when you leave the room, the thermostat at 60 degrees, save the leftovers and don't throw anything away that might prove useful.


Square Deal for Columbus Circle?
LEAD: BACK IN 1985, WHEN THE DE-sign for the skyscraper that has been proposed to replace the Coliseum at Columbus Circle was announced, the project, called Columbus Center, seemed certain to be built.
It did not matter that Columbus Center was too big by half and was a ghastly piece of architecture to boot.


The President and the Children
LEAD: Children are a nation's greatest future resource; that's why America is heading for trouble.
In the next 12 weeks, President Reagan will either seize - or forfeit - his last chance to do something about it.

PLANTING CONTINUES
LEAD: Last call to finish lawn work; seed planted this late may not germinate, but since the seed is hardy, it will remain until early spring when it should sprout, if the birds don't get it first; place conifer branches over seeded bare patches to protect them.
Keep mowing as long as the grass is growing and set mower to cut low, one to two inches.

Hotel Rooms for $100 a Night; Paris
LEAD: Despite inflation in Europe and the dollar's tumble from its high in early 1985, it is still possible to get a decent hotel room in London, Paris and Rome for about $100 a night for two people.
You may have to go off the beaten path, and you will not find such amenities as full room service, free air-conditioning or on-premises parking.

Two Punk Rebels Decide That Rock Isn't So Bad
LEAD: PUNK ROCK'S PROMISE, WHEN it arrived on the mid-70's pop scene in a burst of apocalyptic fury, was that from now on, things would be different.
In England, punk anger and punk style signaled a social upheaval.
But punk's most far-reaching impact was within rock itself.
The music was dominated by middle-aged stars, relics of the 60's who had distanced themselves from the driven intensity and nose-thumbing irreverence of their early years.

INTIMATIONS OF DISASTER, AND 30-SECOND SOUND BITES
LEAD: THERE IS A SENSE THAT SOME-thing is out of hand.
Is the system working or not?
Presidential candidates seem to drop like flies, while a nomination to the Supreme Court is debated in 30-second sound bites.
We watch; we wait.
Television keeps giving us intimations of disaster. ''That could hurt, if not destroy, his campaign,'' Ted Koppel said after revelations about Pat Roberston.

LEAD: Pat Ryan, the 32-year-old Jet quarterback who crossed the picket line Wednesday before the players' strike ended, had not played in four weeks.
He had not thrown a pass in pads until Friday, and was suffering from rotator-cuff problems.
Despite all of that, Ryan dominated the Miami Dolphins' replacement defense today and led the mostly replacement Jets to a dramatic 37-31 overtime victory in front of 18,249 fans at Giants Stadium.

LEAD: THE computer age could not help but affect dance sooner or later.
Would Bill Young, who performed with his company on Friday evening at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater, have thought of or desired to create ''Interleaving'' in any other time?
The new piece is made of four separate dances, with the beginnings of the four all being performed first, all the middle parts second and their endings last.

Nova Output to Be Cut
LEAD: The New United Motor Manufacturing Inc. announced its third cutback in six months of Chevrolet Nova production.
Nummi, the sole producer of the Nova, will reduce production to 450 of the cars a day, from 550, effective Nov. 30.
The cutback is in anticipation of reduced 1988 model sales.
But the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Corporation, co-owners of the venture, said they had no plans to slow production of Toyota Corolla FX automobiles or lay off any of the factory's 2,500 employees.

LEAD: The Detroit Tigers and the other victims of the 1987 Minnesota Twins hardly need a couple of guys with slide rules to tell them what they learned the hard way this season -that it's no picnic taking on a team playing under its own cozy roof.
But in case there are still some skeptics, two sociologists have come up with convincing statistical evidence that a dome magnifies the traditional home-team advantage even as it amplifies the cheers of the crowd.

LEAD: A typhoon, designated Lynn, knocked out power on Guam and swept across the northern Marianas Islands in the western Pacific early today with winds over 100 miles an hour.

Surgery for Moncrief
LEAD: Faced with the prospect of limping through an entire National Basketball Association season, Sidney Moncrief of the Milwaukee Bucks has elected instead to undergo knee surgery today and hopes to rejoin the team in about two months.
A bone spur that prevented Moncrief from extending or flexing his knee will be removed.


Tarpley Tells of Woes
LEAD: Roy Tarpley, the Dallas Mavericks' forward, confirmed yesterday that he had been treated for cocaine and alcohol problems over the summer and said that he was having problems with his aftercare program.
After he appeared late for a Sunday exhibition game with the Boston Celtics - and did not play - Tarpley talked about his problems in a meeting with Rick Sund, the vice president for basketball operations, and General Manager Norm Sonju.


'ARTIFACT' IS FOUND TO BE AN UNUSUAL METEORITE
LEAD: A rock stored in a farmer's collection of Indian artifacts for 11 years is a 4.5 billion-year-old meteorite that could provide new information on how the solar system developed, scientists announced today.

Films About Blacklist: Hollywood's Bad Old Days
LEAD: The blacklisting that demoralized Hollywood during the 1950's was a taboo subject for three decades.
Now Hollywood is spotlighting the McCarthy era and the redbaiting that barred hundreds of producers, directors, writers, actors and technicians from working in the industry.


Iraqi Oil Output High
LEAD: Iraq is pumping 2.7 million barrels of oil a day, nearly double its nominal OPEC quota, an oil publication reported today.
The Middle East Economic Survey said Iraq gave the figure to a quota-discipline ministerial committee of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries that visited Baghdad last week.


Iranian Pledges a 'Crushing Blow' Against U.S. to Avenge the Raid
LEAD: Iran vowed today to deliver a ''crushing blow'' against the United States in revenge for the raids on its offshore platforms in the Persian Gulf.


A SWEDE RESIGNS OVER SPY'S ESCAPE
LEAD: Justice Minister Sten Wickbom resigned today to take responsibility for the embarrassingly easy escape this month of Sweden's most notorious spy.

BOOKS OF THE TIMES
LEAD: REBECCA WEST.
A Life.
By Victoria Glendinning. 300 pages.
Illustrated.
Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.
REBECCA WEST spent much of her long life amid the fumes of private quarrels and public controversy.
Her gifts were formidable but often misdirected, and her contradictions were almost as impressive as her achievements.


604 MILLION VOLUME NEARLY DOUBLES RECORD; Does 1987 Equal 1929?
LEAD: As stock prices soared this year, a chorus of pessimists warned that 1987 was looking more like 1929, when a stock market crash helped to usher in the Great Depression.
Yesterday, after a plunge reminiscent of the worst days of 1929, one pressing question was whether the aftershocks would be as devastating to individuals and the nation.

8.2% Berkey Stake
LEAD: Warner Communications Inc. and an affiliate have purchased the equivalent of an 8.2 percent stake in Berkey Inc., a manufacturer of photographic equipment based in White Plains.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Warner said that it had purchased the Berkey shares for investment purposes only and that it might buy or sell them depending upon market conditions.


Downcast? No, Reagan Is 'Upbeat'
LEAD: Despite the plummeting stock market, his wife's illness and the military action in the Persian Gulf, President Reagan was described by White House aides today as ''surprisingly upbeat.'' He was ''bouncy and buoyant,'' even cracking jokes, though he was coming out of an extraordinarily difficult weekend.

LEAD: Two California supermarket chains have become the first in the nation to test fresh fruits and vegetables for the presence of pesticides, environmental scientists and industry executives say.


Industrial Equity May Buy Calmat
LEAD: Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., a Hong Kong-based investment concern controlled by Ronald A. Brerely, a New Zealand investor, indicated that it was considering a takeover of the Calmat Company, a Los Angeles-based cement maker.
Industrial Equity has raised its stake in Calmat to 19.2 percent, with purchases of 918,900 additional Calmat shares between Oct.


Democrats Charge F.E.C. Inaction In Complaint Against Fund-Raiser
LEAD: The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee has filed suit against the Federal Election Commission, charging that it violated the law by not acting on the committee's complaint against a conservative fund-raiser who figures in the Iran-contra affair.


Careers; Replacing Jobs Lost On Wall St.
LEAD: TELEPHONES at management recruiting firms have been busy in the last week with calls from young and middle-aged municipal bond specialists just dismissed by Salomon Brothers and Kidder, Peabody &amp; Company.
The two firms quite suddenly announced that they were cutting their municipal bond department staffs, involving about 1,000 individuals, mostly high salaried.


Degas's 'Laundry Maids' to Be Sold
LEAD: Edgar Degas's ''Laundry Maids,'' an 1870's masterpiece that has been in the same collection since 1895, will be auctioned Nov. 30 at Christie's in London.

'The Ring of Truth,' On Ways of Perception
LEAD: HOW do we know what we know?
Specifically, how does science know?
When does hypothesis become fact because it has the ring of truth?
In part, as Philip Morrison cheerfully explains in a six-part series, it happens when instruments look, measure and weigh.
The series, beginning on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight, examines how we examine.

Corrections
LEAD: A number of articles about the stock market on Friday and over the weekend misstated Friday's closing Dow Jones industrial average by a hundredth of a point.

Reagan Did Not Weigh Trading Halt, Aide Says
LEAD: President Reagan watched today's 508-point plunge in the Dow Jones industrial average with concern but at no time considered ordering a halt to trading, a White House spokesman said today.


Korean Trade Forecast
LEAD: Big demand for South Korea's low-priced cars and electronic goods should result in a trade surplus this year of around $10 billion, far above a ceiling set in June, the country's national press agency, Yonhap, predicted today.
Bank of Korea officials would neither confirm nor deny the forecast, saying only that the bank would issue its own figures later this week.

The Stage: Israel Horovitz's 'Year of the Duck'
LEAD: IN Israel Horovitz's ''Year of the Duck'' (at the Hudson Guild Theater), life imitates art - up to a point.
A community theater in Gloucester, Mass., is rehearsing a production of ''The Wild Duck,'' and, gradually, the members of the company show signs of creeping Ibsenism.
Led by their director and star (he has cast himself in the pivotal role of Gregers Werle), they cleanse their lives of deception, as the characters do in the original play.

Bridge: U.S. and Britain Take Lead In World Open Team Battles
LEAD: Two long semifinal battles, each of 160 deals, began here this afternoon in the World Open Team Championships.
After 48 deals in the fight for the Bermuda Bowl, the United States led Taiwan by 46 international match points while Britain led Sweden by 28.


Ryan Still an Astro
LEAD: Nolan Ryan will return to the Houston Astros in 1988 after a bizarre season in which he lost twice as many games as he won (8-16), but led the majors with 270 strikeouts and tied the Toronto Blue Jays' Jimmy Key for the lead in earned run average with a 2.76 figure.
The 40-year-old right-handed fastball pitcher, who is baseball's career strikeout leader with 4,547 in 21 years, had his option picked up after meeting Friday with Dick Wagner, the Houston general manager.

Music: American Symphony
LEAD: THERE is a small irony about the American Symphony Orchestra.
Founded 25 years ago by Leopold Stokowski, the ensemble is actually structured more along the lines of an orchestra in London than one in this country: its members are freelancers, not full-timers, who come together for the handful of concerts given by the group each season.

LEAD: THE handwritten letters arrive by the fistful. ''Dear Mr.
Computer Know-It-All,'' they invariably plead, ''please help.
My (wife, husband, daughter, son, pet cockatoo, etc.) is or wants to be a writer and I want to buy (him, her, it) a computer for word processing for Christmas.
But what do I buy (him, her, it)?


Violin: Waterman Plays Bach
LEAD: THE first of two Bach concerts by Ruth Waterman at Merkin Concert Hall Sunday night reminded us that ''authentic'' performance is less objective science than a set of personal decisions.
For this survey of the violin and keyboard literature, Miss Waterman in many ways was very up-to-date.
She played on a modern violin and used vibrato to color sustained tone - choosing not to reserve it for the ornamental and accentual effects the 18th century seems to have favored.


BUSH SEEN TAKING MODERATE STANCE
LEAD: Vice President Bush, in an uncharacteristic political gamble, has begun to move toward the political center in the hope of capturing the Republican nomination, aides and other analysts say.

U.S. Debt Issues Rise Strongly
LEAD: The Treasury securities market benefited tremendously from the steep drop in stock prices yesterday as the inflow of money from investors who sold stocks and prospects for a weaker economy helped raise prices and lower interest rates in all maturities.


Tandem Offers Library System
LEAD: Tandem Computers Inc. today introduced its first optical storage product, an optical disk library system for use with the company's minicomputer systems.


Costume Jewelry: Closer to the Real Thing
LEAD: It isn't fake anything.
It's real costume jewelry.
And it's being worn -without apology - by women of every age and financial bracket.
A teen-ager picks up a vintage rhinestone brooch in a thrift shop, and her grandmother sports a copy of the Duchess of Windsor's jeweled flamingo pin.
Even Brooke Astor has been known to wear bogus gems.

Of Bluffs and Gambles
LEAD: IF there is a computer program that plays poker with anything like the challenge and subtlety a real game can offer, I have yet to see it.
What set of instructions could create such poker-playing companions as the good old boy from Alabama who seems to hold an inordinate number of winning hands, the SoHo slicker who handles the deck much too well, the yuppie puppy who only clams up when he's drawing to a four-card flush?

IC Plans a Buyback And an Acquisition
LEAD: IC Industries said today that it plans to buy back between $500 million and $1 billion of its common stock and spend as much as $3 billion to acquire a company in the consumer goods and services industry.

LEAD: The briefing of Congressional leaders Sunday night on how the United States would retaliate against Iran was considered so sensitive that even after television news reports showed the leaders entering the White House, Reagan Administration officials refused to confirm that the meeting was taking place.


Advertising; Newspaper Ads Rise
LEAD: The Newspaper Advertising Bureau has released estimates for July advertising volume.
Expenditures climbed to $2.3 billion, an increase of 9.7 percent over July 1986.
Retail advertising rose 5.8 percent, to $1.1 billion, with classified increasing 14.7 percent, to $911 million.

LEAD: Beginning today, Presbyterian Hospital will try to prove that a world-famous medical center can emerge from its citadel and become a local community hospital serving poor neighborhoods in upper Manhattan.

Depleted Islanders
LEAD: When the Islanders play Calgary tonight at Nassau Coliseum they will probably be without the services of two right wings, Mikko Makela, who suffered a sprained right wrist in Saturday's 4-3 loss to the Flyers, and Alan Kerr, who has the flu.
Both missed practice yesterday.
Regardless of their status, Coach Terry Simpson said that he definitely would play Brad Lauer, a wing, and Ken Leiter, a defenseman, neither of whom have played in the team's first four games.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q.My friend, who is black, tells me she has to be careful about sunburn.
How is this possible when she has so much more melanin in her skin than I do as a white person?
A.Melanin, a brown or black pigment in the skin, hair and eyes, improves vision in bright sunlight and protects against sunburn.

GOING OUT GUIDE
LEAD:  A World in Small Scale


BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 20, 1987
LEAD: THE STOCK MARKET PLUNGE  The stock market had its worst day in history.
The Dow Jones industrial average plunged an estimated 508 points, to 1,738.74, on trading so heavy that reporting was delayed for hours.
More than 604 million shares changed hands, dwarfing Friday's record of 338.5 million shares, and the decline of 22.6 percent was far greater than the drop of 12.82 percent on Black Monday in 1929, which ignited the Great Depression.

LEAD: Billy Martin, who came and went four times as Yankee manager in a 10-year span that began in 1975, was brought back for a fifth term today in another shakeup by the team's owner, George Steinbrenner.
Lou Piniella, who has been the manager for the past two seasons, was named general manager by Steinbrenner.

The Stage: 'Anything Goes'
LEAD: FORGET about the Colosseum, the Louvre museum, a melody from a symphony by Strauss - Patti LuPone is the top.
As Reno Sweeney, the sassy nightclub singer in the Lincoln Center revival of ''Anything Goes,'' Ms.
LuPone has her first sensational New York role since ''Evita'' in 1979, and, given that Cole Porter is the evening's buoyant guiding spirit, you don't have to fear that she'll succumb to death scenes in the second act.

LEAD: King Baudouin accepted Prime Minister Wilfried Martens's resignation today and asked him to form a new government to amend the Constitution to resolve a 150-year-old language dispute.
Mr.
Martens said he would do so.
The center-right coalition offered its resignation Thursday because of the squabble between Belgium's Flemish people, who speak Flemish, and the Walloons, who speak French.

Music: Monteverdi's 'Vespers' at Basically Bach
LEAD: RICHARD WESTENBURG'S ninth Basically Bach Festival got under way Monday night in Alice Tully Hall with an unfortunately underattended performance of Monteverdi's ''Vespers of 1610.'' Other than a general wish to see this honorable festival fare well, one's disappointment had mostly to do with a regret that so few people were hearing this fine, rarely encountered score.

Brauner Account
LEAD: J.D.
Brauner, a maker of butcher block tables and chairs in Long Island City, Queens, has tapped Fisher Jackson Levy Flaxman to handle its million-dollar budget.
A consumer print campaign will begin next week, the agency said.
The previous agency was Drossman, Lehmann, Marino.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: TENNIS  Connors Wins Easily: Fourth-seeded Jimmy Connors posted an easy victory, but second-seeded Stefan Edberg of Sweden had to struggle to beat one of Japan's top players yesterday in first-round matches of the $375,000 Seiko tournament in Tokyo.
Edberg, ranked second in the world, defeated Tsuyoshi Fukui, ranked 379th, 7-5, 6-2, before a crowd of 4,000 at Yoyogi National Stadium.

GRAHAM SCHEDULE CHANGE
LEAD: The Martha Graham Dance Com-pany has scheduled two additional performances of ''Celebration'' for tomorrow and Friday at the City Cen-ter, 131 West 55th Street.
The 1934 work by Miss Graham has been re-staged this season for the first time in 50 years. ''Embattled Garden'' and ''Primitive Mysteries'' will replace ''Canticle for Innocent Comedians'' Saturday night.

3 Senators Jump Gun In the Bork Debate
LEAD: Three Democratic Senators today jumped the gun on the formal debate on Judge Robert H. Bork's nomination to the Supreme Court, confronting a conservative colleague about his role in a pro-Bork telephone campaign.


Luxury Items Remain on Many Must-Have Lists
LEAD: Investors who took a beating Monday were not backing away from big-ticket consumer purchases just yet, according to those who deal in the luxury items, allaying for now what analysts say is the biggest threat of a stock market collapse: that people will feel poorer and spend less, resulting in a severe economic slowdown.

Man Charged in Sex Attacks
LEAD: A 22-year-old Brooklyn man was indicted yesterday in the sexual assault of a young woman and two girls, 12 and 13 years old, in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman announced.
The man, Charles Murchison, of 433 Lincoln Place in Crown Heights, was charged with rape, sexual abuse, sodomy, attempted sodomy and endangering the welfare of a child.
