LEAD: Official Washington tried hard to look calm and confident today in the face of continuing frenzy in the financial markets, but uncertainty, anxiety and confusion were visible behind the mask.


BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1987
LEAD:  The Stock Market Turmoil


Hutton Net Up 6.1%; Shearson Down
LEAD: Two of the nation's leading securities brokerage and investment banking houses, the E. F. Hutton Group Inc. and Shearson Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc., yesterday reported mixed earnings results for the third quarter.
Hutton's profits rose 6.1 percent, while Shearson fell by 21.1 percent.


DEBBIE REYNOLDS IN 'SADIE AND SON'
LEAD: DESCRIBED in press releases as a lighthearted drama, ''Sadie and Son,'' the made-for-TV movie on CBS at 9 tonight, is the kind of glossy concoction that lacks a single convincing moment.
Start with the setting.
It is supposed to be New York City, and several scenes take place in the subway.
Needless to say, ''Sadie and Son'' was filmed entirely on location - in Toronto.

LEAD: The Bristol-Myers Company said yesterday that earnings had increased by 15.1 percent in the third quarter, to a record $200.2 million, or 70 cents a share, from $173.9 million, or 61 cents a share, a year earlier.

LEAD: The Wall Street collapse of 1987 was only hours old Monday night when an audience at the Lincoln Center revival of Cole Porter's ''Anything Goes'' was applauding and cheering 50-year-old jokes that had helped an earlier generation laugh its way through the Great Depression.

LEAD: Housing construction rose 4.4 percent in September, the biggest advance since last December, the Government reported today, but analysts said recent increases in mortgage rates made further improvement unlikely.

Joseph Orgel Is Dead at 84; Writer and Retired Educator
LEAD: Joseph R. Orgel, a writer and educator who worked in the New York City public school system for almost 30 years, died of pneumonia and heart disease Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach.
He was 84 years old and had lived in Pembroke Pines, Fla., for 14 years.

The Market: Why Does It Matter?
LEAD: Suddenly all everybody wants to know is what's happening to the stock market.
People getting off planes rush to telephones to find out if their stocks are up or down.
Bus drivers ask their passengers whether they should buy or sell.
Does it really matter all that much?
What is the stock market, anyway?


Dart Group Ends Its Bid To Buy Dayton Hudson
LEAD: The Dart Group Corporation said yesterday that it was giving up its $68-a-share takeover bid for the Dayton Hudson Corporation, a move that is expected to result in an after-tax loss of about $70 million.

Edelman Group To Pursue Telex
LEAD: A group led by the New York investor Asher B. Edelman said it planned to continue its $65-a-share offer for the Telex Corporation, according to Daniel Good, head of Shearson Lehman Merchant Banking, which is advising the group.
Telex stock, which lost $8.875 in Monday's market plunge, fell another $11, to $34 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

LEAD: This week's historic plunge in stock prices has thrown the world of corporate finance into turmoil.

The Party Is Over; the Bills Are In
LEAD: The events of the last few months have been trying to tell this country something about its mindless excesses.
They have been saying you can't run a Government on credit cards, that the politics of blame won't solve our problems at home or abroad and that when the party's over the bills come in, The evidence was all around us before the crash: in the Iran-contra hearings, in the budget deficits and the trade deficits, in the adventures of the Persian Gulf, in the moral squalor of the Hart and Biden campaigns.

Tribune Co. and Post Report
LEAD: The Tribune Company, owner of The Chicago Tribune and other media properties, reported yesterday that its third-quarter profit fell 73 percent, to $33.1 million, or 42 cents a share, from $123.5 mllion, or $1.53 a share, last year.
Revenues rose 8 percent, to $535 million, from $497 million.

New York Eases Handcuff Rules For Nonviolent
LEAD: The New York City Police Department, altering a longtime policy at the request of Mayor Koch, will no longer require officers and detectives to handcuff nonviolent prisoners who surrender with their lawyers and are not likely to escape.

Fines for 21 Players
LEAD: Twenty-one players with the Atlanta Hawks and the Indiana Pacers have been fined for fighting during an exhibition game last Thursday in Chattanooga, Tenn.
Scott Hastings of Atlanta was fined $3,000 for throwing a punch and $500 for leaving the area of the bench.
Wayne Rollins of Atlanta and Steve Stipanovich were fined $2,000 apiece for brawling and contributing to the escalation of the incident.


Barcelona Plans a Lasting Olympics
LEAD: The organizers of the XXV Summer Olympic Games, which will be held in this old Mediterranean port in 1992, are using the 1984 Los Angeles Games as a guide for a few aspects of their planning effort.
But over all, Barcelona is taking an entirely different approach toward its production.

CAUTION IS URGED BY ADVISERS
LEAD: Investment advisers ranging from big securities firms to small financial planners were urging caution yesterday, telling their clients to avoid any major moves, either selling or buying, in the wake of Monday's stock market plunge.


Fear Itself
LEAD: ''Don't just do something -stand there,'' was the advice taken by the President of the United States, as the stock market crashed and one third of the air escaped from the nation's balloon of confidence.


Oil Prices Edge Higher, After Advance by Dow
LEAD: Oil prices edged higher yesterday, apparently taking their direction from the Dow Jones industrial average and not from the increasing violence in the Persian Gulf.
A barrel of crude, which had been down 42 cents in near-month trading on the New York futures exchange on Monday, the day of the stock market's huge loss, was up 7 cents yesterday, to $19.87.


Dollar Stages Rebound As Gold Falls Sharply
LEAD: The dollar rebounded against most major currencies yesterday, springing back from six-month lows it hit during Monday's collapse on world stock markets.


Tudor's Comeback: A Stylish Chapter
LEAD: When John Tudor suffered a fractured right leg early this season, the immediate prognosis was that he would not pitch again until spring training.
But he returned to generate a 10-2 record that helped the Cardinals win the National League East and threw a 1-0 shutout that tied the National League Championship Series with the San Francisco Giants at 3-3.


Bank of New York Still Wants Irving
LEAD: The Bank of New York Corporation said it would continue to pursue its downtown rival the Irving Bank Corporation for the terms outlined last month despite the drop in the Bank of New York's stock. ''The offer still stands,'' a spokesman said, even though Bank of New York's stock fell yesterday to $30.125, from $41.50, at the time of the bid.

Northrop Has Profit
LEAD: The Northrop Corporation said today that it earned $34.1 million, or 73 cents a share, in the third quarter.
The aerospace company had lost $30.5 million in the period last year after taking a $90 million write-down on its highly classified research and development contract for the Air Force's Stealth bomber program.


Shultz Expresses Frustration on Talks for Mideast
LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz wound up his latest round of Middle East diplomacy today with a rare expression of frustration at the emphasis that has been placed on how to get to Arab-Israeli peace talks rather than the substance of what is to be negotiated.


Tokyo Rebounds From Its Big Loss
LEAD: Encouraged by Wall Street's rally overnight, the Tokyo stock market bounced back powerfully today after suffering its worst day ever.


Infant Heart Patient Gains
LEAD: An infant who received a heart transplant a few hours after birth is recovering well and his condition has been upgraded from critical to serious but stable, a hospital spokeswoman said Monday.
The infant, Paul Holc, was delivered by Caesarean section Friday when a donor heart became available.

Film: 'Death in Family,' AIDS in New Zealand
LEAD: THE death in ''A Death in the Family'' is that of a young New Zealand man named Andrew Boyd; the family is made up of the friends and lovers who tended him in July 1985, during his final days.
Stewart Main and Peter Wells were two of those friends, and their drama, which opens today at Film Forum 1, is meant as a loving tribute to ''Andy'' as well as an effort to present his disease, AI


4,600-Year-Old Boat Viewed in Pyramid Pit
LEAD: American experts inserted a small camera into a limestone-covered pit at the Great Pyramid of Cheops early today and viewed on a television screen a dismantled boat buried about 4,600 years ago in the golden age of the pharaohs.


Singapore Rules Relaxed
LEAD: The Commerce Department announced today that it had eased its export licensing rules on some high-technology goods destined for Singapore.
The changes, which come partly in response to complaints from Congress and American businesses about export controls, will permit shipments of certain lower-level goods such as commonly available computers to Singapore and for re-export to 19 other non-Communist countries without approval from the Commerce Department.

Toyota Sales
LEAD: A senior executive of the Toyota Motor Company said that the company expected a 6 percent sales decline in the United States next year.
Jim Perkins, group vice president for sales and marketing at Toyota's American subsidiary, said the company's vehicle sales in the United States would decline to about 875,000 in 1988, from about 930,000 in 1987.

LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange placed sharp restrictions on program trading yesterday, in the first major regulatory effort to curb the explosion in computer-assisted buying and selling that many believe accelerated the market's drop on Monday.

LEAD: Vince Dooley, the athletic director and head football coach at the University of Georgia, underwent a 90-minute procedure yesterday to clear two blocked arteries near his heart, then was given the go-ahead to be on the sideline Saturday against Kentucky.
Dooley, 55 years old, was admitted to Emory University Hospital in Atlanta on Monday and had the surgery to clear the arteries feeding the heart muscle.

METROPOLITAN DIARY
LEAD: PETER UMBRAS of Bennington, N.Y., is on line at a Manhattan Red Apple supermarket.
In the next line is another man; in a third line two nuns push a cart full of groceries.
The lines move slowly.
The man in the next line eyes the contents of the sisters' cart.
They observe him staring and look at him with puzzled expressions.

LEAD: In an unprecedented move, exchange officials temporarily halted trading today in several of Chicago's financial futures pits because large numbers of the stocks underlying the indexes had stopped trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

LEAD: A crossword puzzle solver trying to figure out an eight-letter word whose second letter is ''u'' and fifth letter ''d'' might once have been in a quandary.
But help is now at hand.
A new electronic spelling checker resembling a large handheld calculator can instantly retrieve words that fit a given pattern.

LEAD: A crisis in relations between Uganda and Kenya has deepened in recent months, with Uganda stationing troops at the border and Kenya pledging to retaliate against any Ugandan attempt to cross the frontier in pursuit of rebels.

The 7-foot, 245-pound Lister played last season with the Seattle SuperSonics, but has not agreed to contract terms and is a training-camp holdout.

LIFE IN THE 30'S
LEAD: IN 1980 Nancy Ellen Jobes was in a car accident.
She was 24 years old and pregnant with her first child; the fetus was killed in the accident and had to be surgically removed.
During the surgery Mrs.
Jobes died, too, at least in the way I would define that term.
Her body remained in the world for seven years after her self had departed, because medical technology enabled it to do so.

LEAD: Jury selection in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. was delayed yesterday as prosecution and defense attorneys worked out the procedures for selecting the jury.

LEAD: It seemed an unlikely event in an incongruous place.
Yesterday, a Jewish City Councilman, Italian-American dignitaries and local history buffs honored the librettist of three of Mozart's operas at a cemetery in Queens as trucks rumbled by.

Stocks Fall In South Africa
LEAD: The Johannesburg Stock Exchange joined the downward global trend in stock prices today following Wall Street's massive market selloff.


Yankee Players Surprised, Not Shocked
LEAD: Players who have seen the changes in the past conceded today they were surprised, although not necessarily shocked, by the latest Yankee shake-up that sent Lou Piniella into the front office as general manager and brought back Billy Martin one more time as manager.


Brokerage Stocks Fall; Large Losses Rumored
LEAD: The stock price of nearly every major brokerage house tumbled yesterday, as rumors circulated that a number of the firms, including E.F.
Hutton Group Inc., Bear Stearns Companies and Morgan Stanley &amp; Co., had sustained big trading losses over the last few days.


Missile Tests Called Success
LEAD: The Air Force said Monday it had conducted two successful tests of its new Amraam missile last week, both of them involving the weapon's ability to discriminate among targets.
The Air Force said the first test was conducted Oct. 14 when an Amraam, or Advanced Medium Range Air-to-Air Missile, was fired at the Pacific Missile Test Center in California.


Racist Jokes in White House Reported in a Book
LEAD: A book written by President Reagan's first Secretary of Education asserts mid-level Administration officials made racist jokes and sexist remarks in discussions on civil rights at the White House.
The President's spokesman today dismissed the allegations.

Intellicorp-I.B.M Software Deal
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said it had entered a joint-development agreement with Intellicorp Inc., a company specializing in artificial intelligence technology.
Financial terms were not disclosed.


A Glittering Tribute to Audrey Hepburn
LEAD: IN ''Sabrina,'' the romantic comedy she made for Billy Wilder in 1954, Audrey Hepburn is told by a fellow student in a Parisian cooking class that when people are happily in love they burn their souffles.
If the 250 guests at the black-tie event honoring Miss Hepburn at the Museum of Modern Art had decided to bake souffles on the spot, there is no doubt that every one of them would have been charred.


GTE Fiber Optics
LEAD: The GTE Corporation said its GTE Laboratories had developed a high-speed fiber-optic system that could nearly triple the number of broadcast-quality video channels that could be transmitted.
The cable is made up of thin strands of glass over which phone calls, computer traffic and video signals are transmitted as light waves.


Rates Fall In Credit Markets
LEAD: Interest rates continued to fall yesterday as the shake-up in the stock market enhanced the appeal of short- and long-term debt securities.


Hawaiian Air Bid
LEAD: Christopher B. Hemmeter, the hotel developer, said he might be unable to arrange financing for the proposed $100 million acquisition of Hawaiian Airlines because of adverse market conditions.
Last month, his company, Hemmeter Investors Inc. of Honolulu, and HAG Inc., parent of the islands' largest airline, agreed to a $50-a-share merger.


Five More Companies Named in Toshiba Case
LEAD: Machine tool companies in France, Britain, Italy and West Germany have been cited by Norwegian police as conspirators in the diversion of sensitive machine tools to the Soviet Union, according to a Congressional source.


Speaker Presses For Tax Change To Keep Dreyfus
LEAD: Assembly Speaker Mel Miller is pressing New York City to agree to changes in its tax policy that he believes would keep the Dreyfus Corporation from moving its headquarters and back-office operations, which employ 1,200 people, out of the city.


Net at Allegis Declines 25%
LEAD: The Allegis Corporation, which is selling off some of its businesses, said today that third-quarter earnings fell 25 percent, to $82.3 million, or $1.41 a share, from $109.8 million, or $2.43 a share, while revenue increased 15 percent, to $2.26 billion from $1.96 billion.
But earnings from continuing operations rose to $77.4 million, or $1.33 a share, from $30 million, or 66 cents, a year earlier.


Press Curbs Remain, Nicaraguan Editor Says
LEAD: When Concepcion Salazar Gonzalez began organizing relatives of Nicaraguan prisoners 10 months ago, the country's two newspapers, both of them pro-Government, studiously ignored her.

Market Turmoil; BACK IN: THE STRATEGY OF ONE TRADER
LEAD: Harvey P. Eisen sits in his fifth-floor office at Third Avenue and 42d Street with $2 billion in stocks at his badly burned fingertips.
The horror of Monday's stock market plunge has passed.
On the third day of the most turbulent week in the history of the New York Stock Exchange, he has begun to buy again.


Nofziger Loses Bid to Dismiss Indictment Under Ethics Law
LEAD: A Federal judge refused today to dismiss a six-count indictment charging Lyn Nofziger, the former White House political aide, with violating ethics laws.


Market Place; Oil Reserves Called Bargain
LEAD: IN more settled times on the stock market, the price of oil company stocks generally move up when the price of oil does, and down when it falls, reflecting the value of the companies' reserves in the ground.
If the companies' stock price declines, that can mean that the market thinks the price of oil at the wellhead is going to fall.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he expected to make progress on arms control during his talks in Moscow on Thursday and Friday, but he did not know how much.

Village Restaurateur Give Up After Holding Police at Bay
LEAD: A 42-year-old restaurant owner barricaded himself inside his Greenwich Village apartment last night, fired six shots from a .45 pistol into the air and held the police at bay for eight hours before surrendering early today, officials said.


Crude Steel Output Up
LEAD: Crude steel output in non-Communist countries rose 6.8 percent in September, to 36.1 million metric tons, from a year before, the International Iron and Steel Institute reported today.
The sharp rise mainly reflected the fact that the USX Corporation in the United States was idle in September 1986 because of a strike.

Surgery for Molitor
LEAD: The Milwaukee Brewers' Paul Molitor has undergone successful elbow surgery, club officials said.
Molitor was bothered by a series of injuries last season and was placed on the disabled list twice.
When he returned after the All-Star Game break, Molitor was inserted into the lineup as the designated hitter because the elbow injury hampered his throwing.

Placating the Stars of 'Whales'
LEAD: There were no real whales in ''The Whales of August'' and no place to buy a cup of coffee on the island where the movie was made.
The weather was nasty, and the director had to point his camera at whirlpools and pretend they were whales.
The 90-year-old star wore four pairs of leg warmers under her summer dress, and the 78-year-old co-star butted heads with the director every day.

Canadian Stocks Rise
LEAD: Canada's stock exchanges followed Wall Street in a sharp rebound today from this week's record plunge.
Preliminary figures showed the Toronto exchange's 300-stock index was up 273.1 points at the close, to 3,250.4.
This represented a 9.2 percent gain from Tuesday's close.


Gen. Ho Ying-chin Dies at 97; A Nationalist Chinese Leader
LEAD: Gen.
Ho Ying-chin, a former Minister of Defense in the Chinese Nationalist Government who served briefly in 1949 as his country's Prime Minister before the Communist takeover of mainland China, died of heart and lung failure Wednesday in Taipei.
He was 97 years old.

NEW YORK INCREASES FINES FOR LANDLORDS IN SAFETY VIOLATIONS
LEAD: Fines for hazardous violations in New York City residential buildings will increase, from $25 to $125 a day, under a new law signed yesterday by Mayor Koch.


ASYLUM FOR SOVIET DANCER
LEAD: A Soviet dancer who left the Moscow Ballet last week during its United States tour has been granted political asylum in the United States, immigration officials said today.


Apple Investment Post
LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it would broaden its strategic investment activity to potential acquisitions of public or privately held companies.
Apple said it had promoted Daniel L. Eilers to vice president of strategic investments, a new position; as director of strategic investments he has been responsible for the company's venture capital efforts.


Health Group Urges Broader AIDS Panel
LEAD: The American Public Health Association urged President Reagan's AIDS commission yesterday to suspend its deliberations until it was reconstituted to include public health leaders, scientific experts on AIDS and representatives of major risk groups such as homosexuals.


Specialists Man the Ramparts
LEAD: All 52 specialists on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange lost money during the enormous sell-off on Monday and Tuesday, possibly as much as $750 million, trying to fulfill their traditional role of maintaining an orderly market, John J. Phelan Jr., chairman of the exchange, disclosed in an interview yesterday.

Private View of a Passionate Collector
LEAD: ''A COLLECTOR has discretion and makes decisions,'' said Leonard A. Lauder.


The Glitz Is Gone
LEAD: The binge is over.
It couldn't go on forever -the quick fortunes, the midnight raids and computer-driven program trades, the junk bonds, poison pills, leveraged buyouts, options - all the glitz and glamour, the danger and thrill.
It's over.


Key Jobs Filled At BancTexas
LEAD: BancTexas Group Inc., a recently recapitalized bank holding company in Dallas, said this week that Nathan C. Collins had been named chairman, president and chief executive.


2 Officers Are Charged With Robbery of 5 Men
LEAD: Two police officers were indicted yesterday on charges of robbing five men at gunpoint of nearly $2,000 while on patrol in the Bronx.

India in a New Offer to Tamil Rebels
LEAD: India made a new offer of amnesty to Tamil guerrillas in Sri Lanka today if they surrendered their arms to an Indian peacekeeping force, an Indian diplomat said here.
There was no immediate reply from the guerrillas.


Washington Talk: Briefing; On the Phones
LEAD: Over the summer, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company installed a new telephone system for all the offices of the House of Representatives.
By all accounts, the system has more bugs than a draft horse in July.


Gorbachev Foe Loses Politburo Post
LEAD: Geidar A. Aliyev, a senior member of the Politburo who reportedly opposed the policies of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, was removed from the ruling body today, the press agency Tass said.
No new members were named.


Friend of Arts Award To Go To Martin E. Segal
LEAD: Martin E. Segal, a longtime supporter and patron of the arts, will be honored Sunday at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, with a dinner and presentation of Town Hall's annual Friend of the Arts award.
On the same date, Town Hall will mark its 66th anniversary.
Both events will be commemorated with an all-Gershwin piano program in the concert hall by Veri and Jamanis, a husband-and-wife duo, at 4 P.M.


U.N. PRAISES DANNY KAYE AT TRIBUTE
LEAD: With pictures, words and music, the United Nations tonight payed tribute to the memory of Danny Kaye, the impish Brooklyn-born entertainer who spent the last decades of his life as the indefatigable United Nations Ambassador at Large for the world's children.

LEAD:  ''I think it is going to come up like it came down.''  Robert Farrell, a stock market strategist.  [ A1:6. ]

Mrs. Reagan Leaving The Hospital Today
LEAD: Nancy Reagan will return to the White House on Thursday, five days after surgery for the removal of a cancerous left breast, President Reagan announced today.


Artisans' Lesson: Restoring the Past
LEAD: David Bayne loves working with wood. ''When I make something out of wood, I feel like it's a contribution, something I'm sharing,'' said Mr.
Bayne, a 32-year-old resident of Northfield, Vt., who has been a cabinetmaker for seven years.
He is now learning to be a furniture conservator - one of a small group of specialists committed to preserving and restoring old furniture.

Oester Draws the Line
LEAD: Ron Oester, the Cincinnati Reds' second baseman, whose season was cut short by a knee injury, says he won't report to the team next spring unless he has a contract.
Murray Cook, the club's new general manger, met with Oester briefly last Friday on whether the club would exercise its option to renew Oester's contract at $650,000 a year.

LEAD: An expert on suicide testified today that a Fort Lauderdale woman had created a psychological climate that emotionally trapped her 17-year-old daughter and was instrumental in the teen-ager's decision to take her own life last year.

LEAD: The pace of United States divestment in South Africa grew slightly this year, but its overall economic impact was weakened by many companies simply shifting to indirect investment, a report said today.

Contras Release Two Clergymen
LEAD: - A Roman Catholic priest said today that he and another clergyman held by Nicaraguan rebels for 11 days were free, and that they had been threatened and treated poorly during their captivity.


Bregman Raises Multifoods Stake
LEAD: Bregman Partners is still interested in the International Multifoods Corporation, despite the stock market's free fall.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Canadian partnership, consisting of the Belzberg and the Bregman families, said that it had increased its stake in the Minneapolis-based food processing company to 9.4 percent, from 7.4 percent.

Stage: The Roundabout Offers 'Of Mice and Men'
LEAD: FOR what John Steinbeck accurately referred to as a ''little book,'' ''Of Mice and Men'' has had a far-reaching success - as a best-selling novel, Broadway play (it was named best play of 1937 by the New York Drama Critics Circle) and Hollywood movie.
In its various incarnations, it has remained, definitively, a work of its period, a time of propulsive social consciousness.


STOCK TURMOIL ENCOURGAING ANALYSTS TO CHALENGE HIS SUPPLY-SIDE POLICIES
LEAD: The stock market's collapse has given many economists who have been critical of President Reagan's economic policies the dramatic, tangible evidence they have sought to make their case more strongly.


Radioactive Gauge Stolen
LEAD: A construction gauge containing radioactive material was stolen from a parked car, and Federal officials warned that it could cause burns and cancer if opened.
The gauge, used for measuring moisture and density of highway construction materials, was stolen Monday or Tuesday in south Philadelphia, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said.


New Name: Avenue Becomes a Boulevard
LEAD: Mayor Koch signed into law yesterday a City Council measure changing the name of Marcus Garvey Avenue to Marcus Garvey Boulevard.

No MTM Offering
LEAD: MTM Entertainment Inc., the production concern co-founded by the actress Mary Tyler Moore, joined the ranks of companies canceling stock offerings because of unsettled market conditions.
MTM, producer of television's ''Hill Street Blues'' and ''St.
Elsewhere,'' said it was postponing indefinitely an initial public offering of four million shares, or 22 percent of its common stock.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Jaguar in the House
LEAD: While investors on and off Capitol Hill are licking their wounds from the ravages of the stock market, one member of Congress is savoring a $125 investment that won him a $60,000 Jaguar convertible.
Representative Thomas A. Luken, an Ohio Democrat, and his wife, Shirley, won the XJ-S model sports car at a church raffle in Cincinnati.

LEAD: Dramatically revising current official statistics, top New York City health officials reported yesterday that AIDS has killed more intravenous drug addicts than homosexuals in the city.


Amoco Profit Up Sharply
LEAD: The Amoco Corporation reported yesterday that its third-quarter profits were $412 million, or $1.60 a share, a substantial improvement over the comparable quarter last year, primarily because of higher crude oil prices.


Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q.A disappearing stairway leads up to my attic.
How can I insulate the space over it, since brackets extend up over the attic floor and prevent the upper side from lying flush with the floor in the attic?
A.The simplest way is to build a shallow ''box'' that extends up into the attic and forms an enclosure around the stairway opening.

DANCE: MAGUY MARIN
LEAD: WHAT will Maguy Marin do next?
To introduce her dance company's week at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave's Festival, the French choreographer gave us nude dancers in ''Babel Babel.'' Fair enough.
On Tuesday night, the New York premiere of her dance-theater piece ''Eden,'' gave us dancers who only looked nude.

We're not hitting and we don't have a couple of our guys in the lineup, which makes for a hole.

Bomb in Danish Parliament
LEAD: - Assailants threw a firebomb inside the Danish Parliament building today, causing no casualties but burning holes in the Prime Minister Poul Schluter's carpet, the police said.
The Prime Minister was in his office at the time but was not hurt.
The entrance to the building is normally locked and monitored by a television camera that the police said had failed to reveal the identity of the attackers.


Goodyear Net Decreases 2%
LEAD: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the world's largest tire company, said today that its third-quarter earnings fell 2 percent, to $178.7 million, from $182.3 million a year ago.


Critic's Notebook; APPRECIATING THE MUSIC IN MUSICOLOGY
LEAD: WILL this be remembered as the era of the musicologist?
The latter half of the 20th century has produced few certifiably great composers.
But it has clearly witnessed an astonishing growth in historical and theoretical information about the art form, with recordings coming to serve as a fundamental scholarly tool.

2d Bus Lane Is Sought For Tunnel
LEAD: Hoping to please most commuters most of the time, even if the rest are inconvenienced, New Jersey officials are seeking bus riders' support for a second bus lane into the Lincoln Tunnel during the morning rush.


S.E.C. Will Investigate Volatility
LEAD: The new chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, David S. Ruder, said yesterday that he had ordered an investigation into the stock market's plunge and partial recovery to determine what steps ''should be taken to ameliorate future market volatility.''

Cards Turn On Power and Turn Off Twins
LEAD: Outgunned and outscored in the World Series, the St.
Louis Cardinals finally found their long-lost striking power tonight, and struck.
And their secret weapon was a utility infielder named Tom Lawless who hadn't hit a home run in three and a half years.

Talking Deals; Using ESOP's In Buyouts
LEAD: ON Wall Street, where financing fads for acquisitions seem to rise and recede with almost the same volatility as the stock market, one of the latest innovations is a hybrid technique.
It combines an old idea, employee stock ownership plans, with a newer one, leveraged buyouts.

News Session By President
LEAD: President Reagan's news conference will be broadcast live at 8 o'clock tonight on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, and on CNN, the Cable News Network.
In addition, some local affiliates of PBS and SIN, the Spanish International Network, will carry the address, either live or as a tape-delayed broadcast.

Washington Talk: Briefing; Marines in Shorts
LEAD: For nine years the United States Marines have had a friendly side bet with their cousins across the Atlantic, the British Royal Marines, as to which could outrun the other in the Marine Corps Marathon, a race that has become such a popular fixture in the capital that it attracts 10,000 runners from around the world.


Washington Post Trading
LEAD: For two and a half days this week, during the course of the widest gyrations in stock market history, stockholders of the Washington Post Company had no idea how their stock performed.


Robert Madden Hill Is Dead, Federal Appeals Court Judge
LEAD: Judge Robert Madden Hill of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, who presided over the Billy Sol Estes trial in 1979 as a Federal District judge, died Monday on a flight from Africa.
He was 59 years old.


The Dance: Dennis Wayne's Troupe
LEAD: DANCERS has always had good dancers.
Ever since Dennis Wayne founded his company, Dancers, in 1975, it has been blessed with talented dancers.
The group looked as good as ever on Tuesday night when it opened a week's season at the Triplex Theater of Manhattan Community College.

HONDURAN URGING HALT IN CONTRA AID
LEAD: President Jose Azcona Hoyo of Honduras said today that American military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels should be suspended at least until next January.


Ousted From Politburo
LEAD: Geidar A. Aliyev, who reportedly opposed the policies of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, was removed from Soviet ruling body.

Court Orders City to Provide Drug for Inmate With AIDS
LEAD: A State Supreme Court justice has ordered the New York City Department of Correction to provide the drug AZT to an inmate on Rikers Island who has AIDS.


When Good Pitches Lead to Bad Results
LEAD: ALL these years later, in an unhappy postgame World Series clubhouse, the scowl on Juan Berenguer's face was familiar.
It was just like the one he first wore nine years ago on the mound at Shea Stadium, in the days when the Mets were searching for hope and Berenguer was part of the search.


3 Ex-Customs Aides Charged With Aiding in Drug Imports
LEAD: Three former United States Customs supervisors who are suspected of warning smugglers away from patrol boats and steering agents in the wrong direction were among 23 people charged Tuesday with importing cocaine and marijuana.

LEAD: In the sunshine that followed the storm, the wounds of smashed brown limbs and torn green earth seemed to torment the English.

Tassels and Tiebacks
LEAD: RONNIE HENDLER is the third generation of the Hendler family, and the first woman, to work at Hyman Hendler &amp; Sons, a ribbon and trimming shop.
She is pleased about the popularity of the English country style. ''The chintzy English look is very big, so tassels fit perfectly,'' she said.

Newsweek Offering The Match Plan
LEAD: Although plainly unhappy about Time magazine's announced MAX-Plan of advertising rates, Gerard Smith, publisher of Newsweek, is going to initiate a similar plan with the Jan. 4 issue.
His is called the Match Plan.
The essence of both plans is to reward advertisers with discounts for increasing the share of all news weekly spending in a single magazine.


U.S. May Let Some Illegals Stay If Relatives Qualify for Amnesty
LEAD: The Administration announced a policy today under which some illegal aliens may be allowed to stay in the United States if they have immediate relatives who qualify for amnesty under the new immigration law.


DEBATE OVER BORK BEGINS IN SENATE
LEAD: With the majority of senators already counted in opposition, Judge Robert H. Bork's Supreme Court nomination finally reached the Senate floor today, three and a half months after President Reagan had sent it to Capitol Hill.

LEAD: It has become an unwelcome custom, but once again, the third period was the period of consequence for the Rangers, who can't seem to carry sufficient intensity through an entire game.

Boeing Plane Sale
LEAD: The Boeing Company, which is based in Seattle, said it had completed the sale of eight 737-300 aircraft worth a total of $210 million to two European airlines.
Lufthansa of West Germany purchased five, while Maersk Air of Denmark purchased three.
The sale brings the total number of 737's sold to 1,906, more than any other commercial aircraft.


NO TEARS FOR LUPONE'S RENO
LEAD: As Reno Sweeney, the brassy nightclub singer in ''Anything Goes,'' Patti LuPone not only gets to perform such immortal Cole Porter songs as ''I Get a Kick Out of You'' and ''You're the Top,'' but also gets to tap-dance and tango, crack jokes and cut up, yearn over one man and fall in love with another, and even - as if she had not already won its heart - to go so far as to wink broadly at the audience while stealing yet another scene.


Deficit Discussions Start on Capitol Hill
LEAD: White House officials and Congressional leaders began talks today to see if they could reach a compromise that would reduce the budget deficit and calm nervous financial markets.

LEAD: THE macabre caricature of Massenet's ''Manon'' currently offered by the Metropolitan Opera was partly redeemed Monday night by a truly memorable portrayal of the Chevalier des Grieux, sung for the first time in New York by Alfredo Kraus.

LEAD: LOUIS MUSTILLO is far from alone in his one-man show, ''Circumstances,'' at the Susan Bloch Theater.
The seven characters he creates in eight short takes all create other characters who buzz around them like unswattable flies or, in a couple of cases, nightmarish aliens.

LEAD: The State Attorney General is looking into Gov.
Evan Mecham's failure to disclose a $350,000 loan he received before his election last fall, , The Arizona Republic newspaper reported today.
State law requires such disclosures.

Jacqueline du Pre Is Buried in London
LEAD: The coffin of the English cellist being carried yesterday into cemetery in London.
At center was Miss du Pre's husband, the conductor and pianist Daniel Barenboim, and at right was the violinist Pinchas Zukerman.
Miss du Pre, whose career was ended by multiple sclerosis in 1971, died Monday at age 42.

For Commodity Traders, a Week Like No Other
LEAD: Herbert Malkind has had trouble sleeping this week.
He woke up at 3 A.M. on Tuesday and 4 A.M. today, worried whether the trades he had made the day before on the floor of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange would hold up in the morning.

LEAD: Israel, Jordan and the United States are discussing a new proposal for Middle East peace talks in which Jordan and Israel would negotiate directly under the joint auspices of Moscow and Washington, a senior Israeli official said today.

SALVADOR DIVIDED OVER AID TO POLICE
LEAD: A new package of United States aid for the police here has touched off a debate about how to improve the Government's human rights record and prompted opposition both from human rights advocates and some military leaders.


How to Make Star Wars Work
LEAD: Technology is America's strong suit in countering Soviet military might.
Nowhere is that strength more evident than in the esoteric new devices being developed under the Strategic Defense Initiative, like computers, sensors, nuclear-directed energy weapons and free-electron lasers.
The White House is eager to deploy a missile defense system as soon as possible.


HAROLD V. WEBB
LEAD: Harold V. Webb, former executive director of the National School Boards Association, died of cancer Monday at the Evanston Hospital in Evanston, Ill.
He was 68 years old.
Mr.
Webb, who lived in Wilmette, Ill., served from 1961 to 1977 as executive director of the association, which has its headquarters in Alexandria, Va., and represents 15,000 of the nation's local school boards.


Nobel in Economics To M.I.T. Professor
LEAD: Robert M. Solow, a 63-year-old professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science today for seminal contributions to the theory of economic growth.

Report on Daniels
LEAD: An inquiry by Nevada-Las Vegas into possible recruiting violations involving Lloyd Daniels, the former New York City high school basketball star, has received contradictory information and has reached no conclusions.
The report will be sent to the National Collegiate Athletic Association.
The investigation stemmed from an article in Newsday last March saying that Daniels had received cash, clothing, a car, a motorcycle and free housing from Las Vegas coaches, boosters and other representatives of the school.

LEAD: Leading commercial banks have been calling in loans made to stockbrokers or demanding more collateral in the wake of Monday's 508-point decline in the stock market.


Japan Chooses the F-16
LEAD: Japan, as expected, has decided to develop its next fighter plane in cooperation with the St.
Louis-based General Dynamics Corporation.
F-16's will be built in Japan for $36 million each, Tokyo officials said today.

'Rock-Dwelling Predators,' on CBS
LEAD: WHAT have we here?
A fine wildlife documentary, for one thing; an interesting choice for network prime-time programming, for another. ''Mysteries of the Rock-Dwelling Predators,'' on Channel 2 at 8:30 P.M., pre-empts, as they say, the CBS Vietnam series ''Tour of Duty.'' Lions, leopards and little furry creatures replace grunts and Vietcong.


Long Honeymoon Ends For Investors in Britain
LEAD: Millions of Britons who had bought stock since 1979, when Margaret Thatcher came to power pledging to make Britain a nation of shareholders, were rudely introduced this week to the notion of market risk: prices go down as well as up.

LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL A3-14  A new plan for Mideast peace talks isbeing discussed by Israel, Jordan and Washington, in which Jordan and Israel would negotiate directly under the joint auspices of Washington and Moscow, an Israeli official said.


China Theory on Plunge
LEAD: China, in its first comment on the collapse of world stock prices, said today that the drop was an inevitable consequence of the ''casino economy'' in the United States.
Pu Shan, the director of the influential Institute of World Politics and Economy, said that the plunge of prices on the New York and other world exchanges had been expected for some time.

Officials Laud Pilot's Efforts in Crash
LEAD: The military pilot whose jet lost power and hit a hotel Tuesday, killing nine people, ''did everything he could'' to avoid the disaster before ejecting safely, an Air Force general said today.


Drug May Help the Overanxious on S.A.T.'s
LEAD: A drug used to control high blood pressure has dramatically improved Scholastic Aptitude Test scores for students suffering from unusually severe anxiety, according to a preliminary study.


A. M. AL-KAISOUNI
LEAD: Abdel Muneim al-Kaisouni, Former Egyptian Finance and Economy Minister, died of a heart attack today in London, the national Middle East News Agency reported.
He was 71 years old.

LEAD: A Polish court opened hearings today into charges that the chief Government spokesman slandered four Polish citizens by asserting that they had subversive ties to an official of the United States Embassy.

LEAD: THESE are some stores in the metropolitan area with wide stocks of wall-to-wall carpeting.

The prices are per square yard and include installation and padding unless otherwise noted.

LEAD: Under the resolutions that created them, the special Congressional committees that investigated the Iran-contra affair are to go out of existence Oct. 30.
But the preparation of the committees' final report took longer than anticipated, and the report has to be declassified by the White House and then printed.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Monday about the evidence that female AIDS patients are dying more quickly than male ones omitted the identity of the organization that detected this difference in California.
The Ursa Institute made the finding in a consulting project, directed by Paul Harder, for the state health agency.


Quake Close to San Francisco
LEAD: A moderate earthquake rattled the San Francisco Bay area tonight, but officials said there were no immediate reports of damage or injuries.

LEAD: A Queens teen-ager testified yesterday that he saw a baseball bat in the hands of another youth who, prosecutors say, had used the bat shortly before to beat a black man in the Howard Beach case.

LEAD: Under an informal and unpublicized compromise, Representative Mario Biaggi has not voted in Congress since his conviction last month on charges of accepting unlawful gratuities and obstruction of justice, Congressional aides say.

LEAD: Just to be sure, Bob Forsch had checked for any signs of trouble.

Louis Cardinals, warmed up for the fourth game of the World Series.


Penalties Under Study
LEAD: Brian O'Neill, the National Hockey League vice president who handles disciplinary matters, is considering possible penalties for Patrick Roy, the Montreal Canadiens' goalie, in conection with a slashing incident.
On Monday in Montreal, Roy came out of his net during the closing minutes of a game against the Minnesota North Stars and used his stick to pound Warren Babe, a Minnesota forward, who limped off the ice with a badly bruised ankle.

LEAD: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings had risen 63.4 percent, but also said that it would eliminate 1,000 jobs as part of a restructuring.

LEAD: The Soviet Union's national basketball team, whose plane trip from Moscow was delayed a day because of fog, arrived here tonight for an international exhibition series that will include the Milwaukee Bucks of the National Basketball Association.


ITT's Earnings Expand 66.6%
LEAD: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that higher earnings in its insurance, consumer finance, hotel and communications businesses lifted the company's third-quarter profit 66.6 percent.
Net income totaled $210 million, or $1.39 a share, up from $126 million, or 82 cents a share, a year before.


Gunmen Said to Be Sikhs Kill 11 In Delhi on Eve of Hindu Festival
LEAD: Terrorists said to be Sikhs killed at least 11 people Tuesday night in a burst of shooting here on the eve of a Hindu festival.

Gary Gaetti and Tom Brunansky could see the fifth inning, and then the seventh, as if they had just happened.

Greenspan, Under New Pressure, Drawing Mixed Reviews
LEAD: Some say the honeymoon is over.
Others describe it as a trial by fire.
Whatever the catch phrase, nearly everyone agrees that the volatile financial markets have put Alan Greenspan, the new chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, in one of the hottest seats in town.

LEAD: Vince Coleman has always said that, before he can run, he must hit.

Wright Buildings: The Future and Past
LEAD: The agenda was twofold: to discuss the future of Frank Lloyd Wright's remaining buildings, and for those who lived in Wright-designed houses, to share restoration experiences.
This weekend 160 Wright homeowners and 52 architectural historians, curators and academics met at the third annual ''Wright Places'' conference and tour, sponsored by the Frank Lloyd Wright Home and Studio Foundation here.


Rabbits Produce Anti-Cold Agent; Chicken Soup Stock Is Unchanged
LEAD: Protective antibodies have been produced in rabbits against viruses of the common cold, suggesting that vaccines might someday be possible against these widespread infections, researchers reported yesterday.


The Editorial Notebook; A Good Revolution for Federal Courts?
LEAD: After Nov. 1, a person who commits a Federal crime will no longer be subject to indeterminate sentencing and parole.
In concept, that's a welcome revolution - current sentencing and parole practices are outmoded and confusing.

New York's AIDS Programs Shift Focus to Drug Abusers
LEAD: Responding to a report that intravenous drug users have replaced homosexuals as the major AIDS risk group in New York City, city health officials said yesterday that the fight against AIDS was shifting to addicts and the predominantly black and Hispanic communities where they live.

LEAD: The Vatican announced today that its budget deficit this year would be about $3.6 million less than expected because of improved fund raising and cost-cutting measures.


Stennis Leaves the Hospital
LEAD: Senator John Stennis, the 86-year-old Mississippi Democrat, was released from Walter Reed Army Medical Center today, three days after he underwent surgery to correct a prostate gland problem.
The hospital said tests following the Monday operation revealed no evidence of cancer.

Defense Cuts That Won't Hurt Defense
LEAD: The President and Congress have four weeks to put the budget together.
If, despite Wall Street's warning, they still can't come to terms, the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law takes effect on Nov. 20.
Nominally, this meat-ax approach to deficit reduction will cut ''across the board'' - $11.5 billion from non-defense spending and the same from defense.

LEAD: The Department of Trade and Industry in Britain has cleared the way for the takeover of the British life insurance concern Equity and Law by the French financial services group Compagnie du Midi, the French company said.

To the San Francisco Giants, it's Candlestick Park, a house of horrors to visiting teams with its gale winds and wintry temperatures.
To the St.
Louis Cardinals, it's Busch Stadium, mostly because it's big.

LEAD: In the wake of this week's plunge in stock prices and its implications for slower economic growth in 1988, some Wall Street firms are telling clients to cut back on stocks and - if they stick with equities - to go with safer, high-yielding investments such as electric and telephone utilities.

Woolridge Out
LEAD: The Nets, who were hobbled by injuries last season, have lost their leading scorer for up to four weeks, two weeks before this season is scheduled to open.
Orlando Woolridge, the small forward who led the team with an average of 20.7 points a game, cut the pinkie of his right hand with scissors last Sunday at the Nets' training camp at Princeton, N.J.

Art: A New Direction For Susan Rothenberg
LEAD: SUSAN ROTHENBERG'S eagerly awaited exhibition defines the direction in which she has been moving since she exhausted the emblematic images of horses and heads that established her reputation.
It is her first show at the Sperone Westwater Gallery, a larger and more neutral space than the Willard Gallery, which closed last summer and with which she, more than any other artist, was identified.


POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
LEAD: Inkhay, Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street (864-5400).
The Andean quartet performs music from the highlands of Bolivia, Peru, Ecuador, Chile, Colombia, Chile and Argentina, on 26 different instruments, some of ancient origin.
Members include the leader Pepe Santana, who has pioneered the presentation of traditional Andean music in New York, the Ecuadorian harp virtuoso Atahualpa Poalasin and the Bolivian multi-instrumentalists Marcelo Pena and Fredy Maranon.


BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 23, 1987
LEAD: THE STOCK MARKET TURMOIL  The stock market bent but did not break.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 77.42 points, at 1,950.43, but even this was an improvement over an earlier 140-point deficit.
Trading opened with a blizzard of sell orders that caused many participants to expect a rout as complete as Monday's, but a number of factors helped the market to weather the storm.


City Council Offers Bill to Ban Smoking in Most Indoor Public Areas
LEAD: Leaders of the New York City Council yesterday introduced a bill that would ban smoking in most indoor public areas and restrict it in restaurants, stores and offices.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 408 money market mutual funds increased $9.64 billion, to $256.84 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 108 institutional funds were up $4.29 billion, to $69.36 billion.
Assets of the 207 general purpose funds were up $4.12 billion, to $78.14 billion.


Fermenta Rejection
LEAD: Fermenta A.B., the debt-laden Swedish biotechnology group, rejected a United States company's bid for its overseas assets, in part because the Wall Street plunge might have made it harder to finance the deal.
Fermenta's suitor, Trans Resources Inc., a private chemicals and fertilizers group, had offered $218 million for Fermenta's overseas assets in September.

Wickes to Sell 3 Subsidiaries
LEAD: Wickes Companies Inc., streamlining further, said today that it planned to sell three operating units and expected to receive more than the book value of $600 million.
The company plans to use the proceeds to retire debt, repurchase stock and possibly make acquisitions.

The flower show continues through Nov. 15.
It will be accompanied by demonstrations of ikebana (Japanese flower arranging) and origami tomorrow between 11 A.M.

LEAD: Spain said today that it would resume deadlocked talks with the United States next month over cutting the number of American troops stationed here.

Economic Scene; People Wonder What to Think
LEAD: WHAT lies in the minds and bellies of the people who buy and sell stocks these hectic days, driving the market up, driving it down and driving each other crazy?
The forces are so complicated and contradictory.
Rationality, the normal assumption of economics, clashes with fear, the subject matter of abnormal psychology.

She got in touch with the F.B.I., which took Mr.
Ustinov into custody to insure his safety.

LEAD: An expert on suicide testified Wednesday that a Fort Lauderdale woman had created a psychological climate that emotionally trapped her 17-year-old daughter and was instrumental in the teen-ager's decision to kill herself.


About Real Estate; Projects Cater to Couples Moving From Big Home
LEAD: Older buyers who have spent 20 years or more in a detached house on an acre or two of land often have difficulty coming to terms with the idea of moving into the densely populated setting of an apartment building or town house complex.
They want to be rid of the problems of caring for the large house and yard, yet yearn for the space and privacy.


The Financial Crisis, Close to Home
LEAD: New York City is a capital of world finance, and this week it's become a capital of financial trauma.
How will the fallout affect New York and other cities where financial services play a big role in local spending and taxing?
Common sense dictates serious local planning for the worst, even as Federal officials wrestle with the budget and international trade issues.


AUCTIONS
LEAD: AMERICANA - a major folk carving of Punch, a rare Paul Revere silver teapot, a Lincoln letter and an important pair of New York gilded and brass inlaid classical card tables -will be auctioned today at 2 P.M. and tomorrow at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration announced today that it was putting curbs on the export of some high technology products to China, in what officials said was a proportional response to continued Chinese sale of Silkworm anti-ship missiles to Iran.

This is your basic witches' brew of odd-looking neighbors and rosary beads, overlaid with great dollops of thunder and lightning.

LEAD: Senator Daniel K. Inouye, the chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Indian Affairs, offered a compromise today over whether the Museum of the American Indian should be moved to Washington or remain in New York City.


Enron to Close Unit After Costly Trades
LEAD: The Enron Corporation said today that it would permanently close its Enron Oil Corporation subsidiary after learning that the unit had lost $85 million because of unauthorized trading in the petroleum futures markets.

Corrections
LEAD: A report in Business Day on Wednesday about the Bristol-Myers Company's earnings misstated the company's third-quarter sales and the percentage increase.
Sales totaled $1.38 billion, up 9.5 percent from $1.26 billion in the third quarter of 1986.


Sikh Rally Faces Amritsar Curfew
LEAD: The police imposed a curfew on this city today to prevent militant Sikh separatists from holding a rally at the Golden Temple, the Sikhs' most sacred shrine.


Clabir May Sell
LEAD: The Clabir Corporation said it was considering the sale of its entire 83 percent interest in Ambrit Inc., a food maker, as well as the Flinchbaugh division of its General Defense Corporation subsidiary.
The diversified holding and management concern said it had intended to sell only part of its Ambrit stake but had received indications of interest from potential buyers of all of Ambrit.

LEAD: Kuwait's main offshore oil terminal was seriously damaged in a missile attack today, and Kuwaiti and American officials said Iran was responsibile.


Scorned Witness Testifies From the Shadows
LEAD: At the start of yesterday's session in the Howard Beach case, the light in the courtroom was bad.
Some bulbs in the high ceiling had burned out.
And the judge said he was putting a lamp at the edge of the bench to shine down on the witness so the jury could see him clearly.


Looking for a Leader
LEAD: When the United States Olympic Committee executive board meets this weekend in Oklahoma City, its most important order of business will be to name an executive director to succeed George Miller, who resigned under pressure two months ago.
A likely selection, according to committee officials, is Harvey Schiller, the commissioner of the Southeastern Conference, who was among the finalists for the job two and a half years ago when Miller was named.


Fashion Accolades in Paris
LEAD: Jean-Paul Gaultier, the avant-garde designer who spoofs traditional clothing, was welcomed into the fashion establishment last night.
He was honored at an elaborate ceremony at the Opera sponsored by the French Federation of Couture, Ready-to-Wear and Creators of Fashion, the organization of fashion trade groups.

LEAD: It is a predicament that criminal lawyers often face: how to handle key witnesses whose less-than-pristine pasts make them vulnerable to attack when they take the stand.

LEAD: ''Life has a great deal up its sleeve,'' said Joseph Brodsky, who was exiled from the Soviet Union as a ''social parasite'' 15 years ago and lauded today as the winner of the Nobel Prize in literature.

LEAD: The Soviet magazine Novy Mir is negotating to publish the works of Joseph Brodsky, who was imprisoned and then banished from his native country for his poetry and who won the Nobel Prize in Literature today, a Government spokesman said today.

MONSANTO LIABLE IN '79 DIOXIN SPILL
LEAD: After one of the nation's longest jury trials, the Monsanto Company was found liable today for failing to warn a Missouri town about the risks of a 1979 chemical spill.
The jury awarded plaintiffs $16.2 million in punitive damages.

LEAD: NOW the World Series is returning to the Decibeldome in Minnesota, where Whitey Herzog couldn't even hear himself think last weekend.
Maybe that's why the Twins won the first two games, 10-1 and 8-4.

LEAD: Federal prosecutors plan to rest their case in a major racketeering trial in Manhattan without calling a key Mafia figure who was supposed to be an important witness.


Soviet Team Eager To Play the Bucks
LEAD: Ivan Edeshko will probably never be suitably recognized for his contributions to the development of basketball as a global sport.
As a youngster in the Soviet Union he was never his team's most dominating player.
And as a coach he is only beginning to emerge in his country as an influential and respected teacher of the game.

The answer is, ''Plenty!,'' provided the show has an inner coherence and is not just recycled auction material.


Girl Saved From Subway Tracks
LEAD: A 15-year-old girl was pushed onto subway tracks in Manhattan as a train approached and rescued by a stranger yesterday as two other bystanders chased and held the assailant until the police arrived, the authorities said.


Union Carbide Reports Gains
LEAD: The Union Carbide Corporation said today that its third-quarter operating income rose 76 percent, to $74 million, thanks to a strong performance by the company's chemicals and plastics divisions.


Spy's Signal Cited in Cuban Crisis
LEAD: As the Cuban missile crisis unfolded 25 years ago, a Soviet military officer spying for the West sent a signal that the Kremlin planned to attack.
But a mid-level agent of the Central Intelligence Agency decided not to pass the information up to the White House, according to a memoir released today.

LEAD: Insisting that he is not a candidate for President, Donald J. Trump flew to New Hampshire, the state with the earliest Presidential primary, and today delivered what sounded like an impassioned campaign speech to an enthusiastic audience.

LEAD: THOUGH it's a separate novel, Mario Puzo's ''Sicilian'' functions as an extended insert within his ''Godfather'' epic, being an elaboration on what happened during the two years that the young Mafioso heir Michael Corleone was hiding out in Sicily after his brush with the New York law.

Investor Euphoria Is Now Subdued
LEAD: Tentative optimism gave way to nervous caution among small investors yesterday.
After a wave of bargain hunting on Tuesday and Wednesday, small investors seemed more willing to watch and wait as the market took another dive, brokerage officials around the country said.

LEAD: HE forbidding Black Rock, as the CBS building on Avenue of the Americas at 53d Street is dubbed, has sprouted an exotic flower called China Grill, an offshoot of Chinoise on Main in Santa Monica, Calif.

LEAD: Workers at the Government plants that make plutonium for nuclear bombs are being endangered and sometimes injured because managers are ignoring safety requirements, safety auditors told a House subcommittee today.


Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption yesterday about the funeral of the cellist Jacqueline du Pre described the end of her career incorrectly.
She was stricken with multiple sclerosis in 1971, but her final concerts were in 1973.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Blue-Chip Leader for Task Force: Nicholas Frederick Brady
LEAD: Nicholas F. Brady once described himself as the kind of man who likes to prove the experts wrong.


New York Film Festival Head Forced Out
LEAD: Richard Roud, the longtime director of the New York Film Festival, was removed from his position yesterday when the board of the Film Society of Lincoln Center voted unanimously to accept his resignation, which was requested last week.
Mr.
Roud has been with the film festival, a project of the Film Society, for its entire 25 years.


Office-Towers Plan Is Supported in Rally By 7,000 Unionists
LEAD: Four days after a demonstration to protest two huge office towers planned for Columbus Circle, more than 7,000 trade union members rallied yesterday to express their support for the construction project.


Theater: 'Cabaret' and Joel Grey Return
THERE can't be a creepier sight on Broadway right now than Joel Grey.
Back in the role of the sleazy emcee in the musical ''Cabaret,'' the actor is made up just as he was in 1966 - with patent-leather hair, rouged cheeks, purple lips and drag-queen eyelashes.
He darts about like an overwound wind-up doll, twirling his cane with a spastic jerkiness.
As his eyes bulge, so his tongue has a most appalling way of flopping out of his mouth.
And when Mr.
Grey sings, his voice is a piercing siren that doesn't so much welcome revelers to his cabaret, the Kit Kat Klub, as lure them into the hell lurking just out of view - Berlin, 1929.

LEAD: A Miami dispatch about a psychiatrist's testimony on the suicide of a 17-year-old Florida girl was inadvertently omitted from some editions yesterday; a duplicate of an unrelated article appeared under its headline.

Topics of The Times; Another for a Poet
LEAD: Rarely have the Swedes displayed as much wit and sense as in bestowing the Nobel Prize in Literature on Joseph Brodsky, whose writing shimmers, just as their citation says, with raillery, parody and an amazing mastery of English idiom.

BOLD DANCE PROGRAMS THAT EMBRACE SOCIAL ISSUES
LEAD: DANCE, like life, has a way of swinging between extremes.
In modern dance, for instance, the socially involved choreography of the 1930's was very much a thing of the past by the early 60's, when minimalism and abstract formalism came into fashion.
This weekend's varied dance offerings suggest there is a renewed emphasis on work that looks to social issues, although there are performances that range along the spectrum.

Korean Trade Surplus
LEAD: South Korea recorded a $1.27 billion trade surplus in September, putting the total for the year so far at $6.93 billion, the Bank of Korea said today.
The September figure was South Korea's biggest monthly surplus and indicated that the country's economy has weathered a wave of summer strikes.

LEAD: HOW many talented actors does it take to steal a Porsche?

LEAD: Two more suspects were charged yesterday in the slaying of Mildred Greene, a 61-year-old Queens taxi dispatcher who was killed after she testified before a grand jury about a gun battle she had witnessed outside her office, the authorities said.

LEAD: A giant laser station under construction high atop a mountain in the Soviet Union has been photographed by private cameras in space, giving civilian experts on the military their first glimpse of the top-secret site.

LEAD: The Procter &amp; Gamble Company reported today that its profit in its first fiscal quarter rose 30.4 percent.

Correction
LEAD: An article on Sept. 28 about the 200th anniversary of Erasmus Hall High School in Brooklyn misstated its ranking among the oldest public schools in the country.
Hartford High, founded 350 years ago, is among public schools that are older than Erasmus Hall.

Film: 'John and the Missus,' Set in Stark Newfoundland
LEAD: Despite its terrible title and the complete lack of fanfare with which it arrived at the Quad Cinema yesterday, the Canadian film ''John and the Missus'' is a fine little sleeper.
Though it has a good-sized cast, it amounts to a one-man show.
Gordon Pinsent, best known as a Canadian television actor, has adapted his own novel and written and directed this film, in which he also stars.

For Cleaner City Campaigns
LEAD: Albany may be deadlocked over campaign finance reform, but the City Council of New York still has plenty of room to maneuver.
A bold plan before the Council would help curb the impact of big money on politics: all campaigns for city office would be subject to new controls and public financing.


Maxeda vonHesse, 74, Former Speech Teacher
LEAD: Maxeda vonHesse, a speech teacher whose clients included Nelson A. Rockefeller and Christian A. Herter, died of lymphoma Sept. 22 at St.
Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center.
She was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan and Daytona Beach, Fla.


Tours of Art Studios
LEAD: Visitors to the Upper West Side will be able to go through the studios of resident artists during ''Open Studios '87.'' The free open house, held over the next two weekends, is sponsored by the West Side Arts Coalition.
In addition to individual studios, stops are included at the Cork Gallery at Lincoln Center and the West Side Y.M.C.A., at West 63d Street and Broadway.


Transactions
LEAD: BASEBALL
DETROIT (AL) - Sent Dickie Noles, pitcher, to the Chicago Cubs as the player to be named in the trade that brought Noles to Detroit.
MINNESOTA (AL) - Claimed Dwight Lowry, catcher, on waivers from the Detroit Tigers.
PITTSBURGH (NL) - Announced the resignation of Malcolm M.


INSIDE
LEAD:  Soviet Laser Threat Seen
The Soviet Union has developed lasers capable of destroying low-orbiting United States satellites, an Air Force general said.
Page 62.
Robertson on Birth Rates
Pat Robertson, campaigning in New England, said United States Government policy should encourage the birth of more children.


Teamster Move Is Seen As Harmful to U.S. Suit
LEAD: Law-enforcement officials and legal experts outside the Government said today that a reaffiliation by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters with the A.F.L.-C.I.O. could undercut the Justice Department's effort to put the teamsters under Federal control.


Guns, Not Olive Trees Welcome in West Bank
LEAD: To the Editor:


Robertson Urges New Policy To Increase U.S. Birth Rate
LEAD: Pat Robertson, the Republican Presidential hopeful, said today that Government policy should encourage the birth of more American children to pay future bills and to stave off the decline of ''our culture and our values.''

Daggett Recovering
LEAD: Tim Daggett, the American gymnast, was recovering well yesterday in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, after having undergone surgery for two broken bones in his left leg.


Triangle Industries To Merge With CJI
LEAD: CJI Industries, a producer and distributor of coin and currency handling products. proposed a $35-a-share merger yesterday with Triangle Industries, the nation's biggest container maker.


REAGAN 'SADDENED'
LEAD: One of the fiercest battles ever waged over a Supreme Court nominee ended today as the Senate decisively rejected the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork.


Henley Said to Buy Santa Fe Shares
LEAD: Henley Group Inc., which said last summer that it had proposed discussions of a friendly merger with the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation, appears to be buying shares of the company on the open market, market sources said. ''They bought every share in the world,'' one source said.
Henley and Santa Fe both declined comment.

LEAD: The Telex Corporation disclosed that it had held negotiations with unidentified third parties interested in acquiring the company for more than the $65 a share offered by the New York investor Asher B. Edelman in a hostile bid.

PATH Adds Trains For Rush Hours
LEAD: More PATH trains will be operating between Hoboken and New York City during morning and evening rush hours beginning Monday, with trains departing as often as every three minutes, officials say.


Film: 'Nightflyers' Science Fiction Thriller
LEAD: ''This ship is alive!,'' says a telepathic crewmember on a 21st century spaceship. ''It's a seething malignant presence and it hates all of you!'' The ship's captain, whose mother is a jealous computer, has a confession of his own: ''Contact with humans will probably kill me.'' There you have the problem with ''Nightflyers''; it is the talkingest movie ever to pose as a science-fiction adventure.


JARDINE'S ENDS OFFER TO BROKER
LEAD: In another reverberation from Monday's stock market plunge, Jardine Matheson Holdings, the giant British-owned conglomerate in Hong Kong, has withdrawn its $390 million offer to buy a substantial stake of the Bear Stearns Companies, one of Wall Street's most aggressive investment firms.

Savings Units, Banks in Loss
LEAD: The 13,888 banks and savings and loan associations in the United States lost $5.4 billion in the first half of this year, according to Sheshunoff &amp; Company, a bank-rating service, in contrast to earnings of $9.03 billion a year earlier.


Helping Families Cope With Alzheimer's
LEAD: Because of the devastating impact on families, an increasing number of states are establishing day-care and other programs to serve the estimated two million Americans who have Alzheimer's disease, an incurable process of mental deterioration that robs victims of their memories and reasoning abilities.


Recital: Joan Fuerstman
LEAD: Joan Fuerstman, a mezzo-soprano who has appeared often with early music and oratorio groups in New York and elsewhere, gave a song recital Tuesday night at Merkin Concert Hall that showed a better talent for certain kinds of singing than for choosing a program to suit her strengths.

Jump in Local Costs Spurred by Apparel
LEAD: Pushed ahead by the highest monthly price increase in women's and girls' apparel in 35 years, the Consumer Price Index for the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in September, the Labor Department reported yesterday.


Aquino Praises Anti-Communists
LEAD: President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines during rally yesterday in a seaside neighborhood of Davao City where she declared that residents there were a model for the fight against Communism. (AP)

Correction
LEAD: A dispatch on Monday from Goiania, Brazil, about a nuclear accident there misstated the rate of decay for cesium 137.
The isotope has a half-life of 30 years.


Antiquarian Book Fair
LEAD: More than 70 book dealers from the United States, England and Canada are to display thousands of volumes, maps and prints this weekend at the Eighth Antiquarian Book Fair, at the Trinity School, 101 West 91st Street.
Hours are 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. today and tomorrow.
Admission is $5 for today and $3 for tomorrow.


Special Way With Produce
LEAD: Lee Grimsbo collects forgotten varieties of fruits and vegetables the way some people collect Battersea boxes or Presidential autographs.
This ''collector's mania,'' as he calls it, has helped to change the face of the produce business.
All of us have enjoyed the fruits of his passion for six years.


Dance: New Leads In 'Journey'
LEAD: There was a time when changes of cast were rare in the Martha Graham Dance Company and this proved especially true with respect to roles Miss Graham had originally choreographed for herself.


T.G.I.F. on Wall St.: Time to Recover
LEAD: Leaning against a pole outside the New York Stock Exchange during yesterday's final hour of trading, Thomas K. Regan, a battle-weary trader with Baker, Watts &amp; Company, was finally beginning to relax.

Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''There is now a full and permanent record by which the future may judge not only me but the proper nature of a confirmation proceeding.''
- Judge Robert H. Bork.  [ 1:3. ]


Korean Trade Surplus
LEAD: South Korea's trade surplus with the United States grew 27.7 percent in the first nine months of this year, to $6.77 billion, from $5.3 billion a year ago, the Korea Foreign Trade Association reported today.
For the year, the surplus could reach a record $10 billion, compared with $7.3 billion in 1986, association officials said.

Correction
LEAD: A brief article on Thursday about a suit filed by the author of a play entitled ''Moms,'' against the star and others connected with another production by the same name at the Astor Place Theater, reported the program credits incorrectly for the second production.
Ben Caldwell, a co-defendant named in the suit, has been listed in the program of the second production, throughout the run, as its author.


Spill's Legal Odyssey
LEAD: A marathon trial over a spill of dioxin, the highly toxic chemical, has come to an end after nearly four years.
But, even as the two sides are making plans to appeal the verdict, questions are being raised about the wisdom of using lay juries in highly technical cases, about abuses by go-for-broke lawyers and about what, if anything, should be done to streamline the litigation process.

McAdoo Is Enjoying Success in Europe
LEAD: To romantics, Italy has always been a country suggesting images of gondolas, soft ballads and tantalizing cuisine.
To American basketball players, it has sometimes been a place of isolation and despair, a final resting ground for those who are no longer wanted in the National Basketball Association.


Rohatyn Urges City to Abolish School Board
LEAD: The New York City Board of Education has so failed at running the schools that it should be abolished, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, Felix G. Rohatyn, said yesterday.

EUGENE M. KLEBAN
LEAD: Dr.
Eugene M. Kleban, an educator and former executive director of the Polish Institute of Arts and Sciences of America, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Oct. 9 in his Manhattan home.

Cattle Contracts Gain, But a Drop Is Expected
LEAD: Cattle futures rebounded yesterday after five days of steep declines.

Caesars Stake Cut
LEAD: Martin T. Sosnoff, the New York investor, has reduced his stake in Caesars World Inc. to 5.68 percent, from 16.04 percent, selling $31.1 million worth of his common stock.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr.
Sosnoff, who was unsuccessful in a bid to purchase a controlling interest in Caesars earlier this year for $35 a share, gave no reason for the recent sales.

Comings and Goings
LEAD: Dickie Noles was traded for himself yesterday, returning to the Chicago Cubs to complete a deal under which the Detroit Tigers had acquired him for a player to be named later.
Detroit acquired the pitcher on Sept. 21, but he was returned to Chicago after the two clubs failed to agree on which player the Tigers were to send to the Cubs, according to the Tigers' general manager, Bill Lajoie.

U.S. Appeals Judge Retires
LEAD: Chief Judge John C. Godbold of the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit in Atlanta announced today that he is retiring, effective immediately.
Judge Godbold, 67 years old, a Federal appeals judge since 1966, will remain as director of the Federal Judicial Center here, the teaching and research arm of the Federal judiciary.


TWINS' HOPES RIDING ON STRAKER AND DOME
LEAD: The Minnesota Twins' chances of playing baseball Sunday night could be determined by the outcome of two matchups in the sixth game of the World Series Saturday: the St.
Louis Cardinals vs. the Metrodome and the St.
Louis Cardinals vs.
Les Straker.


Bush Splits With Reagan on Taxes
LEAD: The political tightrope Vice President Bush is walking in pursuit of the Presidency vibrated today with the Vice President declaring opposition to any tax increase and President Reagan saying he might consider it.

Globetrotter Exits
LEAD: Lynette Woodard, the former University of Kansas basketball star, said yesterday she was leaving the Harlem Globetrotters after two seasons because of a contract dispute.
Woodard, the first woman to tour with the Globetrotters, said contract negotiations ended Oct. 5 after the team's training camp.


India Says Its Troops Are Nearly in Control of Tamil Rebel Center
LEAD: An Indian official said today that Indian troops had ''more or less'' seized control of a Tamil rebel stronghold in Sri Lanka, but that the top rebel commander had escaped, perhaps with most of his associates.

For New Yorkers, a Week of Full Bars and Bad Jokes
LEAD: Monday morning around 9 A.M., the president of Sherry-Lehmann Inc., Michael Aaron, ordered a lot of expensive Bordeaux.
But at lunch, he said, ''Someone said the market was way off, and I thought, 'Oh God, this is Petrus, this is wine that costs $5,000 to $6,000 a case!' '' That afternoon, he put the order on hold.

2 Hurt as Drilling Rig Collapses in Midtown
LEAD: An injured worker being carried from construction site at 141 West 44th Street.
Drill rig broke apart yesterday, causing rig to fall, injuring two workers.
Accident occurred at construction site where the old Savoy Theater once stood. (NYT/Dith Pran)


GEORGE ANDERS
LEAD: George Anders, a retired New York publisher whose company published the original Weight Watchers cookbooks, died of a heart attack Tuesday at University Hospital in Tamarac, Fla.
He was 78 years old and lived in Tamarac.

LEAD: Asher B. Edelman, The New York investor, said he and a group of affiliates had acquired about 11.5 percent of the outstanding shares of the Foster Wheeler Corporation.

Opera: 'Nixon in China'
LEAD: That was it?
That was ''Nixon in China''?
Finally, on Thursday evening, we had the world premiere of the most heavily publicized and shrewdly promoted new opera of this decade.
Though grandly proportioned, the Houston Grand Opera production turned out to be a Peter Sellars variety show, worth a few giggles but hardly a strong candidate for the standard repertory.
