MacGregor to Sell Three Companies
LEAD: MacGregor Sporting Goods Inc. said it had agreed to sell three of its businesses to the Oppenheimer-Palmieri Fund L.P. for up to $73.5 million.
The partnership would pay $63.5 million for Chicago-based Riddell Inc., which makes and markets football helmets and accessories; the Sports Specialties Corporation, a distributor of licensed sports caps, and the Equilink Licensing Corporation, a licensor of the MacGregor trademark.


Reporter's Notebook: Does the Nobel Panel Have Patterns and Prejudices?
LEAD: For writers, scientists and politicians around the world, the Nobel Prize announcement season each October is a time of suspense.
Among the Stockholm intelligentsia, it is also a time of amused, half-despairing discussion about the idiosyncrasies of the judges and the horse-trading involved in picking the winners.


Inquiry on Komatsu
LEAD: The European Community said today that it was investigating charges of ''dumping'' by a Japanese manufacturer of hydraulic excavators.
Representatives of the European excavator industry charged that Komatsu Ltd. was evading import duties on excavators by importing component parts and assembling them in Britain, the community's executive commission said.

Sidney S. Gaynor, a retired orthopedic surgeon who had been the team physician for the New York Yankees for more than 37 years, died Wednesday at Bartholomew County Hospital in Columbus, Ind.

Venezuelan Minister Quits
LEAD: The Finance Minister of Venezuela, Manuel Azpurua, who was in charge of a controversial debt rescheduling last month that did not guarantee new money for the nation, resigned today.


U.S. Ends Lamberti Inquiry
LEAD: After two and a half years of public uncertainty, a cloud lifted yesterday from Ralph J. Lamberti, the Staten Island Borough President, when Federal prosecutors said they had ended their investigation into allegations of conflict of interest.
No charges will be brought, they said.

LEAD: More Americans want the Minnesota Twins to win the World Series than back the St.

Rises Set for Social Security
LEAD: In the largest increase in five and a half years, benefits will jump by $21 a month, or 4.2 percent, in 1988 for the nation's 38 million Social Security recipients and the four million people who receive Supplemental Security Income, the Government announced yesterday.


MARKET IS STEADY AND TENSION EASES IN SHORTER SESSION
LEAD: The stock market closed out its most wrenching week yesterday with something approaching calm.


Acadian Day Is Proclaimed
LEAD: Gov.
Edwin Edwards has proclaimed Nov. 27 as Acadian Day, making it a state holiday and giving state employees an official four-day Thanksgiving holiday this year.

The Gifts That Gild The Wine
LEAD: IN just about everyone's stack of Christmas catalogues - they begin arriving in the steamy days of July now - there is at least one promoting what have come to be known as wine accessories.
And you thought that all you needed was a bottle and a glass.


MORE DOMESTIC VEHICLES SOLD
LEAD: Sales of American-made passenger vehicles rose 4.1 percent in mid-October, to 266,502, compared with 256,077 in the comparable period a year ago, the seven domestic manufacturers reported today.

Senators Seek Change In Public TV Financing
LEAD: For the first time, a Congressional committee has advanced legislation to finance public broadcasting through a Federal fee assessed whenever a commercial station is sold.


British Searchers Find Body
LEAD: Rescuers today found a body believed to be that of a test pilot who ejected from his fighter plane on Thursday, more than an hour before it crashed into the Atlantic Ocean.
The civilian pilot, Taylor Scott, disappeared during a test of a new version of the Harrier vertical takeoff plane.
The body, dressed in a flight suit and a parachute, was found in a field near the spot where radio contact with Mr.

Lender to Governor's Campaign In Arizona Is Linked to Job Favors
LEAD: A real estate agent and a lawyer named by Gov.
Evan Mecham to a state board on housing bonds were recommended for the posts by a developer who lent $350,000 to the Mecham campaign last year, The Arizona Republic reported today.


As Terrible Turned Worse: A Broker's Harrowing Week
LEAD: Last Saturday. some members of Monness Crespi Hardt &amp; Company, a small stock brokerage firm, were annoyed that they had missed a chance to take profits when the market dropped 100 points the day before.
By yesterday afternoon, they felt lucky to be alive.

U.S. to Segregate 'Predatory' Prisoners With the AIDS Virus
LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Prisons will immediately begin segregating Federal inmates who test positive for the AIDS virus and display ''predatory or promiscuous behavior,'' the Justice Department said today.

LEAD: A fire at the Spring Valley (N.Y.) Civic Center caused extensive damage to the building last night, but no injuries were reported.


Loans to Brokers Urged
LEAD: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York has asked the leading New York banks to be prepared to make additional loans to brokerage firms whose credit lines are being cut by regional and foreign banks, according to banking industry experts.

LEAD: The head of the New York City Charter Revision Commission said yesterday that he favored public financing of municipal election campaigns and that he hoped public financing would be among the changes his commission proposes next year.

Creme Fraiche Wins
LEAD: Creme Fraiche, the little 5-year-old gelding who has made a career of derailing potential champions, did it again tonight when he caught Afleet in the final strides to win the $500,000 Meadowlands Cup by a nose at Meadowlands Race Track.


Mips-Kubota Pact
LEAD: Mips Computer Systems Inc., a manufacturer of chips and computers using ''reduced instruction set computing'' technology, said Kubota Ltd., a leading Japanese industrial company, would invest $25 million for a 20 percent stake in the Sunnyvale, Calif., concern.
Under the terms of the agreement, Kubota will receive a manufacturing and marketing license for certain products under development at Mips.

Airbus Dispute Easing
LEAD: The European Community today reported progress in a dispute over aid to Airbus Industrie.
A London meeting next week will explore American complaints that the plane maker gets unfair government subsidies from West Germany, France, Britain and Spain.

Reagan Firm on 'Star Wars' Despite Insistence by Soviet
LEAD: President Reagan said today that he would not agree to strict limits on the ''Star Wars'' testing program despite Soviet insistence that the two sides make progress on this issue before a summit meeting is held.

Criminal Charges Urged in Collapse
LEAD: Three Connecticut Congressmen said yesterday that the state should consider filing criminal charges against contractors involved in the deadly collapse of a construction project in Bridgeport.


GOING OUT GUIDE
LEAD:  EAST SIDE, WEST SIDE A musical and a drama open uptown today.
The drama is ''My Four Mothers,'' by Ward Morehouse 3d, which explores a man's relationship with his relatives.
It is at the Jan Hus Theater, 315 East 74th Street.

President Links Economic Woes To Capitol Hill
LEAD: President Reagan today blamed Congress in large part for the economic uncertainties that led to the stock market crisis this week and reiterated his opposition to tax increases.


Dollar Drops on Rumor; Gold Prices Advance
LEAD: The dollar plunged in domestic trading yesterday as a rumor swept through trading floors that leaders of seven industrialized democracies had agreed to meet this weekend to devalue the American currency.


For Further Information
LEAD: The New York City Alzheimer's Disease Resource Center has three publications that may helpful to families: ''Caring: A Family Guide to Managing the Alzheimer's Disease Patient at Home''; ''Agendas for Action: The Aging Network Response to Alzheimer's Disease,'' and ''Where to Go for Help With Alzheimer's Disease in New York City.


The U.S.-Spain Connection
LEAD: A number of expletives are being uttered in Washington and other NATO capitals these days about the Spaniards.
Some of the kinder ones are ''selfish,'' ''obstreperous'' and ''treasonous.''


2 RESIGN BAPTIST SEMINARY IN A THEOLOGY DISPUTE
LEAD: The president and the dean of the faculty at Southeastern Baptist Theological Seminary have announced that they will resign in the aftermath of a factional dispute among Southern Baptists.

Port Authority Cancels Plans to Build in Jersey
LEAD: Philip D. Kaltenbacher, chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, says he knows when he and his agency are not welcome.
And Hoboken, the tough industrial town on the west bank of the Hudson River a few miles upriver from his offices at the World Trade Center, has made its feelings clear for some time.


Pirate Official Resigns
LEAD: Malcolm M. Prine, president of the Pittsburgh Pirates, resigned yesterday, citing differences with Syd Thrift, the general manager.
Prine, the former chairman and chief executive officer of Ryan Homes Inc., which shares ownership of the Pirates, said he was stepping down after two seasons ''because of a lack of a harmonious relationship.


Thirst for Verse: Poetry Readings Multiply
LEAD: Out the suburban library's window, it is a balmy fall Sunday, with bronze and purple leaves burnished to radiance by a bright sun, and, inside, the 73-year-old poet David Ignatow is reading his lines about subway trash pickers, dead poets and a son's helpless rage.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  GYMNASTICS  Rumania Triumphs: Rumania had seven perfect scores yesterday to hold off the Soviet Union and win the women's team event at the world championships in Rotterdam, the Netherlands.
Rumania got three perfect 10's from Aurelia Dobre, the individual leader, and two from Daniela Silivas, the European champion, to break the Soviet domination of team gymnastics.

Faults Seen In Portfolio Insurance
LEAD: Portfolio insurance, a fast-growing investment strategy that some market professionals blame for aggravating this week's plunge in stock prices, appears to be in jeopardy.
Executives responsible for corporate pension funds are furious because the insurance strategies did not work in many cases and their stock positions were not adequately hedged during the downturn.

ANSWERING THE MAIL
LEAD: Q. My toilet does not always flush properly.
When it doesn't, the water swirls around without going down and the toilet makes a gurgling sound.
A second flushing usually does it, but in rare cases I even have to use a plunger.
Originally the plumbing system lacked a vent stack, but I retrofitted one by installing a tee fitting that I cut into the main waste line in my basement.


PATTERNED BARK CLOTH FROM TONGA
LEAD: Throughout Polynesia, islanders have traditionally used tapa, richly patterned bark cloth, as a gift for weddings, the installation of chiefs and other special occasions.
In the Kingdom of Tonga, which produces more than any other South Pacific country, tapa continues to be used in these traditional ways and has become popular with tourists as well.

Rapid Transit on the Bio-Bio

Since the first descent in 1978 by a team of California adventurers, white water rafting enthusiasts from around the globe have responded to its call.

Military Roster Increases
LEAD: The active-duty strength of the military services increased in September from both the previous month and the year-ago level, the Pentagon said Thursday.
As of Sept. 30, the Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Air Force had 2,175,713 men and women on active duty, up 8,899 from Aug. 31 and up 6,601 from the combined total of a year ago.

LEAD:  To the Editor:


Replay
LEAD: It was, to use a phrase coined by Yogi Berra, deja vu all over again.
Last week, for the fifth time since 1975, Billy Martin was named manager of the New York Yankees.
It was the 15th managerial change in the 14 years that fiery George Steinbrenner has owned the club.
Martin will replace Lou Piniella, who managed the Yanks to a fourth place finish in their division this year.


The Street Endures Its Cruelest October
LEAD: October's reputation for cruelty to investors is more firmly established than ever.
The late 1970's saw the back-to-back October massacres of 1978 and 1979, with the Dow posting double-digit percentage losses in each of those months.
Of course there was 1929 with its Black Monday on Oct. 28.
Then there was October 1987.

ANSWERS TO BASIC QUESTIONS ABOUT THE COLLAPSE
LEAD: LAST Monday's stock market collapse left everyone from taxi drivers to professional analysts confused and groping for explanations.
What follows are preliminary answers to some basic questions about what happened.
Q.
Why did the market plunge?
A.
The theories vary widely - from investor concern about America's huge budget and trade deficits to growing evidence that President Reagan has entered the lame duck period of his Administration.

Is it any wonder that the additional dishonesty of stealing the script from others arouses genuine outrage?

Music View; A TALE OF TWO OPERAS, OR WHEN NOT TO INTERFERE
LEAD: ABOUT HALFWAY INTO THE first scene of the Metropolitan Opera's new ''Rheingold'' on opening night, I became aware that surprisingly little of the staging was distracting my attention from Wagner's own shrewd way of telling his tale of moral decay and betrayal.
So hardened have we become to seeing directors and designers intrude their daring little persons into opera productions that the absence of conceptual handstands and theatrical back flips can now be startling.


Smoking Aloft
LEAD: To the Editor: I was recently on an Iberia Airlines flight fron Nice to Madrid and had requested a seat in the no-smoking section.
I was seated near the front of the plane on the lefthand side.
A man in the row in front of me on the righthand side began to smoke, and when I asked him to stop, he said that he was seated in a smoking section.

POSTINGS: Plans for East End Temple; Apartment Tower Above Synagogue
LEAD: East End Temple, now 40 years old, has always wanted a new home, but at its current location, the southeast corner of Second Avenue at 23d Street.
The only way the tiny temple could achieve this, it has argued, was to sell its air rights to a developer who would demolish the one-story structure, along with three adjacent tenements owned by the temple, and build an apartment tower above with a new, larger temple at street level.

As they say in the business, the camera likes him.

LEAD:  Gymnastics  Soviet in 1-2-3 Sweep: Dmitri Bilozerchev led a 1-2-3 Soviet Union finish in winning the men's all-round title yesterday at the world championships in Rotterdam, the Netherlands.
He won the crown for six routines with 118.375 points.
Yuri Korolev finished second with 118.350 points and Vladimir Artemov was third with 118.125 points.

Question Of the Week; Do You Assess the Football Strike?
LEAD: We feel strongly that it is time for Pete Rozelle and the National Football League management to intervene and amend the playoff format to include more teams.
In this way, the N.F.L. compensates for unrepresentative replacement teams unfairly influencing the crowning of the champion.
By proportionally increasing the importance of an expanded postseason and reducing the importance of -while not canceling - the replacement games, the league can still salvage this woebegone season.

LEAD: EACH fall, scores of women, many of them recent graduates of the best schools in the country, descend on Manhattan to make their marks in book publishing.
Those who succeed can look forward to jobs that not only offer low salaries and infrequent promotions but also assign homework: boxes of manuscripts that must be lugged home on the subway to be evaluated and edited in what normal people would consider their spare time.

ANSWERING THE MAIL
LEAD: Q. My toilet does not always flush properly.
When it doesn't, the water swirls around without going down and the toilet makes a gurgling sound.
A second flushing usually does it, but in rare cases I even have to use a plunger.
Originally the plumbing system lacked a vent stack, but I retrofitted one by installing a tee fitting that I cut into the main waste line in my basement.

SAVORING FALL'S BEAUTY
LEAD: KEEP up with bulb planting; if small bulbs such as those of anemone and puschkinia appear dried out, soak them in warm water for an hour or so before planting; drain to dry on paper towels first.
Plant grape hyacinth bulbs where their recurrent foliage does not hamper other garden plants.
Finish dividing and replanting thick clumps of ferns; be sure the soil is enriched with peat moss and/or compost.

The Street, Shaken

It came just as many firms were realizing that the days of quick profits were ending and, in a traumatic way, it highlighted the inherent riskiness of the securities business.
Now, firms already planning to retrench may become more determined to shrink their businesses and to cut jobs.

A FAMILY OF FIRSTS
LEAD: I, too, come from a family who loved ''firsts'' (''A Family of Firsts,'' by Patricia Volk, Oct. 4).
My husband thought it was an affliction.
My children even loved being first to use the peanut butter.
In my family, the first to tell the good news was the ultimate.
My dilemma now: should I be first to tell them that you published my letter, or should I let them read it and think they are the first to know?

Opera: Boston Camerata in 'L'Orfeo'
LEAD: MONTEVERDI'S ''Orfeo'' is not the first opera, but it is the first by a truly gripping composer.
Appearing in 1607, it was actually the sixth attempt at this new art - one intended to prod dramatic poetry with a new energy by coloring it with the melodies and rhythms of music.
It was an evolution that the Italian language with its broad vowels and elastic stresses made almost inevitable.

LEAD: PAULA ROBISON and Eliot Fisk gave another of their appealing flute and guitar programs Friday evening at Weill Recital Hall.

THE GUIDE
LEAD:  GOOD EGGS  Never mind the birds and the bees; consider the fish.
The naturalists at the Cold Spring Harbor Fish Hatchery do, and, since this is fall, a traditional ritual, dating back to 1883, has begun: the autumn egg-taking.
That's a demonstration twice a day, Saturdays and Sundays at 1 and 3 P.M., that shows visitors how eggs are extruded from the female trout and then mixed with similarly extruded milt from the male to create fertilized eggs.

LEAD: A juror in one of the longest trials in American history said she only went along with an award for $16 million in damages ''to get this over with.''


Public TV: That Delicate Balance
LEAD: WHEN BILL MOYERS RE-turned to public television a year ago, he arrived with a slate of ambitious projects, a potful of foundation money and high expectations.
However, it was not long before Mr.
Moyers, who had been away for five years, was reminded of the frustrations of working in a system that is maddingly democratic, with as many bosses -317 - as it has stations.


Question Of the Week; Do You Assess the Football Strike?
LEAD: The owners were successful because they enacted a superior game plan.
By not ''closing shop,'' management was able to provide union members with an alternative to striking without pay.
And with renewed television contracts guaranteeing income, public acceptance wasn't even necessary for the replacement games to serve their purpose of breaking union solidarity.

LEAD: CHALLENGING the procedures used by international track officials in banning her from competition for using steroids, Sandra Gasser, the Swiss middle distance runner who received a two-year ban after traces of steroids were found in her system at the world track and field championships in Rome, has filed suit in Bern seeking immediate reinstatement.

ANSWERING THE MAIL
LEAD: Q. My toilet does not always flush properly.
When it doesn't, the water swirls around without going down and the toilet makes a gurgling sound.
A second flushing usually does it, but in rare cases I even have to use a plunger.
Originally the plumbing system lacked a vent stack, but I retrofitted one by installing a tee fitting that I cut into the main waste line in my basement.

REAPING THE HARVEST
LEAD: BETWEEN MID-SEPTEMBER AND early November, segments of rural France take on an air of anticipation, anxiety and celebration.
It is vendange, the grape harvest, when the status of the grapes tells much about the wine for the year.
But regardless of the grapes' condition, vendange is a time for a fete, which translates, quite naturally, into good food and good times.


IGNORING THE PANIC WORSENS THE PROBLEM
LEAD: MARKET analysis provides the single most reliable tool for anticipating major changes in economic trends, and to some degree, accompanying social trends as well.
A particularly dramatic shift in the trend of a major market virtually always constitutes a signal that a fundamental change in the associated environment has occurred or will soon occur.

The Perils of Tinkering With Credibility
LEAD: EVERY FILM REQUIRES ITS audience to make a leap of faith, but some leaps are longer than others.
A lot longer.
It isn't even a question of whether what we're seeing can literally be believed.
One film may make its viewers accept the idea that a nobody from Palookaville can slug his way to the top of the boxing world, or that a schoolboy can travel backward in time to meet his parents as teen-agers; another may strain credulity with the sight of a simple soul making a visit to his neighborhood store.


Social Events
LEAD: Celebrating the Theater  Halloween Preview  Oct. 25 - Costumes are optional but merriment is mandatory at a Caribbean Halloween party featuring Chinese-Hispanic food, a cash bar, dancing and a raffle at Bayamo, 704 Broadway (just north of Fourth Street).
The event, from 7 to 11 P.M., will benefit the Jewish Guild for the Blind, which has provided services for visually impaired people of all religions and races since 1914.

LEAD: SINCE it is the most international of all sports, it has been said that soccer knows no language barrier.

TWO U.S. BRIDGE TEAMS WIN
LEAD: The world bridge championships drew to a close here today with the United States claiming a double victory.
The Americans won the Venice Trophy for women's teams Friday, and their open team defeated Britain in the final of the Bermuda Bowl by 64 international match points.


A Musical Born of South African Protest
LEAD: THE LILTING SOUND OF Mbaqanga, South Africa's distinctive black pop music, filled Lincoln Center's Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater on a recent afternoon.
Six musicians, looking sharp in pressed khaki uniforms, were churning out the music's joyous rhythms, while a seventh player, Douglas Mnisi, swayed back and forth, embroidering the beat with lightning-fast runs on his electric guitar.


NO HEAVY LIFTING
LEAD: Most people share much more in common than they realize.
Our aspirations for ourselves, our families, our associates and our countries are usually not too different.
It is only natural, therefore, to have common ways of expressing these aspirations.


Where Have All the Folk Stars Gone?
LEAD: READING THE MEMOIRS of Joan Baez and Judy Collins, folk-music pioneers who are both now in their late 40's, one is tempted to mourn the vanishing tradition of the folk-music heroine.
Through the 60's and 70's, the image of the long-haired, guitar-toting folkie with flowers in her hair, burning with noble ideals, was a cliche that, while often ridiculed, bespoke a artistic seriousness that in the age of music video is disappearing from the pop mainstream.


New &amp; Noteworthy
LEAD:  THE PIANOPLAYERS, by Anthony Burgess. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $4.95.) Anthony Burgess's 29th novel is about a man, much like the author's own father, whose piano playing provides the real-time soundtrack for silent pictures; his career falls apart with the advent of a new technology called talkies.

Officers said the list had been posted so they could put on protective gloves and take other precautions when responding to calls involving someone with acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

TAMIL RESISTANCE WANES
LEAD: INDIAN troops were winning the real estate in their battle with Tamil guerrillas last week, but their main political target, Velupillai Prabakaran, commander of the separatist Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, reportedly escaped to fight another day.
After a two-week siege, 8,000 Indian soldiers were said to have captured all but a few pockets of resistance in Jaffna, the northern stronghold of Sri Lanka's Tamil minority.

Give Unesco a Second Chance
LEAD: The exit of Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow as Director General of Unesco is welcome in itself and for the signal it sends to entrenched bureaucrats in other international organizations.
After 13 years, Mr.
M'Bow had come to regard his $170,000-a-year post as impregnably tenured.
But his candidacy for a third, six-year term proved so divisive that his own Government in Senegal urged him to withdraw.

LEAD: NOT LONG AGO, I had the chance to work for several months on an archeological salvage ship looking for a sunken Spanish galleon.
I had never even snorkeled before, but I soon became, at the age of 53, one of the ship's regular divers.
My wife and daughter had encouraged me to try it. ''Chance of a lifetime,'' they said.

'Music Talks'
LEAD: I am most appreciative of Michael E. Ross's review of my book ''Music Talks: Conversations With Musicians'' (Oct. 4) but would like to correct three inadvertent inaccuracies.
The book includes material written between 1971 and 1986 - not 1974 and 1981.
About one-third, including the profiles of the bassoonist Hugo Burghauser and the master teacher Dorothy DeLay, is previously unpublished work.


ONE ALLHALLOW'S EVE, NO CHILDREN CAME
LEAD: WHEN all the days of September have dwindled and the shadows of October grow long and crisp, when the majesty of autumn murmurs in the bosom, my husband and I yield to a tropism and head for the mountains.
We go to capture the splendor on film and in memory.

The Flowering of China's Scholar-Artists
LEAD: INTRODUCING ''THE CHINESE Scholar's Studio: Artistic Life in the Late Ming Period,'' at the Asia Society, is a hanging scroll called ''Venerable Friends.'' Painted by Xiang Shengmo and Zhang Qi, it is an imaginary group portrait of six influential literati of the Ming Dynasty.
All were from Jiaxing or Songjiang in the Yangtze River delta.

REBEL WITH A CAUSE
LEAD: John Cougar Mellencamp's sobriquet ''Little Bastard'' might very well be attributable to his fiery demeanor (''Rebel With a Cause,'' by Timothy White, Sept. 27).

Knock Out Tradition
LEAD: IT'S not a common occurrence, but it sometimes happens that a boxer is declared the winner of a bout after being knocked out in the final seconds of the last round.
That is because a fighter who hits the canvas in the last 10 seconds of a bout can be saved by the bell, which, by long tradition, ends not only the round and the bout, but the referee's count as well.

For the Nation's Brokers, The Flood That Wasn't
LEAD: After the stock market's week of wild gyrations, brokerage branches nationwide stayed open yesterday, ready for an onslaught of calls and visits from panicked investors.
But the flood never came.
Advertisments on television and in newspapers told investors of the added office hours.
Work schedules of managers, brokers and support staff were revised.

Officials in black-and-white striped shirts waved their arms.

Hemlines Know Which Way Is Up
LEAD: WHEN we last left them, a few minutes ago, hemlines seemed to be going in two directions: up and down.
Except, of course, the ones that weren't going anywhere.
If you are confused by all this, don't worry about it.
Just put on your best evening duds and get yourself to a fancy party.
There you'll find that hemlines know exactly where they're headed, and that's north.

Question Of the Week; Do You Assess the Football Strike?
LEAD: The players should have gone on strike between the sixth and the eighth games.
They would not be hurt as much financially, the owners would not have time to assemble ''scabs'' and the players would have been able to stay out for the season.
The owners without eight more television games would have caved in.

A NATION'S FEARS FOR PEACE AND PROSPERITY
LEAD: IF there is one quality that sets Americans apart from most peoples, it is our optimism.
But the nation's inherent belief that every problem has a solution and that things will turn out for the best was sorely tested last week by a rat-tat-tat of events that suggested even to the sunniest among us that things might be sliding out of control.

Rewarded
LEAD: Serious poets engage in the riskiest of literary business, seldom achieving anything appoaching unanimous acclaim, let alone big paychecks.
So there seemed a bit of justice done last week when Joseph Brodsky, the exiled Russian poet, won the Nobel Prize in Literature.
The 47-year-old Mr.
Brodsky, who was deported from the Soviet Union in 1972 after serving 18 months in a labor camp for ''parasitism,'' is widely regarded as the best living Russian poet.

NEW DATA ON WIMEN AND ADDICTS
LEAD: EVEN retrospectively, the course of AIDS is not necessarily knowable.
For one thing, although the findings are so stark and so hard to explain that researchers hesitate to say much, AIDS evidently kills women more rapidly than it kills men.
And in New York, city health officials announced last week, it has killed more drug users than anyone had thought.

LEAD: The Hunt brothers wanted to dance to the tune of high-risk/ high-profit business ventures, and now it is only fair that they pay the fiddler his due.

Should the Hunts be treated differently, just because they can afford the legal guns to keep the banks at bay and their creditors satisfied?

Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Oct. 14 about European American Bancorp misstated the company's expected fourth-quarter provision for loan losses in the third world.
The amount is expected to be $120 million to $130 million, leading to a loss of $115 million to $120 million for the quarter, and a loss of $85 million to $100 million for the year.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Tennis  Edberg Upsets Lendl: In a showdown between the world's top two tennis players, second-ranked Stefan Edberg of Sweden upset top-ranked Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia, 6-7, 6-4, 6-4, yesterday for the $60,000 first prize in the $375,000 Seiko Super Classic in Tokyo.
Edberg played his usual serve-and-volley game before a crowd of 11,000 on the Supreme Court of the Yoyogi National Stadium, while Lendl played mostly from the baseline.

LEAD: LEONTYNE PRICE has reached what she once called in an interview ''the maturest stage of vocal maturity,'' and she has said farewell to the operatic stage.
But at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon, in a benefit for the United Negro College Fund, she reminded everyone that the ease and luster of her high notes are still among the wonders of the world.

Proposal for Nutrasweet
LEAD: The Nutrasweet Company said Friday that it had asked the Food and Drug Administration to approve the use of the artificial sweetener aspartame in baked goods and baking mixes.
In the past, the F.D.A. had said that aspartame, sold under the trade name Nutrasweet, was unacceptable for baking because the sweetener would break down at high temperatures.


Correcftions
LEAD: A picture caption last Tuesday, with an article about films on the Hollywood blacklisting of the 1950's, misidentified the man at the left in a scene from ''The House on Carroll Street.'' He was William Sturgis.


Mormon Leader Recovering
LEAD: Ezra Taft Benson, the president of the Mormon Church, was released Saturday from a hospital where he had been recovering from a mild heart attack, a church spokesman said.
The 88-year-old leader of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints will continue his convalescence at home before returning to his regular dutues, the spokesman said.


A Fire Set for Training Firefighters Is Fatal to 3
LEAD: A training session for volunteer firefighters turned deadly today, killing three volunteer firefighters and seriously burning a fourth as they tried to put out a controlled fire in an old farmhouse.


Music: Chamber Works
LEAD: FOUR musicians joined under the auspices of Mid-America Productions to give a program of American chamber music Saturday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall.
It began with Ives's Fourth Violin Sonata, played with feeling, though Stephen Brown did not do enough to give definition and variety of texture to the wonderful piano part.


David Sinclair Is Dead; Researcher in Physics
LEAD: David Sinclair, a retired research physicist and a son of Upton Sinclair, the American writer and journalist, died Saturday of lung cancer at Cabrini Hospital in Manhattan.
He was 85 years old and lived in Martinsville, N.J., and Manhattan.

LEAD: With less than two weeks to go until the new Central American peace accord comes into force, political and diplomatic pressure is building on Nicaragua's Sandinista leaders to take two steps.


STAGE: SOUTH AFRICAN 'SARAFINA!'
LEAD: THOUGH diligent New York audiences of the 1980's may not learn a lot about the political dynamics of the United States at the theater, they have surely become experts on South Africa.
Dissident productions from Johannesburg's Market Theater, urgently telling and retelling the atrocities of apartheid, now reach New York faster than new plays from Louisville or London.

Pilot Flying Leader of F.A.A. Cited for Climbing Too High
LEAD: A pilot flying the head of the Federal Aviation Administration to Las Vegas, Nev., has been cited for climbing 500 feet above his assigned altitude, forcing an airliner to change course, officials said Friday.

LEAD: Three robbers invaded a jewelry store on a crowded thoroughfare in Chinatown yesterday and, as they fled with gold chains and other loot, shot a young woman employee and a male clerk who ran to her aid from a shop next door.

LEAD: Senator Albert Gore Jr. says he does not believe a campaign brochure showing him carrying an M-16 rifle in Vietnam is misleading although he served in a noncombat role.

LEAD: The commander of Indian troops in Sri Lanka said today that most of the separatist Tamil fighters who held out against the Indian Army here for 16 days had escaped into the jungle.

To Texans, Plunge Is Familiar
LEAD: While Texans watched the stock market collapse with the same mix of horror and puzzlement as the rest of the country, there was also a disquieting element of familiarity.
Texas is used to booms and busts. ''A blind man could have seen the Dallas real estate market was overbuilt, but people kept building,'' said Shad Rowe, an investment adviser who heads Rowe &amp; Company there.

LEAD: France sent nearly 500 policemen and troops to Tahiti today to restore order after clashes between striking longshoremen and the police, French officials said.

Mr.

Pistons' Johnson Signs
LEAD: Vinnie Johnson, the Detroit Piston guard, ended his holdout yesterday and signed a multiyear contract.
Johnson will earn an average of $650,000 a season during a three-year agreement and will have an option on a fourth year, according to The Detroit Free Press.
Johnson, 31 years old, averaged 15.7 points a game last season, finishing second in balloting for the National Basketball Associatin's Sixth Man Award.

Florida Investor Kills Broker and Himself
LEAD: A Social Security Administration claims worker, who apparently made millions playing the stock market and faced ruin in last week's collapse, shot and killed an executive with Merrill Lynch Pierce Fenner &amp; Smith today and wounded another, then took his own life with a bullet in the head.


Nance Sidelined
LEAD: After fracturing the ring finger on his right hand, Larry Nance will be sidelined from his starting forward job for the Phoenix Suns for about four weeks.
Nance suffered the injury in the first quarter of an exhibition game against the Chicago Bulls on Saturday night in Las Vegas, Nev., when he hit his hand on the rim while attempting to dunk an offensive rebound.

LEAD: BAD singing heavily outweighed good at the annual star-studded Richard Tucker Music Foundation Gala at Carnegie Hall Sunday night; it was not the kind of evening to send one away with renewed hopes for the health of the operatic mainstream that Mr.
Tucker served so devotedly in his lifetime.
But there were breaths of fresh air to remember the evening by.

The Kremlin's Woes
LEAD: The news that Secretary of State George Shultz went home from Moscow without agreement on a summit meeting came as a shock to an East-West meeting of journalists here.


Cardis Plans to Sell Tuneup Masters
LEAD: The Cardis Corporation said it planned to sell its Tuneup Masters Inc. subsidiary for $78.2 million.
The sale comes a little more than a year after Cardis, an auto-parts supplier, acquired Tuneup Masters for $52 million.
The 282-outlet auto-repair chain had operating revenue of $41.9 million in the nine months ended April 30.


Peripherals; New Look of Magazines
LEAD: UPTIME was mentioned here a few weeks ago as a computer magazine that bypasses the printed page entirely, supplying both editorial matter and ready-to-run programs on a standard disk.
It differs from Compute!'s PC Magazine, which is sold as an integral magazine-and-disk package, and such other publications as Ahoy!

LEAD: Courtaulds P.L.C., a leading British textiles and chemical company, said it had agreed to buy the Porter Paint Company of Louisville, Ky., for $140 million.

Corrections
LEAD: A dispatch from Novi, Mich., yesterday about the growth of the community described the origin of the town's name incompletely in some editions.
The name embodies the Roman numeral for 6: ''No.
VI.'' The town was the sixth stop on the trail from Detroit to Lansing.

LEAD: SCIENTISTS have transplanted the gene for an important human protein into female mice, causing the animals to produce the substance in their milk.

Middleweight Picture
LEAD: Although Thomas Hearns and Juan Roldan are the attractions in the showdown for the World Boxing Council middleweight title in Las Vegas, Nev., Thursday, a couple of other middleweights could be affected by the outcome.
Marvin Hagler, the former undisputed middleweight champion, and Sugar Ray Leonard, the man who beat him last April and then retired, are both expected to be at the fight.


THEATER: A JOURNEY
LEAD: GIVE an aleph for audacity to A Traveling Jewish Theater's ''Berlin, Jerusalem and the Moon.'' The San Francisco group's three actor-writers take us, in the space of 80 minutes, on a journey from Jacob's wrestling match with God to Weimar Germany up to present-day America and Israel.
The goal is to make a big statement on the condition of the contemporary Jew.


Hong Kong Suffers Wild Fluctuations
LEAD: Stock prices fluctuated wildly in morning trading here today, after losing one-third of their value on Monday in one of the worst one-day losses ever suffered by any stock market.

LEAD: Dave Righetti, who is concerned about the way that Billy Martin may use him next season, wasted no time in filing for free agency.
Righetti's agent, Bill Goodstein, sent a telegram to the Players Association at 12:06 A.M. yesterday declaring the pitcher a free agent.

TI Changes Mind On Bundy Offer
LEAD: TI Group P.L.C. of London said its board had decided to urge its shareholders to reject a previously announced plan to acquire the Bundy Corporation of Warren, Mich., for $40 a share.
Late last month, TI and Bundy, which both make steel tubing, said they had signed a definitive agreement for the acquisition, which was valued at $144 million.

He was killed in 1934.

Similar discussions are being held at engineering schools all over the country.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: TENNIS  Jaite and Mayotte Advance: Martin Jaite and Tim Mayotte advanced to the second round of the $923,000 European Community Championship yesterday in Antwerp, Belgium.
Jaite defeated Karel Novacek of Czechoslovakia, 7-5, 6-4, and Mayotte beat a fellow American, Kelly Jones, 6-4, 6-4.
Jaite will face John McEnroe in the second round, while Mayotte will meet eighth-seeded Joakim Nystrom.

Intel Circuit Board
LEAD: The Intel Corporation has introduced a circuit board to allow owners of the International Business Machines Corporation's personal computers and some compatible machines to upgrade their equipment.
Intel said its Inboard 386/PC, priced at $995, uses its 80386 microprocessor to increase the speed of a standard PC with an Intel 8088 microprocessor by as much as 10 times.


Library Plans to Build 84 Miles of Book Shelves Under Bryant Park
LEAD: A rendering of an extension the New York Public Library plans to build under Bryant Park.
The $16.6 million project, the largest since the library opened, will provide space for books now stored in an annex.
The park will be closed during the two-and-a-half years of contruction, and will then undergo a $5 million restoration.


Philleo Nash, at 77; Was a U.S. Official In 3 Administrations
LEAD: Philleo Nash, an adviser to President Truman on minority affairs and the Commissioner of the Bureau of Indian Affairs for five years in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, died Oct. 12 of renal cell cancer at a hospice in Marshfield, Wis.
He was 77 years old.


Market Turmoil; Reagan and Congressional Chiefs Meet to Lay Budget Groundwork
LEAD: President Reagan and Congressional leaders reached a basic agreement today to pursue measures designed to reduce the Federal budget deficit by at least $23 billion.
They left the details of such a package to a negotiating team that will begin work Tuesday afternoon.


An Imposter, Unmasked, Stands Tall
LEAD: THERE is a Mount Everest of the mind.
A rugged monolith with snow-covered slopes, its ridges climb steeply to a single sharp peak towering over the surrounding range of Himalayan mountains.
That Everest is sometimes not the real Everest but actually a nearby summit known as Makalu.


N.H.L. Suspends Two
LEAD: Bryan Murray, the coach of the Washington Captials, and Ron Asselstine, a linesman, have each been suspended for three games by the National Hockey League for an incident between periods of a game on Oct. 11.
At the end of the first period of the Capitals' game with Buffalo, Murray confronted the officials in the area leading to the dressing rooms, the league said in a statement.

LEAD: Family Dollar Stores Inc., a discount chain whose president and chief operating officer quit last month in the wake of lower earnings, has named Ralph D. Dillon to the posts.

LEAD: The financial futures and options industry, bloodied by huge losses from the stock market plunge, is now waging a bitter battle with the New York Stock Exchange.

LEAD: Dr.
Maxwell Finland, internationally recognized for his study of infectious diseases and their treatment, died Sunday in Faulkner Hospital in Boston.
He was 85 years old and lived in the Jamaica Plain section of Boston.


Hodel Urging Shift in Indian Programs
LEAD: Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel is proposing a fundamental restructuring of the relationship between the Federal Government and the nation's 500 Indian tribes, aimed at promoting greater self-determination and less reliance on the Government.


Lithuanian Farce
LEAD: ''When Lithuania Ruled the World,'' a historical musical farce written by Kestutis Nakas and in-spired by traditional Lithuanian folk music, will be presented on Monday nights in November at 9 and 11 o'-clock at the Pyramid, 101 Avenue A, between Sixth and Seventh Streets.
Tickets are $8.
Information and reservations: 475-4132.

LEAD: In the last week, Joe Coleman, a sales representative at a Nashville printing company, watched the value of his stock in a wide range of companies drop by about 40 percent.

Coleman had been convinced that the market would quickly rebound, yesterday's plunge shook his confidence.


Rockaways Need Revitalization and Environmental Protection
LEAD: To the Editor:


Pact for Thrift
LEAD: Syd Thrift signed a two-year contract yesterday to continue as the Pittsburgh Pirates' general manager, just three days after a dispute that led to the resignation of the team president, Malcolm Prine.
During contract negotiations with Thrift, Prine demanded the right to approve all hirings, dismissals and trades.


Liver Problems Halt Test of Alzheimer's Drug
LEAD: Clinical studies on an experimental drug to treat Alzheimer's disease have been halted after about 20 percent of the test subjects experienced changes in liver chemistry, the Food and Drug Administration and the drug's manufacturer have announced.

LEAD: THE Quintet of the Americas and several of its friends brought music by two true originals to the Americas Society on Friday night, one of them celebrated, the other barely known at all.


Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption on Saturday about two men talking outside te Queens courthouse where the Howard Beach murder trial is taking place misidentified the man at the right.
He was Augustus Agate, lawyer for a defendant in a future trial arising from the Howard Beach events.

LEAD: The United States has long welcomed refugees from persecution.
But new rules proposed by the Reagan Administration would make it more difficult for political refugees to remain here.
The proposal ought to be withdrawn.

COMPANY NEWS;
LEAD: Lane Financial Inc. said the La Salle National Corporation, whose parent is Algemene Bank Nederland N.V., had offered about $200 million to acquire the company.
Lane said the proposed price is about 2.5 times its book value.
The company said its board would consider the offer on Nov. 3.

LEAD: Trading was unusually light in the Standard and Poor's 500-stock index pit today, despite the stock market's sharp drop.

Fashion Designers in Europe Go Short, Shorter, Shortest
LEAD: The major fashion trend emerging from three weeks of spring and summer openings in Europe can be summed up in one word: short.
There were subsidiary themes, like the explosion of pretty colors and flower prints, especially roses.
Scooped necklines and bare shoulders emphasized the feeling of extreme femininity, and long gloves and hats recalled glamour of the past.

LEAD:  Stock Market Turmoil


I.M.F. Sees Greater Need
LEAD: The International Monetary Fund's managing director said today that the fund's resources might have to be tapped more than expected to help member nations with their debt problems.
Michel Camdessus said in an address prepared for delivery to the United Nations General Assembly that the I.M.F. would need financial support from other parties in addition to its own resources.


20 MILLION IN U.S. SAID TO GO HUNGRY
LEAD: A study on hunger released today contends that 20 million Americans do not get enough to eat every day.

Dutch Government To Assist Fokker
LEAD: The Dutch Government said it would take a large minority stake in the aircraft maker N.V.
Fokker as part of an elaborate financial aid package.
Fokker would receive 527 million guilders, or about $258 million, from banks and the Government, the Economics Minister, Rudolf de Korte, told Parliament.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Two Views of Hate
LEAD: The National Rifle Association has decided that its major opponent, Handgun Control Inc., is a hate group.


Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. Why does laundry dried outside smell better than laundry dried in a drier?
A.
Some substances, including laundry, undergo chemical changes when they are exposed to the bleaching action of sunlight, a process called photolysis.


Broken Path to Summit
LEAD: In refusing to fix a date for a summit meeting in Washington, Mikhail S. Gorbachev has broken the momentum toward improved Soviet-American relations that had developed before Secretary of State George P. Shultz went to Moscow last week.


Books of The Times
LEAD:  THE MASK OF COMMAND.
By John Keegan. 368 pages.
Illustrated.
Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $18.95.  ''THE MASK OF COMMAND'' is a book about what it means to be a general that starts off from the premise that it can mean many different things.
Over the centuries kings and demagogues have doubled as generals, and generals have doubled as diplomats and priests; a commanding officer, like the army that serves under him, is always the product of a particular society, and the qualities that his position calls for vary from age to age and place to place.


Bond Prices Up, but Trading Slows
LEAD: The fierce bond market rally triggered by the collapse in stock prices continued yesterday but seemed to be running out of steam.

Oilers to Stay Put
LEAD: The Houston Oilers' owner, Bud Adams, spurned an offer from Jacksonville, Fla., yesterday and announced he would keep the team in Houston. ''This is my home,'' Adams said. ''I've been here 41 years.
I could have gone to Jacksonville for a lot more money.'' Adams and his family toured the Florida city several weeks ago.

All good things do not come in a tidy package, and Mr.

Older Homes' Sales Up 1.2%
LEAD: Sales of existing homes rose 1.2 percent in September after three consecutive monthly declines, the National Association of Realtors said today.
Single-family homes sold at an annual rate of 3.45 million units in September, up from an August rate of 3.41 million units.

LEAD: NIGHT vision systems similar to the military devices used on such missions as tracking Iranian warships and minelayers in the Persian Gulf may make driving safer in the 1990's.

LEAD:  Salvador Talks Imperiled  Salvadoran rebels threatened to break off peace talks because of the killing of an outspoken human rights advocate.

Willhite Out for Season
LEAD: Gerald Willhite will be lost to the Denver Broncos for the rest of the National Football League season after suffering multiple fractures of his right leg Monday night in a 34-27 loss to the Minnesota Vikings.
The 5-foot-10-inch, 200-pound running back, who was scheduled to undergo surgery yesterday in Denver, broke away for a 29-yard run that took him a step from the end zone when he was pulled down by Joey Browner, the safety.


BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 28, 1987
LEAD:  Stock Market Turmoil


Malaysia Arrests Political Foes
LEAD: The leader of the main Malaysian opposition party and ethnic Chinese politicians and academics were arrested today under a law allowing detention without trial, political figures said.


LIFE IN THE 30'S
LEAD: WHEN I was a little girl I loved Halloween because it was the only day of the year when I was beautiful.
I had friends who went out dressed as hobos and clowns and witches.
I never would.
I was always a princess or a ballet dancer, Sleeping Beauty or Cinderella. (One year I wanted to go as Barbie.


SOVIET, IN SWITCH, WILL SEEK SUMMIT, OFFICIALS REPORT
LEAD: In a seeming about-face, the Soviet Foreign Minister will return to Washington this week to tell President Reagan that Mikhail S. Gorbachev is ready for a summit meeting even if differences remain over space-based weapons, American and Soviet officials said today.

Hrudey and Mason at It Again
LEAD: In the minutes before overtime, Kelly Hrudey sat along the boards at the Nassau Coliseum, took a couple of deep breaths and a drink of water.
Slowly and only momentarily, he then began to take in the full irony of it all.


Tektronix Products
LEAD: Tektronix Inc. is planning to introduce 14 new products including some that mark its re-entry into the computer work station business, a company spokesman said.
He said the company had entered that market about three years ago and then abandoned it a year later.
The work station models cost between $9,995 and $51,500 and can operate independently of big mainframe computers, the company said.

Genmar Drops Minstar Deal
LEAD: Genmar Industries said today that it had decided to abandon its plan to acquire Minstar Inc. through a new holding company.


Gifts By Mail, Made In New England
LEAD: OUR passion for handmade products extends to food: the cheese made in someone's shed, the cookies baked in batches of 50.
We are certain that handmade food is better than the mass-produced variety, and we are usually right.


Russian Visitors Observe Capitalists
LEAD: Tourists from the Soviet Union had a unique opportunity to watch capitalism at work yesterday at the New York Stock Exchange.
Observing from the administrative platform, they photographed the frenzied activity as traders raced to complete their business before the 2 P.M. closing.
Their visit had been arranged before the volatile events of the past week, although they could not have picked a better day to witness the drama of buying and selling.

But all that most people know about her is that she's called Blaine Trump and she's married to Donald Trump's younger brother,

Edelman Filing On Foster Wheeler
LEAD: Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, said he had filed for permission from the Federal Trade Commission and the antitrust division of the Department of Justice to increase his stake in the Foster Wheeler Corporation from his current 11.2 percent level.


LEON ALCALY
LEAD: Leon Alcaly, a retired mathematics teacher at the Bronx High School of Science, died of complications resulting from leukemia Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital.
He was 78 years old and lived in the Bronx and West Palm Beach, Fla.


Scars of Plunge Not as Deep as Feared
LEAD: Initially, at least, the stock market collapse has not scarred the public psyche, the Republican Party or the President as much as some people at first predicted, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll.


Topics of The Times; Mayor Koch Bites a Hard Bullet
LEAD: Mayor Koch moved decisively and appropriately yesterday to impose a 90-day hiring freeze on 5,200 positions authorized in this year's New York City budget.
The continuing turmoil in world stock markets threatens payrolls, retail sales, tax receipts and real estate values in a city heavily dependent on the finance industry.


MEXICAN-U.S. TRADE TALKS
LEAD: The United States and Mexico will sign an agreement on Nov. 6 creating a framework for talks on trade and investment issues, Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States trade representative, said today.


BOY'S 1969 DEATH SUGGESTS AIDS INVADED U.S. SEVERAL TIMES
LEAD: New evidence that a St.
Louis teen-ager died of AIDS in 1969 suggests that the AIDS virus may have been introduced into the United States several times before touching off the current epidemic, according to experts in disease transmission.


Wall St. Settles Nearly All Trades Made Last Monday
LEAD: The settlement of trades from Monday of last week was nearly completed yesterday, and the settlement of the next day's trades was progressing smoothly, Wall Street executives said.

Torture by Syrians Charged in a Report From Rights Group
LEAD: Amnesty International charged yesterday that the Syrian security forces have tortured thousands of political prisoners in recent years, including large numbers of Palestinians seized from refugee districts in Syria or from Syrian-controlled areas of Lebanon.

LEAD: The Kentucky State Property and Building Commission is tentatively offering about $61 million of tax-exempt bonds for a Toyota project.
Underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers are offering the debt issue due in 2007 with a maximum yield of 8 3/4 percent.

Stage: 'Second Avenue,' Yiddish Music and Skits
LEAD: SECOND AVENUE, like Wall Street, Lenox Avenue, Broadway and Madison Avenue, was shorthand for a very special world. ''On Second Avenue,'' a buoyant and glowing revue that opened Sunday at the Norman Thomas Theater, 111 East 33d Street, explores the world of Yiddish theater, that mix of high drama and low comedy, of polished professionalism and folk roots that was born little more than a century ago in Rumania and flourished on New York's Lower East Side.

LEAD: Mayor Koch announced yesterday a major ''retrenchment'' in municipal hiring, salary increases and pension contributions for New York City caused by concern over the plunge of the stock market and fears of a recession.

Waving Homer Hankies, fans threw millions of dollars of shredded money, about 2,000 pounds worth, during the celebrations.

LEAD: TEN times a year Donnelley Marketing mails out brown envelopes jammed with cents-off coupons to at least 30 million American households of the not-too-rich and not-poor variety.


The Stage: In Revival, 'Fortune and Men's Eyes'
LEAD: TWENTY years after its first staging here, John Herbert's ''Fortune and Men's Eyes'' has been revived at the Actors' Playhouse, where it had its first run.
We have seen many plays, films and television programs about sexual power struggles in prisons since then, so the shock value of this story about a Canadian boys' reformatory has virtually disappeared - and that works to the benefit of the play.


Mario Merola, 65, Prosecutor In the Bronx for 15 Years, Dies
LEAD: The Bronx District Attorney, Mario Merola, died of a cerebral hemorrhage last night, less than 12 hours after suffering what doctors called a ''massive and primary'' neurological disorder that brought on cardiac arrest.


Play-by-Play Woman
LEAD: Gayle Sierens, a news co-anchor in Tampa, has been recruited by NBC Sports with the aim of having her work the play-by-play microphone for a National Football League game.
In the 30 years that N.F.L. games have been televised by the three major networks, no woman has ever worked the broadcast booth.

LEAD: A State Department report, based on classified Central Intelligence Agency data, asserts that the U.S.S.R.
Chamber of Commerce and Industry is headed by a K.G.B. lieutenant general and is systematically engaged in commercial espionage in the West.

LEAD: Among his peers, Richard Dennis is regarded as the most successful of the new breed of Chicago's commodity traders.
But when his firm lost $10 million last week, some people expected him to experience sleepless nights and frayed nerves.

Brazil Radiation Victim Dies
LEAD: A junkyard worker who helped break open a capsule containing radioactive cesium 137 died today, the third victim.
Israel Batista dos Santos, 22 years old, died after three weeks in critical condition at the Marcilio Dias Naval hospital in Rio.
Last Friday, a 6-year-old girl and her aunt died of generalized infection caused by radiation.

Reds Hire May
LEAD: Lee May, a first baseman who spent 16 seasons in the major leagues from 1967 to 1982, was hired yesterday as a coach by the Cincinnati Reds.
The Reds announced that they have rehired all of their coaching staff except Billy DeMars, the batting instructor and third-base coach, who resigned after the season because of a dispute with the front office.

Mets Promote Pitcher
LEAD: The Mets purchased the contract of Jose Roman, a right-handed pitcher, from Tidewater of the International League yesterday.
The Mets acquired Roman from Cleveland in a minor-league trade last May for Mike Westbrook, a minor-league outfielder.
Roman spent most of last year with Tidewater.
He had a 5-4 record with nine saves, and he had an earned-run average of 3.07 in 45 relief appearances.


Wary Maneuvering Ends in a Draw
LEAD: Careful, solid defensive play by Anatoly Karpov perfectly countered Gary Kasparov's positional manuevering in the drawn sixth game of their world championship chess match in Seville, Spain, on Monday.


Lawsuits Fault The Discharge Of Mentally Ill
LEAD: On the eve of a Koch administration effort to hospitalize homeless people who are severely mentally ill, an advocacy group charged yesterday that the city and state were improperly sending psychiatric patients back to the streets.


Reporter's Notebook: A.F.L.-C.I.O. And a New Obsession With Presser
LEAD: Waiting for Jackie Presser.


1950's Standby for Entertaining in the 80's
LEAD: TRAVELING around the country in recent months, I have been surprised by the prevalence of cocktail parties as the chosen form of at-home entertaining - surprised because the cocktail party seemed to be a characteristic of the 1950's.
Although it never died, it always took second place to the dinner party, the formal supper party or even the restaurant meal as a preferred way of entertaining.


Bridge: Honored High School Senior Has a Name That's Familiar
LEAD: For the last 14 years the American Contract Bridge League has named a King of Bridge.
The title goes to the high school senior in North America with the best tournament record, and carries with it a $1,000 scholarship that goes to an outstanding student in the winner's class.


Rodgers Wins Award
LEAD: Bob (Buck) Rodgers, who guided Montreal to a surprising third-place finish in the National League East this season, was named the National League Manager of the Year by the Baseball Writers Association of America yesterday.
Rodgers, in his third season as manager of the Expos, received 92 points from a 24-member committee, easily beating San Francisco's Roger Craig, the runner-up with 65 points.


Charge Against Officer In Stewart Case Is Dropped
LEAD: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority reversed itself yesterday and abandoned its attempt to prosecute a transit police officer on a departmental charge in connection with the arrest and death of Michael Stewart.


Ankara Journal; In Homely Items, the Entombed Ataturk Lives On
LEAD: With the reverence reserved for those who have molded destiny, Turks have paid homage for decades at a stern and towering mausoleum that is as much a national shrine as Lenin's tomb in Moscow.


MISSILE COUP LAID TO RUSSIAN SPIES
LEAD: The Soviet Union, through a military intelligence operation in Greece, acquired specifications for the Stinger missile and developed an almost identical weapon, according to a Greek security official with immediate knowledge of the case.
A Western official confirmed the incident.


Indiana Agency's Tax-Free Bonds
LEAD: In the tax-exempt market, a $120 million issue of the Indiana State Office Building Commission's capital complex revenue bonds was tentatively priced yesterday through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns &amp; Company.


Estimate Board Is Focus of Plan To Revise Voting
LEAD: In an effort to preserve New York City's Board of Estimate, which recent court decisions have said violates the principle of one person, one vote, the City Council President, Andrew J. Stein, yesterday proposed a new weighted voting formula for the board's members.


Canada Wins Approval for a 'Distinct' Quebec
LEAD: In the face of bitter but fragmented opposition, the Canadian Government has won parliamentary approval for changes to the country's Constitution that would recognize Quebec as a ''distinct society'' and strengthen its battle to shore up its French language and culture.


Film: From Mexico, 'Hell Without Limits'
LEAD: ARTURO RIPSTEIN's ''Hell Without Limits,'' the 1978 Mexican film opening today at the Cinema Village, looks and sounds as if it were based on an idea for a Luis Bunuel film, which had been made, instead, by someone completely unqualified for the job.

Washington Talk: Briefing; Gift Is His to Give
LEAD: Senator Steve Symms, who received $1,000 from an openly anti-Semitic group in his re-election campaign last year, thought the controversy the contribution generated was behind him in May, when he gave the money to the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith in Washington and the Idaho Holocaust Council.

LEAD: An article yesterday described the New York City Police Department's monitoring of call-in programs on radio station WLIB-AM last summer.


Series of Soviet Films Is Set for the Modern
LEAD: New Voices From the Soviet Cinema, a series of films by young directors with fresh views of Soviet society and by more experienced film makers who are unknown in the West, will begin on Nov. 10 at the Museum of Modern Art and run through Nov. 17.


Proof Positive: It's Not Green Cheese, After All
LEAD: Sara Feldman, a teacher at Public School 199 on West 70th Street in Manhattan, showing students samples of lunar rocks.
The pieces of the moon, provided by NASA, are being shown at the school this week as part of moon-awareness week.
Each day Mrs.
Feldman stops at a local bank to pick up the sample from a vault and to return it after school.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Watching the Markets
LEAD: Some commodity experts and Congressional aides are voicing concern that the White House may be considering a change in leadership at the Commodity Futures Trading Commission while the markets are still in a state of turbulence.


Bonn Surplus Nears High
LEAD: West Germany reported today its second-highest monthly trade surplus ever, and economists said the figures, further evidence of chronic imbalance in world trade, were likely to increase pressure on Bonn to accept a weaker dollar.

Ozone Hole Raising Concern for Scientists' Safety
LEAD: The atmosphere's protective ozone layer is so depleted over Antarctica in the springtime that there is cause for concern about the safety of scientists and support personnel there, researchers said at a Senate hearing today.


2 Americans Reported Killed In an Ambush in Afghanistan

The U.N. TODAY: OCT. 28, 1987
LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY


Pickens Sees Plunge Spurring Takeovers
LEAD: Depressed stock prices could lead to new corporate takovers ''within a week or so,'' T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, said here today.


West Point-Shaw
LEAD: West Point-Pepperell Inc. said that because of market conditions, its agreement to sell its carpet and rug division to Shaw Industries had been terminated.
West Point, which makes household fabrics, said talks are not expected to resume in the near future.
Shaw is based in Dalton, Ga.


Dollar Hits 6-Year Low Against German Mark
LEAD: The dollar fell sharply yesterday against the West German mark, exceeding lows set in May and putting the currency at its lowest level against the mark in six years.


Cecil Brown Is Dead; A News Broadcaster And Correspondent
LEAD: Cecil Brown, a radio news broadcaster whose career was studded with drama and controversy, died of a ruptured aorta Sunday at the Medical Center at the University of California at Los Angeless.
He was 80 years old.


KOCH DECLARES A HIRING FREEZE
LEAD: Citing concern over the plunge of the stock market, Mayor Koch ordered a major ''retrenchment'' in New York City hiring.


Trump Buying Resorts Stake
LEAD: Donald J. Trump, the developer, said yesterday that he would begin a tender offer for all of the remaining 167,000 outstanding shares of Class B common stock of Resorts International at $135 a share, or a total of $22.5 million, within five business days.


I.B.M. Sets $1 Billion Buyback
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation, joining the hundreds of companies that have announced stock buyback programs since the market's plunge nine days ago, said yesterday that it would repurchase up to $1 billion of its stock.


4 Leading Contenders for Nomination to the Supreme Court


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Soccer  Adelphia Beats Columbia, 2-0: Adelphi strengthened its bid for a regional playoff berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament when the Panthers defeated nationally ranked Columbia, 2-0, yesterday at Garden City, L.I.
Dominic Pascarella, a freshman forward, scored the first goal in the game's fourth minute, then assisted on Paul Howarth's goal with 11 minutes left.


PERSONAL HEALTH
LEAD: AS the AIDS crisis deepens and widens, more and more people are choosing to care at home for friends, relatives and lovers who are dying of AIDS.


One Fell Swoop
LEAD: Here is a bold action that the President and Congress could take to end financial hand-wringing and lay the basis for sustained growth throughout the world: Impose a $10 a barrel fee on all oil imported into the U.S.


PREACHER'S ORDINATION IN DISPUTE
LEAD: The evangelist Oral Roberts says that his ordination has been revoked by the United Methodist Church but that he learned about it only when he read about it in a newspaper.


Westin To Be Sold By Allegis
LEAD: The Allegis Corporation said yesterday that it had concluded the restructuring plan it announced in June, by signing an agreement to sell its Westin Hotels and Resorts business for $1.53 billion to a group comprising the Robert M. Bass Group of Texas and the Aoki Corporation of Japan.

LEAD: The stock market collapse could push the United States economy into low gear next year, and it has increased the chances of a recession before 1989, several economists say.

Scott Paper Outlay
LEAD: The Scott Paper Company said it would spend more than $250 million in the next three years to expand its sanitary paper business in Western Europe.
The company said it would install paper-making machines in France, Italy and Spain. that will have a total capacity of 150,000 tons annually.
Scott said it would also rebuild a machine in Britain and add recycled paer capability in Italy and Spain.


Soviet Offers U.S. Inspections of Additional Radar
LEAD: The Soviet Union has offered to allow United States officials to inspect two radars that some conservative Senators assert may violate an arms control accord, according to senior Administration officials.

LEAD: Orders to American factories for ''big ticket'' durable goods climbed 1.1 percent last month, the first increase in three months.
But some analysts predicted the upturn would be short-lived if the stock market turmoil should cause a recession.

KNICKS, GREEN CLOSER
LEAD: Following more than three weeks of speculation surrounding the Knicks, it appears that the status of Sidney Green, Bernard King and Trent Tucker should be resolved before the end of the week.

LEAD: Once again on Sunday, Fred Lebow will present the New York City Marathon, featuring a cast of thousands.
Who will be playing the leading roles?
Well, Lebow would probably say that the city is the star of this annual run across the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge through the five boroughs.
It is also true, however, that this year's marathon lacks marquee value.

Theater: 'Frankie and Johnny'
LEAD: WHEN we first meet the title characters of Terrence McNally's provocative new play, ''Frankie and Johnny in the Clair de Lune,'' they are grunting through an orgasm on a Murphy bed in a dreary Hell's Kitchen walk-up.
But Frankie (Kathy Bates) and Johnny (Kenneth Welsh) are hardly sweethearts.
They are fellow employees of a greasy spoon -she a waitress, he a recently hired short-order cook - and this is their first and quite possibly their last date.


V.H. Saladino, Interior Designer
LEAD: Virginia Hendrick Saladino, an interior designer, died of cancer yesterday in Manhattan.
She was 50 years old and lived in Manhattan and Norfolk, Conn.


Purchase by Ogilvy
LEAD: The Ogilvy Group has reached an agreement to purchase Thomson-Leeds, a point-of-sale advertising company, and Alert Marketing, an in-store merchandising and sales organization.
They will become part of a newly created Sales Promotion Group, part of Sage Worldwide.


Thompson Appoints Manager in New York
LEAD: J. Walter Thompson USA has appointed 38-year-old James R. Heekin 3d as general manager of the New York office as well as executive vice president and a director of the United States company.
He succeeds Stephen G. Bowen Jr., who held the position for the last three years while also serving as president.


Volcker Advocates Tax Increase
LEAD: The stock market crisis is a warning signal that the budget deficit is too high and that it must be cut through higher taxes, Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve Board chairman, said today.

LEAD: Ronald Reagan has already pushed another trillion dollars of debt onto the next generation of taxpayers.
Now the Republican Presidential candidate Pat Robertson offers an even more refined idea of fiscal conservatism and family values.
America should breed more babies, he says, so there'll be more people to pay taxes.

LEAD: Until a month ago, Koji Yoneyama, a Daiwa Securities executive, was posted to Zurich and enjoying a relatively calm life.

LEAD: Ivan Beshoff, the last survivor of the 1905 mutiny on the Russian battleship Potemkin, a harbinger of the Russian Revolution, died Sunday, his family said today.

STYLES IN HAUNTED HOUSES, FROM VICTORIAN GLOOM TO MODERN MAYHEM
LEAD: TO Gene Wolfe, a writer of horror stories, there is something inherently fearsome about houses.
You can never be sure you're alone, he mused recently.
The fact that you can't see the entire house at one time is unnerving.
There is always the possibility of opening the closet and finding clothes swaying mysteriously, or sneaking into the kitchen for a midnight snack to encounter a monster in the mixing bowl.


GTE Unit Indicted In Fraud Case
LEAD: A military contractor and three of its managers have been charged with submitting fraudulent bills totaling $774,604 to the Federal Government.
The indictment, handed up by a Federal grand jury, accused GTE Government Systems Inc., a unit of the GTE Corporation, of 30 counts of ''making false and fraudulent statements and representations'' between November 1982 and April 1983.


Publishing: Gorbachev Book Due Out in 3 Weeks
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's ''Perestroika'' is ready to go to press, and will be on sale nationally Nov. 18.
But the book, which sets forth the author's plans and hopes, is already the international publishing event of the year, with a first printing of 200,000 copies scheduled in this country and with foreign rights sold in about 15 nations, including West Germany, France, Italy, Japan, Brazil, Spain, Portugal, Israel, Denmark, Sweden, Norway and Finland.

LEAD: Chris Chelios set up all three Montreal goals, and Patrick Roy stopped 22 shots tonight as the Canadiens defeated the Edmonton Oilers, 3-1.

LEAD: A multibillion-dollar leveraged buyout - financed through the sale of assets and the issuance of high-yield bonds - is a risky venture under the best of circumstances.

LEAD: High technology is bringing the world into focus for people with severely limited vision.
Advances in video cameras and computers are making it possible for them to read, write and work independently.


Georgia Fire Routs 15,000
LEAD: A smoky chemical fire here Tuesday routed nearly 15,000 people from their homes, schools and businesses and burned until equipment used to fight fires in jetliners was brought in to douse it.
No injuries were reported in the blaze at a warehouse owned by a swimming pool company.
The fire melted the metal warehouse, and water poured onto it appeared to have little effect.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q.After removing the wallpaper in my hall, I washed the walls and painted them.
Later I noticed some slightly discolored, rough spots on the painted walls, possibly caused by wallpaper glue that was not fully removed.
How can I correct this?
A.It does sound as if you left some small spots of paste, and possibly a little wallpaper, on the wall when you washed it.

LEAD: Rod Woodson, the Pittsburgh Steelers' top pick in last spring's draft, has signed a contract with the team, ending his 95-day holdout.

LEAD: Greek judicial officials said today that a 37-year-old Greek is to stand trial on charges of providing state secrets to Soviet agents, some of which enabled the Soviet Union to copy technology used in a NATO antiaircraft missile.

Cage's last major work before he began using chance procedures as compositional tools.

LEAD: Jeff Burger, the leading passer in the Southeastern Conference, and Jim Thompson, a tackle, were declared ineligible yesterday by Auburn for violating the National Collegiate Athletic Association's extra-benefits rule.
Both accepted a free ride in a private airplane to go hunting in southern Alabama with a friend of Thompson's family Oct.

LEAD: The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico has a surplus of electrical power.

LEAD: COMPANIES that specialize in heart of pine say that more of it is being used in homes for flooring, paneling and wainscoting.


Baseball Needs Instant Replay
LEAD: EVER since the first umpire missed a call, baseball's cop-out has been that bad calls even up, that each team will get its share.
Over a 162-game season, maybe the bad calls do even up, maybe not.
But in the World Series, especially in the seventh game, there's not enough time for them to even up.


Mercedes Price Rise Set
LEAD: Mercedes-Benz of North America said it plans to raise prices on its 1988 models between 2.6 percent and 3.4 percent.
The lowest-priced model, the 190-E sedan with five-speed manual transmission, will sell for $29,190, and the highest-priced car, the 560-SEC coupe with automatic transmission, will sell for $76,380 on the West Coast and $75,850 on the East Coast.

Household Help: Some Questions And Answers
LEAD: AS the ranks of working mothers - particularly those with young children - continue to swell, many of them agree that one of the prerequisites for their success is not an M.B.A. or an undergraduate degree from a prestigious school, but rather a reliable, efficient nanny or housekeeper.
Knowing that there is someone at home they can count on to take good care of their youngsters, and sometimes of their home as well, allows them to concentrate on business while they are in the office.

Big Board Seat Sold
LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that a seat, or membership on the exchange had been sold for $750,000 - a rebound from lows last week when the stock market collapsed.
A seat allows a person or a company to trade stocks on the Exchange.
Prices for seats nosedived last week after the massive selling panic.

LEAD: The Koch administration yesterday began a more vigorous campaign to remove severely mentally ill homeless people from Manhattan streets, parks and byways where they live to try to forcibly provide them with medical and psychiatric care.

LEAD: Critics, right and left, insist that it's wrong to cut the budget deficit now.
Non-experts are entitled to wonder, too.
Why tighten up just when the stock market is in shock and the economy may be on the brink of recession?

Building Contracts Off
LEAD: The value of construction contracts nationally fell 8 percent in September to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $247.4 billion, the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company said.
The report, issued by the company's F. W. Dodge division, attributed the decline from August's $268.3 billion in part to rising interest rates.

Recital: Alice Giles
LEAD: THE constituency of the harp is select; I have never seen the auditorium of the 92d Street Y as sparsely populated as it was for Alice Giles's solo recital there Tuesday night.
But Miss Giles is an assured, communicative performer and an astute program-builder.
There is a certain difficulty inherent in making a whole evening's music on such a highly colored instrument without others to lend variety and context; she minimizes it.

LEAD: The number of working rotary rigs drilling for oil in the United States last week dropped by four, to 1,130, Baker Hughes Inc. said.
But the number of seismic crews searching for oil and gas in the United States increased by six in September, according to the Society of Exploration Geophysicists.
