U.S. Missile Signaled A Launching in 1984
LEAD: The Air Force said today that nearly four years ago an armored car was hurriedly parked atop a Minuteman III silo after the nuclear missile inside gave off false signals suggesting it was about to launch itself.


Post-Marathon Pace Was Grueling for '86 Victor
LEAD: In retrospect, winning the New York City Marathon last year was the easy part for Gianni Poli of Italy.
Dueling for the lead on First Avenue with Rob de Castella, the pre-race favorite, was less demanding than the pace Poli tried to maintain since becoming an overnight hero in his country.
Deciding to defend his title, he said, was based more on a sense of duty than on any real feeling he can win again.

Broken Hill Buying Hamilton Oil Stake
LEAD: Australia's BHP Petroleum Ltd., a unit of Broken Hill Proprietary Ltd., said it would buy a 49.9 percent interest in the Hamilton Oil Corporation of Denver from the Volvo North America Corporation for $393 million.
BHP said it would pay $31 for each of Volvo North America's shares in Hamilton and was considering buying an additional 1 percent of Hamilton's common stock, either in the open market or through private negotiations.


Neighborhoods and Developers Head for War
LEAD: To the Editor:


Outdoors; A Guide to Antique Decoys
LEAD: WITH individual birds by master carvers of yesteryear fetching hundreds of thousands of dollars in recent years, collecting antique waterfowl decoys has become big business.
The growing interest in the field has produced some excellent books on the subject, one of the most recent being ''Connecticut Decoys'' by Henry Chitwood, with Thomas Marshall and Doug


At a Racers' Club, Speed Is Just One of the Lessons Learned
LEAD: LIKE most other first-time competitors in the New York City Marathon, Andre Donegan and Keith Givens have been busy preparing for the race, working out four times a week, increasing their distance in anticipation of Sunday's grueling 26.2-mile course.

Penney to Drop 3 Store Lines
LEAD: The J. C. Penney Company, the nation's third-largest general merchandiser, said it plans to expand its women's apparel lines and to discontinue sale of home electronics, hard sporting goods and photographic equipment in all of its stores.

Darling Returns To the Classroom
LEAD: It has been six years since Ron Darling left Yale for professional baseball.
Now, after four solid years in the major leagues with the Mets, he is back in the classroom.
And it seems as though he never left.


Too Much Focus on Budget Deficit, Experts Say
LEAD: President Reagan and lawmakers, trying to reduce the budget deficit, may be looking through blinders, according to economists and business consultants.


BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1987
LEAD: MARKET TURMOIL  The world's central banks allowed the dollar to slide a notch, apparently fearing that further efforts to maintain its value would rattle the stock market and undermine economies around the world.
Throughout the day, the central banks tempered the currency's decline by buying dollars, although traders said the official buying, though widespread, was modest.

Hagler and Leonard: Still in the Picture?
LEAD: After Thomas Hearns and Juan Roldan decide the World Boxing Council middleweight championship here Thursday night, the sport will have three world middleweight champions for the first time since Marvelous Marvin Hagler beat Alan Minter in 1980.


Calendar: Walking A Ladies' Mile
LEAD:  Ladies' Mile History Walk  A tour led by Judy Gold; 212-242-5762.


Washington Talk: The Economy; HOW WALL STREET LOOKS ON THE CAPITAL'S MAP
LEAD: Separated by only 200 miles, Washington and Wall Street might as well be in different galaxies when it comes to understanding and appreciating each other's imperatives and ways of working.


RUSSIANS AT U.S MANEUVERS
LEAD: Four Soviet military officers arrived in West Germany today to observe United States military maneuvers in the south of the country, the Soviet Embassy said.
Spokesmen for the Soviet Em-bassy and for the West German For-eign Ministry said the officers were to watch exercises involving 11,650 Amer-icans as part of confidence-building measures agreed to by the European security conference.


Corrections
LEAD: A Washington dispatch yesterday about a Navajo venture to build a luxury resort misidentified Senator Pete V. Domenici's home state.
It is New Mexico.


Mexico Market's Fall Is the Steepest
LEAD: Throughout the boom months of 1987, the volatile Mexican stock market performed more spectacularly than any other in the world.
But with bulls having turned to bears all around the globe, Mexico is now suffering the steepest, most rapid slide of any leading exchange.


School Chief Disputes Figures on California
LEAD: Offering figures disputing the conclusions of a University of Chicago study, California's Superintendent of Public Instruction said today that the state's educational program was working and that minority students' scores proved it.


Stock Impact Feared Grave In New York
LEAD: Ten days after the stock market collapse, a growing consensus of economists and officials say its impact on the New York metropolitan area will be severe.
But it will be months, if not years, before the full extent of the fallout is known, the experts said.


Renault Debt Plan
LEAD: The French Cabinet approved a plan to transform the state-owned car maker Renault into a limited liability company, involving a write-off of $2 billion in debt and no more Government subsidies.
A Government spokesman said the bill would be discussed in Parliament this autumn.
The Government announced last week that it was writing off 12 billion francs (about $2 billion), or nearly a quarter of Renault's debt.

Washington Talk: Briefing; Does It Get HBO?
LEAD: Television came to the Senate only a little over a year ago, but life without it has already become almost unthinkable.
That point was underscored last week when the Senate doorkeepers, who spend their days a few paces from the chamber itself, acquired a miniature television set with which to monitor proceedings on the Senate floor.

Music: Julie Wilson at the Kaufman
LEAD: JULIE WILSON is one of a handful of veteran singing actresses who do a great deal more than interpret classic songs with understanding and feeling.
When Miss Wilson sings, her whole body gets into the act.
She flings her arms wide and clenches her fists, and her face mirrors the entire range of human emotion, from helpless love to fury to triumphant joy.


EXECUTIVES
LEAD: *
Bernard Chaus Inc., a maker of women's apparel, named John Consolini executive vice president and chief operating officer, and Anthony J. Farese treasurer.


Siamese Twins Progress
LEAD: West German Siamese twins separated in a historic operation seven weeks ago are making substantial progress, but it may take months for doctors to fully assess their recovery, according to officials at Johns Hopkins Hospital.
The twins, Benjamin and Patrick Binder, were joined at the back of their heads.


Continental Sets Commercial Pullout
LEAD: Under its new management, the Continental Illinois Corporation will be stripped of most of its traditional commercial banking activities and will concentrate on investment banking activities, Thomas C. Theobald, chairman of the bank holding company, announced yesterday.


Becker Is Dropped From Unicef Post
LEAD: It is Boris Becker's belief that sports and politics should not mix.
But that has not prevented the 19-year-old West German tennis star from becoming the center of a controversy that has cost him his position as goodwill ambassador for the United Nations Children's Fund.


Andre Masson, 91, Dies; Was a Major Surrealist
LEAD: Andre Masson, a major Surrealist painter, for more than 60 years a powerful and invigorating presence on the international art scene and the subject in 1976 of a retrospective exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art in New York, died in Paris yesterday.
He was 91 years old.

Washington Talk: Briefing; Sure-Fire Investment
LEAD: Tom C. Korologos, the Washington lobbyist enlisted by the White House to help with the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork, has been roaming Senate corridors this week with a new message for senators and anyone else within earshot: ''Invest in taxes.
They're the only thing that's going up.


'Distaff Side,' Music Composed by Women
LEAD: ''The Distaff Side,'' a festival of works composed by women, will open the Downtown Chamber and Opera Players' fall concert season Tuesday night at 8 o'clock, at Bernhard Mayer Auditorium of the New School for Social Research, 66 West 12th Street.


HERS
LEAD: MOST Americans take speaking correct English for granted.
Not I. And although I graduated from the University of California at Berkeley with a degree in journalism, spent a year in the M.F.A. film program at Columbia University, have had a novel published and now teach creative writing, sometimes I still feel insecure when it comes to speaking - and even writing - grammatically correct English.


Boy Is Shot in Subway; Another Youth Is Held
LEAD: A Brooklyn teen-ager was critically wounded when he was shot in the chest on an IND subway train in a Greenwich Village station yesterday afternoon, and the transit police arrested another Brooklyn youth in the shooting.


Stirring the Slumbering Soviet Masses
LEAD: One group protests the destruction of historic buildings in Moscow.
Another calls for a nongovernmental seminar on human rights.
A third restores a monastery for use as a cultural center.
Such is the diversity of groups mushrooming in the Soviet Union, where even to organize on behalf of the handicapped has long been impossible.


NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1987
LEAD:  International A3-16


L.F. Rothschild Search Cited
LEAD: L.F.
Rothschild Holdings Inc., which was hit with a $44 million loss from the stock market plunge this month, is looking for a buyer or a substantial capital injection to bolster its financial health, according to several Wall Street sources.


Books: Big Man at Fed
LEAD: THE most remarkable thing about William R. Neikirk's commendable biography of Paul A. Volcker is that its very existence demonstrates how much has changed in the world of economics.
What, after all, would have been the market for general interest books about even the most distinguished of Mr.
Volcker's predecessors as head of the nation's central bank?

LEAD: Three newspapers yesterday asked the judge in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. to allow greater access to the jury-selection process.


Knicks Acquire Green
LEAD: Finally, after weeks of posturing by the Knicks and the Pistons, Sidney Green is coming home.


At 7-Year Lows Abroad
LEAD: Amid growing concerns on the American economy, the dollar's value plunged today to its lowest level in seven years against the West German mark.


Suit Says Transplant Caused Cancer Death
LEAD: A Long Island widow has filed a $3.5 million suit charging that the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn implanted a cancerous kidney into her husband and caused his death.


Trooper's Car Hits Auto Killing 3
LEAD: Three people were killed and two others were injured yesterday when a state police car struck another auto outside an entrance to the Finger Lakes Race Track here, the authorities said.


Investment Managers Look for Signs Stock Plunge Is Over
LEAD: Professional investment managers spent much of yesterday looking, almost desperately, for signals that the stock market slide had stopped.
Until they are convinced the debacle is over, many are simply not going to buy stocks.

Prices on Bonds Fall Again
LEAD: Bond prices slumped for the second straight session yesterday, pushed lower by the dollar's weak performance on world currency markets.


IRAQ SAYS PLANES RAIDED 3 VESSELS
LEAD: Iraq said today that its warplanes had raided three tankers off Iran and industrial targets on the mainland.


Glasnost Is Taking A Fashionable Turn
LEAD: POLITICIANS and diplomats may have had trouble arranging a summit meeting, but an American trading company cut through miles of red tape to bring Russian fashions to this country.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: Woody Woodward, who 10 days ago resigned after three years as general manager of the Yankees, was named personnel director of the Philadelphia Phillies yesterday and given free rein to make trades.
Bill Giles, the president of the Phillies, announced Woodward's appointment.
Giles said he would become involved in personnel decisions only if Woodward and Manager Lee Elia disagreed, or a major financial policy was involved.


3 Slain Colombian Journalists To Be Awarded Cabot Prizes
LEAD: Three Colombian journalists who were murdered after reporting on drug trafficking, a reporter for The Miami Herald and a business newspaper in Brazil have been chosen as winners of the 1987 Maria Moors Cabot Prizes from Columbia University.





Parley On Budget Opened
LEAD: Reagan Administration and Congressional negotiators started discussions today over a budget compromise aimed at soothing agitated financial markets, but their initial sparring produced few conclusive results.


Anheuser's Net Gains by 19.2%
LEAD: The Anheuser-Busch Companies Inc. said today that its third-quarter profits climbed 19.2 percent because of strong beer sales.


'Freedom' Director Cuts Film Under Pressure
LEAD: Sir Richard Attenborough said today that he had removed lines from his new film about Steven Biko, the black South African leader who died in police custody 10 years ago, under pressure from a guerrilla group.


Concert: Lincoln Center Chamber Music Society
LEAD: THROUGHOUT its history, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has distinguished itself by drawing together outstanding players devoted to ensemble performance, and in particular to the presentation of new and unusual repertory.
Fittingly, the society's program Tuesday evening in Alice Tully Hall, the first of its 19th season, opened with several out-of-the-ordinary works, including a local premiere.


TV Reviews; Exploring Latin Jazz And Dance
LEAD: TWO giants in their respective artistic fields can be found on this evening's schedule.


Once Desperate, a Bronx Housing Group Earns Praise
LEAD: On a summer evening in 1974, a small group of Bronx neighbors and church leaders created a coalition to rescue their deteriorating community.


Mr. Reagan's Revenge, or Legacy
LEAD: In announcing his second choice for the Lewis Powell vacancy on the Supreme Court, President Reagan combatively showed himself unchastened by the Senate's embarrassing rejection of his first choice.
Whether Douglas Ginsburg's nomination will prove as provocative as that of Robert Bork must await confirmation hearings, but the President's defiant tone is inauspicious.


Watson Leads Richest Event
LEAD: Tom Watson certainly doesn't need the record purse of $360,000 he would take home with a victory Sunday in the $3 million Nabisco Championships.
He has already won $4,085,278 on the PGA Tour, second only to Jack Nicklaus in career earnings.

Andrew Stein Charges $40 Million in Housing Fines Are Uncollected
LEAD: City Council President Andrew J. Stein charged yesterday that the New York City Housing Preservation and Development Department had a $40 million backlog of uncollected fines for residential building-code violations.


Strike Possible At Big Board
LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange is facing a possible strike by most of its clerical workers.
Local 153 of the Office Employees Professional Union voted Wednesday by an 18-to-1 margin to strike when its three year contract runs out Saturday unless a new agreement is reached.


Suspect Killed in Drug Raid
LEAD: A drug dealer was fatally shot by a housing police sergeant last night during a raid on a Harlem apartment where drugs were sold, according to the police.
Three other dealers were arrested, the police said.
The raid at 55 West 129th Street began around 8:50 P.M. when detectives who had earlier made drug buys in the building returned with search warrants.


Gephardt Defends Trade Plan
LEAD: As members of Congress flee from trade bill provisions with any hint of protectionism in the wake of the stock market tumble, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, who has made such measures a centerpiece of his Presidential campaign, said today that he was holding firm.

LEAD: Under cloudy desert skies here, Thomas Hearns tonight became the first man in boxing history to win four world titles in separate weight categories.

That alone said a great deal about his chances.
Fred Lebow, the race director, picks up the tab for the very best runners.
And yet, halfway through the race, there was Mostafa, among the leaders, setting a pace that would have threatened the New York record of 2 hours 8 minutes 13 seconds established by Alberto

Thompson Medical
LEAD: The Thompson Medical Company said its board had received a proposal for a management-led buyout of the company from a group headed by S. Daniel Abraham, its chairman and chief executive.
Under the proposal, shareholders would receive $15 in cash for each of their shares in a merger.
Thompson shares gained 87.5 cents, to $10.875, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.


Willis Jackson, 59, Tenor Saxophonist In Jazz and Blues
LEAD: Willis (Gatortail) Jackson, a tenor saxophonist with a big, robust sound and a wealth of experience in jazz and rhythm and blues, died Sunday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, a week after undergoing heart surgery and suffering complications from diabetes.
He was 59 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Jean Helion, Abstract and Representational Artist
LEAD: Jean Helion, an influential abstract artist who later turned to representational painting, died of pneumonia in a Paris hospital Tuesday night.
He was 83 years old.
His canvases, both abstract and representational, hang in major institutions throughout the world, including the Metropolitan Museum and the Museum of Modern Art in New York.

LEAD: Despite a sharp decline in their stock prices in the past two weeks, officials at Entex Inc. and Arkla Inc. said they are confident their $422 million merger will go ahead as planned.

Tickets are $15.

Sports People; Dallas Green Resigns
LEAD: Dallas Green announced yesterday that he was resigning as president and general manager the Chicago Cubs after six years.
Green, 53 years old, is the fourth general manager to leave since the end of the season.
John Madigan, executive vice presi-dent of the Tribune Company and owner of the Cubs, announced that he would assume the additional position of chairman of the ball club until a di-rector of baseball operations is named.


Davis Journal; Where There Can Be a Patent on Life
LEAD: Old MacDonald had a farm, and on that farm he had some geeps.


Mahabharata
LEAD: The Indian epic poem ''Mahabharata'' is the subject of a daylong symposium with performances tomorrow at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street.
The seminar will begin at 9:30 P.M. with a lecture on the religious meaning of the poem; other lectures during the symposium, which lasts till 4:30 P.M., will cover the poem as theater, the folk dramas associated with the work and the current Peter Brook production at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.


Stock Fall May Affect Trade Bill
LEAD: The stock market collapse has reshuffled yet again the complicated politics of trade legislation, raising questions about what kind of bill will emerge from a Congressional conference committee or whether there will be a trade bill at all this year.


Results Plus
LEAD:  Tennis  Lendl Beats Leconte: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl, second-seeded Mats Wilander, Pat Cash of Australia and John McEnroe all won yesterday to qualify for the quarterfinals of the $923,000 European Community Championships in Antwerp, Belgium.
Lendl outlasted Henri Leconte of France, 6-4, 7-6.


Art: Charles Demuth In Show at the Whitney
LEAD: CHARLES DEMUTH (1883-1935) was a connoisseur's artist.
Though in no way ''major,'' he was a quirkful, many-sided and persistently inventive performer who was close to many of the most gifted people of his day and enjoyed their respect and affection. (Marcel Duchamp said that Demuth was great company because ''he didn't care where he belonged, or was, in the social scale.

LEAD: The stock market's plunge and subsequent gyrations could mean somewhat reduced Christmas sales for the nation's retail stores.
Although sales have not yet been hurt significantly, analysts are shaving their earnings estimates for retailers.

Gene's Causative Link to Alzheimer's Is Disputed
LEAD: New research reports sharply dispute a theory holding Alzheimer's disease to be caused by duplication of a gene that governs production of a particular protein found in the brains of patients.

LEAD: Soviet consumers, alarmed by rumors of impending price increases, have begun hoarding food and other products, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda said today.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration submitted a compromise arms deal to Congress today that would allow Saudi Arabia to purchase $1 billion worth of jet fighters and other military hardware.


VW Offering Said to Be Off
LEAD: The West German Government has indefinitely postponed a public offering of its 16 percent stake in Volkswagenwerk A.G. because of the recent slump in the auto maker's stock, people familiar with the plan said today.
Volkswagen shares have lost 29 percent of their value since the worldwide stock market debacle last week.

L.F. Rothschild Search
LEAD: L. F. Rothschild Holdings Inc. confirmed a report yesterday that the company is seeking a substantial capital infusion to restore it to financial health after large losses from the recent market plunge.
The Manhattan-based securities firm, which said earlier that it lost $44 million in the first three weeks of October, has been working intensively with its investment banker, Salomon Brothers Inc., to find either a buyer or a source for a substantial capital infusion.

LEAD: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday showing the dollar's recent levels misstated the illustrated relationship to the British pound.
The chart tracked dollars per pound, rather than pounds per dollar.

LEAD: Fifty people, most of them army officers drawn from Mauritania's black, non-Arab minority, have been arrested for plotting to overthrow President Mohammed Sid Ahmed Taya, Government officials said today.
Those held include a former Interior Minister, Col.
Anne Mamadou Babaly, who denied being party to the plot but admitted he had been approched by those involved, the officials said.

American Air Sues British Airways
LEAD: American Airlines accused British Airways P.L.C. of unfairly acting to exclude its Sabre computerized reservation system from the British market in order to maintain a monopoly.
In a lawsuit filed in Britain's High Court and a complaint to the European Community, American said British Airways had refused to give it permission to allow travel agents who use Sabre to issue tickets in Britain for British Airways flights.

Shakespeare Marathon At Riverside Church
LEAD: Bard-a-Thon, a weeklong festival of staged readings of plays by Shakespeare, begins tomorrow at 2 P.M. with ''The Comedy of Errors,'' at the Riverside Church, 165 West 86th Street.
The series, presented by the Riverside Shakespeare Company, continues tomorrow night at 8 with ''Macbeth''; at midnight, a second reading of ''Macbeth'' by the group can be heard live over radio station WKCR/FM (89.9).


Group Plans to Spruce Up Area Around Grand Central
LEAD: Businesses in a 50-block area around Grand Central Terminal yesterday announced a sweeping plan to improve the neighborhood by levying fees on all property owners in a newly formed ''business improvement district.''


Czyz Loses Crown; Stopped After 9th
LEAD: Charles Williams won the International Boxing Federation light-heavyweight title tonight when the corner of the champion, Bobby Czyz, stopped the bout after the ninth round of a scheduled 15-round bout.


Film: 'Fatal Beauty,' With Whoopi Goldberg
LEAD: ''FATAL BEAUTY'' asks whether a woman can be just as loudly, obnoxiously macho as a man, and answers with a resounding yes.
The woman is Whoopi Goldberg, the man Eddie Murphy, and the model is ''Beverly Hills Cop,'' though that film had nothing like the incessant firepower of this one.
Someone dies graphically, riddled with bullets and shuddering voluptuously at each shot, on the average of every five minutes or so.


RESPONSE OF MARKETS APPEARS ENCOURAGING
LEAD: In deciding to let the dollar fall against major foreign currencies, the United States is taking a big gamble that the move will enable it to head off a precipitous decline in the economy and check the fall of stock prices.


BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1987
LEAD:  Market Turmoil


Quotation of the Day
LEAD:  ''We are deeply convinced that creating a space-based defense to cover the territory of the United States would radically step up the military threat toward the Soviet Union.''  - Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, chief of the Soviet General Staff.  [ A1:1. ]


VIOLIN DUO AT THE Y
LEAD: Ida and Ani Kavafian, the violinists, are to give a joint recital tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, at Lexing-ton Avenue.
The concert includes works by Krodo Mori, Bach, Sarasate and others.
Tickets are $12.50 to $17.50.
Information: 996-1100.


Police Chief to Retire After Series of Scandals
LEAD: Police Chief Robert G. Schnakenberg of Clarkstown, who refused to resign last summer after scandals had rocked his department, has announced his retirement.


Computer Trading Needs Market Regulation
LEAD: To the Editor:


Our Towns; Ballad of Route 1: Everyone Wants To Be Princeton
LEAD: It was a little more than three years ago that Richard K. Rein, a writer in Princeton who thought he knew a story when he saw one, proposed a story to a local publication about the way the big hotels out on Route 1, just east of town, were competing for the good opinion of corporate travel agents.


BOOKS OF THE TIMES
LEAD: THE ANIMAL ESTATE: The English and Other Creatures in the Victorian Age.
By Harriet Ritvo. 347 pages.
Harvard


B.P. Issue to Proceed; Safeguard Put on Price
LEAD: The British Government announced tonight that it was going ahead with the $12.2 billion sale of British Petroleum Company shares, despite the slump in world stock markets.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in The Home Section yesterday about handicapped students competing in the New York City Marathon misidentified the organization that donated a sports wheelchair to Keith Givens.
It is the Eastern Wheelchair Tennis Association.


N.F.L. Matchups; Draft Revives Colts and Bills
LEAD: Last year it was the most lopsided division in the American Conference: two playoff teams at the top, two teams with a total of seven victories at the bottom.
But who's in first in the Eastern Division now?
Almost everybody.


Ex-General to Run for House
LEAD: James L. Dozier, a Republican who is a retired Army general once held hostage by Italian terrorists for 45 days, says he will seek the seat in the United States House of Representatives being vacated by Representative Connie Mack, a Republican who is running for the Senate seat held by Lawton Chiles, a Democrat.


Money Fund Assets Up On Stock Market Shifts
LEAD: Reflecting the deepening concern about the stock market, assets of the nation's 410 money market mutual funds increased $1.16 billion, to $258.01 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.


Newark's Mayor Backs Jackson
LEAD: Mayor Sharpe James today endorsed the Rev.
Jesse Jackson for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
The Mayor said Mr.
Jackson represented ''new hope and a new vision for a better America.''


2 French Guards Slain in Beirut
LEAD: Two gunmen shot and killed two French Embassy guards and seriously wounded a third today as the Frenchmen shopped in East Beirut.


Guatemala Amnesty Is Passed
LEAD: Guatemala, facing renewed fighting between the army and left-wing rebels, has approved an amnesty law complying with the Central American peace accord signed in August, political figures said today.


Judge Forbids Inmate Move To Jail Barge
LEAD: A judge in Manhattan signed a court order yesterday forbidding New York City from transferring any city jail prisoners to a temporary jail barge docked on the Lower East Side.


New Campaign For AFL-CIO
LEAD: Next year Lois, Pitts, Gershon, Pon/GGK will begin to spend the dollar-a-member advertising fund that the AFL-CIO has just committed to a two-year image campaign.
The total kitty will be $13 million.


President's Remarks
LEAD: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Reagan in Washington yesterday on his nomination to fill a Supreme Court vacancy, as recorded by The New York Times:


Dining Out Guide: New Uptown
LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times.
Stars are followed by the date of original publication.
Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.
CAFE GRECO, #1390 Second Avenue, at 72d Street (737-4300) - **(Aug. 21, 1987) A pretty little bar up front and an informal dining room with ocher walls, high ceilings and tall arching windows that look out on a lighted backyard garden provide the setting for a melange of Mediterranean cuisines.


Allegis Announces Share Payments
LEAD: The Allegis Corporation, which has dramatically slimmed down by selling off its hotel and car rental businesses, announced today that its shareholders would each receive at least $50 a share from the proceeds.

POLITICAL GRAFT CHARGES MOUNTING IN MISSISSIPPI
LEAD: A growing list of local elected officials in Mississippi have been indicted on charges of accepting kickbacks as a result of an undercover investigation that has shaken the state politically.


For Moynihan, Challenge of Campaign
LEAD: The manager of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's re-election campaign is in her Washington headquarters, if you can call it a headquarters.


Film: 'Gaby,' Story of Determination
LEAD: THE heroine of ''Gaby - A True Story'' has cerebral palsy, and she communicates by moving her big toe along an alphabet board, spelling out words that way.
So in one scene, in which Gaby (Rachel Levin) looks upset, her devoted father (Robert Loggia) pulls up a chair, rolls off Gaby's sock and says, ''So tell me -what's going on?


Wave of Opposition Arrests: 3 Days That Shook Malaysia
LEAD: - Malaysians tell stories of the last 72 hours with expressions of disbelief.


Summit Hopes Ride on Talks Today
LEAD: On the assumption that Mikhail S. Gorbachev is ready to set a date for his United States visit, Administration officials say they are looking toward talks Friday with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze to improve the Soviet-American dialogue.


LENINGRAD SYMPHONY
LEAD: The Leningrad State Symphony, conducted by Alexander Dmitriev, is to perform works by Liszt, Tchaikov-sky and Debussy tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. at the Colden Center, Queens College, Kissena Boulevard and the Long Island Expressway, Flushing.
The pianist Lazar Berman is to be the soloist.
Tickets are $25 to $30.


PAUL SPERRY
LEAD: Paul Sperry, a tenor, is to perform works by New York composers Rob-ert Beaser, John Musto, Christopher Berg, Robert Convery and Larry Alan Smith - Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street.
Irma Vallecillo, a pianist, is to accompany.
Tickets are $5, $3 for museum mem-bers and children.


Takeover Stocks Up Sharply
LEAD: Takeover stocks climbed sharply yesterday in a generally strong stock market, encouraged by comments from Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, who said he was willing to consider changes in proposed taxes on acquisitions.


Diner's Journal
LEAD: ANDRE RENE, the chef who opened Windows on the World, has been hired to help get Manhattan's other celebrated celestial dining room off to a high-flying start: the renovated Rainbow Room atop the RCA Building.
Mr.
Rene joins two other Windows alumni at the lavish new dining and dancing complex, which is to open in late December: Alan Lewis, the soon-to-depart director of Windows, who will be director of the Rainbow Room, and Joseph Baum, the restaurant consultant who is overseeing the project.


Real Estate Market Remains Rattled
LEAD: The stock market plunge is taking a toll on the real estate industry, many buyers, sellers and agents agree.
But there is little agreement as to whether the disruption is temporary or likely to be long-lasting.


The U.N. Today: Oct. 30, 1987
LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY Political and Security Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
LEAD: Steve Reich, the Guggenheim Museum, Fifth Avenue and 89th Street (360-3500).
One of Steve Reich's recent compositions, ''Electric Counterpoint,'' features Pat Metheny, an inventive electric guitarist, who will be on hand to perform an excerpt from it at the Guggenheim; the entire composition will have its premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music later in November.


In the Crystal Ball, One Seer Looks for a Rally Next Week
LEAD: Wall Street's bulls are irrepressible.


Stocks Are Broadly Higher Despite Dollar's Early Drop
LEAD: Stock prices moved strongly and broadly higher yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing more than 90 points as Wall Street appeared to accept a lower level for the dollar on foreign exchange markets.


Art: Bruce Nauman Retrospective
LEAD: IN the retrospective of his drawings at the New Museum, the sculptor Bruce Nauman comes across as the complete Post-Minimalist artist, an exemplary representative of the almost frenzied experimentation that took hold of art, and especially sculpture, in the late 1960's and early 70's.
During those years, younger artists built on and broke through the limitations of Minimalism, branching out into areas soon designated as Conceptual, Performance, Installation and Process art.


Relief at British Decision
LEAD: The British Government's decision yesterday to soften the immediate impact of its sale of British Petroleum shares by providing market support through the Bank of England should encourage international markets today, investment fund managers and economists said.

Financial Aid Urged for Teachers
LEAD: Robert F. Wagner, the president of the Board of Education, last night suggested a series of financial incentives - including a loan forgiveness program - to help attract talented young teachers to the New York City public school system.

LEAD: IN the arts, yesterday's scandal is today's classic.
This maxim does not hold quite as true for ''Le Sacre du Printemps'' simply because the ballet that Vaslav Nijinsky created to Igor Stravinsky's score in 1913 disappeared from the international repertory.

Sports People; Gooden Buys Homes
LEAD: Dwight Gooden, whose scuffle with Tampa, Fla., olice last winter at-tracted national attention, has bought two houses in St.
Petersburg, Fla., and plans to move there part time with his family.
Gooden, a native of Tampa, bought waterfront houses in the Pinellas Point neighborhood.
Jim Neader, Gooden's agent, said the Met's pitcher, who is engaged to be married Nov.


Advertising; Big Drive To Begin For the Pill
LEAD: ORTHO PHARMACEUTICAL, the country's leading manufacturer of birth control pills, is sponsoring an image ad campaign in behalf of the entire category.
It will appear in print and on a number of TV stations, but not on the networks.


Where to Search for the Spirits of Halloween
LEAD: THE annual convention of departed New Yorkers will reune in New York tomorrow, as it does every Halloween, when the spirits of New Yorkers long gone are believed to return to the city that once knew them as flesh and blood.
Now, one must regretfully concede that there are New Yorkers whose credence in such goings-on matches their belief that they will live to ride on a Second Avenue subway.


Amgen Named In Countersuit
LEAD: Genetics Institute Inc. said today that it had filed a countersuit against Amgen Inc. and its Japanese partner the Kirin Brewery Company for infringing on its patent covering a process for making erythropoietin, also known as EPO.

LEAD: Keith R. Harris, president of the United States subsidiary of Morgan Grenfell &amp; Company, has left to join Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.


Foes of Shoreham, Dismayed By Decision, Vow to Fight On
LEAD: Opponents of the Shoreham nuclear power plant were dismayed by a change in evacuation-plan rules adopted today by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, but they said it would have little effect on whether Shoreham is licensed to operate.

Washington Talk: Briefing; Some of Us Are Sensible
LEAD: Somebody out there is listening to Congress, somebody named Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.
In an Oct. 2 speech in Murmansk, Mr.
Gorbachev focused in unusual detail on hearings held in September by the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.
And the subject was Mr.
Gorbachev's economic reforms.


Western Union
LEAD: The Western Union Corporation gained support from one of its largest stockholders for a restructuring plan the company says is critical to keeping it from bankruptcy court.
The shareholder, the Prudential Insurance Company of America, holds large interests in two series of Western Union's preferred stock, out of seven that vote, said Warren Bechtel, a Western Union spokesman.

THE EVENING HOURS
LEAD: AT the Humane Society benefit, the subject was dogs and cats, but at most other parties this week the talk was of bulls and bears and their effect on the price of everything from horses to irises.


Washington Talk: Housing and the Poor; Priest's Proteges Honor A Persuasive Life
LEAD: Stephen Adubato was a junior high school teacher in Newark in 1970 when a Roman Catholic priest walked into his classroom and persuaded him to quit his job.


Morris's Injuries Alter Giants' Plans
LEAD: The possible absence of Joe Morris could affect more than just the Giants' running game against the Dallas Cowboys Monday night.
It may also have an impact on the special teams.


Residents Seek Tighter Zoning For Apartments
LEAD: Hundreds of Queens residents came to City Hall yesterday to protest a city law that, they said, encourages developers to raze habitable single-family homes and build higher density housing, thereby threatening the ''villagelike'' atmosphere of many Queens neighborhoods.

Restaurants
LEAD: WHEN the Harry Cipriani restaurant in the Sherry-Netherland Hotel closed abruptly eight weeks ago in a landlord dispute, many of its soigne patrons trotted down to the family's other celebrity corral, Bellini by Cipriani, on Seventh Avenue at 51st Street.
This five-month-old clone was still fine tuning its engine when the new wave of customers arrived, requiring the opening of a new downstairs dining room.


College Football Notebook; Army, Temple Try New Quarterbacks
LEAD: Can anyone here play quarterback?
That might be the theme for Army's game against Temple at West Point tomorrow.
The Cadets have lost three quarterbacks and have two left, Morrell Savoy and Bryan McWilliams; whoever plays for the Owls will be starting for the first time.


INSIDE
LEAD:  Managua Refuses Talks  Sandinista leaders, after a special party meeting in Nicaragua today, again said they would not agree to hold political talks with the U.S.-backed contras.
Page A3.
Woody Herman Is Dead  The leader of one of the biggest of the big bands, whose career playing the clarinet and saxophone spanned 50 years of styles from blues to rock-and-roll, died at 74.


A Slimmer Pavarotti Plans Recital
LEAD: One of the more delicious experiences in life is doing a good deed while thoroughly enjoying oneself, and that is precisely the opportunity that Luciano Pavarotti will afford us this Sunday and next.

LEAD:  International A3-9


E.F. Hutton Censured
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission censured E. F. Hutton &amp; Company today in connection with a purported money laundering scheme at the Providence, R.I., branch office.


2 FESTIVAL FILMS OPEN
LEAD: Two films will open today that were originally shown at the re-cent New York Film Festival.


Treasury Prices Stage Rally
LEAD: Prices of short- and long-term Treasury issues rose yesterday as lower commodity prices and signs of falling interest rates abroad helped to heighten expectations of lower interest rates.

Jets Counting On Their Defense Offense Is Lagging
LEAD: A distinct turnabout has taken place between the Jets' offense and defense.


Precious Metals Slump; Livestock and Meat Up
LEAD: Prices of precious metals futures fell sharply yesterday in response to fears of a recession and the selling of gold by foreign central banks to prop up the dollar.


Tucker Ponders Long Wait
LEAD: TRENT TUCKER might have been upset, perhaps even furious.
After five seasons in which he was asked to perform in a system nonconducive to his skills, the 27-year-old guard had apparently been reduced to an afterthought.

LEAD: Hal McRae, who turned down the Kansas City Royals' interim manag-inig job last summer, was hired yes-terday as the Pittsburgh Pirates' minor-league hitting instructor, based in Bradenton Fla. ...
The Phoenix Suns have obtained James Bailey, a veteran forward-center, from the Cleveland Cavaliers for a future draft pick.

Cooking Light Gets Publisher From People
LEAD: Jeffrey C. Ward, who has spent a decade with Time Inc., has been named publisher of Cooking Light, a six-issue-a-year magazine of Southern Progress, a Time property.


BUSH WON DEBATE, REPUBLICANS AGREE
LEAD: George Bush won by not losing.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Saturday about stockbrokers' earnings during the market collapse misstated the view of one analyst about job opportunities in the industry.
Nancy Young, of the firm Tucker Anthony &amp; R. L. Day, said that while staff cuts were possible, they were unlikely because the industry had already eliminated the jobs of many poor-performing brokers.


Bilzerian Holds 9.9% Of Singer
LEAD: Paul A. Bilzerian, who has made repeated takeover attempts but never ended up owning his targets, disclosed yesterday that he owned 2.1 million shares, or 9.99 percent, of the outstanding common stock of the Singer Company.


SEEING NEW YORK CITY THROUGH THE EYES OF ITS ARCHITECTS
LEAD: Architects are a different breed from most New Yorkers.
They are forever perusing the city, soaking up views we often overlook.
Some are preoccupied with details - a ferocious-looking gargoyle, a graceful window or a wide front stoop.
Others examine entire streets or neighborhoods that have a character all their own.

Hoboken Is Disrupted By Water Main Break
LEAD: A water main broke here today, cutting off service to thousands of residents for about eight hours, flooding streets and causing a tie-up of traffic trying to use the nearby Lincoln Tunnel, officials said.


Washington Talk: Labor Department; Two Studies Discover A Miracle: Same Thing
LEAD: One report for the Department of Labor on what the American work force would look like at the end of the century runs 117 pages.
Another report runs 63 pages.
They are nearly identical except that the 117-page study cost $1.3 million, the other nothing.


Corrections
LEAD: The Discoveries column in The Living Section on Wednesday gave an incorrect address for Carole Stupell Ltd., which sells a Halloween lantern.


Decree Is Lifted in Ecuador
LEAD: - President Leon Febres Cordero has lifted the national state of emergency he declared to deal with the one-day anti-Government general strike Wednesday.
A Government spokesman said that Mr.
Febres Cordero, who declared the state of emergency Tuesday night, had lifted it at midnight Wednesday.
The decree suspended constitutional rights.


Bridge: In Simplified Club System, Neglected Tactic Is Used
LEAD: A bidding concept that has been popular in Europe for half a century but neglected on this side of the Atlantic is ''canape'': bid a short suit first, and keep a long suit in reserve.
Many Italian and French experts have employed it in winning world titles.


RESCUED YOUNGSTER MAKES A PUBLIC APEPARANCE
LEAD: Jessica McClure being held by Her mother, Reba, at a news conference at hospital in Midland Tex.
It was the first public outing for the 18-month-old since she was rescued from the abondoned well she had fallen into.
It took volunteers more than 58 hours to free her.
The rescuers, who numbered more than 400, were honored with a parade yesterday and Jessica was able to watch it from her window.


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
Beckman Industrial Corp., Fullerton, Calif., a maker of electronic components and microcircuits for industrial and military applications, named Carl F. Gigandet president of its electronic technologies division.


AUCTION
LEAD: THE first major test of how the art market is weathering the international financial crisis is expected next week in the contemporary art sales taking place at Sotheby's and Christie's.
The auctions of postwar works - Rauschenbergs, de Koonings, Pollocks, Bacons and Lindners - are estimated to bring between $35 million and $46 million, the highest combined total value for such sales of paintings and sculpture in a three-day period.


Salvador Rebels to Boycott Talks After Killing of Rights Advocate
LEAD: - Leftist guerrillas said today that they would not attend a new round of peace talks with the Salvadoran Government, blaming it for the killing of a prominent human rights advocate.


Editors' Note
LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday reported that Morgan Stanley &amp; Company, one of four American underwriters for the British Petroleum Company's share offering, could post a loss of about $120 million from the underwriting.
The article said the loss could be particularly painful for Morgan Stanley because the firm had $576 million in shareholder's equity at the end of 1986.


Sports of The Times; Parents of the Twins
LEAD: LEE MacPHAIL could sit with his son at the moment of ultimate triumph while Frank and Helen Viola had to watch their son celebrate from a distance.
But all three parents shared the joy of seeing somebody who used to be a child now handle the details and the pressures of being an adult.


Jorge Dalto Dies at 39; A Jazz-Fusion Pianist
LEAD: Jorge Dalto, an Argentine-born jazz pianist whose version of ''This Masquerade'' with the guitarist George Benson won a Grammy Award in 1976, died of cancer Tuesday in New York, his family said.
He was 39 years old.

LEAD: The stock market's plunge will hurt military contractors because the Federal Government is likely to reduce Pentagon spending to trim the budget deficit, the president of the Martin Marietta Corporation said yesterday.
The company head, Norman


Presser Foresees Merger Creating 'Political Giant'
LEAD: Jackie Presser, leading his 1.7 million teamsters back into the A.F.L.-C.I.O. three decades after the union was expelled, said today that the labor movement could now ''create the greatest political giant this country has ever seen.''

Russian Bond Payment
LEAD: The holders of Tsarist Government bonds issued in London before the 1917 Russian Revolution will start to receive payment on Friday as part of an Anglo-Soviet accord, Foreign Office officials said today.
Payments of up to $:5,000, or $8,500, will be sent out to bondholders as a first installment, the officials said.

LEAD:  Dawn Steel to Columbia


OPENINGS APLENTY AT ARTS FESTIVAL
LEAD: The monthlong First New York International Festival of the Arts will begin next June with not one but three opening nights.
It also will feature a free concert in Central Park by the Spanish tenor Placido Domingo, according to the festival's chairman, Martin E. Segal.


Capturing the Fire of 'Carmen' on Ice
LEAD: Her athletic clock was ticking, but not so loudly that Debi Thomas could not hear the music she was using for her figure skating programs.


Art: Ferdinand Hodler, His Swiss Landscapes
LEAD: FERDINAND HODLER may have been the most influential Swiss artist in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, but his work does not travel well.
Compared with Corot, Courbet, Gauguin and Munch, Hodler's partly Realist, partly Post-Impressionist, partly Symbolist, partly Expressionist paintings seem unresolved.


Market Place; The Big Rally In Transports
LEAD: AFTER being hit especially hard in the mammoth October selloff, transportation stocks moved to the forefront of yesterday's rally.
The Dow Jones transportation average, which is concentrated in railroad, airline and trucking issues, forged ahead 39.91 points, to 725.50, for a sparkling gain of 5.82 percent.


Sports People; Anderson Honored
LEAD: Sparky Anderson, who led the Detroit Tigers to a 98-64 record, the best in the game this season, was named the American League Manager of the Year yesterday by the Baseball Writers' Association of America.
Anderson, who also earned the honor in 1984 when the Tigers won 104 games and the World Series, received 11 first-place votes and a total of 90 points in balloting by a panel of two members of the association from each American League city.


Koch Dismisses Gross, Faulting His Leadership
LEAD: Mayor Koch announced yesterday that he had dismissed Dr.
Elliot M. Gross, whose performance as Chief Medical Examiner of New York City has been under official scrutiny for almost three years.


TAX RISE IS PASSED BY HOUSE
LEAD: After a bruising partisan fight that sent an uncertain signal to Wall Street, the House of Representatives approved by one vote tonight $12 billion in tax increases to help reduce the Federal deficit.

Mets Raise Ticket Prices
LEAD: The team may not have the same luster it did a year ago, but it's going to cost a bit more next season to watch the Mets from a choice seat in Shea Stadium.
The club announced yesterday that the price of a box seat has been increased 10 percent, from $10 to $11, and that the price of reserved seats in the loge and mezzanine have gone from $8.50 to $9.

Trial Opens in Slaying of Radio Talk Show Host
LEAD: Four members of a white supremacist group plotted to kill Alan Berg, the Jewish host of a radio talk show, because of his religious background and argumentative personality, a Justice Department official said in a Federal court here today.


Ginsburg Choice Renews Tension Between Factions in White House
LEAD: President Reagan's nomination of Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg for the Supreme Court has renewed tensions between White House factions and has frustrated Howard H. Baker Jr., the White House chief of staff, Administration officials said today.


The Proper Dismissal of Dr. Gross
LEAD: For two and a half years, the office of New York City's Chief Medical Examiner has faced charges of incompetence and mismanagement.
Mayor Koch now addresses them, properly and directly, by dismissing the chief coroner, Dr.
Elliot Gross.

U.S. Approves Merger Of USAir and Piedmont
LEAD: The Transportation Department yesterday approved USAir Group Inc.'s acquisition of Piedmont Aviation Inc., rejecting the advice of an administrative law judge who had called the merger anticompetitive.


Pact on Taxes Keeps Dreyfus In New York
LEAD: In a reversal, the Koch administration agreed yesterday to tax cuts for the mutual fund industry in exchange for a commitment from the Dreyfus Corporation to remain in New York City.


Driver in Fatal '86 Bus Crash Sentenced to 4-Years in Jail
LEAD: The driver of a speeding bus that plunged off a mountain highway in May 1986, killing 21 passengers, has been sentenced to four years in prison on six manslaughter charges.


Health Care at Home: A Mixed Blessing
LEAD: At the rehabilitation center where Ella Gross stayed for nine weeks after she had a stroke, there was no one to help her to the bathroom in the middle of the night.
That was the policy.
She would lie awake and tell herself, ''I don't want to be here.''

L.I.R.R. Delayed by Suicide
LEAD: A man apparently committed suicide on a Long Island Rail Road train last night, delaying homebound commuters on the Port Washington line by up to an hour, a railroad spokesman said.
The body of a man, who was not immediately identified, was found in the restroom of the fourth car of the 5:29 P.M. train out of Penn Station that was to arrive in Great Neck at 6:05 P.M., said the spokesman, Brian Dolan.

RESTORED STATURE SOUGHT FOR STAFF OF THE CORONER
LEAD: The chairman of the advisory board that recommended dismissing Dr.
Elliot M. Gross as New York City's Chief Medical Examiner said yesterday that the city would ''make every effort'' to restore the Medical Examiner's office to the high national position it once held.


B.P. Loss Casts Doubt On Wood Gundy Deal
LEAD: The large potential losses of a Canadian brokerage involved in underwriting the sale of British Petroleum Company stock appear to have put in doubt First National Bank of Chicago's plans to take a 35 percent stake in the brokerage, Wood Gundy Inc.


Dr. Florence Wislocki, Psychiatrist, Dies at 83
LEAD: Dr.
Florence Clothier Wislocki, a psychiatrist and former assistant to the president of Vassar College, died of a stroke Wednesday in the Charlton Memorial Hospital in Fall River, Mass.
She was 83 years old and lived in Little Compton, R.I.


Spectrum Group
LEAD: Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. said it is offering to sell its Spectrum Group unit.
Spectrum, based in Jacksonville, Fla., makes insecticides, herbicides and fertilizers.
It had 1986 sales of $42.1 million.
The decision is consistent with the company's long-term strategy of focusing on its traditional core businesses, which include cosmetics, fragrances, personal care products and packaged foods.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''The smiles were out this morning.
We've come from complacency, to apprehension, to fear, to relief, and now to hope over the last four weeks.''
- Peter G. Grennan,
of Shearson Lehman Brothers.  [ 1:3. ]

Woman Held in Philadelphia In Kidnapping of an Infant
LEAD: A woman was arrested here today for kidnapping a baby boy from his mother's Baltimore hospital room in June.

Kamal el-Mallakh
LEAD: Kamal el-Mallakh, an Egyptologist who discovered the 4,600-year-old boat of the Pharaoh Cheops next to his Great Pyramid at Giza, died of a heart attack Thursday.
He was 69 years old.


Rock: Lisa Lisa Performs With Cult Jam at Radio City
LEAD: Lisa Lisa and Cult Jam seemed likely to become ''one-hit wonders'' when a follow-up to their first hit record, ''I Wonder If I'd Take You Home,'' was not immediately forthcoming.
Lisa Lisa's lack of polish, the quaver in her voice, and the aching sincerity it seemed to convey sold the record.
But raw naivete, however charming the first time around, is rarely enough to sustain an ongoing career.

Dance: The Joffrey Ballet in Ashton Works

Hadson to Merge With Ultrasystems
LEAD: The Hadson Corporation, a natural gas distributor, said it planned to merge with Ultrasystems Inc., a developer of cogeneration plants, in a stock deal valued at about $86.9 million.
Hadson, based in Oklahoma City, would issue 2.2 shares of its stock in exchange for each of 7.9 million outstanding shares of Ultrasystems, based in Irvine, Calif.

Ideological Clash
LEAD:  To the Editor:


AIDS Book Brings Fame To a Gay San Franciscan
LEAD: ''I'm not a very good homosexual - I can't keep house, decorate, cook or dress,'' said Randy Shilts, explaining why he did not want to meet at his messy apartment.
But one thing Mr.
Shilts can do well is report and write, and he has written an unforgiving book on AIDS, the scourge of San Francisco.


FIRERY ENSIGN WINS IN RALLY
LEAD: Firery Ensign proved his talent is superior to his owners' spelling by overcoming early trouble to score a 1 1/4-length victory tonight in the $500,000 Young America Stakes at Meadowlands Race Track.

LEAD: The Pennzoil Company has won a potentially significant victory in its effort to gain access to information on Texaco Inc.'s financial condition.

LEAD: The Haas Securities Corporation, which stopped trading on the New York Stock Exchange last week when its capital fell below the exchange's minimum requirements, said yesterday that it had raised between $3 million and $5 million in financing from two private investors, allowing it to resume operations.

Carhaix Journal; Sowing a Language's Seed in Brittany
LEAD: Now 50 years old, Yann Puillandre still remembers the hurt.
When he was caught speaking Breton in class, his teacher would hang a wooden shoe around his neck, a stigma that could be lifted only by denouncing another schoolmate who had let slip a few words of the ancient Celtic language.

WATSON'S PUTTING INCREASES HIS LEAD
LEAD: Tom Watson has regained his confidence on the greens.
He proved it today when he sank four consecutive lengthy putts and threatened to run away from the 29 other golfers in the richest tournament in golf history, the $3 million Nabisco Championships.


HARVARD PROFESSOR TO AID STOCK-PLUNGE PANEL
LEAD: Robert R. Glauber, a Harvard Business School professor, has been selected executive director of the Presidential commission investigating the Oct. 19 stock market plunge, Nicholas F. Brady, a Wall Street investment banker heading the panel, said yesterday.

FENCE-SITTING ENDS FOR MANY INVESTORS
LEAD: Growing more confident about the prospects for stocks, institutional investors unleashed some of their buying power yesterday.
From the market's opening, many of the money managers for banks, insurance companies and pension and mutual funds found battered prices too compelling to ignore.


Music: Leningrad State Symphony Plays Shostakovich at Carnegie Hall
LEAD: The best reason for being in Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening came at the close of the program, when the Leningrad State Symphony fashioned a thoroughly absorbing performance of Shostakovich's brooding Symphony No. 10.
The Soviet orchestra, which in 1953 gave the work its first performance, obviously has this music in its bones.

Merola's Colleagues Bid Him Farewell
LEAD: A hearse carrying the coffin of the Bronx District Attorney, Mario Merola, arriving at the Bronx County Building yesterday where a crowd of judges, lawyers and court officials waited to pay their respects.
His body will lie in the rotunda until the funeral this afternoon. (NYT/Jim Wilson)


After Nobel Prize, Caviar for Russian Poet
LEAD: Joseph Brodsky returned to New York University yesterday, greeting friends and reading some poems as he has done many times before.
But this time, the mood was a good deal more jocular than reverential, with hugs and congratulations and excitement, not to mention caviar and champagne instead of the salami sandwiches served on other such occasions.


Make Room for Jersey Buses
LEAD: For tens of thousands of Manhattan-bound New Jersey commuters, morning rush hour usually means a slow crawl under the Hudson.
The New Jersey Department of Transportation sensibly proposes a second Lincoln Tunnel lane exclusively for buses.


Witt on List
LEAD: Mike Witt, who has averaged 16 victories a season for the past four years, yesterday became the most attractive starting pitcher to add his name to the free-agent list.
The California Angels' right-hander is one of 28 players who have filed for free agency in the first week of the 15-day filing period.


Stock Options: Price Cut Seen
LEAD: EXECUTIVE stock options, like other investment devices tied to the stock market, have been hurt by the October market plunge and accompanying financial turmoil.
In fact, the price at which many of these options can be exercised is now much higher than the market price - which is known as being ''under water.

Star of 'Wings' Recalls 1927
LEAD: In ''Wings,'' the 1927 movie about World War I fliers that won the first Academy Award, Charles (Buddy) Rogers brushes away a tear from the cheek of Clara Bow.
The other day, 60 years later, Mr.
Rogers brushed away another tear while watching the film.
This time it was his own.
In an evening of sentimentality and laughter, Mr.


Ryan Beck Layoffs
LEAD: The investment banking firm Ryan Beck &amp; Company said it would lay off 45 of its 275 employees as part of a plan to reduce operating expenses.
About 25 of the layoffs will come from the company's community capital group, which is being disbanded, a spokesman said.
The group was involved in the conversion of thrift institutions from stock to mutual form.


Bad Bedfellows for Big Labor
LEAD: Thirty years after its expulsion and still reeking of corruption, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters has been welcomed back into the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
The teamsters' motivation for returning now is transparent: the Federal Government threatens a lawsuit to oust their leaders and take over the union; affiliation with ''respectable'' organized labor offers political cover.

Jefferies Expects Loss
LEAD: Jefferies Group Inc., the brokerage pioneer of round-the-clock trading off the exchange floor, said today that it expected a $5 million to $10 million loss in October because of the Wall Street plunge.
Frank Baxter, president and chief executive of the Los Angeles firm, said in a statement that he did not know whether the company would post a deficit for the whole fourth quarter because of the loss.


Boeing Officer Will Retire
LEAD: The Boeing Company said today that T. A. Wilson would retire as chairman on Dec. 31, ending a 44-year career.
Mr.
Wilson, known throughout the aerospace industry simply as ''T,'' will be succeeded by Frank A. Shrontz, Boeing's president and chief executive.


IN COLUMBIA, RISING VIOLENCE BREEDS NEW DOUBTS
LEAD: Within the space of a few days this month, the leader of Colombia's main leftist party was assassinated, the country's best-known sculptor was kidnapped and several prominent writers and artists were forced into exile by death threats.

Shots Fired in Berlin Escape
LEAD: Communist border guards fired two shots Thursday at a 21-year-old East German man who escaped over the Berlin wall, the West Berlin authorities said today.
The police said the man told them that border guards arrested a 21-year-old companion trying to escape with him.


Moscow Police Arrest 2 Editors of Magazine
LEAD: Two editors of an independent Soviet magazine founded to test the limits of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's openness policy were detained by the police today, dissidents said.


FLORIDA'S SMITH PASSES THE FRESHMAN CLASS
LEAD: Every Wednesday morning since the season began, Kerwin Bell, Florida's rifle-armed senior quarterback, has talked nationwide.


Tax Bill Revision Seen on Takeovers
LEAD: Congressional tax proposals aimed at slowing corporate takeover activity are likely to be dropped or at least toned down in any final tax package, according to House and Senate tax aides.
Such proposals are blamed by some on Wall Street for bringing on the stock market debacle.


Police Raid Korea Campuses
LEAD: The police raided campuses in four cities before dawn today and seized fire bombs, clubs and leaflets to try to cripple planned nationwide rallies by dissidents, opposition leaders said.
The raids followed riots Friday in which students demanded that the governing party's candidate, Roh Tae Woo, pull out of the presidential race and that a neutral interim regime be set up to insure fair elections.

Grand Jury Refuses to Indict Donovan in 3d U.S. Inquiry
LEAD: A special Federal prosecutor said yesterday that a reinvestigation of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan had found ''insufficient corroborative evidence'' to indict Mr.
Donovan on new allegations that he had lied about seeking a $250,000 kickback while in private business.


About New York; Acting Landlord Has to Act, Well, Like a Landlord
LEAD: The law says that if one-third of the tenants in a building petition the court out of health and safety concerns, the court can appoint an administrator, who becomes, in a sense, the acting landlord.
The administrator collects the rent, maintains the building, sees to repairs -does, in short, what the landlord should have been doing.


Margaret Price
LEAD: Margaret Price, soprano, is to give a recital of works by Mozart, Schubert, Mahler and Strauss tomorrow at 5 P.M. in the Metropolitan Opera House.
James Levine is to be the pianist.
Tickets are $10 to $25.
Information: 362-6000.


Music: New Works in Tribute to Science
LEAD: In 1887 two scientists, Albert A. Michaelson and Edward W. Morley, performed one of the most important scientific experiments of their time.
It proved that the speed of light was not affected by the movement of the earth through space and that there was no mysterious ''ether'' that had been assumed to be the medium through which light traveled beyond the earth's atmosphere.

MARATHONERS RUN WHEN MONEY TALKS
LEAD: They are the Yankee Doodle Dandies among marathoners, a couple of old geezers nearing 40 and still prominent in their field.
Frank Shorter, wearing a red, white and blue windbreaker yesterday, and Bill Rodgers, in basic blue, popularized distance running in the United States, each reaping a variety of financial rewards, among them clothing lines that carried their names.

AIDS and Hepatitis Cited in Move to Cut Health Worker Risks
LEAD: Two Federal agencies today began a campaign to reduce the risks of exposing health care workers to the viruses that cause AIDS and hepatitis B. A joint letter from the Secretary of Labor and the Secretary of Health and Human Services is being mailed to about 500,000 hospitals, blood banks, hospices, laboratories and other health care employers to urge them to follow guidelines to protect employees from accidental infection with the viruses.


INSIDE
LEAD:  Senate Votes Airline Bill
The Senate approved a consumer protection bill for airline passengers that also would require drug testing of transportation workers.
Page 7.
Lower Profile for Deng
The Chinese leader will drop most of his Communist Party posts but will not lose much authority.


Albert Crary, Geophysicist, Dies; An Explorer of Both Polar Regions
LEAD: Albert P. Crary, a polar explorer and scientist, died Thursday at George Washington University Hospital in Washington, D.C., of complications following surgery for a spinal tumor.
He was 76 years old and lived in Bethesda, Md.


SECURITIES ANALYST CHARGED IN SLAYING OF HIS WIFE
LEAD: A Wall Street securities analyst has been charged with the murder of his wife, whose body was found Wednesday in a drainage ditch near the Gov.
Thomas E. Dewey Thruway three miles south of the Newburgh exit.

Correction
LEAD: A brief article in Weekend yesterday about a free series of staged readings by the Riverside Shakespeare Company gave an incorrect address.
The series will be at the West Park Presbyterian Church, 165 West 86th Street.


4,300 Opponents of Regime Reported Held in Bangladesh
LEAD: Security forces have detained 4,300 opposition leaders and workers in a five-day sweep intended to silence demands that President H. M. Ershad resign, opposition leaders said today.
Government officials acknowledged that 519 people had been detained.


CANADIENS WIN ON GOAL BY MCPHEE
LEAD: Mike McPhee's goal with 5 minutes 29 seconds left in the third period lifted the Montreal Canadiens to a 5-4 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight.

LEAD: Rear Adm.
John M. Poindexter testified today that Michael K. Deaver, the former White House aide being tried for perjury, telephoned him at the White House to help secure a Presidential meeting for a trade envoy of the South Korean Government.

Rangers Recall Donnelly
LEAD: The Rangers, who remain uncertain how long Pierre Larouche's strained back will keep him out of the lineup, have recalled Mike Donnelly, a 24-year-old left wing, from their Denver farm club.
Donnelly, who had a strong training camp with the Rangers, has been the leading scorer at Denver in seven games.


Stock Price Off On USG's Suit
LEAD: Reacting to a cold response by the USG Corporation to takeover overtures received on Wednesday, the stock of the Chicago-based company fell $2.25 a share today, to close at $35.25.


Social Security Cuts, Too
LEAD: In accepting the urgent need for deficit negotiations with Congress, President Reagan left one string attached to the bargain: no reductions in Social Security.
Mr.
Reagan's reluctance to tackle the giant program is understandable.
When he broached the issue six years ago, Democratic Congressional leaders tripped over each other in their eagerness to denounce him.


Investors Group Drops Wynn's Bid
LEAD: Wynn's International Inc. said a group of investors led by the Security Pacific Corporation's venture capital unit had dropped its unsolicited $109 million acquisition proposal.
However, Susan Taha, a Security Pacific spokeswoman, said the unit was continuing to hold discussions with Wynn's and may make a revised offer.


NOCTURNAL RUNNERS REVIVE CENTRAL PARK
LEAD: Long after twilight, Susan and Marcel Lipkowitz appeared at the East 90th Street entrance to Central Park.
They dutifully stretched their bodies, then bolted into the night.


A New American Pledges His Allegiance
LEAD: Jason Matiko, five years old, taking oath at naturalization ceremony yesterday in Scranton, Pa.
Jason, from Korea, was one of 37 people sworn in as American citizens at the Federal courthouse in Scranton. (AP)


Inspired by U.S. Gains, Foreign Stocks Surge
LEAD: Stock prices rose worldwide yesterday, inspired by sizable gains on Wall Street and the dollar's rebound.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Tennis  Mecir Topples McEnroe: Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia defeated John McEnroe, 7-5, 6-4, yesterday to join Ivan Lendl, Pat Cash and Mats Wilander in the semifinals of the $923,000 European Community Championship in Antwerp, Belgium.
Cash, who struggled past Wojtek Fibak, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4, will face Lendl, who dominated Tim Mayotte, 6-3, 6-3.

Comings and Goings
LEAD: Nelson Piquet of Brazil clinched his third Formula One driving championship when Nigel Mansell of Britain, his teammate and the only driver with a chance to catch him, was forced to withdraw from Sunday's Grand Prix of Japan because of injury.
Mansell was hurt during a qualifying session yesterday when his car went out of control.


What the World Body's University Does
LEAD:  To the Editor:


More Surgery for Kerr
LEAD: Tim Kerr, the right wing for the Philadelphia Flyers who has undergone four operations on his left shoulder since June 12, will probably have surgery a fifth time.
Doctors plan to remove a surgical screw that is causing an infection.
Kerr said he expected the operation to take place within the next few weeks.


Andre A. Perebinossoff
LEAD: Andre A. Perebinossoff, an oil-exploration engineer, died of a heart attack Sept. 16 at the Baylor University Medical Center in Dallas.
He was 82 years old.


Housing Leader Killed In a Brooklyn Robbery
LEAD: A 65-year-old Brooklyn woman, described by neighbors as a leader in efforts to build housing for the poor in the Park Slope section, was killed yesterday in a robbery, the police said.


Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, the Home Beat column in The Home Section on Thursday misstated the prices of a collection of Navajo rugs at ABC Carpets.
They are $500 to $15,000.

Iranian Caviar Seized By Customs Officials
LEAD: A load of caviar has become the first goods to be seized under President Reagan's new ban on imports from Iran.


Thatcher's B.P. Move Is Praised
LEAD: The Government of Margaret Thatcher has emerged almost unscathed from a very public predicament involving the huge $12 billion offering of British Petroleum Company shares.
Its deft last-minute modification in the stock issue, in fact, appears to have allowed the Government to prevent a political setback and to avoid panicking international stock markets.

LEAD: A worldwide Synod of Bishops ended today without accepting an American recommendation that ministries short of the priesthood be opened to women, a Vatican official said.

It is $4 for both adults and children.


Film: 'Deadly Illusion'
LEAD: There's an engaging bravado about ''Deadly Illusion,'' a brassy suspense-melodrama that has the manner of a man who refuses to acknowledge that he's painted himself into a corner.
Instead of standing there, wringing his hands and looking silly, he boldly walks away, ignoring the footprints left behind.
